LIMEENERGYCO_09_09_1999-EX-10-DISTRIBUTO.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated September 7, 1999, is between Electric City Corp. (Company) and Electric City of Illinois LLC (Distributor).  It establishes an exclusive distributorship for the Company's "Energy Saver" product (and potentially others) within Illinois for a 10-year term, renewable for another 10 years.

The Distributor's key obligations include purchasing minimum quantities of products annually (escalating from 375 units in 1999 to 2,856 units annually thereafter), actively promoting sales, and providing a purchase order of at least $250,000 monthly.  A $500,000 irrevocable letter of credit (LC) is required, renewable bimonthly.  The Company's obligations include supplying products, general advertising, and providing warranty support.  The relationship is vendor-vendee, not agency or partnership.

The agreement includes provisions for price adjustments based on CPI and Company-wide changes, product returns (defective and non-defective), payment terms (30 days), and a 24-month warranty on products.  The Distributor has an option to distribute other products the Company may introduce.

Termination can occur for cause (e.g., breach, insolvency) with 30 days' notice or immediately for certain events.  Upon termination, the Company has the option to repurchase remaining inventory.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, non-disclosure provisions, and a non-solicitation clause.  Illinois law governs.

WHITESMOKE,INC_11_08_2011-EX-10.26-PROMO.summary:
This Promotion and Distribution Agreement, effective August 1, 2011, is between Whitesmoke Inc. ("Distributor") and Google Inc. ("Google").  The agreement concerns the bundling and distribution of Google's Chrome Browser and Google Toolbar (the "Products") with Whitesmoke's software ("Distributor App(s)") in specified territories (Exhibit A).

Distributor's key obligations include bundling the Products with its app, adhering to Google's distribution guidelines (Exhibit B & C), obtaining end-user consent for installations via a clear EULA presentation (Clause 3.6), accurately reproducing the Products (Clause 3.7), and providing regular reports on distribution metrics (Clause 3.9).  Distributor is prohibited from modifying the Products or engaging in activities that harm Google's brand.

Google grants Distributor a non-exclusive license to bundle and distribute the Products.  Google warrants the Products' functionality for a specified period.  Both parties warrant reasonable care and skill in fulfilling their obligations.  Google's liability is capped (Clause 9.4).

Financial terms stipulate payments from Google to Distributor based on installations and offers presented (Exhibit A, Clause 4.1), subject to a Maximum Distribution Commitment (Clause 4.2).  Payment is in USD, excluding Distributor's income taxes (Clause 4.4).

The agreement lasts for two years or until the Maximum Distribution Commitment is reached (Clause 5.1). Termination clauses cover material breach (Clause 5.2), insolvency (Clause 5.3), change of control (Clause 5.4), and specific breaches (Clause 5.5).  Upon termination, all licenses cease,

LohaCompanyltd_20191209_F-1_EX-10.16_119.summary: This supply agreement, dated December 9, 2019, is between Shenzhen LOHAS Supply Chain Management Co., Ltd. ("Buyer") and an unnamed Seller.  The agreement is a framework contract, governing all subsequent purchase orders placed by the Buyer through its entrusted parties, Shenzhen Yichangtai Import and Export Trade Co., Ltd. or Shenzhen Leheyuan Trading Co., Ltd.  The Seller's key obligation is to supply goods as specified in individual purchase orders, subject to a three-day acceptance period.  The Buyer is responsible for payment via Letter of Credit (L/C) or Telegraphic Transfer (T/T), with specific payment schedules outlined in the contract.  The Seller is responsible for packaging, insurance (110% invoice value), and shipment (CIP Incoterms 2000) to Shenzhen, China.  The contract includes provisions for quality guarantees, claims procedures (within 7 days of arrival), force majeure events, late delivery penalties (up to 5% of total value), and arbitration in Beijing under the rules of the China Beijing Council for the Promotion of International Trade.  The contract's duration is five years, governed by Chinese law, with the Chinese version prevailing in case of discrepancies.  The final price is confidential.

CENTRACKINTERNATIONALINC_10_29_1999-EX-1.summary:
This Web Site Hosting Agreement, dated April 6, 1999, is between Centrack International, Inc. (Customer) and i-on interactive, Inc. (i-on).  The agreement outlines i-on's provision of web hosting services for Centrack's website for a monthly fee of $450.

i-on's obligations include 24/7 website operation (excluding scheduled maintenance), internet connectivity via a T1 line, server space (up to 150MB), database services (MS SQL Server), email accounts (up to 10), and one hour of monthly website administration.  Centrack is responsible for all website content, customer support, marketing, and security.  Centrack also bears responsibility for any software installed on the server, requiring i-on's prior approval.

The agreement includes limitations on i-on's liability, capped at one month's fees, excluding consequential damages.  Centrack indemnifies i-on against any liabilities arising from Centrack's use of the services.

The initial term is six months, automatically renewing monthly unless terminated with 15 days' notice.  Either party may terminate with 30 days' written notice.  Payment is due by the 5th of each month; late payments may result in service interruption.  Governing law is Florida.  The agreement explicitly excludes content creation and help desk services from i-on's responsibilities.

NELNETINC_04_08_2020-EX-1-JOINT FILING A.summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement (JFA), dated March 27, 2020, between Shelby J. Butterfield and the Butterfield Family Trust (collectively, "the parties"), governs the joint filing of Schedule 13G or 13D (and amendments) with regulatory authorities.  The purpose is to report their combined ownership of securities in an unnamed issuer, utilizing Rule 13d-1(k) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Each party is obligated to ensure the timely filing of amendments and the accuracy of their own reported information.  While each is responsible for their own data, they are not liable for the other's accuracy unless aware of inaccuracies.  The agreement doesn't specify a duration or termination clause; it implicitly continues until the parties cease joint reporting.  No financial arrangements are detailed.  The agreement focuses solely on the joint reporting compliance and allocation of responsibility for accuracy of the respective information provided.

ADAMSGOLFINC_03_21_2005-EX-10.17-ENDORSE.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated January 13, 2005, is between professional golfer Tom Watson ("Consultant") and Adams Golf, Ltd. ("Adams Golf").  The agreement grants Adams Golf exclusive worldwide rights to use Watson's name, likeness, and endorsement for advertising and promoting its golf products for a period of [redacted] years and [redacted] months (commencing September 1, 2004).

Watson's key obligations include exclusive use of specified Adams Golf products in PGA/SPGA events (with limited exceptions for non-competing products), cooperation in product design and promotion, and participation in promotional appearances.  Failure to meet minimum tournament participation requirements may result in repayment of a portion of his compensation.

Adams Golf's obligations include providing Watson with sufficient products, paying a base compensation of [redacted] dollars, and paying performance bonuses based on Watson's tournament wins and year-end rankings (with a total annual bonus cap).  Adams Golf must also submit advertising materials to Watson for approval.

The agreement includes mutual indemnity clauses, provisions for termination for cause or Watson's inability to play, and a detailed repayment schedule for compensation in case of underperformance or termination.  Governing law is Kansas law, and disputes are subject to arbitration in Kansas.  The agreement also contains standard clauses on confidentiality, non-agency, and severability.  Specific financial details, including the exact duration and compensation amounts, are redacted.

KIROMICBIOPHARMA,INC_05_11_2020-EX-10.23.summary: This Consulting Agreement, dated July 20, 2018, is between Kiromic, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and Gianluca Rotino (Consultant).  The agreement outlines Rotino's consulting services for Kiromic, encompassing business analysis, business development strategy, marketing, and clinical pipeline support.  Rotino is obligated to maintain confidentiality regarding Kiromic's proprietary information and irrevocably assigns all intellectual property rights arising from his work to Kiromic.  He is also prohibited from engaging in competing activities.  Kiromic agrees to pay Rotino $400/hour (capped at 19 hours/month, with any overtime requiring pre-approval), subject to standard payroll deductions.  The agreement includes clauses regarding independent contractor status, non-debarment, conflict of interest, and dispute resolution via binding arbitration in Houston, Texas under Texas law.  Either party may terminate with written notice.  Confidentiality, intellectual property assignment, and payment obligations survive termination.  The agreement is governed by Texas law and constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.

VEONEER,INC_02_21_2020-EX-10.11-JOINT VE.summary:
This Amendment and Termination of Joint Venture Agreement, effective October 30, 2019, involves Veoneer AB, Veoneer US (Veoneer Parties), Nissin Kogyo Co., Ltd., Nissin Kogyo Holdings USA, Inc., and Zhongshan Nissin Industry Co., Ltd. (Nissin Parties).  It amends a pre-existing Joint Venture Agreement (JV Agreement) concerning several joint ventures (VNBJ, VNBA, VNBZ, ANRA).  The amendment primarily addresses the sale of Veoneer's equity interests in VNBJ and VNBZ to Honda and Nissin.

The key obligation is the termination of the JV Agreement concerning VNBJ and VNBZ upon closing of the respective share purchase agreements (SPAs).  The JV Agreement remains in effect for ANRA, solely between the Nissin Parties and Autoliv AB, for liquidation purposes.  Veoneer Parties are released from further obligations under the JV Agreement except for pre-closing liabilities.  Nissin Parties are obligated to ensure VNBJ and VNBZ comply with the JV Agreement's D&O indemnity provisions for pre-closing liabilities.  The Amendment's governing law is Japanese law.  The Amendment's effectiveness is contingent upon the closing of the VNBJ and VNBZ SPAs; failure to close renders the Amendment void.  Financial arrangements are detailed in separate SPAs, not within this amendment itself.

DovaPharmaceuticalsInc_20181108_10-Q_EX-.summary:
This Co-Promotion Agreement, dated September 26, 2018, is between Dova Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("Dova") and Valeant Pharmaceuticals North America LLC ("Valeant").  It's a co-exclusive co-promotion agreement for Dova's DOPTELET (avatrombopag) in the US.

Valeant's key obligations include detailing DOPTELET to gastroenterologists (at least 100 sales reps), adhering to Dova-approved promotional materials, and complying with all applicable laws.  Dova retains all rights to DOPTELET except for the co-promotion rights granted to Valeant. Dova is responsible for manufacturing, distribution, regulatory matters, and safety reporting.  A Joint Steering Committee (JSC) oversees the collaboration.

Key terms include definitions of "Specialty" (target physicians), "Net Sales" (calculation for payments), and "Details" (face-to-face sales calls).  The agreement includes detailed reporting requirements for sales, compensation, and compliance.

The agreement lasts four years, but either party can terminate early for cause (material breach, insufficient sales reps or details, product withdrawal, etc.) or for convenience (with specified notice periods).  Dova pays Valeant a tiered quarterly promotion fee based on net sales, plus a milestone payment upon reaching a specific sales threshold.  Both parties have audit rights.  Detailed indemnification and limitation of liability clauses are included.  The agreement is governed by the laws of [***].  A confidential version was filed with the SEC.

PACIRA PHARMACEUTICALS, INC. - A_R STRAT.contract_id: PACIRA PHARMACEUTICALS, INC. - A_R STRATEGIC LICENSING, DISTRIBUTION AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
PACIRA PHARMACEUTICALS, INC. - A_R STRAT.contract_title: PACIRA PHARMACEUTICALS, INC. - A_R STRATEGIC LICENSING, DISTRIBUTION AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
PACIRA PHARMACEUTICALS, INC. - A_R STRAT.summary:
This Amended and Restated Strategic Licensing, Distribution, and Marketing Agreement, dated October 15, 2009, is between Pacira Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (PPI) and EKR Therapeutics, Inc. (EKR).  It amends and supersedes a prior agreement from August 10, 2007.  The agreement's main purpose is to grant EKR exclusive rights to distribute and market PPI's DepoDur product (an extended-release opioid analgesic) in specified territories within the Americas.

**Key Obligations:** PPI manufactures and supplies DepoDur; EKR markets, distributes, and sells it, obtaining necessary marketing authorizations and bearing related costs.  PPI retains manufacturing rights and certain liabilities related to pre-Agreement Date activities.  EKR assumes post-Agreement Date liabilities related to the transferred NDA.  PPI provides assistance to EKR for post-marketing studies.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement defines key terms like "Competing Product," "Confidential Information," and "Marketing Authorization."  It establishes a Commercialization Committee to oversee marketing strategies.

**Financial Arrangements:**  EKR makes upfront, milestone, and advanced royalty payments to PPI.  Royalties are based on net sales, subject to a cap and offset provisions.  A sale and leaseback agreement for manufacturing equipment is included.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement has an initial term tied to patent expiry or 15 years from the first commercial launch, renewable for two-year periods.  Either party may terminate for material breach or insolvency. EKR has a right to terminate for convenience and PPI can terminate if EKR fails to launch DepoDur within a specified timeframe.  Specific consequences of termination

MetLife, Inc. - Remarketing Agreement.summary:
This Remarketing Agreement, dated August 26, 2014, is between MetLife, Inc. ("Company") and Deutsche Bank Securities Inc. (initial "Remarketing Agent"), with Deutsche Bank Trust Company Americas acting as Stock Purchase Contract Agent.  The agreement facilitates the remarketing of MetLife's Series E Senior Component Debentures (Tranches 1 & 2), modifying their maturity dates upon successful remarketing.

The primary purpose is to remarket the debentures, with Deutsche Bank obligated to use commercially reasonable efforts to achieve a sale price meeting specified criteria (including a Remarketing Fee detailed in a separate Pricing Agreement).  MetLife warrants the accuracy of its disclosures in the registration statement and prospectus, and agrees to indemnify Deutsche Bank for liabilities arising from untrue statements.  Deutsche Bank undertakes to remarket the securities and determine the Reset Rates for the remarketed debentures.

Key terms include "Remarketing Date," "Remarketing Settlement Date," "Successful Remarketing," and "Remarketing Price."  The agreement's duration is contingent on a successful remarketing; otherwise, it terminates.  If unsuccessful, the Remarketing Agents return the securities.  Financial arrangements involve a Remarketing Fee payable to Deutsche Bank and MetLife's responsibility for various expenses related to the remarketing process.  The agreement includes detailed indemnification and contribution clauses between the parties, specifying liability for untrue statements in the prospectus.  New York law governs the agreement.

FTENETWORKS,INC_02_18_2016-EX-99.4-STRAT.summary: This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective February 17, 2016, through February 16, 2019 (renewable month-to-month), is between EDGE Communications Solutions, LLC ("EDGE") and FTE Networks, Inc. ("FTE").  The agreement outlines a subcontractor relationship where FTE will provide labor, materials, and services for EDGE's work with customer Mediacom, LLC.  Work is defined by individual Purchase Orders (POs), each incorporating the Agreement's terms.  FTE's key obligations include performing the work (Route Feasibility & Site Acquisition, Materials Management, OSP Construction, and Other Work) as specified in POs, maintaining insurance, and indemnifying EDGE against liens and claims.  EDGE's obligations include paying FTE for completed work (not a "pay-when-paid" contract), and providing access to review FTE's work and insurance.  The agreement specifies payment terms based on POs,  includes provisions for change orders, work inspection, termination for default (after a cure period), and suspension of work.  Crucially, FTE is an independent contractor, and the agreement addresses subcontracting, non-solicitation, confidentiality, and dispute resolution (Texas law governs, with venue in Collin County, Texas).  The agreement has a non-exclusive nature, anticipating POs exceeding $20MM.  The agreement terminates upon 30 days' written notice after the initial term.

DOMINIADVISORTRUST_02_18_2005-EX-99.(H)(.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated February 4, 2005, is between Domini Advisor Trust (a Massachusetts business trust) and Domini Social Investments LLC (a Massachusetts LLC, the "Sponsor").  The agreement outlines the Sponsor's provision of oversight, administrative, and management services to the Trust, which operates as a registered open-end investment company.

The Sponsor's key obligations include maintaining office facilities, arranging for personnel to serve as Trust officers/trustees, supervising Trust administration (including regulatory compliance), preparing necessary documentation (e.g., reports, proxy statements), and responding to investor inquiries.  Crucially, the Sponsor is *not* responsible for asset management or investment advice.

The Trust pays the Sponsor a 0.50% annual fee based on average daily net assets.  The Trust covers all other operating expenses.  The Sponsor's liability is limited to willful misfeasance, bad faith, or gross negligence.  The Sponsor may subcontract with prior Trust approval, remaining fully responsible for subcontractor actions.

The agreement is effective immediately and may be terminated by either party with 60 days' written notice.  Amendments require written consent from both parties.  Massachusetts law governs the agreement.  The Sponsor is not restricted from providing similar services to others.

PfHospitalityGroupInc_20150923_10-12G_EX.summary:
This Non-Disclosure and Non-Competition Agreement, dated September 23, 2015, is between a Pizza Fusion franchisee (Franchisee) and its officer, director, or employee (Member).  It's supplementary to a Franchise Agreement between the Franchisee and PfHospitalityGroupInc (Franchisor).  The agreement's purpose is to protect Franchisor's confidential information and business interests.

The Member agrees to maintain the confidentiality of Franchisor's trade secrets and operational information.  Crucially, the Member is prohibited from competing with Pizza Fusion during the Franchise Agreement's term and for two years afterward (Post-Term Period) within a three-mile radius of any existing or planned Pizza Fusion franchise.  This restriction covers ownership, employment, consultation, or any interest in a competitive business.  The agreement also prevents the Member from diverting business or customers from Pizza Fusion.

Franchisor is a third-party beneficiary with enforcement rights.  Breach entitles Franchisor to injunctive relief and attorney's fees.  The agreement contains severability and waiver clauses.  No specific financial arrangements are detailed in this excerpt.  The duration is tied to the Franchise Agreement and a two-year post-term period, triggered by various events including termination of the Franchise Agreement or the Member's employment.

CerenceInc_20191002_8-K_EX-10.4_11827494.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated September 30, 2019, is between Nuance Communications, Inc. ("Nuance") and Cerence Inc. ("SpinCo"),  governing intellectual property rights in connection with SpinCo's spin-off from Nuance.  The IPA's main purpose is to establish reciprocal, perpetual, worldwide, non-exclusive licenses for patents and shared technology assets between the parties,  limited to each party's respective field of use (defined in Schedule A).  

Nuance licenses its patents and shared technology assets to SpinCo, and SpinCo reciprocally licenses its patents and shared technology assets to Nuance.  Both parties agree not to challenge each other's IP and to maintain confidentiality of disclosed technical information.  Specific obligations include recordation of IP assignments (Article II) and restrictions on the use of licensed technology assets (Articles III & IV).  The agreement includes disclaimers of warranties and limitations of liability (Article VII).

The agreement may be terminated only by mutual written consent (Section 9.01), except for termination by Nuance prior to the spin-off distribution (Section 9.02).  Articles I, VI, VII, Section 9.03, and XI survive termination.  Financial arrangements are largely addressed in a separate Separation Agreement, with this IPA focusing on IP rights and related obligations.  Governing law is Delaware, with exclusive jurisdiction in the Delaware Court of Chancery.  A jury trial is waived.

ThriventVariableInsuranceAccountB_201907.summary:
This July 1, 2019 endorsement agreement amends the Thrivent Variable Insurance Account B contract (N-6).  It addresses the dissolution of Thrivent Life Insurance Company and the transfer of all its assets and liabilities, including this contract, to Thrivent Financial for Lutherans (TFFL). TFFL now assumes all obligations under the contract.

The main purpose is to update the contract to reflect the corporate restructuring, amending references to the former entity ("Thrivent Life Insurance Company") to "Thrivent Financial for Lutherans" throughout the document.  Key changes include updating the address and contact information, clarifying the definition of "We/Us/Our" to refer to TFFL, and amending the "Entire Contract" section to include the Society's Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws.

TFFL's main obligation is to fulfill all previous obligations under the original contract.  The insured's obligations remain largely unchanged, though a maintenance of solvency provision outlines potential extra payments in case of TFFL's impaired solvency.  Dividend provisions are clarified, specifying payment methods.  The contract also addresses membership rights (separate from contract ownership) and assignment of ownership (subject to bylaws).  No specific duration or termination clause is detailed in this summary, but the underlying contract's terms remain in effect, subject to the amendments.  Financial arrangements are governed by the original contract, with the addition of the solvency provision.

ReynoldsConsumerProductsInc_20191115_S-1.summary:
This Master Supply Agreement, effective November 1, 2019, is between Reynolds Consumer Products LLC ("Seller") and Pactiv LLC ("Buyer"), both Delaware limited liability companies.  The agreement governs the sale of products by Seller to Buyer for Buyer's resale.  Specific products and quantities are detailed in separate Purchase Schedules, which supersede conflicting provisions in the main agreement.

Seller's key obligations include supplying conforming products meeting specified warranties (Section 6),  defending Buyer against certain third-party claims (Section 7), and maintaining specified insurance coverage (Section 8). Buyer's key obligations include purchasing products as outlined in Purchase Schedules, and defending Seller against specified third-party claims (Section 7).  Financial arrangements are detailed in Purchase Schedules and include provisions for late payment fees (Section 11(e)).

The agreement's term lasts until the first anniversary of the last Purchase Schedule's expiration, or earlier termination by either party with notice (Section 1).  Sections 9 and 11 address limitations on liability (excluding indirect damages, except for indemnification and intentional misconduct) and dispute resolution (negotiation, mediation, then litigation in Illinois courts; waiver of jury trial).  Confidential information provisions (Section 10) detail protection and use restrictions.  The agreement is governed by Illinois law (Section 12(d)) and is non-assignable without consent (Section 12(f)).  The relationship is explicitly defined as that of independent contractors (Section 12(j)).

IntegrityFunds_20200121_485BPOS_EX-99.E.contract_id: IntegrityFunds_20200121_485BPOS_EX-99.E UNDR CONTR_11948727_EX-99.E UNDR CONTR_Service Agreement
IntegrityFunds_20200121_485BPOS_EX-99.E.contract_title: IntegrityFunds_20200121_485BPOS_EX-99.E UNDR CONTR_11948727_EX-99.E UNDR CONTR_Service Agreement
IntegrityFunds_20200121_485BPOS_EX-99.E.summary:
This Distribution and Services Agreement, dated January 18, 2020, is between Integrity Short Term Government Fund (the "Fund"), a Delaware statutory trust, and Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC ("Integrity").  The agreement appoints Integrity as the principal underwriter for the Fund's shares.

Integrity's key obligations include using best efforts to sell shares at the public offering price, complying with all applicable securities laws, and providing shareholder services.  The Fund's obligations include providing necessary information for share sales, executing documents, and paying Integrity distribution and service fees as outlined in the Registration Statement and the Shareholder Services Plan (Rule 12b-1 compliant).

Integrity's compensation is the difference between the sales price and the net asset value of shares sold, plus applicable distribution fees.  All distribution expenses are borne by Integrity.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification against liabilities arising from untrue statements in the registration materials, subject to exceptions for willful misconduct or gross negligence.

The agreement runs until January 18, 2022, automatically renewing annually unless terminated by either party with 60 (Fund) or 90 (Integrity) days' written notice, or by a majority vote of the Fund's Qualified Trustees.  Assignment of the agreement automatically terminates it.  The agreement is governed by Kansas law.

PREMIERBIOMEDICALINC_05_14_2020-EX-10.2-.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement, dated May 12, 2020, involves Marv Enterprises, LLC (Marv), Premier Biomedical, Inc. (Premier), and Technology Health, Inc. (THI).  The agreement primarily concerns the licensing of patents and patent applications related to a potential COVID-19 treatment.  Marv, owner of key patents, grants THI an exclusive worldwide license to these patents and applications, previously exclusively licensed to Premier.  Premier assigns its rights under prior agreements to THI.

THI's key obligations include substantial upfront payments to Marv ($20,000 already paid, ~$80,000 owed to Marv by Premier, plus IP prosecution costs), and ongoing royalty payments (5% of Fair Market Value of Licensed Products and services, plus a separate 5% to specified Premier shareholders totaling $40M).  THI also commits to reporting requirements.  Failure to make payments results in license reversion to Premier.

A joint venture between Premier and THI for COVID-19 product development is also established, with THI committing further payments totaling $2,400,000.  Marv has a limited consulting role.  THI's failure to meet joint venture payment obligations results in partial ownership reversion to Premier.

The agreement is governed by Pennsylvania law, with venue in Mercer County.  It's a complete agreement, superseding prior understandings (except for specified prior agreements).  No duration is explicitly stated; termination is implied through payment defaults.  The agreement includes confidentiality and non-exclusive engagement clauses.

SIBANNAC,INC_12_04_2017-EX-2.1-Strategic.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated November 30, 2017, is between Bravatek Solutions, Inc. (Colorado corporation) and Sibannac, Inc. (Nevada corporation).  The agreement establishes a non-exclusive business relationship where Bravatek acts as a sales lead generator for Sibannac's patented Air Cylinder Wheel, focusing on government clients.

Bravatek's key obligations include promoting Sibannac's product, providing quarterly sales leads reports, and assisting with marketing materials. Sibannac must list Bravatek as an alliance partner, respond to inquiries, and support joint marketing efforts.  Both parties agree to collaborate on sales strategies and product development.

Bravatek receives a lead-finder fee (10-20% of project revenue, exact percentage to be determined based on project margins) for sales resulting from its leads.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality, indemnification, and governing law (Texas) clauses.  The initial term is 12 months, automatically renewing unless terminated with 90 days' written notice.  The agreement is not assignable without written consent.  All modifications must be in writing.

INTRICONCORP_03_10_2009-EX-10.22-Strateg.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement (SAA), effective October 1, 2008, is between Intricon Corporation (Intricon) and Dynamic Hearing Pty Ltd (Dynamic Hearing).  The agreement grants Intricon an exclusive (for Hearing Aids, subject to exceptions) license to use Dynamic Hearing's technology and software (Licensed Subject Matter) to manufacture, import, sell, and offer for sale hearing aids and assistive listening devices globally.  This excludes Contact Center products and ADRO technology for auditory stimulation.

Intricon's key obligations include making minimum annual payments (detailed schedule in the contract), paying royalties based on sales volume (with tiered rates), providing reports on sales, maintaining records for audit, and indemnifying Dynamic Hearing for certain liabilities.  Dynamic Hearing's key obligations include providing services (up to 260 hours/month free, exceeding hours billed at $150/hour), maintaining its intellectual property, and not licensing its Hearing Aid technology to non-identified parties for hearing aids (subject to exceptions).

Important terms include definitions of various products and technologies, exclusivity provisions with exceptions for identified parties (listed in Exhibit C), and limitations on liability. The initial term is five years, renewable by mutual agreement.  Termination can occur for material breach, insolvency, or upon three months' written notice after two years, with certain rights and obligations surviving termination (including confidentiality, indemnification, and record-keeping).  Financial arrangements include annual access fees ($300,000), tiered minimum annual payments, and tiered royalty payments based on sales volume of Base Products and Enhanced Products.  The agreement is governed by Victorian law.

BONTONSTORESINC_04_20_2018-EX-99.3-AGENC.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated April 18, 2018, governs the liquidation of The Bon-Ton Stores, Inc. (Merchant), a debtor in possession under Chapter 11 bankruptcy, by a joint venture of GA Retail, Inc. and Tiger Capital Group, LLC (Agent), and Wilmington Savings Fund Society, FSB (Notes Trustee), collectively Purchaser.  The agreement appoints the Agent as Merchant's exclusive agent to conduct a "going-out-of-business" sale (GOB Sale) of substantially all of Merchant's assets.

Key obligations include the Agent's responsibility to conduct the GOB Sale, manage store operations (paying expenses within defined limits), and designate assignees for leases and contracts.  Merchant's obligations include providing access to assets and records, cooperating with the Agent, and maintaining certain insurance policies.  The Notes Trustee provides a credit bid of $125,000,000 against its claims.  The Cash Purchase Price includes a DIP payoff, funding for a carve-out account, and liquidity for outstanding checks.  Additional funding is provided for wind-down expenses ($93.8 million cap).  Expenses are borne by the Agent, primarily from sale proceeds.

The Sale Term runs until August 31, 2018, or earlier termination by the Agent with seven days' notice.  The Agreement includes detailed provisions on sales tax collection, employee matters (including retention bonuses), and insurance.  Purchaser receives proceeds after the Cash Purchase Price and expenses are paid, and holds a senior lien on assets and proceeds.  The Agreement is governed by Delaware law, with exclusive jurisdiction in the Delaware Bankruptcy Court.  The agreement includes

ON2TECHNOLOGIES,INC_11_17_2006-EX-10.3-S.summary:
This Support and Maintenance Agreement, dated April 2005, is between On2 Technologies, Inc. (On2) and Wildform, Inc. (Wildform), following an Asset Purchase Agreement.  The agreement covers transition services, software deliverables, and intellectual property rights related to Wildform's Flix software.

Wildform's key obligations include providing transition services (detailed in Exhibit A), delivering specified software (Deliverables #1 and #2 in Exhibit B), resolving program errors for 12 months, and maintaining confidentiality. On2's main obligations are payment ($160,000 plus 280,000 shares of common stock), cooperation with Wildform, and respecting Wildform's intellectual property rights.  Important terms define "Confidential Information," "Program Errors," and "Deliverables."

The agreement lasts 18 months, terminable for material breach (30-day cure period) or bankruptcy.  Upon termination, Wildform must cease use and return/destroy On2's Incorporated Technology.  Articles I, IV (outstanding payments), V-X survive termination.  New York law governs, with dispute resolution via negotiation, mediation, and then court action.  Each party indemnifies the other for breaches of confidentiality, warranties, and intellectual property provisions.

Freecook_20180605_S-1_EX-10.3_11233807_E.summary: This Website Design, Development and Hosting Agreement, dated January 11, 2018, is between Natalija Tunevic (FreeCook) and Mitchell Vitalis (Mitchell's Web Advance, PLC).  The agreement outlines the design and development of a website for FreeCook for a total price of $5,000 ($1,900 upfront, $3,100 upon completion).  Mitchell's Web Advance is obligated to design and develop the website according to the attached Scope of Work (Exhibit A), encompassing stages from competitor analysis to SEO, within a 12-week timeframe (February 8 - May 3, 2018).  Delays are possible due to client-provided materials or approvals.  FreeCook is responsible for providing accurate, typewritten content in specified formats.  The agreement grants Mitchell's Web Advance a limited license to use FreeCook's trademarks for marketing purposes and allows placement of a website footer credit.  The agreement includes provisions for change orders, rush work surcharges ($40/hour + 25%), and limited customer service.  No explicit termination clause is detailed.

OPERALTD_04_30_2020-EX-4.14-SERVICE AGRE.summary:
This Service Agreement, effective April 1, 2019, through March 30, 2020, is between PC Financial Services Private Limited (India) and Mobimagic Co., Ltd. (China).  Mobimagic provides system/platform maintenance and data processing services to PC Financial, supporting PC Financial's small unsecured loan offerings.  Mobimagic warrants non-infringement of third-party rights and compliance with all applicable laws, including anti-corruption legislation.  Crucially, Mobimagic will not store PC Financial's data beyond transactional metadata for invoicing purposes.

PC Financial pays Mobimagic a monthly fee of USD 970,000, exclusive of GST, payable within 45 days of invoice confirmation.  The agreement includes confidentiality clauses (surviving 5 years post-termination), mutual indemnification provisions, and limitations of liability excluding consequential damages.  Either party may terminate for material breach after a 30-day cure period.  The agreement is governed by Indian law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New Delhi courts and arbitration under the 1996 Arbitration and Conciliation Act.  The agreement is non-assignable without written consent.  Both parties are independent contractors.

BORROWMONEYCOM,INC_06_11_2020-EX-10.1-JO.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement, dated March 20, 2020, establishes a five-year joint venture (BM&V2GO) between BorrowMoney.com, Inc. (Florida) and JVLS, LLC dba Vaccines 2Go (Georgia) for IT development, internet back-office maintenance, and medical service deployment.  The venture's principal place of business is in Fort Lauderdale, FL.

BorrowMoney.com contributes office space valued at $3,500,000 and provides technical services (website development, database maintenance). JVLS contributes $60,000 monthly from government contracts plus 10% of gross revenue generated from those contracts.  Both contribute equally to the initial capital.  Management is vested in Aldo Piscitello and Jody Stewart, appointed by the members.  Major decisions require joint manager agreement or a majority member vote.

Key obligations include fulfilling specified technical and financial contributions.  Members are responsible for their respective duties, and the managers oversee day-to-day operations.  The agreement outlines procedures for amending duties, capital contributions, member withdrawal (including involuntary withdrawal for breach), dissolution, liquidation, and dispute resolution (mediation and arbitration).  The agreement is governed by Florida law.  The venture's term is until February 28, 2025, extendable by unanimous consent.  No member is personally liable for the debts of the venture except in cases of gross negligence or willful misconduct.

ZEBRATECHNOLOGIESCORP_04_16_2014-EX-10.1.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated April 14, 2014, is between Motorola Solutions, Inc. ("Seller") and Zebra Technologies Corporation ("Purchaser"), concerning intellectual property (IP) rights related to a larger acquisition agreement (Acquisition Agreement).  The IPA governs the assignment and licensing of IP assets.

The main purpose is to define IP ownership and usage rights post-acquisition of a business ("Business") by the Purchaser.  Seller assigns certain IP ("Assigned IP") to Purchaser Assignees, while Purchaser grants Seller a license back for specified uses ("Seller Licensed Activities").  Conversely, Seller licenses other IP ("Licensed IP") to Purchaser Licensees for use in the Business ("Purchaser Licensed Activities").  A complex review process is established for patents and invention disclosures jointly developed.  Transitional licenses are provided for certain trademarks.

Key obligations include assignment of Assigned IP, granting reciprocal licenses, and adherence to quality control standards for trademark usage.  Schedules detail specific IP assets and contracts.  The IPA contains detailed definitions of various IP categories and related terms.

The agreement is perpetual unless terminated per Section 4.3 (upon termination of the Acquisition Agreement) or Section 4.2 (limited termination of specific trademark licenses for material breach).  The IPA is royalty-free; financial arrangements are implicit within the broader Acquisition Agreement.  Dispute resolution, including arbitration for patent ownership disagreements, is outlined.  Governing law is Delaware.

ChinaRealEstateInformationCorp_20090929_.summary: This Domain Name and Content License Agreement, effective upon closing of a Share Purchase Agreement between SINA and CRIC, is between Beijing SINA Internet Information Service Co., Ltd. (Licensor) and Beijing Yisheng Leju Information Services Co., Ltd. (Licensee).  It grants Licensee an exclusive, non-transferable license to use specified domain names (house.sina.com.cn, jiaju.sina.com.cn, construction.sina.com.cn) and licensed content for an online real estate platform in China ("Business").  Licensee has exclusive control over the Business's operation and content, subject to compliance with laws and content monitoring/censorship obligations (including removal of illegal or offensive material).  Licensor retains ownership of the domain names and content.  The agreement's initial term is ten years, renewable by mutual agreement.  Termination clauses exist for bankruptcy, material breach (with cure periods), change of control in CRIC, and termination of a related Advertising Sale Agency Agreement.  While initially fee-free, fees may be introduced if E-House becomes entitled to charge Licensee for licensed data.  The agreement includes standard indemnification clauses and a confidentiality provision.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration in Beijing, China.  Governing law is the People's Republic of China.

HERTZGLOBALHOLDINGS,INC_07_07_2016-EX-10.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), effective June 30, 2016, involves The Hertz Corporation (THC), Hertz System, Inc. (HSI), and Herc Rentals Inc. (HERC) –  THC's wholly-owned subsidiaries, with HERC being indirectly owned by Hertz Global Holdings, Inc. (HGH) post-separation of the Vehicle Rental Business (VRB) and Equipment Rental Business (ERB).  The IPA governs the ownership, licensing, and use of trademarks and other intellectual property related to the separation.

The main purpose is to delineate intellectual property rights post-corporate separation.  Key obligations include HSI retaining ownership of VRB trademarks, granting HERC a royalty-free, non-exclusive license for certain Hertz trademarks for an interim four-year period, and HERC retaining ownership of its own trademarks.  HSI assigns certain foreign HERC trademarks to HERC.  HERC must cease using licensed trademarks after the interim period.  THC assigns certain non-Hertz domains to HERC.

Important terms include mutual indemnification clauses (with specific provisions for HSI indemnifying HERC regarding Hertz trademark infringement during the interim period), a non-competition clause restricting HERC from VRB activities during the interim period, and a requirement for HERC to maintain liability insurance naming THC and HSI as additional insureds.

The agreement's duration is four years (Interim Period), automatically terminating upon material breach (with a 30-day cure period) or upon certain events like HERC's insolvency.  No financial arrangements beyond insurance and cost reimbursement for trademark maintenance are explicitly detailed.  The governing law is New York state law.

GLOBALTECHNOLOGIESLTD_06_08_2020-EX-10.1.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated January 2, 2020, is between Global Technologies, Ltd. ("Company"), a Delaware corporation, and Timothy Cabrera ("Consultant"), an individual.  The agreement is non-exclusive and outlines the Consultant's services in assisting the Company with transactional business, specifically focusing on business plan development for subsidiaries, acquisition of products, negotiation of acquisitions/mergers, and asset sales.

The Consultant's key obligations include devoting reasonable time and effort to these tasks, using commercially reasonable efforts, and adhering to all applicable laws.  The Consultant is not responsible for services if the Company fails to provide necessary information and will not provide legal or accounting opinions.  The Company's obligations include cooperation, keeping the Consultant informed, and abiding by the agreement.  Confidentiality and mutual indemnification clauses are included.

The Consultant's compensation is $250,000, reducing the principal of a pre-existing convertible note, plus additional compensation for the sale of specific inventory and future products, to be negotiated separately.  The Consultant is responsible for all taxes.

The agreement's term is one year or until service completion.  Either party may terminate for cause (bankruptcy, insolvency) without notice or with notice.  The agreement includes standard clauses on amendment, waiver, expenses, compliance with regulatory agencies, assignment, delegation, publicity, arbitration (Florida law, Pinellas County venue), and severability.  A non-circumvention clause protects the Consultant's introductions of business opportunities.

PfHospitalityGroupInc_20150923_10-12G_EX.summary:
This Franchise Agreement, dated September 23, 2015, is between Pizza Fusion Holdings, Inc. (Franchisor) and a Franchisee (individual or entity).  The agreement grants the Franchisee the right to operate a single Pizza Fusion restaurant at a specified location for ten years, renewable for two additional ten-year terms.

The Franchisee's key obligations include paying an initial franchise fee ($30,000), weekly royalties (6% of Gross Revenues), and advertising contributions (up to 7% of Gross Revenues).  They must adhere to the Franchisor's operational standards, use approved products and suppliers, maintain insurance, and comply with marketing requirements.  The Franchisor retains rights to operate competing businesses and control marketing efforts.

Significant terms include the Franchisor's right to approve the location, lease, and advertising; limitations on the Franchisee's geographic reach; and the Franchisor's right to inspect the Franchisee's operations.  The Franchisee's obligations regarding confidential information and non-competition are also prominent.

The agreement may be terminated by the Franchisor without cause (for specified breaches) or with a cure period (for other defaults).  Financial defaults trigger a 10-day cure period; other defaults, a 30-day cure period.  Upon termination, the Franchisor has the right to purchase the Franchisee's assets and collect liquidated damages.  Florida law governs the agreement.  Dispute resolution involves mediation, followed by litigation in a Florida court.  Class actions and jury trials are waived.

CORIOINC_07_20_2000-EX-10.5-LICENSE AND.summary:
This License and Hosting Agreement, effective October 29, 1999, is between Corio Inc. (Corio) and Commerce One, Inc. (Commerce One).  It's a licensing and hosting agreement where Commerce One licenses its proprietary software ("Software," primarily Hosted BuySite v6.0) to Corio for hosting and resale to Corio's customers within North America.

Corio's key obligations include hosting the Software on its servers, sublicensing it to customers (primarily those with <$1B annual revenue), securing end-user license agreements, and paying license fees, maintenance fees, and revenue sharing. Commerce One's key obligations include providing the Software, updates, upgrades, support, and training.  Both parties agree to joint marketing efforts.

Important terms include a 60-day warranty on the Software, indemnification clauses protecting Corio and its customers from infringement claims, limitations of liability, confidentiality provisions, and a source code escrow agreement.  Revenue sharing is based on MarketSite transactions and Corio's application management revenue.

The agreement has an initial five-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  Termination can also occur for material breach (uncured after 30 days) or insolvency.  Specific sections survive termination, including payment and support obligations.  Financial arrangements are detailed in Exhibit B, including license fees, maintenance fees, revenue sharing percentages, and implementation fees (time and materials).

TUNIUCORP_03_06_2014-EX-10-COOPERATION A.summary:
This 2014 Cooperation Agreement amends a 2008 agreement between Nanjing Tuniu Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party A") and Beijing Tuniu Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party B"), both Chinese companies with Yu Dunde as the legal representative of both.  The agreement establishes an exclusive cooperation for Party B to provide Party A and its subsidiaries with technical and business consultancy services related to internet-based tour product sales and promotion.

Party B's obligations include developing, maintaining, and upgrading technology and internet platforms, designing tour product plans, providing training, and offering sales/promotion consultancy.  Party A is obligated to use Party B exclusively for these services and refrain from competing activities without Party B's consent.

Crucially, Party B is entitled to 100% of the profits generated from the cooperative business as a service fee, payable quarterly with a strict late payment penalty.  Party B retains all intellectual property rights generated under the agreement.

The agreement's duration is tied to Party B's operational term.  Party B can unilaterally terminate the agreement before its expiration, while Party A cannot.  Termination clauses also address bankruptcy and force majeure events, with limited liability for either party in those scenarios. Disputes are resolved through negotiation or arbitration in Beijing.  The agreement is governed by Chinese law, supplemented by international business practices where applicable.

CYBERIANOUTPOSTINC_07_09_1998-EX-10.13-P.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, dated January 26, 1998, is between CNET, Inc. ("CNET") and Cyberian Outpost, Inc. ("Cyberian").  It's a marketing agreement where CNET agrees to promote Cyberian's products and services via online and television promotions (including banner ads, website links, and a TV spot on TV.COM).  Cyberian will compensate CNET.

CNET's key obligations include providing a specified number of "Retail Impressions" (website link displays) across its sites (CNET.COM, SEARCH.COM, etc.), banner ads, and a TV spot.  Guaranteed impression numbers are redacted but are detailed for each three-month period of the contract.  CNET will also provide monthly reports on impressions and click-through rates. Cyberian is responsible for maintaining its website's functionality (meeting performance standards in Exhibit B), providing monthly reports on sales generated from CNET referrals ("CNET Sales"), and reciprocal marketing efforts.

Cyberian's financial obligations include a minimum monthly cash payment to CNET, plus a percentage of CNET Sales.  The exact amounts are redacted.

The agreement's term is one year from February 1, 1998, but either party can terminate with 30 days' notice after the first three months, or immediately for material breach.  The agreement includes exclusivity provisions limiting CNET's similar agreements with competitors, mutual indemnification clauses, and a limitation of liability excluding consequential damages.  Governing law is California.  Confidentiality is governed by a separate NDA.

SENMIAOTECHNOLOGYLTD_02_19_2019-EX-10.5-.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement (dated 02/19/2019), between Didi Chuxing Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party A") and Hunan Ruixi Financial Leasing Co., Ltd. ("Party B"), governs their cooperation in providing vehicle leasing services to Didi's driver-users.  The agreement facilitates Party B's offering of vehicle leasing and financing solutions to drivers via Didi's platform.

Party B's key obligations include providing vehicles meeting specified criteria, ensuring accurate information on the platform, managing driver contracts using Didi's template, handling insurance claims, and maintaining favorable leasing terms for drivers.  Party A maintains and operates the platform, ensuring its functionality and responding to Party B's inquiries.  Party A retains the right to inspect information, remove listings, and terminate the agreement under certain circumstances (e.g., significant business risks for Party B).

The agreement establishes a tiered system of breaches with corresponding liquidated damages (ranging from RMB 1,000 to RMB 50,000+), culminating in termination for severe breaches.  A deposit mechanism is in place, with Party B required to pay a deposit based on the number of vehicles listed (RMB 100,000 for the first 100 vehicles, and so on).  The agreement lasts one year, unless terminated earlier by either party under specified conditions (e.g., breach, force majeure, or mutual agreement).  Dispute resolution is through negotiation, followed by arbitration in Beijing.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on confidentiality, intellectual property, and anti-bribery.  A separate Honesty & Integrity and Anti-Commercial Bribery Agreement is appended.

HealthcareIntegratedTechnologiesInc_2019.summary:
This Walabot-HOME Reseller Agreement, effective July 31, 2019, is between Vayyar Imaging Ltd. ("Supplier") and Inde Living Holdings, Inc. ("Reseller").  It's a non-exclusive reseller agreement appointing Reseller to sell Supplier's Walabot HOME devices in the USA.

Reseller's key obligations include complying with all laws, using Supplier's branding, attending training, ensuring End Users sign the End User Agreement (bearing liability for non-compliance), and making no unauthorized warranties.  Supplier is responsible for shipping and obtaining necessary export/import documentation, with Reseller reimbursing reasonable costs.  Supplier retains all intellectual property rights.  Data generated by the product is uploaded to Supplier's server.

The agreement includes a minimum order quantity (MOQ).  Payment terms and pricing are detailed in Schedule 1 (redacted in provided text).  Supplier disclaims warranties except as explicitly stated, and liability is limited.  Reseller indemnifies Supplier against third-party claims.

The initial term is one year, automatically renewing annually, terminable by either party with 3 months' notice after the initial term or immediately for material breach.  Upon termination, all rights revert to Supplier, except for unsold inventory which Reseller can continue to sell for up to one year.  Governing law is New York.  The relationship is that of independent contractor and supplier.

LOYALTYPOINTINC_11_16_2004-EX-10.2-RESEL.summary:
This Reseller Agreement, dated August 1, 2004, is between American Express Incentive Services, L.L.C. ("AEIS") and Schoolpop, Inc. ("Schoolpop").  It's a distribution agreement granting Schoolpop exclusive rights to resell AEIS stored-value cards (Encompass(R) Select, Persona(R) Select, Fill It Up(R), Be My Guest(R), and others) within the Non-Profit Organization (NPO) marketplace in the US, contingent on Schoolpop meeting a $52,000,000 minimum annual purchase.

Schoolpop's key obligations include accurate forecasting of card sales and inventory, maintaining adequate security for card storage, complying with all applicable laws (including anti-money laundering), and adhering to AEIS branding guidelines.  Failure to meet forecasting targets incurs penalties.  AEIS is responsible for card production, fulfillment (with specified timelines), and 24/7 customer service.

Schoolpop pays AEIS a $1,250,000 marketing rights fee in installments and a $250,000 Encompass(R) Select fee upfront.  Payment for cards is via wire transfer (Period One) or ACH debit (Period Two).  Risk of loss for cards transfers to Schoolpop upon delivery.

The agreement runs from August 1, 2004, to July 31, 2009, unless terminated earlier for breach, insolvency, or non-payment.  AEIS retains the right to cancel client participation or refuse card provision.  Liability is capped at $50,000, except for specific breaches

BNCMORTGAGEINC_05_17_1999-EX-10.4-LICENS.summary: This Licensing and Website Hosting Agreement, dated February 26, 1999, is between Mortgage Logic.com, Inc. ("Client") and TrueLink, Inc. ("TrueLink").  The agreement covers TrueLink's provision of interface software ("Interface"), access to credit bureau information, and hosting services for Client's website.  TrueLink grants Client a non-exclusive license to use the Interface for mortgage origination and related activities.  TrueLink's obligations include hosting services (specified disk space, bandwidth, response times, backups, etc.), support services (programming assistance), and transmission of credit data via the Interface.  Client's obligations include payment of fees (detailed in Exhibits A & B, minimums specified), compliance with laws (credit reporting, privacy, etc.), and non-engagement in spamming.  TrueLink provides warranties regarding Y2K compliance of the Interface.  Both parties have indemnity obligations for breaches of the agreement.  The agreement lasts one year, automatically renewing unless terminated with 30 days' notice.  Confidentiality provisions protect both parties' proprietary information.  Applicable law is California law, with venue in San Luis Obispo County.  The agreement includes standard clauses on assignment, modification, waiver, and severability.

ENERGOUSCORP_03_16_2017-EX-10.24-STRATEG.summary: This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated November 6, 2016, is between Dialog Semiconductor (UK) Ltd. ("Dialog") and Energous Corporation ("Energous").  The agreement establishes a strategic relationship for Dialog to manufacture, sell, and distribute Energous' wireless charging products ("Products").  Dialog receives a non-exclusive, royalty-bearing license under Energous' intellectual property ("Product IP").  Key obligations include Dialog's marketing and sales efforts, subject to certain excluded applications initially, and Energous' provision of technical support and Product Updates.  Energous retains ownership of the Product IP.  Financial arrangements involve royalties and service fees payable by Dialog to Energous, calculated based on net sales, with audit rights granted to Energous.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on confidentiality, indemnification, limitation of liability, and compliance with laws.  The initial term is seven years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach or insolvency, with additional termination rights for Energous upon Dialog's change of control involving a competitor, and vice-versa.  A wind-down period allows for completion of existing customer orders post-termination.  The agreement is governed by California law and provides for arbitration in San Francisco.

CytodynInc_20200109_10-Q_EX-10.5_1194163.summary:
This Commercialization and License Agreement, effective December 17, 2019, is between CytoDyn Inc. (CytoDyn) and Vyera Pharmaceuticals, LLC (Vyera).  The agreement grants Vyera an exclusive, royalty-bearing license to commercialize CytoDyn's leronlimab (PRO 140) for the treatment of HIV in the U.S.

CytoDyn's key obligations include development of leronlimab (per the Development Plan),  patent prosecution, and regulatory filings. Vyera's key obligations are commercialization (per the Commercialization Plan), purchasing leronlimab exclusively from CytoDyn (via a separate Supply Agreement), and paying royalties (50% of Net Sales, reducing post-Step-Down Date).  A Joint Committee oversees the collaboration.

Significant terms include definitions of "Net Sales" (complex formula accounting for combination products), "Commercially Reasonable Efforts," and various milestone payments triggering upon specific development and sales achievements.  Vyera also makes a $4,000,000 equity investment in CytoDyn.

The agreement's duration is tied to the Royalty Term, ending upon the latest of patent expiration, 10 years post-First Commercial Sale, Regulatory Exclusivity expiration, or Biosimilar Entry Date.  Vyera has unilateral termination rights under specific circumstances (e.g., lack of FDA approval, commercial failure), while CytoDyn can terminate for Vyera's breaches (e.g., failure to meet Minimum Requirements, patent challenges).  Both parties have termination rights for material breach.  Dispute resolution is primarily through arbitration, with certain "Reserved Disputes" decided by a designated executive officer.

MSCIINC_02_28_2008-EX-10.10-.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated November 20, 2007, is between Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated ("MS") and MSCI Inc. ("MSCI"), both Delaware corporations.  The IPA's purpose is to grant each party a perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide, royalty-free, non-exclusive license to use, modify, copy, create derivative works of, and sublicense certain pre-existing intellectual property ("Licensed Materials").  MS's Licensed Materials comprise specific hardware settings, software libraries, and document templates; MSCI's are similarly defined.  Crucially, the license excludes patents, trademarks, infrastructure software, and separately licensed materials.

The agreement explicitly disclaims all warranties, limiting liability to exclude indirect, consequential, and punitive damages.  Each party agrees to use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate damages arising from the other party's breach.  The IPA is governed by New York law, with jurisdiction in the Southern District of New York, and includes a jury trial waiver.  There are no specified termination clauses or financial arrangements beyond the mutual grant of licenses.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes prior agreements.

NICELTD_06_26_2003-EX-4.5-OUTSOURCING AG.summary:
This Manufacturing Outsourcing Agreement, dated January 21, 2002, is between Nice Systems Ltd. (NICE), an Israeli corporation, and Flextronics Israel Ltd. (Contractor), also an Israeli corporation.  The agreement outlines a turnkey manufacturing outsourcing arrangement for NICE's digital recording products.

NICE's key obligations include providing forecasts, purchase orders, specifications (via a PDM system), and certain components.  The Contractor's key obligations are to manufacture, test, and deliver the products according to purchase orders, manage component purchasing (subject to NICE oversight and approval), maintain quality control (subject to NICE audits), and meet specified due dates and shipment dates (with liquidated damages for delays).  The agreement details lead times (purchase, sub-assembly, production), change order procedures (ECRs and ECOs), and cancellation provisions.  Intellectual property rights are carefully delineated, with mutual indemnification clauses.  A detailed pricing structure, including cost adjustment mechanisms, is outlined in Appendix C.  The agreement includes a warranty period of 13 months.

The initial term is three years, automatically renewing indefinitely, unless terminated by NICE with 45 days' notice or by the Contractor with six months' notice during the extended term.  Termination provisions address fundamental breaches, insolvency, and force majeure events.  Financial arrangements include payment terms (30 days), cost adjustments based on component pricing, and specific payment provisions upon termination.  The agreement is governed by Israeli law and subject to the jurisdiction of Tel Aviv-Jaffa District Courts.  Numerous appendices detail specific aspects of the agreement, including product specifications, pricing, quality assurance, and security requirements.

ImpresseCorp_20000322_S-1A_EX-10.11_5199.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective March 3, 2000, is between VerticalNet, Inc. (Pennsylvania) and Impresse Corporation (California).  The agreement establishes a co-branded website promoting Impresse's printing services to VerticalNet's online community users.

VerticalNet's key obligations include designing and maintaining the VerticalNet area of the co-branded site, creating and maintaining a link to it from VerticalNet's sites (V-Solutions Link), and refraining from advertising competing printing services. Impresse is responsible for designing and maintaining the Impresse area, integrating with VerticalNet's online communities, and providing technical support.

Financially, Impresse pays VerticalNet a one-time development fee, slotting fees, banner/newsletter purchase commitments, and a hosting fee, totaling a specified amount payable quarterly.  Impresse also shares a percentage of revenue generated from users registering through the co-branded site.  VerticalNet has audit rights.

The agreement lasts 15 months, terminable by either party for material breach after a 30-60 day cure period.  Post-termination, Impresse remains liable for outstanding payments.  Disputes are resolved through negotiation and, if unsuccessful, binding arbitration under the AAA rules.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality, indemnification, and limitation of liability clauses, governed by Delaware law.  A jury trial is waived.

AlliedEsportsEntertainmentInc_20190815_8.summary:
This Joint Content License Agreement, effective February 1, 2018, is between WPT Enterprises, Inc. ("WPT") and Zynga Inc. and Zynga Game Ireland Limited ("Zynga").  The agreement governs a worldwide (excluding Asia) cooperative marketing and content licensing relationship for a three-year initial term, automatically renewing for two years if WPT receives over $12 million in payments during the initial term.

The core purpose is mutual brand promotion: WPT promotes Zynga in its tournaments, and Zynga features a WPT-branded tournament mode in its Zynga Poker game.

Zynga's key obligations include:  paying WPT a $3 million annual minimum guarantee, payable in installments; and paying a 10% royalty on net revenue from the WPT-branded tournament mode (offset against the minimum guarantee).  Both parties grant each other non-exclusive licenses to use each other's trademarks, subject to approval and trademark guidelines.  Detailed reporting and audit rights are included.

Important terms include detailed definitions of "Net Revenue," "Royalty," and "Zynga Competitor,"  extensive indemnification clauses, and confidentiality provisions referencing a separate NDA.  Termination is permitted for material breach, insolvency, or intellectual property infringement, with a 30-day cure period.  Specific post-termination rights and obligations regarding content usage are detailed.  California law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in the Northern District of California.

CHERRYHILLMORTGAGEINVESTMENTCORP_09_26_2.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated 2013, is between Freedom Mortgage Corporation (a New Jersey mortgage bank) and Cherry Hill Mortgage Investment Corp. (a newly formed Maryland REIT affiliate of Freedom Mortgage).  The agreement establishes a strategic alliance to facilitate the transfer of mortgage assets from Freedom Mortgage to Cherry Hill.

Key obligations include the execution of ancillary agreements: an Acknowledgement Agreement with Ginnie Mae, an Excess MSR Acquisition and Recapture Agreement, and a Flow and Bulk Purchase Agreement.  Freedom Mortgage warrants its operational capabilities and compliance, while Cherry Hill warrants its own.  Freedom Mortgage is obligated to designate a Standby Issuer under certain triggering events.  Cherry Hill will cooperate with revisions to the Acknowledgement Agreement.  Financial arrangements involve servicing fees (including a Base Servicing Fee and Excess MSRs), with specific rates detailed within.  Freedom Mortgage indemnifies Cherry Hill against Ginnie Mae termination.

The agreement lasts for three years or until an affiliate of Freedom Mortgage ceases managing Cherry Hill, whichever is later. Termination can occur for material breach after a 30-day cure period.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York County courts.  Both parties waive jury trials.

CreditcardscomInc_20070810_S-1_EX-10.33_.summary:
This Affiliate Agreement, dated April 6, 2007, is between Chase Bank USA, N.A. ("Chase") and an Affiliate participating in Chase's Affiliate Program.  The agreement governs the Affiliate's promotion of Chase credit cards via links on their website.

The Affiliate's key obligations include placing Chase-provided links on their website, adhering to strict guidelines on content (prohibiting certain keywords, brands, and website designs), and refraining from unauthorized data collection or deceptive marketing practices.  Chase's main obligations include processing credit card applications originating from the Affiliate's links, tracking approved accounts, and paying commissions to the Affiliate.

Commissions are tiered, based on private offer terms, and paid monthly for each "Approved Account"—a Chase credit card application submitted via the Affiliate's link and approved by Chase.  Chase reserves the right to modify commission rates and other terms with notice.

The agreement is terminable by either party at any time with notice.  Chase may terminate for Affiliate's breach of contract or unsuitable website content.  Chase's liability is limited to the total commissions paid.  Delaware law governs the agreement.  The Affiliate indemnifies Chase against losses arising from the Affiliate's actions or breaches.  Confidentiality clauses protect Chase's information.  Chase disclaims warranties and limits its liability for damages.

GALACTICOMMTECHNOLOGIESINC_11_07_1997-EX.summary: This Web Hosting Agreement, dated September 9, 1997, is between Galacticomm Technologies Inc. and Horst Entertainment Inc.  It supersedes all prior agreements.  The agreement concerns web hosting services provided by Galacticomm to Horst Entertainment.  Galacticomm's obligations include 24/7 technical support via phone or beeper. Horst Entertainment's main obligation is payment to Galacticomm: $0.01 per access up to 400,000, then $0.005 per access, payable weekly by Wednesday for the previous week's usage.  Horst Entertainment must also provide 24/7 support at its broadcast location.  The agreement includes a termination clause allowing Horst to purchase a software license for $15,000 upon termination by Galacticomm.  Jurisdiction for disputes is Florida.  No specific duration is stated, implying an ongoing agreement until terminated by either party.

Zounds Hearing, Inc. - MANUFACTURING DES.contract_id: Zounds Hearing, Inc. - MANUFACTURING DESIGN MARKETING AGREEMENT
Zounds Hearing, Inc. - MANUFACTURING DES.contract_title: Zounds Hearing, Inc. - MANUFACTURING DESIGN MARKETING AGREEMENT
Zounds Hearing, Inc. - MANUFACTURING DES.summary:
This Manufacturing, Design, and Marketing Agreement (October 3, 2018) is between Zounds Hearing, Inc. ("Subcontractor") and InnerScope Hearing Technologies, Inc. ("Manufacturer").  The agreement outlines a ten-year (auto-renewing annually) subcontracting relationship where Zounds will manufacture hearing aids for InnerScope under InnerScope's brand.

InnerScope pays Zounds a $1,000,000 technology access fee ($500,000 upfront, $500,000 within 60 days).  Zounds manufactures products based on InnerScope's purchase orders, which are non-cancellable. Payment terms vary based on order size (50% or 100% upfront).  Product pricing is cost-plus, with additional royalties (80% or 100% of product cost, or $80/$100 per unit, depending on product type).  Cost reductions are shared proportionally.  Zounds provides monthly inventory reports.

InnerScope leases space in Zounds' FDA-registered facility (separate lease agreement). Zounds is responsible for maintaining the facility and regulatory compliance.  Zounds provides limited warranty support, with InnerScope bearing primary warranty responsibility.  The agreement includes confidentiality, intellectual property, indemnity, and dispute resolution clauses (negotiation, mediation, Arizona courts).  Termination can occur for material breach (30-day cure period) or insolvency.  Upon termination, liability depends on the cause.  The agreement also includes provisions for joint marketing (separate agreement).

CUROGROUPHOLDINGSCORP_05_04_2020-EX-10.3.summary:
This Servicing Agreement, dated April 8, 2020, is between CURO Receivables Finance II, LLC ("Owner") and CURO Management, LLC ("Servicer"), both Delaware limited liability companies.  The agreement outlines the Servicer's duties in master servicing the Owner's receivables and participation interests ("Serviced Assets"), as defined in Annex A and the referenced Loan Agreement.

The Servicer, acting as an independent contractor, is obligated to service and administer the Serviced Assets, adhering to a "Servicing Standard" of reasonable care and compliance with applicable law.  This includes collection activities, administrative duties (detailed in the Loan Agreement), reporting to the Owner and Agent (Midtown Madison Management LLC), and maintaining accurate records.  The Servicer may use Sub-Servicers but remains ultimately liable.  The Servicer is indemnified by the Owner except for willful misconduct.

The Servicer's compensation is a Servicing Fee calculated as 2% of the daily average Receivable Balance for each month.  The agreement is terminable by either party under specific conditions (e.g., Servicer default, Owner's consent, Event of Default under the Loan Agreement), requiring a successor Servicer's appointment.  New York law governs the agreement.  The Agent is a third-party beneficiary with enforcement rights.  The agreement contains standard clauses regarding representations and warranties, limitations of liability, and amendments.

SouthernStarEnergyInc_20051202_SB-2A_EX-.summary:
This Affiliate Agreement, between element 5 GmbH (and subsidiaries) and (i) website owners ("Affiliates") and (ii) software publishers ("Software Publishers"), governs an affiliate program and affiliate management service.  The core purpose is to promote software products via affiliate websites.

**Key Obligations:** Affiliates promote designated software using provided links, maintaining accurate website content and complying with advertising guidelines.  Software Publishers activate Affiliates, set commission rates (up to 50% of gross sales), and provide technical support. element 5 processes orders, handles payments, and pays commissions to Affiliates (minimum €100/ $100 payout) after deducting a 2% service fee and applicable taxes.

**Important Terms:**  Affiliates receive commission based on sales generated through their unique links (cookie lifespan max 180 days).  element 5 is responsible for order processing and payment distribution.  Both Affiliates and Software Publishers have access to secure online control panels.  element 5 reserves the right to modify the agreement with 14-day objection period.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement is indefinite, terminable by either party with written notice. Upon termination, Affiliates must remove all relevant links.

**Financial Arrangements:** Affiliates receive a commission percentage (set by the Software Publisher) of gross sales. element 5 receives a 2% service fee per sale.  Payments are made monthly if exceeding the minimum threshold.  element 5 retains the right to offset or invoice previously paid commissions in case of refunds or chargebacks.  Applicable law is German law, with jurisdiction in Cologne.  Liability is limited, excluding gross negligence.

ConformisInc_20191101_10-Q_EX-10.6_11861.summary:
This Development Agreement, effective September 30, 2019, is between Howmedica Osteonics Corp. (Stryker) and Conformis, Inc.  Its purpose is for Conformis to develop patient-specific instrumentation (KIB Product) for Stryker's Triathlon Off-The-Shelf Knee Implant.  This agreement is executed concurrently with an Asset Purchase Agreement and other related agreements.

Conformis' key obligations include developing the KIB Product according to the R&D Work Plan, ensuring deliverables are free from infringement, and meeting acceptance criteria. Stryker's obligations include providing necessary information and paying milestone payments of $2 million upon delivery of the first prototype and $3 million upon design freeze.  Intellectual property rights are allocated based on inventorship and improvements, with joint ownership of certain IP.  Conformis is granted a non-exclusive license to Stryker's background IP for the project.

The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses, limitations on liability (with redacted specifics), and confidentiality provisions.  The term lasts until acceptance of all deliverables and completion of Milestone #3, subject to earlier termination for material breach, Stryker's final rejection of deliverables, or insolvency events.  New York law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  Specific details regarding timeframes, liability caps, and other key terms are redacted.

Principal Life Insurance Company - Broke.contract_id: Principal Life Insurance Company - Broker Dealer Marketing and Servicing Agreement
Principal Life Insurance Company - Broke.contract_title: Principal Life Insurance Company - Broker Dealer Marketing and Servicing Agreement
Principal Life Insurance Company - Broke.summary:
This Broker Dealer Marketing and Servicing Agreement governs the relationship between Principal Life Insurance Company ("Issuer"), Princor Financial Services Corporation ("Distributor"), and a Broker Dealer (and its affiliated insurance agencies) regarding the sale and servicing of Principal variable annuity contracts.  The agreement authorizes the Broker Dealer to solicit sales, subject to compliance with all applicable securities and insurance laws and regulations.

Key Broker Dealer obligations include:  meeting prospectus delivery requirements; training and supervising registered representatives to ensure suitability of sales; promptly forwarding applications and payments; maintaining accurate books and records; complying with anti-money laundering regulations; and indemnifying Issuer and Distributor for certain liabilities.  Issuer and Distributor are obligated to pay compensation to the Broker Dealer as outlined in the attached Exhibit A, which details various commission structures (front-end loaded, with or without trailing commissions).  They also agree to indemnify the Broker Dealer for certain liabilities arising from their own actions.

The agreement includes confidentiality provisions protecting client information and specifies that the Broker Dealer acts as an independent contractor.  Termination can occur upon written notice from any party or automatically if the Broker Dealer loses its FINRA membership.  The agreement is governed by Iowa law and cannot be assigned by the Broker Dealer without consent.  The financial arrangements center around commission payments based on sales and, in some options, a percentage of the annuity's value over time.  Any indebtedness of the Broker Dealer to the Issuer or Distributor will be offset against payable compensation.

LegacyEducationAllianceInc_20200330_10-K.summary:
This Real Estate Education Training Program Development Agreement, effective December 23, 2019, is between T&B Seminars, Inc. (T&B), representing Tarek El Moussa, and Legacy Education Alliance Holdings, Inc. (LEA).  The agreement licenses T&B's intellectual property (including El Moussa's name and likeness) to LEA for the development and operation of a "Tarek's Real Estate 101" branded educational business.

LEA's key obligations include developing and marketing educational products, conducting the business, and paying royalties to T&B.
