T&B's obligations include providing certain marketing materials and El Moussa's appearances at events.  LEA's use of the intellectual property is exclusive within a defined field.

The agreement outlines tiered royalty payments to T&B based on LEA's monthly cash sales, with a minimum guaranteed royalty.  Specific royalty percentages and sales thresholds are redacted.  The agreement also details joint ownership of created work product, with a 90-day freeze period allowing either party to license the other's distinct contributions by reimbursing costs.

The initial term is five years, automatically renewable unless terminated with 90 days' written notice.  Early termination clauses exist for breach, insolvency, cessation of business, court injunction against LEA's use of the licensed property, or certain actions by El Moussa.  Confidentiality, indemnification, and governing law (New York) clauses are included.  The agreement also contains standard representations and warranties from both parties.

VerizonAbsLlc_20200123_8-K_EX-10.4_11952.summary:
This Transfer and Servicing Agreement, dated January 29, 2020, governs the securitization of Verizon device payment plan agreements.  The parties are Verizon Owner Trust 2020-A (Issuer), Verizon ABS LLC (Depositor), and Cellco Partnership d/b/a Verizon Wireless (Servicer, Marketing Agent, Custodian).

The agreement's purpose is to transfer receivables from the Depositor to the Issuer, who will issue notes secured by these receivables.  Cellco, as Servicer, is responsible for collecting payments, managing delinquencies, and providing reports.  As Marketing Agent, Cellco facilitates upgrade programs.  As Custodian, Cellco maintains the receivables' documentation.  The Depositor warrants the validity of the transferred receivables.

Key terms include "Receivables," "Acquisition Date," "Credit Enhancement Test," "Pool Composition Tests," and "Servicer Termination Events."  The agreement outlines detailed procedures for payment application, fund management (via several designated accounts), and reporting requirements.  The Servicer's obligations are subject to specific liability limitations and indemnification provisions.

The agreement terminates upon the payment of all receivables or the Issuer's termination.  Financial arrangements include servicing fees for Cellco, and provisions for reserve accounts and other funds to support note payments.  The Class A Certificateholder has options to acquire remaining receivables and redeem notes under specific conditions.  Dispute resolution mechanisms include mediation and arbitration.  New York law governs the agreement.

VERICELCORP_08_06_2019-EX-10.10-SUPPLY A.summary:
This Supply Agreement, dated May 6, 2019, is between Vericel Corporation (Michigan) and MediWound Ltd. (Israel).  It governs the manufacturing and supply of NexoBrid products (Intermediate Drug Product, Bulk Vehicle Gel, Finished Product) by MediWound to Vericel for the US, Canada, and Mexico.  MediWound is obligated to manufacture the products according to specifications, maintain cGMP compliance, and meet Vericel's forecasts (with a minimum annual purchase obligation).  Vericel is responsible for labeling and payment.  MediWound holds exclusive supply rights for the first five years.

Key obligations include quality control, record-keeping, regulatory compliance, and timely delivery.  The agreement includes provisions for non-conforming products, supply failures, audits, and recalls, with liability and indemnification clauses specifying responsibilities for breaches and third-party claims.  Pricing is detailed in Exhibit A, with annual adjustments based on the PPI.  Additional services are defined in Exhibit B with associated fees.

The initial term is five years, renewable for up to ten more years at Vericel's discretion, with a total maximum of fifteen years.  Termination clauses allow for termination for material breach, by either party after the initial term, or automatically upon License Agreement termination.  Financial arrangements include payment terms, late payment penalties, and tax responsibilities.  Significant portions of the contract, deemed non-material and competitively sensitive, are redacted.

WPPPLC_04_30_2020-EX-4.28-SERVICE AGREEM.summary:
This Service Agreement, dated October 1, 2019, is between WPP 2005 Limited ("Company") and John Rogers ("Executive").  It constitutes an employment contract appointing Rogers as Chief Financial Officer and Executive Director of WPP plc.

The Executive's key obligations include diligently performing assigned duties, promoting the Company's business, complying with all company policies and regulations (including data protection and anti-bribery), and maintaining confidentiality.  The agreement details extensive intellectual property rights assignment to the Company.  Significant protective covenants restrict the Executive's post-employment activities for 12-18 months within specified territories.

The Executive's remuneration comprises a £740,000 annual salary, a £30,000 benefits allowance, and eligibility for bonus and share incentive plans (detailed in Schedule 2), subject to performance and discretionary committee approval.  Pension participation is addressed, noting the Executive's opt-out and fixed protection status.  Expenses are reimbursed per company policy.

The contract's duration is indefinite, terminable by either party with 12 months' written notice.  The Company retains the right to terminate immediately for cause, providing a payment in lieu of notice (subject to pro-rata reduction for subsequent employment).  A garden leave provision is included.  Governing law is English law, with exclusive jurisdiction in the courts of England and Wales.  The agreement includes a comprehensive non-compete clause (Schedule 3).

WASTE2ENERGYHOLDINGS,INC_06_03_2010-EX-1.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated May 19, 2010, is between SHBV (Hong Kong) Ltd. (SHBV) and Waste2Energy Group Holdings PLC (W2E).  The agreement aims to establish a collaborative manufacturing facility for W2E's waste-to-energy equipment, integrating SHBV's steam and hot water technologies.  

SHBV's key obligations include manufacturing and supplying W2E equipment (governed by a separate Manufacturing Agreement), providing technical assistance, and performing project-specific calculations. W2E's obligations involve using reasonable endeavors to incorporate SHBV's boilers into its engineered solutions, undertaking project design and implementation, and collaborating on marketing.

The agreement includes clauses on non-solicitation, non-circumvention, intellectual property rights (granting non-exclusive licenses), confidentiality, and dispute resolution (mediation under CEDR rules).  Financial arrangements are not explicitly detailed but are deferred to the separate Manufacturing Agreement, which dictates pricing and payment terms for equipment.

The agreement's term is ten years, terminable by either party for material breach (after a 30-day cure period), insolvency, or failure to meet annual business targets (as defined in the Manufacturing Agreement's Schedule 2).  Termination also occurs if the Manufacturing Agreement isn't finalized within one month.  English law governs the agreement, with non-exclusive jurisdiction in English courts.

WORLDWIDESTRATEGIESINC_11_02_2005-EX-10-.summary:
This Reseller Agreement, dated September 14, 2005, is between TouchStar Software Corporation (TouchStar), a Delaware corporation, and Worldwide Strategies Inc. (Worldwide), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement appoints Worldwide as a non-exclusive reseller of TouchStar's call center software and support services within a defined territory (Exhibit D).

Worldwide's key obligations include vigorous promotion and resale of the software, adherence to a TouchStar-approved marketing plan (Section 4.3), providing customer assistance, delivering license agreements (Exhibit B), and meeting pre-agreed sales quotas (Section 4.11).  TouchStar's main obligations involve providing software, support services (Exhibit C), marketing materials, and installation assistance.  TouchStar retains ownership of all intellectual property.

Crucial terms include definitions of intellectual property rights, confidentiality obligations (Section 7), limitations of liability (Section 6.5), and a covenant not to solicit TouchStar employees (Section 4.15).  Financial arrangements involve fees for software, support, and installation (Exhibit A), with payment terms specified (Section 6.1).  Worldwide must also pay all applicable taxes and assessments (Section 6.2).

The agreement has a 12-month term (Section 8.1), renewable by mutual agreement.  TouchStar may terminate for various breaches by Worldwide, including non-payment, quota failure, intellectual property violations, or other material breaches (Section 8.2).  Upon termination,  obligations regarding intellectual property, confidentiality, and indemnification survive (Sections 7, 8.4, 9).  Disputes are subject to binding arbitration in Denver

FEDERATEDGOVERNMENTINCOMESECURITIESINC_0.summary:
This Second Amendment, effective March 1, 2016, modifies a Services Agreement between Federated Investment Management Company ("Adviser") and Federated Advisory Services Company ("FASC").  The original agreement, dated January 1, 2004, and amended in 2009, covers FASC's provision of performance attribution, administration, and risk management services to the Adviser.

This amendment expands FASC's services to include equity trading and transaction settlement, fundamental analysis, and quantitative analysis for accounts where the Adviser trades equities, equity derivatives, and related investments.  These added services are explicitly defined in a revised Exhibit A.  For registered investment companies, these added services are classified as "investment advisory services" under Section 5(b) of the original agreement.

The amendment does not affect the original agreement's terms regarding accounts where the Adviser does not trade equities.  The governing law is Pennsylvania law.  No specific termination clause or financial arrangements are detailed in this amendment; those remain as defined in the underlying Services Agreement.  The amendment is executed by the Presidents and Chairmen of both companies.

AzulSa_20170303_F-1A_EX-10.3_9943903_EX-.summary:
This Amendment No. 1, dated January 6, 2016, modifies a Global Maintenance Agreement (GMA) between Azul Linhas Aéreas Brasileiras S/A ("Azul"), a Brazilian company, and Avions de Transport Regional, G.I.E. ("ATR"), a French GIE.  The amendment primarily revises the GMA's invoicing and payment terms (Clause 12) and price adjustment conditions (Exhibit 14),  specifically altering the number of required items for invoicing and the parameters for price adjustments based on aircraft standard operations.  Confidential details regarding these changes are redacted.

Key obligations include maintaining confidentiality of disclosed information for five years post-termination, and adhering to a dispute resolution process involving initial amicable settlement attempts followed by ICC arbitration in New York under New York law.  The amendment's duration mirrors the underlying GMA's term.  Financial arrangements are detailed in the redacted sections concerning invoicing and price adjustments.  The amendment supersedes prior agreements and is governed by New York law, excluding Section 7-101 of the New York General Obligations Law.

PelicanDeliversInc_20200211_S-1_EX-10.3_.summary:
This Software Development Agreement, dated February 11, 2020, is between Pelican Delivers Inc. ("Client") and Seattle Software Developers ("Developer").  The agreement outlines the development of a cannabis delivery platform, including iOS and web applications (Phase 1).  Developer's key obligations include creating a customer portal for ordering, a dispensary portal for managing orders and inventory, a driver app, and backend integration with payment processors (Evergreen Gateway, Daily Pay), ID verification (Trulioo), and communication services (Twilio).  The project encompasses features such as POS integration, Google Maps API integration, age verification, and order tracking.

Client's main obligation is payment of $279,000 in four 20% installments tied to project milestones (January 1st, February 1st, March 1st, and April 1st, 2019 – note discrepancy between text stating 4 months and these dates).  The agreement specifies a detailed scope of work for each application component, including user functionalities and administrative features.  The contract lacks explicit termination clauses but implies completion upon delivery of all Phase 1 deliverables.  Commission fees (25% on deliveries), flat fees ($1 for in-store pickup), and monthly dispensary subscriptions ($500 or $750) are outlined.  The agreement includes specific technical specifications (tech stack, languages) and a payment schedule.

ORBSATCORP_08_17_2007-EX-7.3-STRATEGIC A.summary: This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated September 9, 2005, is between UTEK Corporation ("UTK") and World Energy Solutions ("AVDU").  UTK, an independent contractor, will identify technology acquisition opportunities for AVDU from universities and government labs, as detailed in Exhibit A (Confidential Term Sheet).  AVDU's key obligations include providing UTK with necessary information, complying with securities laws regarding disclosures about their relationship, and not soliciting UTK employees for 24 months post-agreement.  UTK's key obligations include using commercially reasonable efforts to identify and present suitable technologies, maintaining confidentiality, and potentially negotiating licenses.  The agreement lasts 12 months, renewable by mutual written consent, with 30-day termination notice.  AVDU's compensation to UTK is $120,000 worth of unregistered common stock (31,413 shares), vesting monthly.  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses, non-solicitation provisions, and a detailed confidentiality agreement.  Technology transfer involves UTK acquiring licenses through subsidiaries, then selling them to AVDU in a stock-for-stock exchange.  The agreement specifies that it constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.

DRAGONSYSTEMSINC_01_08_1999-EX-10.17-OUT.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated January 1998, is between Modus Media International (MMI), Netherlands, and Dragon Systems, Inc. (DSI), USA.  MMI agrees to provide turnkey production services for DSI's three speech recognition products (NaturallySpeaking, Dictate Power, Dictate Classic), encompassing materials management, production, delivery, inventory, and financial services.  Specific service levels are to be mutually agreed upon.  DSI has 60 days to reject non-conforming services.

MMI warrants diligent service provision and indemnifies DSI against liabilities arising from MMI's actions.  DSI compensates MMI according to pricing schedules (omitted from provided text), payable within 30 days of delivery.  Inventory storage fees apply to materials older than 90 days.  DSI may offset payments against amounts owed by MMI.  MMI warrants against intellectual property infringement, defending DSI against such claims.  DSI grants MMI limited copying rights for master materials.

The agreement is indefinite but terminable immediately for material breach, change of control, bankruptcy, or by DSI with 60 days' notice.  Governing law is Massachusetts or Netherlands.  MMI must maintain insurance for DSI's property.  MMI is not liable for indirect damages unless caused by intent or gross negligence.

SEPARATEACCOUNTIIOFAGL_05_02_2011-EX-99..summary:
This Unconditional Capital Maintenance Agreement, dated March 30, 2011, is between American International Group, Inc. ("AIG") and American General Life Insurance Company of Delaware ("Company").  AIG is the indirect, wholly-owned parent of the Company.  The agreement's purpose is to ensure the Company maintains a specified minimum capital level.

AIG's key obligation is to provide capital contributions (cash, cash equivalents, securities) to the Company if its Total Adjusted Capital falls below a specified percentage (initially 350%) of its projected Company Action Level RBC (Risk-Based Capital), as determined quarterly.  The Company's obligation is to pay dividends to its equity holders if its Total Adjusted Capital exceeds the specified minimum percentage, subject to regulatory approvals and limitations.  These contributions and dividends must occur within specified timeframes after quarterly or annual financial statement filings.  The specified minimum percentage is subject to annual review and may be revised more frequently if agreed upon by both parties.

The agreement defines key terms like "Total Adjusted Capital" and "Company Action Level RBC" according to Delaware insurance law and NAIC guidelines.  The agreement is indefinite but may be terminated by AIG with 30 days' notice under specific conditions (significant corporate structure changes or sale of the Company to a qualified acquirer).  Policyholders have limited rights to enforce the agreement against AIG under specific circumstances and only until termination.  The agreement explicitly states it is not a guarantee or endorsement of the Company's liabilities by AIG.  New York law governs the agreement.

GridironBionutrientsInc_20171206_8-K_EX-.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement Addendum I, dated November 7, 2017, amends a prior agreement between Gridiron BioNutrients™ (and Food For Athletes, Inc.) (collectively, "Company"), National Football League Alumni, Inc. ("NFLA"), and National Football League Alumni - Northern California Chapter ("NFLA-NC").  The addendum adds Gridiron CBD H2O Probiotic™ Water to the list of "Licensed Products" which utilize the Pro Football Legends logo.

The Company grants the NFLA and NFLA-NC the right to use the logo on specified products.  In return, the Company will donate $0.05 per unit sold of Licensed Products within a defined territory to NFLA-NC.  Unit conversions are specified for different product sizes.  NFLA-NC will then donate 15% of these proceeds to NFLA.  The Company is obligated to provide quarterly sales reports to NFLA-NC.  All amendments require written consent from all parties.  The agreement's duration and termination clauses are not explicitly detailed in this addendum but are presumably governed by the original October 30, 2017 agreement.  Financial arrangements center around the per-unit donation to NFLA-NC based on sales of the Licensed Products.

ImperialGardenResortInc_20161028_DRS (on.summary:
This outsourcing agreement, dated October 29, 2015, concerns the development of the Miaoli Royal Resort Hotel.  Parties involved are HUANG JIA Country CLUB and Recreation Inc. (Party A) and Chang Chen-Bin Architects Office (Party B).  Party B is obligated to provide architectural, business, soil and water conservation, environmental impact assessment, landscaping, and miscellaneous works planning and design services, including construction monitoring, for a 29-hectare site.

Party B's key responsibilities encompass various stages of development, from initial planning and design to obtaining necessary licenses and construction oversight.  The total fee is NTD 12 million for initial phases, plus 3.5% of the legal construction cost for building planning and design and construction monitoring. Payment is staged based on project milestones.  The contract outlines specific deliverables and timelines for each stage.

The contract excludes fees for land surveying, geological drilling, and certain regulatory compliance costs.  Dispute resolution involves negotiation, followed by arbitration in Miaoli County, with the Miaoli District Court as the court of first instance.  The contract doesn't explicitly state a termination clause beyond implications related to non-performance by either party.  Specific timelines are provided for each phase of the project, but an overall contract duration isn't explicitly defined.  Non-refundable payments are stipulated under specific circumstances.

VIRGINGALACTICHOLDINGS,INC_04_08_2020-EX.summary:
This Joint Filing Statement (JFS), dated April 8, 2020, filed pursuant to Rule 13d-1(k), concerns a Schedule 13G filing regarding Virgin Galactic Holdings, Inc. (CUSIP No. 30734W208).  The parties are Sculptor Capital LP, Sculptor Capital Holding Corporation, Sculptor Management, Inc., and Sculptor Master Fund Ltd., all represented by Thomas Sipp, Chief Financial Officer.

The JFS's main purpose is to establish a joint filing agreement for a Schedule 13G, reporting beneficial ownership of Virgin Galactic securities.  Each signatory is responsible for the timely filing of amendments and the accuracy of their own information within the filing, but not for the accuracy of others' information unless they know or have reason to believe it is inaccurate.  No specific financial arrangements are detailed.  The agreement is ongoing, contingent upon the continued existence of the Schedule 13G filing and its amendments.  No explicit termination clause is present; the agreement implicitly terminates upon the final disposition of the relevant securities.

FuseMedicalInc_20190321_10-K_EX-10.43_11.summary:
This Distributorship Agreement, dated March 29, 2018, is between Signature Orthopaedics Pty Ltd (Australia) and CPM Medical Consultants LLC (USA).  The agreement appoints Signature Orthopaedics as a non-exclusive distributor for CPM Medical's orthopedic products (specified in Schedule 1) within the USA (Schedule 2).

Signature Orthopaedics' key obligations include promoting and selling the products, maintaining inventory, providing sales reports, complying with CPM Medical's directives, and adhering to anti-bribery laws.  CPM Medical's obligations include providing product information and support, approving promotional materials, and maintaining product liability insurance (minimum AU$10 million).

Pricing is detailed in Schedule 4 (USD). Payment terms are 45 days from invoice.  The agreement includes clauses on intellectual property rights (granting Signature Orthopaedics non-exclusive use of CPM Medical's trademarks), product liability and indemnification, and confidentiality.

The initial term is one year, automatically renewing unless terminated with 12 months' written notice.  Either party may terminate immediately for material breach (14-day cure period) or insolvency events.  Upon termination, CPM Medical has the option to purchase remaining inventory or allow Signature Orthopaedics to dispose of it and account for the proceeds.  The agreement is governed by Ohio law, with Ohio courts having non-exclusive jurisdiction.

ASPIRITYHOLDINGSLLC_05_07_2012-EX-10.6-O.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated 2012, is between Twin Cities Power Holdings, LLC ("Company") and Redwater LLC ("Contractor").  The agreement outlines the Contractor's role in servicing the Company's $50,000,000 offering of renewable, unsecured, subordinated notes ("Notes").  The Contractor acts as the Company's agent for marketing, sales, investor relations, and administrative tasks related to the Note program.

Key Contractor obligations include developing and executing a marketing strategy (subject to Company approval), managing investor inquiries (with limitations), maintaining Note records, and acting as Registrar.  The Company is responsible for all marketing costs and determining acceptance of subscriptions.  The Contractor's compensation is based on a per-note fee, media services fees (15% gross/net differential), and fulfillment fees.

Important terms include the Company's right to terminate with 60 days' notice, the Contractor's right to terminate with 90 days' notice, and mutual indemnification clauses.  The agreement specifies that the Contractor is an independent contractor with no obligation to purchase Notes.  The agreement's duration is tied to the Note offering and can be terminated earlier by either party under specified conditions.  All financial arrangements are detailed in the agreement and associated exhibits.  Minnesota law governs the agreement.

OASYSMOBILE,INC_07_05_2001-EX-10.17-OUTS.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated July 31, 2000, is between E.piphany, Inc. (licensor) and High Speed Net Solutions, Inc. (HSNS, licensee).  The agreement licenses E.piphany's application software to HSNS for use in providing outsourced customer relationship management (CRM) services (Outsourcing Services) to HSNS's clients (Outsourcing Customers).

HSNS's key obligations include using the application solely for providing Outsourcing Services,  submitting annual reports on email volume, conducting business professionally, jointly marketing the application, and providing customer support.  E.piphany warrants the application's performance for one year and provides maintenance services with tiered response times.

The agreement includes a three-year initial term, renewable annually.  Termination can occur for insolvency, material breach, or non-cure of breaches within 30 days.  Financial arrangements involve significant upfront and ongoing fees, including development license fees, minimum sell-through revenue commitments (with potential increases based on email volume), annual maintenance fees, and lead-sharing fees.  Liability is capped, and consequential damages are excluded.  Intellectual property rights remain with E.piphany, with HSNS assigning any modifications made to the application.  The agreement is governed by California law, with jurisdiction in San Francisco or San Mateo County.  Several clauses survive termination, including confidentiality and indemnity provisions.  Exhibit A details specific fees and scope of use, while Exhibit B describes the Outsourcing Application and Services, and Exhibit C outlines training requirements.

MEDIWOUNDLTD_01_15_2014-EX-10.6-SUPPLY A.summary:
This Supply Agreement, amended February 28, 2010, is between MediWound Ltd. (Israel) and Challenge Bioproducts Corporation Ltd. (Taiwan).  Its purpose is to supply Bromelain SP, a pineapple stem-derived material, by CBC to MediWound for use in MediWound's burn treatment product, "Debridase."

CBC's key obligations include supplying Bromelain SP meeting specified quality standards (GACP, cGMP, ISO 22000 compliant), maintaining sufficient manufacturing capacity and inventory, and adhering to strict quality control and testing procedures.  MediWound's main responsibilities are purchasing Bromelain SP according to a pre-determined annual forecast, conducting quality inspections and approvals, and commercializing the Debridase product.  The agreement includes detailed provisions regarding pricing (based on annual quantity purchased, with potential increases subject to MediWound's approval), payment terms, and quality control procedures, including sample and batch testing and dispute resolution mechanisms.  MediWound made an initial payment of [***] USD upon the effective date.

The agreement is terminable by MediWound with six months' written notice, and by CBC with 24 months' notice (or a longer period to allow MediWound to find an alternative supplier).  Breach allows termination after a 90-day cure period.  The contract is governed by New York law and provides for arbitration in New York City.  Confidentiality and liability/indemnity clauses are included, with limitations on consequential damages (except for confidentiality breaches).  Significant portions of the financial terms and specifications are redacted.

UpjohnInc_20200121_10-12G_EX-2.6_1194869.summary:
This Manufacturing and Supply Agreement, dated [●], is between Pfizer Inc. ("Manufacturer") and Upjohn Inc. ("Customer"),  governed by Delaware law.  It stems from a prior separation agreement between the parties.  The agreement's main purpose is for Pfizer to manufacture and supply products to Upjohn for sale in specified territories.

Key obligations include Upjohn providing forecasts and purchase orders, Pfizer manufacturing to those orders (subject to capacity and quality standards detailed in a separate Quality Agreement), and meeting specified delivery timelines and quality standards.  Pfizer is responsible for procuring materials (with certain exceptions requiring Upjohn's approval), maintaining facilities, and complying with all applicable laws and regulations.  Upjohn retains ownership of its intellectual property, with Pfizer receiving a limited license for manufacturing purposes.  A Joint Advisory Committee facilitates communication and dispute resolution.

Pricing is based on a tiered system: an initial price for the first year, followed by adjustments based on material and conversion costs.  Price reviews and audits are available to Upjohn.  Both parties have indemnification obligations, subject to limitations on liability.  The agreement has a four-year initial term, extendable for three additional one-year periods, and includes termination clauses for cause, insolvency, breach of anti-bribery provisions, and convenience (by Upjohn).  Detailed provisions address supply chain security, confidentiality, and transitional support for technology transfer.

Antares Pharma, Inc. - Manufacturing Agr.summary:
This Manufacturing Agreement, effective March 20, 2018, is between Antares Pharma, Inc. ("Antares") and AMAG Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("AMAG").  It governs the manufacture and supply of a drug delivery device (the "Product") containing AMAG's drug, 17-alpha hydroxyprogesterone caproate.

Antares' key obligations include manufacturing the Product (using AMAG-supplied pre-filled syringes) and trainers, adhering to cGMPs and specifications detailed in Exhibits B & C. AMAG provides the drug and pre-filled syringes, manages recalls, and is responsible for labeling and regulatory approvals.  A Quality Agreement (Exhibit E) further defines quality control responsibilities.

AMAG provides forecasts and purchase orders; Antares confirms delivery dates.  Pricing is detailed in Exhibit D ("Transfer Price").  AMAG purchases its entire product requirement from Antares.  Minimum order quantities apply.

The agreement's term is tied to a Development and License Agreement, allowing for termination by either party for material breach (with specified cure periods) or specific events like a supply failure or AMAG ceasing commercialization.  Detailed indemnification clauses exist (Articles 9), along with provisions for dispute resolution (Article 11) and governing law (New York).  Significant portions of the contract, including specific financial terms, remain redacted.

RareElementResourcesLtd_20171019_SC 13D_.summary:
This Intellectual Property Rights Agreement (IP Agreement), dated October 2, 2017, is between Rare Element Resources Ltd. ("Company") and Synchron (the "Investor").  It's contingent upon a concurrent Investment Agreement and grants the Investor a license under the Company's patents and technical information related to rare earth mineral processing and separation.

The license, initially non-exclusive and royalty-free for the Option Period, becomes exclusive and perpetual if the Investor exercises its option to purchase Company shares.  If the option isn't exercised, a commercially reasonable annual licensing fee applies.  The Company retains a non-exclusive license for its own use.  The Investor is obligated to maintain confidentiality of unpublished technical information, except under specified circumstances.  The Company indemnifies the Investor against third-party infringement claims.  Improvements made solely by either party are owned by that party, with a non-exclusive, royalty-free cross-license granted to the other for use in rare earth processing. Joint improvements are owned by the Investor.

The Company retains sole right to prosecute patents unless the option is exercised, at which point the Investor gains this right.  The agreement is governed by New York law and includes a dispute resolution mechanism involving negotiation and mediation before litigation.  The agreement's term is tied to the patents' lifespan, with certain provisions surviving termination.  Financial arrangements are primarily tied to the option exercise and potential annual licensing fees.

VARIABLESEPARATEACCOUNT_04_30_2014-EX-13.summary:
This Amended and Restated Unconditional Capital Maintenance Agreement, dated February 18, 2014, is between American International Group, Inc. ("AIG") and American General Life Insurance Company ("Company").  AIG is the indirect wholly-owned parent of the Company.  The agreement's purpose is to ensure the Company maintains sufficient capital.

AIG's key obligation is to make capital contributions to the Company if its Total Adjusted Capital falls below a Specified Minimum Percentage (385% of Company Action Level RBC, as defined by Texas insurance law or NAIC guidelines) of its projected Company Action Level RBC in the first and third fiscal quarters.  Contributions must be made within specified timeframes (between the filing of quarterly statements and the end of the following quarter) and can be made directly to the Company or through its direct parent.  The Specified Minimum Percentage is subject to annual review and may be revised more frequently based on changes in rating agency criteria or material Company events.

The Company must comply with AIG's financial and budgetary requirements.  Policyholders have recourse against AIG if the Company fails to enforce its rights under the agreement or defaults on payments.  The agreement is indefinite but may be terminated by AIG with 30 days' notice under specific conditions relating to AIG's corporate structure or sale of the Company, maintaining a minimum rating.  The agreement automatically terminates one year after a sale of the Company.  The agreement explicitly states it does not create indebtedness or give policyholders direct recourse to AIG's assets.  New York law governs.

ABILITYINC_06_15_2020-EX-4.25-SERVICES A.summary:
This Services Agreement, effective November 1, 2019, is between [Provider Name] ("Provider") and TELCOSTAR PTE, LTD. and Ability Computer & Software Industries Ltd. ("Recipient").  The agreement outlines the provision of services detailed in Exhibit A (redacted), which includes a commitment to good faith performance and maintenance of service standards.  Provider is obligated to provide services using dedicated personnel, remaining fully responsible for subcontractors, and assigning all intellectual property rights created during service provision to Recipient.  Recipient retains the right to engage other providers for similar services.

Financially, Recipient reimburses Provider for actual costs plus a 10% service fee, and all out-of-pocket expenses.  Payments are due within 15 days of invoicing.  No right of setoff exists.  The agreement runs until December 31, 2020, unless terminated earlier.  Either party may terminate with 90 days' written notice, with Recipient liable for services rendered and expenses incurred.  Termination for breach requires 30 days' notice following uncured material breach.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality, indemnification (Provider indemnifies Recipient), and governing law (Israel) clauses.  Specific performance is stipulated as a remedy for breach.

ELECTRAMECCANICA VEHICLES CORP. - Manufa.summary:
This Manufacturing Agreement, effective February 2017, is between Electrameccanica Vehicles Corp. ("EMV"), a British Columbia corporation, and Chongqing Zongshen Automobile Industry Co., Ltd. ("Manufacturer"), a Chinese company.  The agreement concerns the exclusive manufacturing of EMV's "Solo" electric vehicle by Manufacturer in China.

EMV grants Manufacturer an exclusive, non-transferable license to manufacture the Solo, providing specifications and proprietary rights.  Manufacturer's key obligations include manufacturing to EMV's specifications, maintaining quality control (including spot testing and inspections by EMV), sourcing components from EMV-approved vendors (for key components), and meeting delivery schedules outlined in Purchase Orders.  EMV is responsible for providing specifications, conducting certain testing, and paying for the manufactured vehicles.

The agreement outlines a payment schedule: 30% deposit upon order, 70% upon delivery and quality inspection.  Pricing is determined annually, with provisions for adjustments based on raw material price fluctuations and export tax changes.  A minimum purchase volume of 50,000 units over three years is stipulated, with penalties for EMV if this target isn't met.  The agreement includes provisions for order adjustments, cancellations, and dispute resolution via Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre (HKIAC) under UNCITRAL rules.

The agreement has a four-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated for material breach (unresolved within 60 days) or EMV's dissatisfaction with Manufacturer's performance (after two consecutive unsatisfactory assessments and failure to correct within 180 days).  Intellectual property rights remain with EMV.  Confidentiality clauses are included, along with standard

GopageCorp_20140221_10-K_EX-10.1_8432966.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated February 10, 2014, is between PSiTech Corporation (Licensor) and Empirical Ventures, Inc. (Licensee).  The agreement grants Licensee an exclusive, non-transferable license to use specified Licensed Content (detailed in Schedule 2) on its website (Licensee Site) and related media within Canada, the US, and Mexico (excluding vacation rentals and MLM businesses, per Schedule 1).

Licensee's key obligations include displaying the content as specified, maintaining Terms of Use and Privacy Policy acceptable to Licensor, promptly updating content, and removing content upon termination.  Licensee must also provide copyright and trademark notices.  Licensor retains ownership of the content and trademarks.

The Licensee pays a $200,000 license fee ($50,000 upon MOU signing, $50,000 upon agreement signing, $100,000 by March 28, 2014) plus royalties based on a tiered percentage of Gross Revenues (detailed in the Royalty Schedule).  Licensor has audit rights.

The initial term is five years, automatically renewing for three years unless either party provides 90-day notice.  Termination can occur for material breach (cure periods vary), insolvency, or other specified events.  Upon termination, Licensee must delete all Licensed Content.  Indemnification clauses cover infringement claims related to the Licensed Content (Licensor) and other aspects of the Licensee Site (Licensee).  Liability is capped at amounts paid to Licensor in the preceding 12 months, excluding gross negligence or willful misconduct.  Nevada law governs,

BICYCLETHERAPEUTICSPLC_03_10_2020-EX-10..summary:
This Service Agreement, dated September 26, 2019, is between BicycleTX Limited (the "Company"), an English company, and Nigel Crockett ("Employee"), appointing Crockett as Chief Business Officer (CBO).  The agreement outlines Crockett's duties, including exclusively devoting his time and skills to the Company's business and potentially working for group companies.

Key obligations include maintaining confidentiality, adhering to company policies, and refraining from competing businesses for 12 months post-termination (with specific restrictions detailed).  Crockett receives a USD 370,000 annual salary (converted to GBP), a potential 35% annual performance bonus (payable in cash or BTL share options), and equity incentives (options to acquire BTL shares contingent on specific transactions).  Benefits include pension contributions, healthcare, and a death-in-service scheme.

The agreement includes detailed provisions on expenses, working hours, holidays, sick leave, and garden leave.  Termination can occur with six months' notice from either party, or summarily for cause (gross misconduct, breach of contract, etc.) or for good reason (material diminution of responsibilities, salary, or location; material breach by the Company, subject to a defined process).  Severance pay varies depending on the reason for termination and whether it occurs within 12 months of a change in control.  The contract is governed by English law, with exclusive jurisdiction in English courts.  Intellectual property rights created during employment vest in the Company.

FreezeTagInc_20180411_8-K_EX-10.1_111396.summary:
This Corporate Sponsorship Agreement, effective March 22, 2018, is between the American Diabetes Association (ADA), an Ohio non-profit, and Freeze Tag, Inc., a Delaware corporation.  The agreement outlines a national sponsorship of ADA's "Get Fit Don't Sit Day" for a two-year term (March 15, 2018 – March 14, 2020).

Freeze Tag's main obligation is a $150,000 sponsorship payment (in installments),  and providing services detailed in Attachment A, including utilizing the ADA's marks in promotional materials subject to ADA's prior approval.  Freeze Tag also commits to a pin pad/POS donation campaign for ADA events. ADA's key obligation is to acknowledge Freeze Tag as a sponsor across various platforms (website, social media, etc.), adhering to IRS regulations for non-profit sponsorships.  Both parties grant each other limited licenses to use their respective marks.

The agreement includes clauses for intellectual property rights, indemnification, insurance requirements (Freeze Tag must maintain $2M liability insurance naming ADA as an additional insured), confidentiality, and termination (for material breach, reputational damage, or insolvency).  Virginia law governs, with jurisdiction in Alexandria/Arlington courts.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties, superseding prior agreements.

TELEGLOBEINTERNATIONALHOLDINGSLTD_03_29_.summary:
This April 18, 2000, Construction and Maintenance Agreement governs the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2) between numerous telecommunications companies (Initial Parties listed in Schedule A, including but not limited to China Telecom, SingTel, Telstra, KDD),  acting as both owners and users.  The agreement's main purpose is to establish the framework for the construction, operation, and maintenance of the APCN 2 submarine and terrestrial fiber optic cable system.

Key obligations include the provision of terrestrial segments (Segment T) by designated Terminal Parties, construction of the submarine segment (Segment S) via a Procurement Group, and joint operation & maintenance by Maintenance Authorities.  The agreement details capacity allocation (Allocated Capacity, IRU Capacity, Unallocated Capacity),  use restrictions, and transfer provisions.  Financial arrangements involve pro-rata sharing of capital and operational costs (Schedules B & C), billing procedures via a Central Billing Party, and stipulations for financial charges and default.

Important terms include definitions of various capacity types,  the establishment of a Management Committee with voting rights based on investment shares, and dispute resolution mechanisms.  The agreement has an initial 25-year term following the Ready For Service Date (RFS Date), terminable thereafter by agreement or with one-year notice.  Termination clauses address the disposition of assets and liabilities.  The agreement also includes provisions for confidentiality, force majeure, and compliance with applicable laws.  The MOU (Memorandum of Understanding) is superseded by this agreement.

WEBHELPCOMINC_03_22_2000-EX-10.8-HOSTING.summary:
This Hosting Agreement, dated March 22, 2000, is between eGain Communications Corporation ("eGain") and Eliance Corporation ("Customer").  eGain agrees to provide Customer with web-based access to eGain's software (specified in Exhibit A) and hosting services for processing online inquiries.  Customer is responsible for its internet access and equipment, lawful use of the system, and maintaining password confidentiality.  eGain provides 24/7 telephone support.  

Key obligations include eGain's provision of hosting services and Customer's payment of fees (detailed in Exhibit A), payable monthly in advance.  Late payments incur a 1.5% monthly fee.  eGain offers limited warranties regarding software performance and Year 2000 compliance, with remedies limited to service credits or software repair/replacement. Liability is capped at the price paid for the services.  Confidentiality and indemnification clauses are included.

The agreement has a one-year initial term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach (with a 30-day cure period), insolvency, or bankruptcy.  Sections regarding confidentiality, payment of accrued fees, liability limitations, and indemnification survive termination.  Customer grants eGain limited rights to use its name and logo for marketing purposes.  California law governs.

INTERNATIONALFASTFOODCORP_04_04_1997-EX-.summary: This 1997 Franchise Agreement between Burger King Corporation ("BKC") and International Fast Food Polska Sp zo.o ("Franchisee"), with International Fast Food Corporation as principal guarantor, grants Franchisee a license to operate a Burger King restaurant in Poland for a specified term (detailed in Schedule 1).  The agreement mandates strict adherence to BKC's operating standards (MOD Manual), including building specifications, menu, and marketing.  Franchisee's key obligations include continuous operation, royalty payments (5% of Gross Sales), advertising contributions (6% of Gross Sales), and maintaining comprehensive liability insurance.  BKC retains rights of entry, inspection, and audit.  The agreement details procedures for transferring ownership, including BKC's right of first refusal and consent requirements.  Termination clauses stipulate automatic termination for Franchisee's default (e.g., non-payment, breach of standards) or BKC's default (failure to perform obligations).  Financial arrangements include an initial franchise fee, monthly royalty and advertising payments, and interest on overdue amounts.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration in New York, except for injunctions, which are handled in New York courts.  A restrictive covenant prevents Franchisee from operating competing restaurants for a year post-termination within a specified radius.  The agreement emphasizes Franchisee's independent contractor status and the confidentiality of BKC's trade secrets.

BIOCEPTINC_08_19_2013-EX-10-COLLABORATIO.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, dated November 2, 2012, is between Biocept, Inc. (a California corporation) and Life Technologies Corporation (a Delaware corporation).  The agreement outlines a collaboration to develop, promote, and commercialize Biocept's OncoCEE-LU™ assay (a laboratory-developed test for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer – NSCLC) in the U.S.

Biocept's key obligations include performing the technical component of the assay, maintaining necessary licenses, providing training to Life Technologies personnel, and contributing to marketing efforts. Life Technologies is responsible for the professional component (interpretation of results), marketing and sales, billing and collection, and providing a demand forecast.  Both parties will share patient data for research purposes, subject to HIPAA compliance.  The agreement grants each party non-exclusive licenses to use the other's trademarks.

Financial arrangements involve Biocept billing Life Technologies monthly for the technical component, based on a pricing structure agreed upon and adjusted annually based on Medicare rates.  Revenue sharing is outlined for discrepancies between billed and received amounts.  Life Technologies will cover the cost of sample collection systems.

The agreement has an initial three-year term, renewable annually.  Termination can occur for material breach (after a 60-day cure period) or by either party with 120 days' notice.  A specific termination clause exists if Biocept fails to secure $10 million in equity financing by December 31, 2012, granting Life Technologies an option to negotiate a license.  The agreement includes standard indemnification clauses and dispute resolution provisions (Joint Steering Committee, mediation).  California law governs.

PACIFICSYSTEMSCONTROLTECHNOLOGYINC_08_24.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated April 14, 2000, is between American Champion Media, Inc. ("ACM"), a Delaware corporation, and Shun Li De Commerce & Trading Ltd ("SLD"), a Beijing company.  The agreement concerns SLD's sponsorship of ACM's boxing event in Guangzhou, China on April 22, 2000.

SLD's key obligation is payment of US$400,000 to ACM, due 180 days post-event. In return, SLD receives specified advertising space (floor cards, drapes, banners) at the event. SLD may resell some or all sponsorship components, subject to ACM's prior approval of third-party materials (at least five days before the event).  SLD must deliver its display materials two days before the event.

ACM retains all intellectual property rights related to the event.  The agreement specifies that it is governed by California and Hong Kong law, with dispute resolution via mediation in a mutually agreed-upon third country.  The contract is the entire agreement between the parties, superseding prior agreements.  No assignment of rights or obligations is permitted.  The agreement lacks explicit termination clauses beyond the completion of the event.

NANOPHASETECHNOLOGIESCORP_11_01_2005-EX-.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated October 24, 2005, is between Nanophase Technologies Corporation ("NTC"), a Delaware corporation, and Johnson Matthey Catalog Company, Inc. d/b/a Alfa Aesar ("Alfa Aesar"), also a Delaware corporation.  The agreement establishes Alfa Aesar as the exclusive worldwide distributor of NTC's nanomaterials ("Products") in research quantities for research purposes.

NTC's key obligations include supplying Products to Alfa Aesar at a specified price (Schedule A),  using commercially reasonable efforts to fill orders promptly, and providing training and marketing materials.  NTC retains the right to sell commercial quantities and provide free samples.  Alfa Aesar's main obligations are to purchase all its research quantity needs exclusively from NTC,  market and distribute the Products using reasonable efforts, and repackage them for resale.  Alfa Aesar also receives a commission on referrals for commercial quantities and custom services (Section 6, amount redacted).

Important terms include provisions for product returns (Section 5),  pricing adjustments with notice, FOB shipping terms (FCA Incoterms 2000), net 30 payment terms,  mutual indemnification clauses (Section 10),  limited warranties (Section 9), and confidentiality obligations (Section 15).  The agreement includes a 5-year initial term with automatic 2-year renewals unless terminated with 6 months' notice, or earlier for material breach or insolvency (Section 13).  Disputes are to be resolved through negotiation, then arbitration (Section 16), except for those related to indemnification or confidentiality, which are excluded from arbitration.  Delaware law governs the

AzulSa_20170303_F-1A_EX-10.3_9943903_EX-.summary:
This Global Maintenance Agreement ("GMMA"), dated March 9, 2015, is between Azul Linhas Aéreas Brasileiras S.A. ("Azul," the "Company") and Avions de Transport Régional, G.I.E. ("ATR," the "Repairer").  The GMMA governs the provision of maintenance services and the lease of a stock of spare parts for Azul's ATR aircraft fleet.

Azul's key obligations include operating and maintaining aircraft according to specifications, timely reporting of aircraft activity, returning unserviceable parts, and maintaining specified insurance coverage. ATR's main obligations involve providing maintenance services (listed in Exhibit 2), managing the spare parts pool (Exhibit 9), and leasing the parts stock (Exhibit 8).  Specific services are priced differently, with some on a time-and-materials basis.

Key terms include definitions of "Abnormal Use," various maintenance events, and removal rates.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on invoicing, payment terms (USD, SWIFT transfer), reconciliation procedures (quarterly), and a security deposit (cash or LOC).  Warranties are provided for new and repaired parts.  Liability is limited, except for death or personal injury.

The initial term is [redacted], renewable annually unless terminated.  Termination events include insolvency or material breach by either party, with specified procedures and consequences, including early termination fees.  Governing law is New York, with dispute resolution via ICC arbitration.  Significant portions of the contract, particularly those detailing pricing and specific parts, are redacted.

PelicanDeliversInc_20200211_S-1_EX-10.3_.summary: This Software Development Agreement, effective December 3, 2018, is between DOT COM LLC, OBA Seattle Software Developers ("Developer") and Pelican Delivers Inc. ("Client").  The agreement outlines the development of the "Pelican Delivers Application Phase 1."  Developer's key obligations include design, development, and delivery of the application and related documentation, according to specifications detailed in a Statement of Work (SOW).  Client's responsibilities include acceptance testing of deliverables within specified timelines, providing necessary information to the Developer, and payment of fees as outlined in the SOW.  The agreement includes provisions for change orders, with associated cost and schedule adjustments.  Intellectual property rights vest with the Client, with Developer retaining ownership of its proprietary technology.  A detailed confidentiality clause protects both parties' confidential information.  The agreement is terminable by either party with two weeks' written notice or immediately for cause (material breach, non-payment, etc.).  Financial arrangements are defined in the SOW, including fees, potential bonuses for early completion, and payment terms.  Governing law is Washington State law, with dispute resolution via negotiation and, if necessary, litigation in King County, Washington.  The agreement contains standard indemnification and non-disparagement clauses.

NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-AMENDMEN.contract_id: NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-AMENDMENT TO THE DISTRIBUTOR AGREEMENT BETWEEN INGRAM MICRO AND NETGEAR
NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-AMENDMEN.contract_title: NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-AMENDMENT TO THE DISTRIBUTOR AGREEMENT BETWEEN INGRAM MICRO AND NETGEAR
NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-AMENDMEN.summary: This document comprises an amendment (and a subsequent amendment) to a Distributor Agreement between Netgear, Inc. ("Netgear") and Ingram Micro ("Ingram").  The agreement concerns the distribution of Netgear products.  Key obligations include Ingram's role as a distributor within a specified territory (initially amended to include the US and unspecified regions, further amended in 1998 to again include the US and unspecified regions), subject to mutually agreed-upon marketing activities. Netgear retains the right to appoint additional distributors in certain circumstances and after an initial exclusivity period.  The agreement includes a discount schedule (details redacted for confidentiality), and a force majeure clause excusing performance due to unforeseen circumstances.  Assignment of rights requires written consent.  The agreement is governed by California law, excluding conflict of law provisions.  Financial details, including the discount rate, are redacted.  The amendment's duration is tied to the original agreement's term and any renewals.  Termination clauses are not explicitly detailed in the provided text.

NEONSYSTEMSINC_03_01_1999-EX-10.5-DISTRI.summary:
This First Amendment to Distributor Agreement, dated January 1, 1999, modifies a pre-existing agreement between Peregrine/Bridge Transfer Corporation ("Licensor") and NEON Systems, Inc. ("Licensee"), with Skunkware, Inc. (sole shareholder of Licensor) also joining.  The amendment converts the distributorship from non-exclusive to exclusive (except for a specific Licensor product licensed to IBM), significantly altering royalty payment terms.

Key obligations include Licensee's payment of royalties (50% initially, reducing to 40% after royalty advances are credited against earnings) on Licensed Products and services.  Licensee must make quarterly royalty advances totaling $1M-$5M annually, increasing by $1M each year beyond 2003.  These advances are credited against future royalties, with interest accruing on late payments.  Licensor must repay outstanding advances upon termination.

The agreement includes a right of first refusal for Licensee to purchase Licensor's stock or assets, and an option to purchase all of Licensor's assets or stock exercisable after $10M in royalties are paid or January 1, 2002.  The agreement's term extends to March 31, 2004, with automatic annual renewals unless terminated with 60 days' notice.  Termination may also occur for material breach, with the non-breaching party entitled to acceleration of payments.  The amendment significantly alters liability limitations, excluding those related to misrepresentation in Section 6.2 and royalty advance repayment.

Columbia Laboratories, (Bermuda) Ltd. -.contract_id: Columbia Laboratories, (Bermuda) Ltd. - AMEND NO. 2 TO MANUFACTURING AND SUPPLY AGREEMENT
Columbia Laboratories, (Bermuda) Ltd. -.contract_title: Columbia Laboratories, (Bermuda) Ltd. - AMEND NO. 2 TO MANUFACTURING AND SUPPLY AGREEMENT
Columbia Laboratories, (Bermuda) Ltd. -.summary:
Amendment No. 2 to a Manufacturing and Supply Agreement, dated 2018, is between Columbia Laboratories (Bermuda) Ltd. ("Columbia") and Fleet Laboratories Limited ("Fleet").  It amends their existing 2009 agreement (as amended in 2013) concerning Fleet's manufacture and supply of Products to Columbia.

Key obligations include Fleet's manufacturing and supply, adhering to specified Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP) and Good Distribution Practices (GDP), including Brazilian ANVISA regulations.  Fleet warrants compliance and allows Columbia access to manufacturing records.  Columbia retains ownership of provided equipment and materials.  Fleet is responsible for most raw materials, with Columbia providing specific ones.  A new KPI system will be implemented.  Pricing is detailed in a confidential Exhibit A, adjusted annually based on CPI and raw material costs.  Delivery is EXW Fleet's facility.

Significant terms include provisions for audits, insurance requirements (minimum coverage specified), detailed indemnity clauses allocating liability, and strict confidentiality provisions with permitted disclosures outlined.  The agreement includes a detailed process for termination, including provisions for reimbursement and assistance in transferring manufacturing to a new supplier. The initial term expires December 31, 2024, with potential for extension, and specific termination rights for both parties are defined.  The governing law is English law, with exclusive jurisdiction in English courts.  An anti-bribery clause is included.  Many details, including specific quantities, pricing formulas, and raw material specifications, are redacted as confidential.

SPARKLINGSPRINGWATERHOLDINGSLTD_07_03_20.summary: This Software License and Maintenance Agreement, dated May 2000, is between Garman Routing Systems, Inc. ("Garman") and Sparkling Spring Water Group Limited ("Sparkling").  Garman licenses Sparkling non-exclusively, non-transferable software ("Software") for use at specified locations ("Authorized Locations").  Sparkling agrees not to copy, reverse engineer, or sublicense the Software.  Garman provides installation, training, and maintenance services (including updates, telephone support, and repairs) for a renewable one-year term, commencing after successful acceptance testing.  Sparkling has an option to reject the Software if deficiencies aren't corrected within 45 business days.  Fees are detailed in a separate schedule.  Garman warrants the Software's performance for one year post-acceptance testing.  Garman provides intellectual property indemnity.  The agreement includes confidentiality and non-solicitation clauses.  Liability is limited to direct damages.  Source code is escrowed, with Sparkling gaining perpetual access under specific termination scenarios.  The agreement is perpetual unless terminated by Sparkling (90-day notice) or due to material breach (30-day cure period).  Governing law is Nova Scotia.

N2KINC_10_16_1997-EX-10.16-SPONSORSHIP A.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated September 23, 1997, is between Excite, Inc. (Excite) and N2K Inc. (Sponsor).  The agreement establishes N2K as the exclusive retail music store sponsor of Excite's website and broadcast pages for two years from the commencement date (around October 15, 1997).

N2K's key obligations include providing music-related content (detailed in Exhibit A) and maintaining a co-branded area on its website linking to Excite. Excite's main obligations are to deliver a guaranteed number of impressions (link appearances) to N2K's site, as detailed in Section 3, and to provide monthly traffic reports.  Excite retains control over the "look and feel" of its site and broadcast pages.

The agreement includes a right of first refusal for N2K to renew the sponsorship.  Financial arrangements involve annual exclusivity fees for N2K, payments tied to impression delivery, and revenue sharing based on gross margins from transactions originating on Excite's site, exceeding a specified revenue floor.  Detailed payment schedules are outlined in Section 7.

The agreement can be terminated by either party for material breach after a 30-day cure period, with specific exceptions related to content errors and quality standards.  Sections regarding confidentiality, warranties, indemnities, limitation of liability, and dispute resolution survive termination.  New York law governs the agreement.

NUVEEN - REMARKETING AGREEMENT.summary:
This Remarketing Agreement governs the relationship between Nuveen AMT-Free Municipal Credit Income Fund ("Fund"), Nuveen Fund Advisors, LLC ("Investment Adviser"), and a designated Remarketing Agent regarding Series [●] MuniFund Preferred Shares ("MFP Shares").  The agreement outlines the Agent's responsibilities in remarketing the MFP Shares, which are in a Variable Rate Remarketed Mode.

The Remarketing Agent's key obligations include using best efforts to remarket tendered shares at the Purchase Price (acting as principal, not agent), calculating the Purchase Price and Dividend Rate, providing various notices (per Exhibits A-D), and adhering to specified timing requirements.  The Fund provides the Agent with necessary information and pays a monthly fee based on the number of outstanding MFP Shares.  Both the Fund and Investment Adviser provide indemnification to the Remarketing Agent against certain liabilities.

Important terms include definitions from the Supplement to the Statement Establishing and Fixing the Rights and Preferences of the MFP Shares,  conditions precedent to the Agent's obligations (Section 8), and provisions regarding the Agent's resignation, suspension, or removal (Section 5).

The agreement terminates upon the earliest of the Agent's resignation/removal, successful transition to a new mode, or no outstanding MFP Shares.  The indemnification and fee payment obligations survive termination.  Governing law is New York, except for Section 25 (Massachusetts).  A jury trial is waived.  The Agent is explicitly *not* acting as an underwriter.

ArconicRolledProductsCorp_20191217_10-12.summary:
This Trademark License Agreement, effective [Date], is between Arconic Inc. ("Licensee") and Arconic Rolled Products Corp. ("Licensor"), both Delaware corporations, stemming from their Separation and Distribution Agreement.  The agreement licenses the "ARMX" trademark ("Licensed Mark") to Licensee for specified products (Schedule 2) and pre-existing agreements (Schedule 1).  Licensee obtains a non-exclusive, worldwide, royalty-free license for existing inventory during a transition period.

Licensee's key obligations include maintaining the Licensed Mark's quality (subject to Licensor's inspection and approval rights, including third-party audits), complying with trademark usage guidelines, and cooperating with Licensor in protecting the mark.  Licensee must indemnify Licensor for claims related to the Licensed Mark and Licensed Products.  Licensor retains ownership and benefits from the Licensed Mark's goodwill.

The agreement's term is defined in Schedules 1 and 2, and can be terminated for material breach (after a 120-day cure period) or bankruptcy.  Sections regarding cooperation, indemnification, and confidentiality survive termination.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law, with exclusive jurisdiction in Wilmington, Delaware.  No financial arrangements (e.g., royalties) are explicitly detailed in this excerpt.  A jury trial is waived.

SECURIANFUNDSTRUST_05_01_2012-EX-99.28.H.summary:
This Restated Net Investment Income Maintenance Agreement, effective May 1, 2012, is between Securian Funds Trust (Trust), Advantus Capital Management, Inc. (Investment Adviser), and Securian Financial Services, Inc. (Underwriter), concerning the Advantus Money Market Fund.  The agreement's primary purpose is to ensure the Fund maintains a daily Net Investment Income (defined as Fund Investment Income minus Fund Operating Expenses) of zero or more.

The Investment Adviser's key obligation is to waive its advisory fee or reimburse the Fund to achieve this.  The Underwriter may also waive its Rule 12b-1 fees and has similar reimbursement rights.  The Investment Adviser has the right to recover any waived or reimbursed amounts (Expense Waiver) when the Fund's Net Investment Income exceeds zero, subject to a three-year limitation and a cap preventing Fund operating expenses from exceeding 1.25% of average daily net assets.  Reimbursements must occur within 30 days of month-end.

The agreement lasts one year, renewable annually with approval from non-interested Trust trustees.  It terminates upon termination of the related Investment Advisory Agreement, except for the Investment Adviser's right of recovery.  The agreement incorporates definitions and interpretations consistent with the Investment Advisory Agreement, Underwriting Agreement, and the Investment Company Act of 1940.  Specific financial arrangements involve fee waivers and reimbursements to maintain the Fund's Net Investment Income at or above zero.

WELLSFARGOMORTGAGEBACKEDSECURITIES2006-6.summary:
This Yield Maintenance Agreement, dated April 27, 2006, is between UBS AG, London Branch ("UBS AG") and Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., acting solely as Master Servicer for Wells Fargo Mortgage Backed Securities 2006-6 Trust ("Wells Fargo").  It confirms an interest rate cap transaction governed by the 2000 ISDA Definitions and, where applicable, a 1992 ISDA Master Agreement (or a substantially similar agreement to be executed).

The agreement's main purpose is for UBS AG to sell an interest rate cap to Wells Fargo.  UBS AG's key obligation is to pay Wells Fargo the greater of zero or a calculated amount based on a formula involving the USD-LIBOR-BBA rate and a cap rate of 5% per annum. Wells Fargo's primary obligation is to pay a fixed amount. The calculation amount is capped at USD 20,000,000 or the aggregate principal balance of Class I-A-22 Certificates.

Key terms include a trade date of April 27, 2006, an effective date of April 1, 2006, and a termination date of April 1, 2009.  The agreement includes extensive provisions regarding default, termination events, governing law (New York), and waiver of jury trial.  Wells Fargo's obligations are limited recourse obligations payable solely from the Trust Estate.  The contract also addresses regulatory compliance (Regulation AB) and requires UBS AG to provide financial disclosures under certain circumstances.  Several clauses of the ISDA Master Agreement are modified or excluded.

REWALKROBOTICSLTD_07_10_2014-EX-10.2-STR.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement (SAA), effective September 24, 2013, is between Yaskawa Electric Corporation ("YEC"), a Japanese company, and Argo Medical Technologies Ltd. ("ARGO"), an Israeli company.  The SAA establishes a ten-year strategic alliance (renewable with mutual written consent) focused on collaborating in the marketing, distribution, and development of healthcare robotics products.

YEC's key obligations include marketing and distributing ARGO's products (via a separate Distribution Agreement – DA), potentially investing in ARGO via a Share Purchase Agreement (SPA), and contributing its motion control and robotics expertise to improve ARGO's products. ARGO's key obligations involve appointing YEC as an exclusive distributor (per the DA), utilizing YEC's expertise for product improvement, and collaborating on future R&D (via separate agreements).  A Joint Steering Committee will oversee progress and future collaborations.

The SAA contains a non-solicitation clause for twelve months post-termination, and specifies that monetary damages are insufficient remedy for breach thereof, allowing for specific performance and injunctive relief.  The agreement is governed by Israeli law, with disputes resolved in Tel Aviv courts.  Termination can occur by either party for material breach (after a 60-day cure period), or mutually by both parties.  The SAA also includes provisions for confidentiality, intellectual property rights, and assignment restrictions.  Financial arrangements are detailed in separate agreements (SPA and DA).  Prior agreements are superseded by this SAA and a new NDA.

PenntexMidstreamPartnersLp_20150416_S-1A.summary:
This Gas Transportation Agreement, effective April 14, 2015, is between PennTex North Louisiana Operating, LLC ("Transporter") and MRD Operating LLC ("Customer").  The agreement governs the transportation of Customer's natural gas through Transporter's system.

**Main Purpose:**  Transporter agrees to transport Customer's gas from specified receipt points (Lincoln Parish Plant and future Mount Olive Plant) to delivery points (RIGS and Cardinal Arcadia Storage), with a guaranteed minimum daily Firm Service of 400,000 MMBtu, expandable with new facilities.  Customer commits to deliver all its residue gas, though there's no minimum delivery quantity.

**Key Obligations:** Transporter provides Firm and Interruptible Service, subject to curtailment based on system capacity and priority (Interruptible curtailed first). Customer nominates gas volumes, and imbalances are settled monthly based on Gas Daily's Texas Gas Transmission Corp. Zone 1 Index price.  A transportation fee of $0.04/MMBtu applies.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement defines various terms related to gas measurement, quality, and imbalances.  Force Majeure events suspend obligations (except payment).  Customer warrants title to its gas and indemnifies Transporter for related claims.  Transporter provides similar indemnification.  Liability is limited, excluding gross negligence or willful misconduct.  Customer must provide performance assurance if creditworthiness is questionable.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement runs for 15 Contract Years, renewable unless terminated with 30 days' written notice. Indemnification obligations survive termination.

**Financial Arrangements:** Customer pays a transportation fee and settles monthly imbalances at the specified index price, with adjustments

FerroglobePlc_20150624_F-4A_EX-10.20_915.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, effective January 1, 2009, is between Silicon Smelters Pty Ltd ("Customer"), a ferro-alloy manufacturer, and Espacio Information Technology, SA ("EIT"), an IT services provider, both subsidiaries of Group Villar Mir.  The agreement outlines EIT's provision of IT management services to the Customer, excluding industrial/production IT.

EIT's key obligations include managing the Customer's network (WAN, excluding LAN), servers (central server maintenance, local server hardware responsibility with Customer), applications (support, maintenance, and development), and standard software licenses.  EIT is responsible for service level agreements (SLAs) detailed in Annex 2, including uptime and response times.  The Customer is responsible for hardware purchases (workstations, printers, local servers) and communication lines.

The initial annual fee is €200,000 (€100,000 per factory), invoiced quarterly, subject to annual adjustment based on the Spanish CPI.  The agreement is year-to-year, tacitly renewable, terminable by either party with three months' written notice.  Early termination clauses exist for EIT's breach of contract or insolvency, with specific financial penalties outlined.  The agreement includes provisions for data confidentiality, intellectual property rights (EIT retains rights to GES-INDUS), and dispute resolution (initially internal to Group Villar Mir, then Spanish courts/arbitration).  Governing law is Spanish.

TodosMedicalLtd_20190328_20-F_EX-4.10_11.summary:
This Marketing and Reseller Agreement, effective December 20, 2018, is between Todos Medical Ltd. (Israel) and Care G.B. Plus Ltd. (Israel).  Todos grants Care G.B. Plus exclusive rights to distribute and sell Todos' proprietary blood screening tests (Products) in Israel, including the Palestinian Authority, for five years, renewable.  Exclusivity is contingent on Care G.B. Plus meeting annual sales milestones; failure to meet 50% results in potential exclusivity cancellation or termination after 180-day notice.

Todos' obligations include providing technical assistance, training, support, and marketing materials; obtaining Israeli Ministry of Health approval (AMAR); and fulfilling orders within 90 days.  Care G.B. Plus must market and sell the Products, establish a laboratory meeting Todos' specifications, provide customer support, and submit quarterly sales reports.  Pricing is to be agreed upon, with payments due within 30 days of shipment.  Todos warrants product performance for one year.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.  The agreement is governed by Israeli law, with disputes resolved through arbitration.  The agreement contains standard confidentiality, intellectual property, and limitation of liability clauses.  The relationship is defined as independent contractors.

PrecheckHealthServicesInc_20200320_8-K_E.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated March 19, 2020, is between Co-Diagnostics, Inc. ("Principal") and PreCheck Health Services, Inc. ("Distributor").  It establishes a non-exclusive distributorship for Co-Diagnostics' qPCR infectious disease kits, Logix Smart COVID-19 PCR diagnostic test, and Co-Dx Box™ instrument within Romania.

The Distributor's key obligations include using commercially reasonable efforts to promote and sell the Products, obtaining necessary licenses, and complying with all applicable laws.  The Principal retains the right to directly contact customers but must forward leads and orders to the Distributor.  The Principal can unilaterally adjust product lists and prices, except for adding new products, which requires mutual agreement.  The Distributor is prohibited from handling competing products within the territory.

The agreement runs until March 18, 2021, terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice. Upon termination, the Distributor receives payment for accepted orders.  The Distributor is an independent contractor, and the agreement is governed by Texas law.  Financial arrangements include a volume-based discount (percentage unspecified).  The agreement contains standard clauses regarding non-assignment, entire agreement, and dispute resolution (no challenges to termination).

INKTOMICORP_06_08_1998-EX-10.14-SOFTWARE.summary:
This Software Hosting Agreement, effective July 27, 1997, is between Inktomi Corporation (Inktomi) and Microsoft Corporation (Microsoft).  It governs Inktomi's hosting and maintenance of Microsoft's customized search engine ("Product") on Inktomi-owned servers.  Inktomi's key obligations include deployment, hosting, and maintenance according to detailed specifications (Exhibit A), adherence to security measures, and providing specified reports.  Microsoft's primary obligation is payment for services.

The agreement outlines a complex payment structure including monthly fees for server usage (varying based on server age and capacity), maintenance costs, a management fee, and payments related to Inktomi's subcontractor, Exodus.  Specific financial details are redacted.  Inktomi retains ownership of the servers, but Microsoft has certain rights regarding capacity and server location.  Data ownership is split between the parties.

The agreement is indefinite but includes termination clauses. Inktomi can terminate with one year's notice after two years from the Launch Date. Microsoft can terminate with [redacted] days' notice, subject to payment for services rendered and an early termination penalty for Inktomi, with options involving financial compensation or return of collateral (detailed in the Loan Agreement).  Termination is also possible for material breach or insolvency of either party.  Governing law is Washington State.  Numerous other provisions address confidentiality, warranties, indemnification, limitations of liability, and miscellaneous terms.  Several ancillary agreements are referenced.

OAKTREECAPITALGROUP,LLC_03_02_2020-EX-10.summary:
This Services Agreement, dated September 25, 2018, is between Oaktree Capital Management, L.P. ("Oaktree US"), a Delaware limited partnership, and Oaktree Capital Management (International) Limited ("Sub-Advisor"), a UK-based company.  The agreement replaces a prior agreement and appoints the Sub-Advisor as sub-investment manager and sub-advisor to Oaktree US's funds ("Funds"), including marketing services in Europe and the Middle East.

The Sub-Advisor's key obligations include assisting with Fund investment management, exercising delegated investment powers (subject to Oaktree US's oversight and potential limitations), and providing marketing services.  Oaktree US retains ultimate control and responsibility for the Funds.  The Sub-Advisor acknowledges its fiduciary responsibilities under US law, including ERISA where applicable.

Oaktree US will pay the Sub-Advisor agreed-upon fees, potentially subject to reductions based on management fees or earnings on cash equivalents received by the Sub-Advisor.  Oaktree US handles administrative functions and custody of Fund assets.  The agreement is governed by English law.

The agreement's term is tied to the life of each Fund, subject to early termination by either party with 30 days' written notice.  Upon termination, the Sub-Advisor must cooperate with an orderly transition and provide a full account of investments.  A detailed indemnification clause protects Oaktree US from losses caused by the Sub-Advisor's negligence or willful misconduct.  The Sub-Advisor is prohibited from assigning its rights without Oaktree US's consent.

BANGIINC_05_25_2005-EX-10-Premium Manage.summary:
This Premium Managed Hosting Agreement, dated March 1, 2005, is between AstroNutrition.com (Ku) and deep systems (Thompson).  It's a 12-month contract (March 1, 2005 – February 28, 2006) for managed hosting services of AstroNutrition.com's website.
