deep systems is obligated to provide system administration (SMTP, IMAP, DNS, SQL, HTTP), change management (Zen Cart updates), and 24/7 emergency phone support with 1-business-day email response for non-critical issues.  A 99% server uptime guarantee is included.  Services are hosted on FreeBSD 5, Apache 2, MySQL 4 servers co-located in Vancouver.

AstroNutrition.com will pay $175/month for up to 10GB of bandwidth; overages cost $20/GB.  Additional services like project management and custom software development are available at $55/hour.  Billing is monthly, starting March 1st.  The agreement lacks explicit termination clauses.

AMERICANPHYSICIANSCAPITALINC_03_31_2003-.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated May 25, 1999, is between Mutual Insurance Corporation of America (MICOA), a Michigan insurer, and Stratton, Cheeseman & Walsh-Nevada, Inc. (Agency), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement appoints Agency as MICOA's exclusive agent in Nevada to sell professional liability insurance.

Agency's key obligations include soliciting insurance proposals, issuing certificates and binders (without binding authority), providing customary agency services, promptly reporting claims, and refraining from admitting or denying liability.  Agency agrees to exclusivity for MICOA's professional liability products in Nevada, with exceptions for risks declined by MICOA.  Agency must maintain errors & omissions and fidelity insurance.

MICOA's key obligations include paying commissions (12% of premiums, subject to a repayment plan detailed in a separate project memorandum reducing the rate to 11.5% until certain premium thresholds are met) within 30 days of premium receipt, sharing promotional costs, and providing Agency with a list of existing policies upon termination.  MICOA will purchase Agency's expirations upon termination for twice the commissions earned in the preceding 12 months, subject to a non-compete clause.

The agreement may be terminated by either party with 120 days' written notice, automatically upon Agency license cancellation, or immediately for gross misconduct.  MICOA may also terminate for Agency delinquency.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration.  Nevada law governs the agreement.  Agency is an independent contractor.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses for both parties.  A separate project memorandum outlines cost-sharing arrangements for the initial development of the Nevada market.

GULFSOUTHMEDICALSUPPLYINC_12_24_1997-EX-.summary:
This Affiliate Agreement, dated December 14, 1997, is between Physician Sales & Service, Inc. ("PSS") and several shareholders of Gulf South Medical Supply, Inc. ("GSMS") (the "Undersigned").  It governs the Undersigned's rights and obligations concerning PSS stock received in a merger between GSMS and PSS.

The agreement's purpose is to restrict the sale of PSS stock received by the Undersigned in the merger until certain conditions are met.  Key obligations include the Undersigned's agreement not to sell PSS stock until PSS publishes financial results post-merger (within 45 days of the first fiscal quarter's end, per ASR 130 and 135), and the Undersigned's representation that the stock is for their own account. PSS is obligated to publish these results and to file timely reports under Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 for three years post-merger.  The agreement also addresses transfer restrictions via legends on stock certificates and compliance with Rule 145(d) and Rule 144.  The Undersigned acknowledges potential tax implications (Section 368 of the Internal Revenue Code) and Section 16(b) liability if they are PSS officers/directors.

The agreement's duration is implicitly tied to the fulfillment of the post-merger financial reporting requirements and the expiration of the restrictive periods under Rule 145(d) and Rule 144.  No specific termination clause is explicitly stated.  There are no explicit financial arrangements beyond the stock exchange in the underlying merger.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law.

BELLRINGBRANDS,INC_02_07_2020-EX-10.18-M.summary: This Master Supply Agreement, effective October 31, 2019, is between Premier Nutrition Company, LLC ("PNC") and Fonterra (USA) Inc. ("Fonterra").  It governs the supply of protein ingredients by Fonterra to PNC for the production of ready-to-drink shakes, protein powders, and other nutritional products.  Fonterra's key obligations include supplying ingredients meeting PNC's specifications, providing Certificates of Analysis, and maintaining a robust food safety program subject to audits by PNC.  PNC is obligated to place purchase orders specifying quantities, prices, and delivery dates.  The agreement includes detailed quality and food safety provisions, including recall procedures and Fonterra's responsibility for defects.  Intellectual property rights remain with the respective owners.  Confidential information is protected by a detailed confidentiality clause.  The agreement has a five-year initial term with automatic five-year renewals unless terminated with 12 months' notice.  Termination clauses allow for termination for cause (material breach) or insolvency.  Financial arrangements are partially redacted but include a liability cap (with exceptions for confidentiality breaches and intentional misconduct), indemnification clauses, and insurance requirements for Fonterra.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law.

AimmuneTherapeuticsInc_20200205_8-K_EX-1.summary:
This License, Development, and Commercialization Agreement, dated February 4, 2020, is between Xencor, Inc. ("Xencor") and Aimmune Therapeutics, Inc. ("Aimmune").  The agreement grants Aimmune an exclusive, worldwide license to develop, manufacture, and commercialize Xencor's XmAb7195 (renamed AIMab7195) antibody for human diseases, subject to specified restrictive covenants.

Aimmune's key obligations include development (bearing all costs), regulatory filings, and commercialization of the Product (defined as AIMab7195 or specified variants).  Xencor's key obligations include technology transfer and indemnification for pre-Effective Date activities.  Aimmune must maintain accurate records subject to Xencor's audit rights.

The agreement includes tiered royalty payments to Xencor based on Net Sales, subject to reductions for invalid claims, third-party licenses, and generic competition.  A significant upfront payment ($5 million cash and $5 million in Aimmune equity) is payable to Xencor, along with potential milestone payments totaling up to $385 million.

The agreement's term is defined by the Royalty Term (country-specific, ending upon patent expiration or a specified timeframe).  Termination clauses exist for material breach (with cure periods), bankruptcy, and convenience (by Aimmune only).  Confidentiality, indemnification, and dispute resolution provisions are included.  California law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in California courts.

HEALTHGATEDATACORP_11_24_1999-EX-10.1-HO.summary:
This Hosting and Management Agreement, dated March 20, 1998, is between HealthGate Data Corp. (HealthGate) and Blackwell Science Limited and Munksgaard A/S (the Publishers).  The agreement outlines HealthGate's development and hosting of an online journal website for the Publishers' content (up to 200 journals).

HealthGate's key obligations include developing the website per the Specification (Schedule 1), providing hosting and management services (including content loading, access, and maintenance), and meeting specified service levels.  The Publishers are responsible for providing content and subscription management.  HealthGate grants a non-exclusive license to the Publishers for the Proprietary Software.  Upon termination, HealthGate will provide assistance with transitioning services and may grant a license to the Publishers for continued use of the Software.

Important terms include detailed service level agreements, payment schedules (totaling $1,000,000+ in installments and Use Fees based on Schedule 2),  intellectual property rights assignments, confidentiality provisions, and indemnities.  The initial term is until February 28, 2000, with renewal options.  Termination clauses exist for breach of contract, bankruptcy, and change of control at HealthGate.  Specific performance is available as a remedy for breach.  Governing law is English law, with dispute resolution in London or Boston depending on the plaintiff.  Clauses 4.2, 5, 10.2, 20.4, 23.2, 25-28, 30-34 survive termination.

INTELLIGENTHIGHWAYSOLUTIONS,INC_01_18_20.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated January 10, 2018, is between Bravatek Solutions, Inc. (Bravatek) and Fazync LLC (Fazync), a subsidiary of Intelligent Highway Solutions, Inc. (IHSI).  The agreement establishes a non-exclusive business relationship where Bravatek acts as a sales lead generator for Fazync's energy-saving solutions within the government sector.

Bravatek's key obligations include marketing Fazync's products, providing sales leads reports, and assisting with sales materials. Fazync's obligations include acknowledging Bravatek as a partner in marketing materials, providing technical support to Bravatek, and collaborating on sales efforts.  Both parties agree to jointly develop a product strategy and utilize each other as preferred vendors where possible.

Bravatek receives a lead-finder fee (10-20% of project revenue, exact percentage determined by Fazync based on project margin and costs) for sales resulting from leads it provides.  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses and confidentiality provisions lasting five years post-termination.

The agreement has a 12-month term, automatically renewing for another 12 months unless either party provides 90-day written notice of non-renewal.  Either party may terminate with 90 days' written notice.  Governing law is Texas.  The agreement is non-assignable without written consent.

ATMOSENERGYCORP_11_22_2002-EX-10.17-TRAN.summary:
This 1992 Transportation Service Agreement (TSA) between Arkansas Western Pipeline Company ("Transporter") and Associated Natural Gas Company ("Shipper") governs natural gas transportation.  The Shipper tenders gas to the Transporter at specified receipt points (Exhibit A), who transports and redelivers equivalent quantities (less fuel usage and shrinkage) to delivery points (Exhibit B).  The agreement specifies a Maximum Daily Quantity (MDQ) of 23,000 Dth.  Service is either firm or interruptible, as defined in Transporter's Rate Schedule FTS/ITS, incorporated by reference.  Shipper pays Transporter according to the FTS/ITS Rate Schedule and FERC Gas Tariff.

Key terms include Maximum Daily Delivery Obligation (MDDO), Equivalent Quantity, and Fuel Usage and Applicable Shrinkage.  The agreement has a ten-year primary term, renewable month-to-month, terminable with 60 (interruptible) or 180 (firm) days' written notice.  Rate adjustments require FERC authorization; Shipper retains rights under the Natural Gas Act and Natural Gas Policy Act.  Capacity reductions for firm transportation are pro rata.  Governing law is Arkansas.  The agreement supersedes all prior agreements.  Later exhibits and addendums detail capacity assignments and releases to Atmos Energy Corporation, involving partial assignments of capacity under the original contract.

PacificapEntertainmentHoldingsInc_200511.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated November 3, 2005, is between Pacificap Entertainment (Licensor) and The Henry Film and Entertainment Corporation (Licensee).  Pacificap grants Licensee a 10-year exclusive, worldwide license to use Pacificap's nostalgic television show library content across various media (TV, DVD, internet, radio, mobile, etc.).  Licensee owns all resulting works.

Licensee's key obligations include using best efforts to restrict commercial redistribution of the content and sharing 10% of net revenue (or a minimum of $50,000 annually) from all derivative works with Pacificap.  Pacificap's obligations include content delivery, technical assistance, and indemnification for any third-party claims related to the licensed content.

The agreement includes confidentiality provisions, public announcement requirements, and clauses for future cooperation.  The initial term is 10 years, automatically renewing for 3-year periods unless terminated with 60 days' notice.  Either party may terminate immediately for cause (e.g., insolvency, material breach).  All revenue sharing ceases upon termination.  Disputes are resolved through binding arbitration in San Diego County, California.

ReedsInc_20191113_10-Q_EX-10.4_11888303_.summary:
This Recipe Development Agreement, effective October 11, 2019, is between Reed's, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and B C Marketing Concepts Inc., dba Full Sail Brewing Company (an Oregon corporation).  The agreement outlines the development of ginger-based alcoholic beverage recipes (specified in Exhibit A: Ready-to-drink Mule and Hard Ginger Seltzer) for Reed's.

Full Sail is responsible for recipe development and deliverables (recipes, documentation, samples),  while Reed's retains exclusive ownership of all resulting intellectual property (IP).  A Development Committee (members listed in Exhibit B) oversees the process, with final approval required from both parties.  Full Sail's costs are covered except for Reed's personnel and contractors.  Full Sail will not use the developed IP outside this agreement.

Key terms define IP ownership, confidentiality obligations, and work-for-hire status of Full Sail's contributions.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses protecting both parties against third-party IP claims.  Liability is limited except for indemnification obligations.

The agreement lasts for one year or the duration of a concurrent Manufacturing and Distribution Agreement, whichever is longer, and may be terminated early for breach or insolvency.  No specific financial arrangements beyond cost allocation are detailed in this excerpt.  New York law governs, with venue in New York City.

RgcResourcesInc_20151216_8-K_EX-10.3_937.summary:
This Gas Franchise Agreement, dated November 17, 2015, is between the Town of Vinton, Virginia (Grantor) and Roanoke Gas Company (Grantee).  The agreement grants Roanoke Gas Company a 20-year franchise (commencing January 1, 2016) to operate a gas distribution system within Vinton's territorial limits, subject to Ordinance No. 967 (incorporated by reference).

Grantee's key obligations include maintaining a local business office open at least 40 hours weekly, non-discrimination in employment, and payment of a franchise fee.  The annual franchise fee is a percentage share of a tri-locality total ($98,196 base year, increasing 3% annually compounded), calculated pro rata based on the Grantee's gas sales within Vinton relative to sales in Roanoke and Salem.  The fee is payable by March 31st of the following year.

The agreement includes standard notice provisions and is governed by Virginia law (implied).  No explicit termination clause is detailed in this excerpt, but termination may be implied within the referenced Ordinance.  The agreement is signed by authorized representatives of both parties.

BELLICUMPHARMACEUTICALS,INC_05_07_2019-E.summary:
This Supply Agreement, effective March 27, 2019, is between Miltenyi Biotec GmbH (Miltenyi) and Bellicum Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (Bellicum).  It governs Miltenyi's non-exclusive supply of specified products (Miltenyi Products) to Bellicum for use in manufacturing cell-based therapeutics (Bellicum Products).

Miltenyi's key obligations include supplying Miltenyi Products according to agreed forecasts and purchase orders, maintaining quality control per agreed standards and a Quality Agreement (to be separately executed), and providing regulatory support (Master Files). Bellicum's key obligations include providing rolling forecasts, placing purchase orders within specified parameters (including a "Firm Zone" for binding orders), performing acceptance testing, and paying for Miltenyi Products according to a tiered pricing structure detailed in Exhibit E and subject to discounts in Exhibit F.  Both parties are responsible for regulatory compliance within their respective spheres.

The agreement includes detailed provisions on change control, delivery, acceptance/rejection, intellectual property rights (Miltenyi grants a limited license to Bellicum), warranties, limitations of liability, indemnification, confidentiality, and dispute resolution.  The initial term is ten years, renewable for five-year periods at Bellicum's option.  Termination clauses exist for material breach, bankruptcy, force majeure, and Bellicum's discontinuation of Bellicum Product programs or without cause.  Financial arrangements include a €2,000,000 upfront fee, milestone payments, and tiered pricing based on purchase volume.  Governing law is New York, with specific jurisdiction clauses.

MARTINMIDSTREAMPARTNERSLP_01_23_2004-EX-.summary:
This Marine Transportation Agreement, dated December 23, 2003, is between Martin Operating Partnership L.P. ("Owner") and Midstream Fuel Service LLC ("Charterer").  The agreement covers the Owner's provision of marine transportation services for #2 fuel oil and high sulfur diesel.  The Owner's key obligations include providing seaworthy vessels, qualified crews, and adhering to established loading/offloading protocols.  The Charterer's main responsibilities are payment for transportation services and compliance with the Owner's protocols.

The agreement has a three-year initial term, automatically renewing annually unless either party provides 30-day written notice of non-renewal.  Fees are renegotiated annually; failure to agree results in termination.  Either party may terminate for breach after a 10-day cure period.  Payment is a per-gallon fee, invoiced monthly, with a 30-day payment term.  The fee is adjusted annually based on the Consumer Price Index.  The contract includes detailed indemnity clauses, pollution prevention provisions, and a force majeure clause.  Governing law is Texas.  Title to the product remains with the Charterer.  Assignment requires written consent.  The contract incorporates additional terms, including detailed invoicing, payment, and insurance requirements.

RUBIOSRESTAURANTSINC_03_31_2008-EX-10.75.summary: This 2008 Sponsorship Agreement between Rubio's Fresh Mexican Grill ("Rubio's") and San Diego Ballpark Funding LLC ("SDBF") governs Rubio's sponsorship of the San Diego Padres.  The agreement outlines Rubio's sponsorship benefits, including signage at Petco Park, Padres Magazine advertising, and season tickets.  Rubio's is obligated to pay SDBF a specified annual fee in installments (exact amounts redacted).  SDBF is responsible for signage installation and maintenance; Rubio's for advertising copy creation and approval.  The agreement's term runs from November 1, 2007, to October 31, 2008, subject to earlier termination for non-payment or Noteholder disapproval (if the annual payment exceeds $500,000).  The agreement explicitly disclaims any partnership or agency relationship.  Important clauses address payment defaults, insurance requirements (with Rubio's responsible for obtaining and maintaining specified coverages), limitations on liability (excluding consequential damages), and governing law (California).  Noteholder approval is a condition precedent to SDBF's obligations, except for certain specified provisions.  The agreement includes standard indemnity clauses and provisions for temporary interruptions of sponsorship benefits.

CardlyticsInc_20180112_S-1_EX-10.16_1100.summary:
This Customization Schedule, part of a larger Software License, Customization, and Maintenance Agreement, details customizations between Bank of America, N.A. ("Bank of America") and an unnamed Supplier (Cardlytics, Inc. implied).  The agreement outlines the Supplier's obligation to deliver customizations meeting Bank of America's specifications, detailed in provided and subsequently approved documents (Functional, System Design, and Test Specifications).  The Supplier must deliver these documents by a specified date.  The customizations encompass both Bank of America's and the Supplier's proprietary elements, notably including "B-1 vTIP2010."

Financial terms are based on either a time and materials rate (with a potential "not to exceed" limit) or a fixed price.  Crucially, Bank of America can terminate the schedule and receive a refund if the Supplier increases the price after delivering specifications.  The schedule specifies delivery and installation dates and identifies project personnel from both parties.  The agreement incorporates the environment described in the main agreement's Product License Schedule A.  No explicit duration or termination clauses beyond the price increase condition are detailed in this excerpt.

XLITECHNOLOGIES,INC_12_11_2015-EX-10.1-S.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, effective December 1, 2015, through November 30, 2016, is between RMF Empire, Inc. DBA West Coast Customs ("WCC") and Bosch International, LLC / XLI Technologies, Inc. ("XLI").  The agreement centers on XLI's promotion of its "Light Sheets" product using WCC's branding and media presence.

Key obligations include reciprocal licensing of trademarks (West Coast Customs and Light Sheets), with each party granting the other a limited, non-exclusive license for promotional use.  WCC commits to promotional activities detailed in Attachment A (Sponsor Benefits Schedule), including brand mentions, commercial spots, and event participation.  XLI's obligations include payment to WCC (detailed in Attachment B), and providing Light Sheets for WCC's promotional use at XLI's discretion.

Crucially, XLI provides WCC 5,500,000 common stock shares upon signing.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification for claims arising from breach of contract or trademark use.  The agreement includes standard clauses on representations and warranties, independent contractor status, confidentiality, and force majeure.  Termination can occur upon breach (with a 30-day cure period), mutual consent, or bankruptcy.  Sections regarding indemnification, insurance, and confidentiality survive termination.  The agreement is governed by a detailed notice provision.

ScansourceInc_20190822_10-K_EX-10.38_117.summary:
This Software License Agreement (SLA) is between Cisco Systems, Inc. (or its subsidiary) and a Customer (business entity).  The agreement grants the Customer a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use Cisco software for internal business purposes only, subject to license fees specified in the Purchase Order.  The license is limited to the specific hardware or number of users/sessions detailed in the Purchase Order.

Key obligations for the Customer include restrictions on transferring, modifying, reverse-engineering, or using the software for third-party services without Cisco's consent.  The Customer must maintain Cisco's proprietary notices and implement reasonable security measures to protect the software.  Cisco warrants the software media and substantial conformance to specifications for 90 days (or the software's warranty period, whichever is longer).  Liability is limited to the software's purchase price.

The agreement is effective until terminated by the Customer (by destroying all copies) or Cisco (for breach of contract).  Cisco retains the right to audit Customer's records to verify compliance.  Financial arrangements are governed by the Purchase Order and include license fees for the software and potential fees for interoperability information.  California law governs, excluding the UN Convention on International Sales.  The SLA supersedes any conflicting purchase order terms.

VERTEXENERGYINC_08_14_2014-EX-10.24-OPER.summary:
This Operation and Maintenance Agreement (OMA), dated November 3, 2010, is between Magellan Terminals Holdings, L.P. ("Owner") and Omega Refining, LLC ("Operator").  The OMA governs Operator's management, operation, and maintenance of Owner's six-spot rail car loading/offloading facility ("Rail Facility") in Marrero, Louisiana.

Operator's key obligations include facility operation and maintenance (to a standard consistent with industry practices and applicable laws),  regulatory compliance (including Environmental Laws), financial record-keeping, and reporting to Owner.  Operator acts as an independent contractor, not an employee or agent.  Specific responsibilities include compliance with the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasure (SPCC) Regulations and adherence to an approved Operating and Capital Expenditure Budget.  Owner retains oversight and approval rights for significant expenditures and alterations.

The OMA includes detailed indemnification clauses, requiring each party to indemnify the other for losses arising from their respective negligence or breach of contract.  Operator must maintain comprehensive insurance coverage naming Owner as an additional insured.  Financial arrangements are not explicitly detailed in the provided excerpt but involve Operator covering operating expenses, with Owner reimbursing for certain specified expenditures.

The agreement's term is tied to the duration of a separate Lease, unless terminated earlier for cause (material breach by either party) or without cause by Owner with seven days' notice.  Termination provisions include detailed procedures for notice, dispute resolution (negotiation followed by litigation), and transition of operations.  The governing law is Delaware.  Consequential damages are excluded from liability.

NYLIACVARIABLEANNUITYSEPARATEACCOUNTIII_.summary: This 1998 Service Agreement between Fidelity Investments Institutional Operations Company, Inc. ("FIIOC") and New York Life Insurance and Annuity Corporation ("NYLIC") governs the provision of fund information to NYLIC.  FIIOC, serving as transfer agent for its Variable Insurance Products Funds, agrees to provide NYLIC with periodic information (investment objectives, policies, holdings, performance) regarding these funds.  NYLIC, holding fund shares to support its annuity and insurance products, uses this information to respond to customer inquiries, reducing FIIOC's workload.  NYLIC's use is limited;  it cannot alter the provided information without prior Fund approval as per existing Participation Agreements between NYLIC and the Funds.  FIIOC compensates NYLIC quarterly based on NYLIC's average daily assets held in the Funds, subject to a maximum annual cap.  The agreement is terminable by NYLIC at will, by FIIOC with 90 days' notice, or immediately for material breach or regulatory reasons.  Automatic termination occurs upon termination of NYLIC's Participation Agreements with the Funds.  Massachusetts law governs.  Assignment requires consent, except for automatic assignment to FIIOC's successor as transfer agent.

STWRESOURCESHOLDINGCORP_08_06_2014-EX-10.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated August 6, 2014, is between the City of Fort Stockton, Texas (COFS) and STW Resources Holding Corp. (STW), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement concerns the development of water wells in the Capitan Reef Aquifer Formation on COFS property.  STW will explore, drill, and produce groundwater, primarily to sell within a 500-mile radius.  COFS grants STW a 30-year lease (renewable annually, unless terminated with 60-days' notice), potentially extending beyond 30 years depending on STW's sales contracts.

STW's key obligations include deepening an existing well or drilling a new one at its expense, conducting hydrogeological studies (Post-Well Studies), complying with all regulations, and constructing and maintaining the wells.  If the Post-Well Study demonstrates sufficient water production (minimum 1,200 GPM), STW pays COFS a $5,000,000 bonus and a 17% royalty on sales exceeding 3 million GPD (with 3 million GPD provided to COFS at no cost).  STW also pays for all construction and study costs.  COFS provides access to its property, existing easements, and assists with obtaining permits.

The agreement includes provisions for termination by either party under specific circumstances, including reimbursement clauses for STW's costs under certain termination scenarios.  STW has a one-year option to produce water after the Post-Well Study, with ongoing royalty payments to maintain the agreement if the option isn't exercised or if water isn't sold for 180

AlliedEsportsEntertainmentInc_20190815_8.summary:
This Event Sponsorship Agreement, effective February 1, 2019, is between Newegg Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and Allied Esports International, Inc. (a Nevada corporation).  The agreement outlines a five-year sponsorship of the HyperX Esports Arena Las Vegas by Newegg.

Newegg's key obligations include paying a sponsorship fee (detailed in Schedule 3) and providing specified sponsorship benefits.  Allied's obligations include granting Newegg non-exclusive license to use Allied's marks for promotional purposes and providing Newegg with specified sponsorship rights (detailed in Schedule 4), including advertising space and marketing participation.  Both parties grant each other limited licenses to use their respective marks, subject to strict conditions regarding usage and quality.  Newegg is designated as the exclusive Technology E-Commerce sponsor.

The agreement includes detailed provisions on confidentiality, indemnity, and liability, limiting liability for consequential damages.  Termination clauses allow for termination by either party for material breach (after a cure period) or for convenience after the second year, with provisions for fee proration and refund.  Governing law is California.  Dispute resolution is via arbitration in Los Angeles County.  The agreement also addresses exclusivity,  representation and warranties, and force majeure.

SLOVAKWIRELESSFINANCECOBV_03_28_2001-EX-.contract_id: SLOVAKWIRELESSFINANCECOBV_03_28_2001-EX-4.(B)(II).3-Maintenance and support contract for SICAP(R) modules
SLOVAKWIRELESSFINANCECOBV_03_28_2001-EX-.contract_title: SLOVAKWIRELESSFINANCECOBV_03_28_2001-EX-4.(B)(II).3-Maintenance and support contract for SICAP(R) modules
SLOVAKWIRELESSFINANCECOBV_03_28_2001-EX-.summary:
This Maintenance and Support contract, dated October 10, 2000, is between EuroTel Bratislava a.s. (Slovakia) and Sicap Ltd (Switzerland).  It governs maintenance and support for Sicap(R) PPB, VCA, and OTA modules, replacing a prior agreement.

Sicap Ltd provides standard service (hotline support, 20 hours monthly phone support, remote support, change management) and optional additional support (on-site, remote outside working hours). EuroTel is responsible for first-level maintenance (day-to-day operations), while Sicap Ltd handles second-level maintenance (bug fixes, performance issues).  Detailed procedures for incident reporting and response times (varying by priority) are specified.  Change management requires formal Request for Change (RFC) procedures.

The contract includes pricing for standard service (annual fees based on subscriber numbers) and additional support (hourly rates plus expenses).  Payment is semi-annually in advance. Price adjustments are permitted annually.

The initial term is two years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with six weeks' written notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach after a 30-day cure period.  Sicap Ltd's liability is limited; indirect or consequential damages are excluded.  Assignment of rights requires written consent.  Governing law and dispute resolution are not explicitly stated.

ANIXABIOSCIENCESINC_06_09_2020-EX-10.1-C.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, dated April 14, 2020, is between Anixa Biosciences, Inc. (Anixa), a Delaware corporation, and OntoChem GmbH (OntoChem), a German company.  The agreement outlines a research collaboration to discover and develop novel drug candidates for COVID-19 treatment.

OntoChem's key obligations include conducting research as detailed in Exhibit A (redacted), providing weekly updates and data to Anixa, and maintaining confidentiality.  Anixa's main obligations involve funding the research (100,002 Euros in installments plus reimbursement of pre-approved expenses), selecting up to 200 "Hit Compounds" as "Lead Scaffolds" within one year, and holding sole rights to their further development and commercialization.  Additional payments are due upon scaffold selection ($10,000 annually) and first patient dosing in a clinical trial ($300,000).

Intellectual property rights are assigned to Anixa for "Anixa Inventions" and to OntoChem for "OntoChem Inventions," with a non-exclusive license granted to Anixa for Lead Scaffolds.  OntoChem is granted exclusivity on rejected compounds after a two-year period, subject to Anixa's right of first negotiation.

The agreement may be terminated by Anixa with 30 days' notice or by either party for material breach after a 60-day cure period.  Specific termination clauses address Lead Scaffolds, with ownership reversion to OntoChem if clinical trials aren't initiated within five years.  Confidentiality, indemnification, and governing law (Delaware) clauses are included.  The

ELFBEAUTY,INC_07_02_2020-EX-10.1-COOPERA.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated July 1, 2020, is between e.l.f. Beauty, Inc. ("Company") and Marathon Partners Equity Management, LLC, and related entities (collectively, "Marathon Parties").  The agreement resolves a shareholder dispute where Marathon Parties, holding 2,585,000 shares, withdrew their director nominations (Cibelli, Fonseca, Birnbaum) and a Section 220 demand.

The main purpose is to secure Marathon Parties' support for Company proposals at the 2020 and (potentially) 2021 annual meetings.  Key obligations include Marathon Parties withdrawing their nominations, voting for the Company's slate of directors and other Board recommendations (except for extraordinary matters), and maintaining a standstill for a defined period ("Support Period").  The Company agrees to appoint Lori Keith as an independent director, amend its equity incentive plan, and hold quarterly investor calls with Marathon Parties.

The Support Period lasts until 30 days before the 2021 Annual Meeting nomination deadline, potentially extending to 2022 based on specified conditions (including Marathon Parties maintaining at least 2% ownership, Keith's continued service, and adherence to other conditions).  The agreement includes mutual non-disparagement clauses and a press release provision.  The Company reimburses Marathon Parties up to $250,000 for expenses.  The agreement terminates automatically upon Support Period expiration, except for certain survival clauses.  Breach allows for injunctive relief.

HarpoonTherapeuticsInc_20200312_10-K_EX-.summary:
This Development and Option Agreement, dated November 20, 2019, is between Harpoon Therapeutics, Inc. (Harpoon) and AbbVie Biotechnology Ltd. (AbbVie).  It's a collaborative development and licensing agreement concerning Harpoon's Licensed Compound (HPN217) and resulting Licensed Products.

AbbVie has an option to license Harpoon's intellectual property rights for worldwide development and commercialization.  Harpoon's key obligations include conducting initial development activities (detailed in Schedule 1.84), delivering specified reports (Opt-In and Final Development Reports), and transferring manufacturing technology post-option exercise. AbbVie's primary obligations are to fund development, potentially assuming certain development activities, and to commercialize the Licensed Products using commercially reasonable efforts.  A Joint Governance Committee oversees the collaboration.

Key terms include definitions of "Commercially Reasonable Efforts,"  "Net Sales," and detailed royalty structures (tiered rates, reductions for competition, etc.) in Article 6.  Intellectual property ownership and licensing rights are extensively defined in Article 7, addressing patent prosecution, enforcement, and defense.  Confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations are significant (Article 9).

The agreement's term is until the last Royalty Term expires or the option period lapses.  Termination clauses (Article 12) cover material breach (with cure periods and dispute resolution via arbitration, Schedule 13.7.3), AbbVie's unilateral termination right, and insolvency.  Financial arrangements include a $30 million upfront payment, substantial milestone payments (development, regulatory, sales-based), and tiered royalties on Net Sales.  Significant indemnification provisions (Article 1

DigitalCinemaDestinationsCorp_20111220_S.summary:
This Network Affiliate Agreement, dated March 14, 2011, is between National CineMedia, LLC ("NCM") and Digital Cinema Destinations Corp. ("Network Affiliate").  It's a strategic alliance establishing NCM as the exclusive provider of advertising services to Network Affiliate's theaters for a five-year initial term, renewable by mutual agreement.

NCM's key obligations include providing advertising services (Pre-Feature Program, Video Display Program, Digital Carousel, etc.), installing and maintaining "small d" digital equipment (up to $9,000 per screen), and managing advertising inventory. Network Affiliate must exhibit the services, provide operational support (access, data, etc.), and maintain its equipment.  Both parties grant each other limited licenses to use their respective trademarks.

Financially, NCM pays Network Affiliate a digital screen usage fee ($30/screen) and shares 50% of net advertising revenue.  A minimum fee is guaranteed annually, based on Network Affiliate's patron base.  Payment terms are within 60 days of invoice.

The agreement may be terminated by either party for material breach (30-day cure period, except for intellectual property clauses which have a 5-day cure period). NCM can terminate with 30 days' notice if service to all theaters is discontinued.  Several clauses survive termination, including intellectual property rights, payment obligations, and indemnification.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law, with jurisdiction in New York courts.  Both parties have extensive indemnification obligations.  Specific limitations on liability are included.

VERTICALNETINC_04_01_2002-EX-10.19-MAINT.summary:
This Maintenance and Support Agreement, effective October 1, 2001, is between VerticalNet, Inc. (VNI), VerticalNet Enterprises LLC (VNE), collectively "Vert," and Converge, Inc.  It governs maintenance and support services for proprietary software licensed by Vert to Converge under a separate Subscription License Agreement.

The agreement outlines Vert's obligations to provide maintenance and support services (responding to problem reports and support requests, providing updates) and professional services (enhancements, training, consulting). Converge is responsible for Level 1 support, problem reporting, and cooperation with Vert.  Specific response times and resolution efforts are detailed based on problem severity levels (Exhibit B).  Converge must provide remote access to its servers.

Key terms include definitions of "Problem," "Enhancement," "Services," and various support levels.  Intellectual property rights are addressed, with Vert retaining ownership of enhancements unless otherwise specified.

The Initial Term runs until March 31, 2003, renewable for three one-year terms by mutual written agreement.  Termination may occur due to material breach (30/60-day cure period) or non-payment (3-day cure period).

Converge pays a $4.5 million minimum fee in 18 installments.  Services exceeding a quarterly allocation are billed separately.  Converge reimburses Vert for reasonable materials and expenses.  Liability is limited, excluding willful misconduct or gross negligence.  Confidential information is protected, and non-solicitation clauses apply for one year post-termination.  Governing law is Pennsylvania law, excluding conflicts of law rules, and jury trial is waived.

TcPipelinesLp_20160226_10-K_EX-99.12_945.summary:
This Transportation Service Agreement (TSA), dated November 1, 2016, is between Great Lakes Gas Transmission Limited Partnership ("Transporter") and ANR Pipeline Company ("Shipper").  The TSA governs the transportation of gas by Transporter on behalf of Shipper, superseding a prior agreement with the same contract ID (FT18150).  The agreement runs from November 1, 2014, to October 31, 2017.

Shipper's primary obligation is payment for transportation services at Transporter's maximum rates (unless otherwise agreed upon in writing), as detailed in the applicable FERC Gas Tariff, which is incorporated by reference.  Transporter's main obligation is to transport gas up to a maximum daily quantity of 101,300 Dth/day, with specific receipt and delivery points outlined in Appendix A.  The TSA incorporates Transporter's FERC Gas Tariff, including rate schedules and general terms and conditions, subject to FERC approval for any changes.

The agreement specifies that any disputes will be resolved under Michigan law.  Importantly, the Shipper's recourse for any Transporter breach is limited to Transporter's assets; no personal liability extends to Transporter's partners or employees.  Upon termination, pre-termination obligations remain in effect.  The agreement includes standard clauses regarding waivers and notices.

HUBEIMINKANGPHARMACEUTICALLTD_09_19_2006.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, effective June 1, 2006, is between DGT Corp. (Canada) and Dolphin Industries Limited (Hong Kong).  The agreement concerns the outsourcing of photo-editing services by Dolphin for DGT's North American clients.

Dolphin will undergo beta testing ($10,000 payable in two installments) to assess service quality and bandwidth.  Following successful testing, DGT guarantees Dolphin either $5,000/30-day period for 90 days or a minimum of 3,300 edited photos/30-day period at $1.50/photo for 90 days.  Dolphin's obligation is to complete photo editing within 14 days to DGT's standards, charging $1.50 per photo (price subject to renegotiation).  Exclusivity is granted to Dolphin if DGT's annual photo volume reaches 50,000.  Dolphin agrees not to copy photos without permission.

DGT's liability is limited to the cost of the products. Dolphin indemnifies DGT against claims arising from the agreement.  Dolphin must maintain detailed records and provide annual reports.  The agreement is governed by Nevada law, with disputes resolved through arbitration.  Either party may terminate for material breach after providing notice and a cure period (10 days for Dolphin, 30 days for DGT).  Force majeure is a valid excuse for delay.  The agreement is comprehensive and supersedes prior agreements.

CardlyticsInc_20180112_S-1_EX-10.16_1100.summary: This addendum (CW255039), effective March 3, 2011, amends the Software License, Customization, and Maintenance Agreement (SLCMA) between Cardlytics, Inc. ("Supplier") and Bank of America, N.A. ("Bank of America"), dated November 5, 2010.  The addendum incorporates Schedule A, which details the Supplier Offer Placement System Software provided by Cardlytics to Bank of America.  The main purpose is to add this software to the existing SLCMA.  Cardlytics' key obligation is to provide the specified software; Bank of America's is to pay under the terms of the underlying SLCMA (financial details are not specified in this addendum).  The addendum doesn't specify duration or termination clauses; these are governed by the SLCMA.  No financial arrangements are detailed within this addendum; those are presumably outlined in the original SLCMA.  The agreement was signed by Scott Grimes (CEO, Cardlytics) and Chandra Torrence (VP, Sourcing Manager, Bank of America).

ACCURAYINC_09_01_2010-EX-10.31-DISTRIBUT.summary:
This Multiple LINAC and Multi-Modality Distributor Agreement, effective June 8, 2010, is between Accuray Incorporated (Accuray), a Delaware corporation, and Siemens Aktiengesellschaft (Siemens), a German corporation.  The agreement appoints Siemens as a non-exclusive, worldwide distributor of Accuray's CyberKnife radiosurgery systems and related products and services, but only in connection with purchases including at least one Siemens imaging product (e.g., CT, MR, PET-CT) and/or linear accelerator, and at least one Accuray system ("Multiple LINAC or Multi-Modality Purchase").

Accuray's key obligations include providing product specifications, promotional materials, warranty (one year from installation, up to 18 months from shipment), and  installation (unless otherwise agreed).  Siemens' key obligations include marketing and sales efforts, meeting annual sales targets (as defined in a separate Strategic Alliance Agreement), providing customer support, and complying with all applicable laws and regulations.  Pricing is based on Accuray's price lists, subject to change and approval processes outlined in the contract.  Payment terms involve a deposit and balance due upon shipment, with specific payment methods (letter of credit or wire transfer) detailed.  Siemens bears the risk of non-collection from customers.

The agreement's term lasts until termination of the Strategic Alliance Agreement, or 36 months after a termination election under that agreement. Termination may occur due to material breach (30-day cure period), bankruptcy, or other specified events.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on dispute resolution, confidentiality, intellectual property, indemnities (including limitations of liability), and miscellaneous clauses (governing law, assignment,

MIDDLEBROOKPHARMACEUTICALS,INC_03_18_201.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, effective February 3, 2010, is between MiddleBrook Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("MBRK") and DoctorDirectory.com, Inc. ("DD").  The agreement outlines DD's promotion of MBRK's drug, MOXATAG®, to US physicians and medical professionals.

DD's key obligations include promoting MOXATAG using various methods (detailed in Exhibit 4), subject to MBRK's approval of all promotional materials and compliance with all applicable laws and regulations.  MBRK's responsibilities include providing promotional materials, samples, and data;  managing MOXATAG's sales and distribution; and covering costs associated with samples and coupons.

The agreement's financial terms include a $50,000 upfront payment and a deposit (initially $100,000, adjusted monthly to maintain double the monthly promotion fee).  Monthly promotion fees are calculated based on MOXATAG prescriptions written by DD's target prescribers and MBRK's gross margin, with a true-up process for quarterly adjustments.  The deposit is used to settle outstanding amounts.

The agreement runs for three years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination clauses allow for termination with 30 days' notice for breach (with cure period), immediate notice for insolvency, and 60 days' notice for a change of control in MBRK, each with associated fees (Early Termination Fee and/or End of Agreement Fee).  A force majeure clause excuses performance delays due to unforeseen events.  North Carolina law governs the agreement, with arbitration as the dispute resolution mechanism.  Intellectual property rights related to promotional materials belong to MBRK.

AIRSPANNETWORKSINC_04_11_2000-EX-10.5-Di.summary: This Distributor Agreement, effective March 31, 2000, is between Airspan Networks Inc. (Washington) and GLS LLC (South Dakota).  It establishes GLS LLC as Airspan's independent, exclusive distributor for specified telecommunications products ("Airspan Products") within a defined territory.  GLS LLC's key obligations include aggressive sales promotion, customer identification, reporting, inventory maintenance, installation, and maintenance services (all at GLS LLC's expense),  and non-competition for three months post-termination.  Airspan's obligations include providing technical and commercial assistance, training, and sales materials.  The agreement specifies ordering procedures, payment terms (Net 45 days), delivery terms (CIP Incoterms 2000), and warranty provisions (12 months for Equipment and Software, with repair/replacement as the sole remedy).  Pricing is detailed in Schedule IV, firm for 24 months.  The agreement includes clauses on intellectual property rights, confidentiality, limitation of liability (excluding liability for death or personal injury), and export controls.  The initial term is 60 months, renewable for five years with mutual written agreement and six months' prior notice.  Termination clauses allow for termination for material breach with 30 days' notice and automatic termination in certain events (e.g., bankruptcy).  The governing law is South Dakota law, and disputes are resolved through mutual agreement or in Minneapolis, MN courts.

ArcGroupInc_20171211_8-K_EX-10.1_1097610.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, effective April 1, 2018, through February 2023 (or the conclusion of the 2022/23 NFL season), is between Jacksonville Jaguars, LLC ("Club") and The ARC Group, Inc. ("Sponsor"), owner of Dick's Wings and Grill.  The agreement grants Sponsor exclusive rights within a defined territory to use the Jacksonville Jaguars' trademarks and designations ("Official Designations") to advertise its restaurants.

Sponsor's key obligations include paying annual fees escalating from $200,000 to $216,490, payable in six installments, plus providing food and beverage products valued at $35,000-$37,890 annually.  Additional payments are due for playoff games.  In return, Sponsor receives various advertising benefits (Exhibit A), including stadium signage, radio spots, digital advertising, game tickets, and branded concession stand space.  Sponsor is responsible for all costs associated with its provided advertising materials and concession branding.

The agreement incorporates standard terms and conditions (Exhibit B) governing Club's approval rights over Sponsor's use of benefits.  Termination is not explicitly detailed but implied by the scheduled expiration date.  The agreement is governed by Florida law and may only be amended in writing.  Dispute resolution mechanisms are not specified.

AtnInternationalInc_20191108_10-Q_EX-10..summary:
This Network Build and Maintenance Agreement, effective July 31, 2019, is between Commnet Wireless, LLC ("Vendor") and AT&T Mobility LLC ("AT&T"), encompassing AT&T affiliates.  It's a multifaceted agreement covering the build and ongoing maintenance of a radio access network (RAN) at specified cell sites.

Vendor's key obligations include RAN construction (Addendum 1), ongoing maintenance (Addendum 2), and provision of related materials and services, all conforming to specified requirements.  AT&T's primary obligation is payment: structured payments for the build and maintenance fees for ongoing service.  The agreement details extensive definitions (e.g., "Service Affecting Defect," "Excusable Delay"), indemnification clauses (reciprocal, with specific provisions for infringement losses),  confidentiality obligations regarding AT&T data, and stringent insurance requirements for Vendor.  The agreement prohibits offshore work and includes clauses on compliance with laws (including anti-corruption and government contract provisions), intellectual property ownership, dispute resolution (escalation and arbitration), and audit rights for AT&T.

The agreement's term continues until the last addendum expires or is terminated.  Termination clauses exist for cause (material breach, insolvency),  and specific termination remedies are detailed in Addendum 1.  Financial arrangements include structured payments for the build and ongoing maintenance fees, with detailed invoicing and payment procedures.  AT&T retains ownership of all AT&T-provided equipment and materials.

SightLife Surgical, Inc. - STRATEGIC SAL.contract_id: SightLife Surgical, Inc. - STRATEGIC SALES _ MARKETING AGREEMENT
SightLife Surgical, Inc. - STRATEGIC SAL.contract_title: SightLife Surgical, Inc. - STRATEGIC SALES _ MARKETING AGREEMENT
SightLife Surgical, Inc. - STRATEGIC SAL.summary: This Strategic Sales & Marketing Agreement (Agreement) is between SightLife Surgical, Inc. ("Surgical") and Imprimis Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("Imprimis").  Surgical will provide sales representation services for Imprimis' autologous serum tears formulation ("Product") in the U.S.  The agreement outlines Surgical's obligations to promote and sell the Product, including utilizing a four-person sales team.  Surgical warrants its qualifications and compliance with all applicable laws.  Imprimis will pay Surgical a 10% commission on Net Sales, defined in Appendix A, and potential milestone payments in Imprimis stock based on sales targets.  Intellectual property created by Surgical related to the Product becomes Imprimis' sole property.  A separate Confidentiality Agreement governs confidential information exchange.  Both parties agree to indemnify each other for certain liabilities.  Surgical cannot assign the Agreement without Imprimis' consent.  The agreement's term is 36 months, terminable by either party at any time.  California law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in California courts.  Sections related to intellectual property, confidentiality, and indemnification survive termination.

InmodeLtd_20190729_F-1A_EX-10.9_11743243.summary:
This Turn-Key Manufacturing Agreement, effective 1.4.2011, is between Invasix Ltd. ("Customer," Israel) and Flextronics Israel Ltd. ("Contractor," Israel).  The agreement outlines Contractor's manufacturing services for Customer's medical devices (specified in Exhibit A).  Contractor's obligations include material planning/procurement, assembly, testing, packaging, and delivery, utilizing allocated production space and personnel.  They must maintain ISO 13488 standards.  The Customer provides technical specifications, materials, and support.

Key terms include detailed provisions for material procurement (including EOQ and LLI management), forecasting and purchase orders (with liability clauses for forecast inaccuracies and order cancellations), finished goods inventory management, quality control, a 12-month warranty on products (excluding certain items), engineering change management, and delivery/inspection procedures.  Pricing is detailed in Appendix C (USD), with quarterly price reviews.  Payment terms are net 30 days.

The agreement has a one-year initial term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 90 days' written notice. Termination for cause (breach) allows 60 days' notice; termination without cause requires four months' notice.  Immediate termination is possible for insolvency.  Detailed provisions address liability limitations, confidentiality, non-competition, dispute resolution (negotiation first, then legal action), and governing law (Israel).  The contract includes indemnification clauses for intellectual property infringement related to the product design (Customer's responsibility) and manufacturing methods (Contractor's responsibility).

GRANTIERRAENERGYINC_05_07_2012-EX-10.6-T.summary:
This Transportation Contract (VIT-005-2012), dated January 30, 2012, is between Ecopetrol S.A. (owner of the Trasandino and Mansoyá-Orito pipelines) and Solana Petroleum Exploration Colombia Limited (Sender).  The contract governs the transportation of Solana's crude oil through Ecopetrol's pipelines from Mansoyá to Tumaco.  It's a "spot" contract, meaning Solana pays per barrel transported, subject to available pipeline capacity.

Ecopetrol's main obligation is to transport the crude, while Solana must pay the transportation fee (USD $0.5192/barrel for OMO, USD $3.1143/barrel for OTA) within 20 days of invoicing.  Solana must also provide a performance bond (COP $4,047,000,000).  Crude quality must meet specified parameters (e.g., maximum 12% of total light crude received daily at Orito Plant).  Solana is responsible for pre- and post-pipeline services (unloading, storage).

The contract runs from January 30, 2012 to July 29, 2012.  Ecopetrol may terminate early for Solana's serious breach (including non-payment), dissolution, unauthorized assignment, regulatory changes increasing Ecopetrol's costs, or actions endangering pipeline operations.  A penalty clause of 10% of the final contract value applies for Solana's breaches.  The estimated contract value is USD $6,745,000.  The contract incorporates several annex

VIVINT SOLAR, INC. - NON-COMPETITION AGR.summary: This Amendment No. 1, dated August 16, 2017, modifies a pre-existing Non-Competition Agreement between Vivint Solar, Inc. (Delaware) and Vivint, Inc. (Utah), both affiliates under 313 Acquisition, LLC.  The amendment primarily revises the non-competition and non-solicitation clauses.  Specifically, it *deletes* the original non-competition section entirely.  The non-solicitation section is replaced, extending its duration until the expiration of the "Sales Term" defined in a separate Sales Dealer Agreement between Vivint and Vivint Solar Developer, LLC.  The remaining sections of the original Non-Competition Agreement remain in effect, except as amended herein.  The amendment incorporates by reference the Master Framework Agreement (dated September 30, 2016) for definitions and governing provisions, including confidentiality and miscellaneous terms.  No financial arrangements are detailed in this amendment.  The amendment's effectiveness is contingent upon the terms of the referenced Sales Dealer Agreement.

FUSIONPHARMACEUTICALSINC_06_05_2020-EX-1.summary:
This Supply Agreement, effective [Effective Date], is between the Centre for Probe Development and Commercialization (CPDC) and Fusion Pharmaceuticals Inc. (FUSION).  CPDC agrees to supply FUSION with specified radiopharmaceutical products (including Ac-225 FPI-1434 and other undisclosed products) for FUSION's clinical trials.  The agreement operates under a pre-existing Master Services Agreement and Quality Agreement, which govern in case of discrepancies.

CPDC's key obligations include manufacturing the products according to cGMP standards and specified production orders from FUSION,  subject to a US import restriction. FUSION is responsible for IND applications and precursor materials.  Pricing and payment terms are detailed in Schedule 1, including a production standby fee.  FUSION has the right to test batches, and disputes over quality are resolved through independent testing.  Both parties have indemnification obligations, with limitations on liability for CPDC.

The agreement has an initial term of [***] years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated. FUSION may terminate without cause with [***] notice or for cause immediately. CPDC may terminate for non-payment or FUSION insolvency.  Upon termination, CPDC returns FUSION's property, and outstanding orders are cancelled.  The agreement includes clauses on non-solicitation, force majeure, and compliance with law.  CPDC's maximum liability is capped at [***].

CHIPMOSTECHNOLOGIESBERMUDALTD_04_18_2016.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, executed December 11, 2015, is between ChipMOS TECHNOLOGIES INC. (Taiwan) and Tsinghua Unigroup Ltd. (PRC).  The agreement supports a concurrent Share Subscription Agreement where Tsinghua Unigroup, via a controlled subsidiary, will subscribe to 299,252,000 ChipMOS shares.

The main purpose is to establish a three-year strategic alliance to foster cooperation in the semiconductor industry, particularly in LCD driver and wafer bumping services within Mainland China.  Tsinghua Unigroup commits to facilitating ChipMOS's expansion in China, including introductions to suppliers and customers. ChipMOS commits to using the subscription proceeds to enhance R&D, expand production in Taiwan, increase capital in its Shanghai subsidiary, and potentially for mergers and acquisitions.

Key obligations include regular meetings to implement the alliance, mutual cooperation, and adherence to the Share Subscription Agreement.  The agreement is governed by Taiwanese law, with disputes resolved through Hong Kong International Arbitration.  Termination can occur through mutual agreement, material breach (curable within 10 days), or termination of the Share Subscription Agreement.  Confidentiality is a significant provision.  Financial arrangements center around the share subscription, with each party bearing its own expenses related to the agreement.

URSCORPNEW_03_17_2014-EX-99-COOPERATION.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated March 13, 2014, is between JANA Partners LLC ("JANA") and URS Corporation ("URS").  JANA, a significant shareholder (owning 6,745,623 shares), seeks to influence URS's board and strategic direction.  The agreement primarily involves board nominations and corporate governance changes.

URS agrees to expand its board to 14 members, appointing four JANA-nominated directors (the "JANA Nominees").  URS commits to nominating these individuals for re-election at the 2014 Annual Meeting, actively soliciting their election, and not seeking re-election of two existing directors.  URS also agrees to establish a Value Creation Committee, including two JANA Nominees, to explore options for enhancing shareholder value, including a strategic review.  Further, one JANA Nominee will be appointed to the Compensation Committee and two to the CEO Succession Committee.  URS agrees to limitations on acquisitions.

JANA agrees to a standstill, refraining from disparaging statements about URS and committing to vote its shares in favor of URS's nominated directors at the 2014 Annual Meeting.  JANA also agrees to limitations on further share acquisitions and other actions that could influence URS's management or policies.

The agreement includes mutual non-disparagement clauses, remedies for breach (including specific performance and resignation of JANA Nominees), and a severability clause.  The agreement terminates upon the expiration of the Cooperation Period, defined as 30 days before the deadline for shareholder nominations for the 2015 Annual Meeting, or earlier upon material breach by either party.  No

GpaqAcquisitionHoldingsInc_20200123_S-4A.summary:
This Media License Agreement, effective upon Closing of a Merger Agreement, is between the Pro Football Hall of Fame (PFHOF), HOF Village Media Group, LLC (Village Media Company), and HOF Village, LLC (HOFV).  The agreement grants Village Media Company a non-exclusive, limited license to exploit PFHOF's assets (PFHOF Works) to create new works (HOFV Works).

Village Media Company's key obligations include obtaining PFHOF's approval for all uses of PFHOF Works, submitting usage proposals to an Advisory Board, and paying an annual minimum guarantee of $1,250,000 (increasing annually), plus project-specific license fees.  PFHOF retains ownership of PFHOF Works and grants Village Media Company a right of first refusal for certain new PFHOF Works.  Both parties provide mutual indemnities.

The agreement lasts until December 31, 2034, automatically renewing for five-year terms unless terminated with six months' notice.  Termination can also occur for material breach (with a cure period), insolvency, or a change of control at Village Media Company.  The agreement terminates automatically upon termination of a related License Agreement between PFHOF and HOFV.  Ohio law governs, with disputes resolved through arbitration in Canton, Ohio.  Exhibit A lists excluded categories and properties.

SalesforcecomInc_20171122_10-Q_EX-10.1_1.summary:
This Sub-Reseller Agreement, dated November 22, 2017, is between Salesforce.com, Inc. ("Salesforce") and Salesforce.org, a non-profit (the "Reseller").  It amends a pre-existing Reseller Agreement (dated August 1, 2015) to allow the Reseller to sub-resell Salesforce services to a specific customer.  The agreement appoints Salesforce.org as a sub-reseller, granting it resale rights subject to the original Agreement's terms.

Salesforce.org's key obligation is to comply with all terms of the original Reseller Agreement as if it were an original party.  Any breach by Salesforce.org is considered a breach by the Reseller.  Salesforce.org is not a third-party beneficiary of the original agreement.  The original agreement remains in effect, modified only by this sub-reseller agreement.  The agreement is complete and supersedes prior agreements.  It can be executed in multiple counterparts.  No duration or termination clauses are explicitly stated, nor are financial arrangements detailed in this excerpt.  The agreement is void if the parties' signatures are more than ten business days apart.

SLINGERBAGINC_05_27_2020-EX-10.7-CONSULT.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated April 30, 2020, is between Slinger Bag Inc. (Nevada) and Aitan Zacharin (Israel).  It engages Zacharin as a consultant for investor relations, corporate structure, public relations, and commercial development for a three-year term.  Zacharin's key obligations include advising the CEO, facilitating company activities in the specified areas, supervising service providers, and reporting to the Company.  His initial monthly fee is $3,250, increasing to $8,500 on August 20, 2020, subject to annual board review and potential increases.  He also receives 1,250,000 warrants to purchase common stock (Annex A), potential stock bonuses (upon achieving a $100 million company valuation and for extraordinary contributions), and participation in company benefit plans.  Reasonable business expenses are reimbursed.  A confidentiality and non-competition clause is included.

The agreement may be terminated by either party for cause (material breach, gross negligence, etc.) with 30 days' notice, or without cause with 60 (Company) or 120 (Zacharin) days' notice.  Termination without cause by the Company entitles Zacharin to two years' base consulting fee as a lump sum, plus vested stock and options.  Upon termination, accrued fees, expenses, and vested equity are payable.  New York law governs.  The agreement contains standard clauses on waivers, amendments, assignment, severability, and governing law.  Annex A details the warrant terms, including exercise price and restrictions on transfer.

RitterPharmaceuticalsInc_20200313_S-4A_E.summary:
This Distribution and Development Agreement, effective May 1, 2016, is between Sekisui Diagnostics, LLC and its affiliates ("Sekisui") and Qualigen, Inc. and its affiliates ("Qualigen").  The agreement establishes an exclusive distribution arrangement for Qualigen's diagnostic products worldwide (excluding certain Qualigen retained customers).

Sekisui's key obligations include exclusive distribution of Qualigen's products,  marketing and sales efforts (per a Business Plan), and providing up to $6,200,000 in financing for product development (per a Development Plan).  Qualigen's key obligations include supplying products meeting regulatory standards, maintaining necessary approvals, providing technical support, and indemnifying Sekisui for certain liabilities.  Pricing is based on a formula aiming for a specific margin split between the parties, subject to a semi-annual true-up.

Qualigen retains rights to sell directly to specified customers.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on intellectual property rights, confidentiality, and indemnification.  The initial term is five years, automatically renewable annually unless terminated by either party with sufficient notice.  Termination clauses allow for immediate termination upon a sale transaction or bankruptcy, and other grounds for termination are specified for each party, with varying notice periods.  Significant post-termination obligations remain for both parties, including intellectual property ownership and financial settlements.  Delaware law governs.

IGENEBIOTECHNOLOGYINC_05_13_2003-EX-1-JO.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement, dated March 18, 2003, establishes a joint venture between Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. ("T&L") and Igene Biotechnology, Inc. ("Igene") to manufacture and sell Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide (excluding neutraceuticals for direct human consumption).  The venture comprises two entities: a Bermuda LLC (Operating Company) and a UK corporation (Manufacturing Company).

T&L contributes $24,614,000, while Igene contributes its Astaxanthin technology and related assets.  Both parties hold a 50% interest, sharing profits and losses equally.  Key obligations include mutual non-competition within the defined "Field of Agreement,"  provision of specified services (detailed in Support Services Agreements), and joint management through a six-member board (three appointed by each party).  A right of first refusal exists for the sale of either party's interest.

The agreement includes detailed tax allocation provisions,  indemnification clauses protecting T&L from Igene's intellectual property liabilities, and warranties regarding the contributed assets and technology.  The joint venture's duration is indefinite, subject to termination upon an Event of Bankruptcy by either party, mutual agreement, or through a dispute resolution process leading to a buyout or liquidation.  Financial arrangements involve initial capital contributions, profit sharing, and a complex tax distribution scheme.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law.

ENERGYXXILTD_05_08_2015-EX-10.13-Transpo.summary:
This Transportation Agreement, effective March 11, 2015, is between Energy XXI Gulf Coast, Inc. ("Shipper") and Energy XXI USA, Inc. ("Transporter"), both Delaware corporations.  The agreement governs the transportation of Shipper's crude petroleum through Transporter's Grand Isle Gathering System.

Shipper's key obligations include nominating crude for transport, meeting quality specifications (including BS&W limits and pressure restrictions), providing necessary platform equipment and information, and participating in a gravity bank. Transporter's main obligations are to transport the crude and redeliver it at the designated point, less specified losses.  

Key terms include detailed definitions of crude petroleum, force majeure events, and procedures for measurement, testing, and quality control.  The agreement establishes transportation rates (Exhibit A), handling charges for excess impurities, and a gravity bank mechanism to adjust for differing crude qualities.  A lien on the crude secures payment.

The agreement is terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice.  Financial arrangements include payment terms, interest on late payments, and a setoff right for Transporter.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, limitations on liability (excluding indemnification obligations), and a Texas governing law clause with a jury trial waiver.  Disputes are to be resolved in Harris County, Texas courts.

EtonPharmaceuticalsInc_20191114_10-Q_EX-.summary:
This Exclusive License and Product Development Agreement, dated June 12, 2019, is between Eton Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("ETON") and Aucta Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("Aucta").  The agreement grants ETON an exclusive license to develop, manufacture, market, and sell Aucta's products (specified in Exhibit A) within the United States.  Aucta retains rights outside the U.S.

Aucta's key obligations include product development, dossier filings with the FDA, and ongoing regulatory compliance. ETON is responsible for marketing, sales, and distribution within the licensed territory.  ETON must pay Aucta significant upfront licensing fees ($5,000,000), commercial milestones (up to $18,000,000 based on net sales), and royalties (a percentage of net sales, the exact amount redacted).  Detailed net sales calculations are defined, including allowable deductions.  Both parties have indemnification obligations for losses arising from their respective breaches or negligence.

The agreement's term is contingent upon FDA acceptance of the dossier and ETON securing a manufacturing agreement.  Termination clauses exist for material breach, insolvency, and at ETON's discretion (with notice periods).  Post-termination provisions address inventory, royalty payments, and transition services.  Governing law is Delaware.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality, intellectual property, and force majeure clauses.  Specific royalty percentages and other financial details are redacted.

ScansourceInc_20190822_10-K_EX-10.38_117.summary:
This Non-Exclusive Value Added Distributor Agreement, effective January 19, 2007, is between Cisco Systems, Inc. ("Cisco") and ScanSource, Inc. ("ScanSource").  ScanSource is appointed as a non-exclusive distributor of Cisco products and services to resellers within a defined US territory (excluding territories).

The agreement's main purpose is to govern ScanSource's purchase and resale of Cisco products.  Key obligations include ScanSource's commitment to distribute products solely to authorized resellers within the territory, maintain adequate inventory, provide reseller support, and comply with Cisco's branding and sales programs. Cisco's obligations include providing products at specified prices, technical support (detailed in Exhibit B), and warranty service.  Significant terms address intellectual property rights, reseller requirements, payment terms (net [*****] days), price protection, return policies for obsolete or excess inventory, and export compliance.  Confidential information provisions are included.

The agreement's initial term is two years, renewable for up to one year.  Termination clauses allow for termination for convenience ([*****] days' notice), material breach, bankruptcy, or acquisition of a competitor.  Upon termination, outstanding invoices become immediately due, and provisions address return of products and confidential information.  Financial arrangements include payment terms, price protection credits, and inventory return credits, with limitations on Cisco's liability.  The governing law is New York, with jurisdiction in California courts.  Many specific financial terms are redacted as non-material confidential information.

CardlyticsInc_20180112_S-1_EX-10.16_1100.summary:
This Software License, Customization, and Maintenance Agreement (Agreement), effective November 4, 2010, is between Bank of America, N.A. ("Bank of America") and Cardlytics, Inc. ("Supplier").  The agreement governs Supplier's provision of software, customizations, and maintenance services to Bank of America.

**Main Purpose:**  The agreement licenses software to Bank of America, outlines customization services, and details ongoing maintenance and support.  Bank of America retains ownership of customizations.

**Key Obligations:** Supplier provides software, updates, and maintenance services (including 24/7 help desk support and error correction within specified timeframes). Bank of America provides access to its systems (subject to security protocols) and pays fees as outlined in the agreement and orders.  Supplier must maintain an Information Security Program meeting Bank of America's requirements and undergo audits.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement includes detailed definitions (e.g., "Operative," "Error"),  licensing restrictions (no reverse engineering), confidentiality provisions (strict protection of Bank of America's data), indemnification clauses (Supplier indemnifies Bank of America for certain liabilities), and limitation of liability clauses.  Supplier warrants software operability.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement is perpetual unless terminated by Bank of America with 45 days' notice or by either party for material breach (30-day cure period).  Termination clauses specify procedures for returning work product and handling fees.

**Financial Arrangements:**  Fees for software licenses, customizations, and maintenance are detailed in schedules and orders.  Payment terms are specified, including a 2% discount for early payment and provisions for tax reimbursement.  Time and materials

NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16-DISTRIBU.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective March 1, 1996, between Ingram Micro (Distributor) and NETGEAR, Inc. (NETGEAR), governs the distribution of NETGEAR products within the United States.  The agreement initially grants Ingram Micro exclusive distribution rights for one year, contingent on meeting mutually agreed-upon marketing activities (detailed in a separate Exhibit 4).  After the initial term, distribution becomes non-exclusive.

Ingram Micro's key obligations include purchasing products at prices listed in NETGEAR's price list (subject to discounts detailed in Exhibit 1),  promoting and selling to resellers only, providing first-level customer support, and submitting monthly sales and inventory reports.  NETGEAR's obligations include providing second and third-level support, offering warranties (detailed in Section 7), and defending against intellectual property infringement claims (Section 14).  

Important terms include order procedures, payment terms (with late payment charges), product return policies (including RMA requirements), inventory price protection provisions, and limitations on liability.  The agreement includes provisions regarding software licenses, trademark usage, and export compliance.

The agreement has a one-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated by either party with 90 days' written notice or immediately for material breach.  Financial arrangements include payment terms, discounts, and credit for returned products.  Specific financial details (discount percentages, credit amounts, payment deadlines) are redacted in the provided text.  California law governs the agreement.

EcoScienceSolutionsInc_20171117_8-K_EX-1.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, effective November 14, 2017, is between Eco Science Solutions, Inc. ("ESSI") and Stephen Marley ("Talent").  It engages Marley as a spokesperson to endorse ESSI products globally.  Marley's obligations include two production sessions for commercials and acting as a brand ambassador online, with additional sessions available for extra compensation.  ESSI receives rights to use Marley's image and likeness subject to his prior approval.  The agreement is for one year, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.

ESSI's consideration includes 1,000,000 shares of restricted common stock and $10,000 monthly for social media promotion (amount dependent on activity). ESSI covers travel and accommodation expenses for Marley and a representative.  The agreement includes exclusivity clauses preventing Marley from endorsing competing products.  Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for cause with 10 days' notice, subject to specific conditions regarding breach and cure periods.  ESSI provides indemnification for Marley against liabilities arising from ESSI's actions.  Michigan law governs the agreement.  A confidentiality clause restricts Marley from disclosing non-public ESSI information.

AMERICASSHOPPINGMALLINC_12_10_1999-EX-10.summary:
This Site Development and Hosting Agreement, dated August 9, 1999, is between Hanover Direct, Inc. ("HDI"), a New Jersey corporation, and The Deerskin Companies, Inc., a Nevada corporation.  The agreement concerns the design, development, and hosting of a website for Deerskin's apparel and accessories, excluding closeout and Joan Cook Catalog products.

HDI's key obligations include website design, development, hosting, maintenance, and promotion, bearing all associated costs.  Deerskin is responsible for providing website content and processing customer orders.
