HDI will receive 30% of net sales exceeding $11,000 monthly, payable within 30 days, with quarterly reconciliations.

The agreement grants HDI exclusive rights to use the "Deerskin" brand online for Deerskin Products, with exceptions for closeout merchandise.  Deerskin retains artistic and editorial control over the site.  The agreement has a one-year term, automatically renewing annually, terminable by either party with 90 days' written notice.  Termination involves a payment calculation based on the preceding 12 months' net sales, less $800,000, with the remainder split equally.  The agreement includes confidentiality, warranty, and general provisions typical of commercial contracts, governed by New York law.

DataCallTechnologies_20060918_SB-2A_EX-1.summary: This Content Licensing Agreement, dated September 18, 2006, is between Data Call Technologies, Inc. ("Licensor") and PLAN_B MEDIA AG ("plan_b").  The agreement licenses specified content (detailed in Appendix 2) to plan_b for commercial distribution to end-users worldwide.  Licensor's obligations include initial content delivery within 14 days and providing content in plan_b's specified formats.  plan_b must distribute the content, market it using reasonable commercial efforts, and provide quarterly reports on downloads to Licensor, who retains audit rights.  Licensor retains all intellectual property rights but grants plan_b a license for distribution and marketing.  Licensor warrants against intellectual property infringement and indemnifies plan_b.  plan_b pays Licensor a revenue share (Appendix 2 specifies percentages).  The initial term is 24 months, automatically extending by six months unless terminated with 60 days' written notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach, with a 30-day cure period.  A three-month sell-off period follows termination.  The agreement is governed by US law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York City.  Payments are in USD.

JINGWEIINTERNATIONALLTD_10_04_2007-EX-10.summary: This Intellectual Property Agreement, dated February 8, 2007, is between JingWei HengTong Technology (ShenZhen) Co., Ltd. (Party A) and ShenZhen JingWei Communication Co., Ltd. (Party B), both PRC entities.  Party A licenses non-exclusively its intellectual property (specified in Appendix 1, including software copyrights and consumer databases) to Party B for use within the PRC, solely for Party B's business.  Party B agrees to maintain confidentiality, protect Party A's IP rights, and not sublicense.  Party B pays an annual license fee of RMB 1,000,000 (payable by December 31st each year), subject to Party A's right to waive or adjust the fee.  The agreement lasts five years, renewable by mutual written consent, but is terminable by either party for material breach (30-day cure period) or by Party A with 30 days' written notice.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration by CIETAC in Beijing.  The agreement is governed by PRC law.  Assignment or sublicensing requires Party A's prior written consent.

FEDERATEDGOVERNMENTINCOMESECURITIESINC_0.summary:
This Services Agreement, effective January 1, 2004, is between Federated Investment Management Company ("Adviser") and Federated Advisory Services Company ("FASC"), both Delaware statutory trusts.  The agreement outlines FASC's provision of services (performance attribution and administration/risk management) to the Adviser, supporting the Adviser's management of various investment accounts.

FASC's key obligations include providing specified services (detailed in Exhibit A) and maintaining compliant books and records (per Section 31(a) of the 1940 Act).  The Adviser's main obligations are to pay FASC fees (calculated per Exhibit B, based on a cost-plus model with a 10% margin, and payable monthly in arrears) and indemnify FASC against certain liabilities.  FASC's liability is limited, except for willful misconduct or gross negligence.

The agreement's duration is indefinite, terminable by either party with 60 days' written notice. However, for services to registered investment companies under the 1940 Act,  annual Board approval is required for continuation, and termination can be initiated by the Board or a majority vote of outstanding voting securities with 60 days' notice.  Amendments require mutual written consent and, for registered investment companies, Board and shareholder approval as per Section 15(a)(2) of the 1940 Act.  Pennsylvania law governs the agreement.

AMBASSADOREYEWEARGROUPINC_11_17_1997-EX-.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated August 24, 1995, is between Kathy Ireland, Inc. (KI Inc.), The Sterling/Winters Co. (SW), and Diplomat Ambassador Eyewear Group (Diplomat).  It grants Diplomat an exclusive worldwide license to use Kathy Ireland's name and likeness for the manufacture, sale, and distribution of specified eyewear products (sunglasses, eyeglasses, etc.) until January 30, 2000, unless terminated earlier.  Termination can occur if Kmart doesn't carry KI eyewear before January 30, 1997, or due to Diplomat's breach of material obligations.

Diplomat's key obligations include paying royalties (a percentage of net wholesale volume, subject to minimum guarantees), providing sales reports, maintaining quality standards, obtaining product liability insurance, and securing KI Inc.'s approval for marketing materials.  KI Inc. is obligated to endorse the products and make specified appearances.  SW produces promotional materials.

Financial terms include a royalty percentage of net wholesale sales, with minimum annual royalty payments.  Diplomat must also pay SW for photo and video shoots.  The contract includes detailed provisions regarding intellectual property rights, indemnification, and dispute resolution.  California law governs the agreement.  The contract also specifies conditions for termination and the disposition of inventory upon termination.

MRSFIELDSORIGINALCOOKIESINC_01_29_1998-E.summary:
This Franchise Agreement, dated January 29, 1998, is between Pretzel Time, Inc. (Franchisor) and a Franchisee (individual, corporation, or partnership).  The agreement grants the Franchisee the right to operate a single Pretzel Time Unit (store, kiosk, or cart) at a specified location for 20 years, renewable for a further 5 years under specific conditions.

The Franchisee's key obligations include adhering to Pretzel Time's system and standards (detailed in the Operations Manual), paying initial and ongoing fees (including a $25,000 franchise fee, 7% royalty on net revenues, and 1% advertising fund fee), maintaining insurance, and complying with all laws and regulations.  The Franchisor's main obligations include providing training, assistance, and advertising materials.

Important terms include the Franchisor's right to approve locations, suppliers, and marketing materials;  the Franchisee's non-compete obligation;  Pretzel Time's right to audit Franchisee's records; and provisions for transfer of the franchise (subject to Franchisor approval and fees).

The agreement can be terminated by either party for various reasons, including default (with a 30-day or immediate notice period depending on the nature of the default), repeated breaches, or non-compliance with the Operations Manual.  Upon termination, the Franchisor has the right to purchase the Franchisee's assets.  The agreement specifies governing law (Pennsylvania) and a waiver of jury trial.  Financial arrangements include detailed fee structures, payment methods (electronic funds transfer), and interest charges for late payments.

PalmerSquareCapitalBdcInc_20200116_10-12.summary:
This Trademark License Agreement, effective [date], is between Palmer Square Capital Management LLC (Licensor) and Palmer Square Capital BDC Inc. (Licensee), with Palmer Square BDC Advisor LLC as a third-party beneficiary.  The agreement grants Licensee a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the "Palmer Square" trademarks solely as part of its corporate name and in marketing services provided by the Investment Advisor.

Licensee's key obligations include maintaining business quality standards, complying with all applicable laws, and notifying Licensor of any trademark infringement or claims.  Licensor retains the right to use the trademarks and to defend against any infringement claims.  The agreement is terminable by either party with 60 days' notice, or immediately by Licensor upon a third-party claim, or if the Investment Advisor ceases to advise Licensee.  Upon termination, Licensee must remove "Palmer Square" from its name and publicly disassociate from Licensor for 24 months.  The agreement is governed by New York law.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed beyond the royalty-free nature of the license.  The agreement contains standard clauses regarding assignment, waivers, severability, and the entire agreement.

LUCIDINC_04_15_2011-EX-10.9-DISTRIBUTOR.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated [date], is between Lucid Inc. (New York corporation) and [Distributor Name].  Lucid appoints [Distributor Name] as its exclusive distributor for specified VivaScope models within a defined territory ([Territory details]).  The agreement's purpose is to establish a distribution channel for Lucid's products within the medical and research sectors.

Key obligations include the Distributor's commitment to actively promote and sell Lucid products, provide customer training and installation, and meet minimum purchase obligations (quantities to be agreed upon annually).  Lucid's obligations include product supply, providing sales and technical support, and supplying marketing materials.  The Distributor must maintain a dedicated sales professional and provide Lucid with sales data and competitive intelligence.

The agreement is for three years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination can occur for breach of contract, bankruptcy, change of control, or with 90-day written notice.  Financial terms include a 30% discount off Lucid's published price list and payment via 100% irrevocable letter of credit within 90 days of order placement.  Lucid's liability is limited; consequential damages are excluded except for death or personal injury.  New York law governs the agreement.  The agreement includes clauses regarding intellectual property rights, incident reporting, and traceability.

UsioInc_20040428_SB-2_EX-10.11_1723988_E.summary:
This Affiliate Office Agreement, dated April 28, 2004, is between Network 1 Financial, Inc. ("Network 1"), a Virginia corporation, and Payment Data Systems, Inc. ("Affiliate"), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement governs Affiliate's role in marketing Network 1's payment processing services and recruiting independent contractors ("Contractors") for Network 1.

Affiliate's key obligations include marketing Network 1's services, recruiting and vetting Contractors (subject to Network 1's approval), establishing and maintaining local offices for Contractors, and submitting all Merchant Agreements to Network 1 for approval.  Affiliate is responsible for all Local Office expenses. Network 1 retains the right to accept or reject Contractors and inspect the Local Offices.

Network 1's main obligations involve reviewing and approving Merchant Agreements, paying Affiliate fees (detailed in Exhibit A, based on successful Merchant applications and revenue share), and providing equipment and software to Affiliate at specified prices.  Loss allocation is detailed in Exhibit C.

The agreement includes a right of first refusal for Network 1 should Affiliate receive a bona fide offer to purchase its revenue or the company.  A significant term is the 180-day initial term (extending to 3 years if Network 1's ISO application is not approved), automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' notice or upon Affiliate entering a processing and ISO sponsorship agreement with Network 1 and Harris Bank.  Termination clauses cover default, insolvency, and cause (including fraud or regulatory violations).  Upon termination,  Affiliate's fee payments may continue under certain conditions, but cease immediately if terminated for cause.  The agreement specifies independent contractor status for

EmmisCommunicationsCorp_20191125_8-K_EX-.summary: This Local Programming and Marketing Agreement, dated November 25, 2019, is between MediaCo Holding Inc. ("Licensee") and WBLS-WLIB LLC ("Programmer").  The agreement concerns the rebroadcast of WLIB-AM's programming on WQHT-FM's HD2 channel.  Programmer is obligated to provide 24/7 simulcast of its programming (excluding 6-8 AM Sundays) to Licensee, maintaining technical quality standards and securing necessary music licenses.  Licensee is responsible for broadcasting the received programming on the HD2 channel, subject to its right to reject content violating public interest, FCC rules, or third-party rights.  Licensee retains operational control of the station.  No payment is exchanged between the parties.  Programmer indemnifies Licensee against liabilities arising from the broadcast.  The agreement runs until December 31, 2022, or earlier termination by either party (with notice) or mutual agreement, or upon termination of a specified lease.  Termination clauses include a 15-day cure period for material breaches.  The agreement is governed by Indiana law.

ENTERTAINMENTGAMINGASIAINC_02_15_2005-EX.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective January 21, 2005, is between VendingData Corporation (Nevada, "Vendor") and Technical Casino Supplies Ltd (England, "Distributor").  It grants Distributor exclusive rights to market, sell, and service VendingData's casino shuffling machines (the "Products") outside the US, Caribbean, and US-based cruise ships for a five-year initial term, automatically renewable for three-year periods.

Distributor's key obligations include purchasing a specified quantity of Products, actively promoting them, and providing sales reports.  Vendor's obligations include providing marketing materials, samples, and spare parts.  A significant purchase commitment is outlined in Section 5.1, with specific quantities and pricing for various shuffler models.  Vendor retains ownership of intellectual property and future inventions.

Termination can occur with 90 days' written notice, by mutual agreement, for material breach, or upon a change of control of Vendor or transfer of a product line to a third party.  In the latter two scenarios, Distributor receives monthly compensation for lost profits for the remainder of the term (up to 24 months).  Financial arrangements include specific pricing for Products, payment terms (180 days or 30 days post-sale), and a 25% commission to Vendor for sales leads.  The agreement includes standard indemnification and confidentiality clauses, and is governed by Ontario, Canada law, with disputes resolved through arbitration there.

Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. - Master Deve.contract_id: Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. - Master Development and Manufacturing Agreement
Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. - Master Deve.contract_title: Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. - Master Development and Manufacturing Agreement
Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. - Master Deve.summary:
This Master Development and Manufacturing Agreement (February 13, 2018), between Magenta Therapeutics, Inc. ("Magenta") and Bachem Americas, Inc. ("Bachem"), governs Bachem's provision of development and manufacturing services for Magenta's pharmaceutical products.  The agreement outlines Bachem's obligations to manufacture products according to Project Plans (detailed statements of work), adhering to Good Manufacturing Practices (GMPs) and all Applicable Laws (including FDA regulations).  Magenta's key obligations include payment of fees detailed in each Project Plan, acceptance/rejection of products within specified timelines, and cooperation in regulatory submissions.

Bachem warrants its authority, the quality of its services and products, and compliance with intellectual property rights.  Magenta retains ownership of its pre-existing and developed intellectual property, while Bachem retains its own, granting Magenta licenses as needed.  A detailed confidentiality clause governs the handling of confidential information.  Indemnification clauses allocate liability for product defects and other issues.

The agreement has a five-year initial term, renewable annually, with termination clauses for material breach, insolvency, or by Magenta with notice.  Financial arrangements are project-specific, with fees and payment schedules outlined in each Project Plan.  Dispute resolution involves good-faith negotiation followed by binding arbitration in New York.  The agreement is governed by New York law.

GRIDIRONBIONUTRIENTS,INC_02_05_2020-EX-1.summary: This Supply Agreement, dated January 26-27, 2020, is between EWSD 1, LLC d/b/a Shi Farms (Shi Farms), a Delaware LLC, and Gridiron BioNutrients, Inc., a Nevada corporation (Gridiron).  The agreement concerns the sale and purchase of 30,000 lbs of hemp biomass with a minimum 6% CBD/CBDA content and less than 3% THC.  Shi Farms is obligated to deliver the biomass, meeting specified quality standards (free from contaminants), to a Gridiron-designated processor.  Gridiron is obligated to pay $150,000 upon execution of the agreement.  A Certificate of Analysis (COA) from a third-party lab is required, with Gridiron retaining the right to conduct independent testing.  Shi Farms will quarantine the product post-payment until delivery.  Either party may terminate before delivery.  Gridiron indemnifies Shi Farms against claims arising from Gridiron's actions.  The agreement is governed by Colorado law and prohibits assignment or amendment without written consent.  Confidential information must be returned upon termination.

PapaJohnsInternationalInc_20190617_8-K_E.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, effective March 15, 2019, is between Papa John's Marketing Fund, Inc. and Papa John's International, Inc. (collectively, "Papa John's") and ABG-Shaq, LLC ("ABG"), representing Shaquille O'Neal ("Celebrity").  The agreement grants Papa John's worldwide rights to use O'Neal's name, image, and likeness ("Celebrity Endorsement") to advertise and promote its products for a three-year term (renewable for one year).

ABG's key obligations include providing O'Neal's services for specified appearances, social media posts, and public relations activities.  Papa John's must obtain ABG's approval for all uses of the Celebrity Endorsement.  All materials created remain Papa John's property, except for the Celebrity Endorsement, which remains ABG's.

Papa John's agrees to pay ABG $1,250,000, $1,375,000, and $1,500,000 in yearly installments, plus additional payments for union-covered services.  Papa John's also grants ABG a royalty-free license to use certain materials.  Papa John's further agrees to grant O'Neal 87,136 restricted stock units, vesting over three years.

The agreement includes detailed provisions regarding approval processes, brand restrictions, indemnification (mutual), insurance requirements (Papa John's to maintain liability insurance naming ABG as an additional insured), and a limitation of liability for ABG.  Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach or specific

SUMMAFOURINC_06_19_1998-EX-10.3-SOFTWARE.summary:
This Software License and Maintenance Agreement, effective August 4, 1997, is between D2 Technologies, Inc. ("D2") and Summa Four Inc. ("Summa Four").  The agreement licenses D2's voice processing software technology (Licensed Technology) to Summa Four for incorporation into its product (Licensee Product).  Summa Four pays a development license fee and a runtime license fee (per copy distributed to end users), with a potential buyout option.  A maintenance fee is payable annually after a one-year warranty period, potentially credited based on runtime license fee revenue.

Summa Four obtains a perpetual, non-exclusive, worldwide license for the Licensed Technology in object code, with a limited license to the source code for maintenance under specified conditions (e.g., D2 insolvency).  D2 warrants the Licensed Technology's performance and agrees to correct defects according to a prioritized schedule, with late fee penalties for non-compliance.  Summa Four must provide reports and allow audits of its distribution records.  Both parties make standard representations and warranties, and D2 provides indemnification for infringement claims.  Liability is limited.  The agreement includes confidentiality provisions for both the software and the agreement itself, and addresses export restrictions.  Summa Four can terminate for convenience with 90 days' notice; D2 can terminate for material breach after 30 days' notice.  Specified articles survive termination.  New York law governs, with Delaware venue.

MACROGENICSINC_08_02_2013-EX-10-COLLABOR.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, effective June 2010, is between MacroGenics, Inc. (a Delaware corporation) and Green Cross Corp. (a Korean company).  The agreement's main purpose is to collaborate on the development and commercialization of MacroGenics' anti-HER2 antibody, MGAH22, exclusively in South Korea.

MacroGenics grants Green Cross an exclusive license for MGAH22 in South Korea.  Key obligations include joint development (Phases I & II), with MacroGenics responsible for manufacturing clinical and commercial supplies and Green Cross responsible for South Korean clinical trials, regulatory filings (post-Phase I), and commercialization.  Green Cross will bear all commercialization costs.  A Joint Steering Committee (JSC) and Joint Development Committee (JDC) oversee the collaboration.

Important terms include commercially reasonable efforts, detailed definitions of various terms (e.g., Regulatory Approval, Net Sales), confidentiality provisions, and intellectual property ownership and licensing arrangements.  Green Cross is obligated to pay MacroGenics an upfront fee, milestone payments tied to development and sales, and royalties on Net Sales of MGAH22 and competing products.  Upstream royalties are also addressed.

The agreement's term extends until the end of the Royalty Term (defined by several factors including patent expiry), unless terminated earlier.  Termination clauses exist for change of control of either party, patent validity challenges, material breach, and force majeure.  Detailed indemnification provisions are included.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration.

GSVINC_05_15_1998-EX-10-SPONSORSHIP AGRE.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated March 31, 1998, is between Excite, Inc. (Excite) and CyberShop (Client).  The agreement outlines a multi-faceted sponsorship and advertising campaign for CyberShop on Excite's online network (Excite Network), including the Excite and WebCrawler sites.

Excite's key obligations include providing various promotional placements (links and banner ads) across different Excite channels, guaranteeing a minimum number of impressions and clickthroughs for the first year.  Specific placement locations and frequencies are detailed for each channel (Shopping, Lifestyle, Entertainment, WebCrawler Home & Family). Excite is responsible for hosting and maintaining the Excite Network and providing monthly performance reports.  They also agree to give CyberShop more prominent placement than competitors.

CyberShop's main obligation is payment of tiered sponsorship and advertising fees for the first and second years, plus a variable revenue share based on sales generated from Excite-referred traffic.  Payment schedules and auditing provisions are included.

The agreement's term is at least two years, contingent upon Excite achieving specified impression and clickthrough goals.  Early termination clauses exist if Excite fails to meet clickthrough targets or if either party materially breaches the contract.  The agreement includes standard clauses on confidentiality, indemnity, limitation of liability, dispute resolution (mediation and arbitration), trademark usage, and governing law (New York).  Redacted portions of the contract relate to specific financial figures (fees and revenue share percentages).

MorganStanleyDirectLendingFund_20191119_.summary:
This Trademark License Agreement, effective [Date], is between Morgan Stanley Investment Management Inc. ("Licensor") and Morgan Stanley Direct Lending Fund ("Licensee").  The agreement grants Licensee a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use the "Morgan Stanley" brand solely for permitted activities (public filings, regulatory communications, marketing, and press releases related to investment advisory services provided by Licensor).  Licensee may sublicense to wholly-owned subsidiaries with Licensor's consent.

Licensee must maintain Licensor's brand standards, obtain prior written approval for all brand uses, comply with all applicable laws, and indemnify Licensor against any liabilities arising from Licensee's breach or brand misuse.  Licensor retains ownership of the brand and can terminate the agreement immediately for breach or convenience.  The agreement is perpetual unless terminated as specified.  No financial arrangements beyond indemnification are detailed.  New York law governs, and jury trial is waived.  Specific performance is available to Licensor for brand-damaging breaches.  Sections regarding ownership, indemnification, and miscellaneous provisions survive termination.

ELANDIAINTERNATIONALINC_04_25_2007-EX-10.summary: This Network Management Outsourcing Agreement, dated May 2004, is between Bank of South Pacific Ltd (BSP) and Datec (PNG) Ltd.  Its purpose is to outsource BSP's network management services to Datec for five years, renewable for another five.  Datec's key obligations include WAN management, help desk support, incident management,  MACs (Moves, Adds, Changes), and adherence to service level agreements (SLAs) detailed in Schedule B.  BSP retains asset ownership (Schedule A).  Material breaches by Datec allow BSP to terminate.  BSP can also terminate for convenience with six months' notice, paying a termination fee (Schedule C).  Datec must indemnify BSP against certain liabilities.  Pricing involves a base fee (Schedule C), subject to CPI adjustments (capped at 10% annually), plus pass-through expenses.  Service level failures result in rebates (Schedule C). Dispute resolution involves negotiation, expert determination (non-binding), or mediation.  Governing law is Papua New Guinea.  Significant confidentiality provisions are included.

PareteumCorp_20081001_8-K_EX-99.1_265480.summary:
This Mobile Virtual Network Enabler (MVNE) Hosting Agreement, dated September 18, 2008, is between Elephant Talk Communication Holding AG (Switzerland) and T-Mobile Netherlands B.V. (Netherlands).  Elephant Talk will operate as an MVNE, providing mobile services to its customers using T-Mobile's network.

T-Mobile's key obligations include providing hosting services (detailed in Appendix 1), ensuring network connectivity, and supporting lawful intercept requests.  Elephant Talk's key obligations involve timely payment for services (detailed in Appendix 2), providing quarterly traffic forecasts (Appendix 4), maintaining its own customer support, and complying with T-Mobile's network usage policies.  Significant restrictions are placed on the types of customers Elephant Talk can serve.

The agreement includes detailed service level agreements (Appendix 6), data protection clauses, and intellectual property rights provisions.  Liability is limited, with exceptions for willful misconduct and gross negligence.  The initial term is [redacted] from the Commercial Launch Date, with a [redacted] termination notice period.  Financial arrangements include upfront development costs and monthly charges based on usage.  Dispute resolution involves internal escalation, followed by court proceedings in The Hague.  The agreement is governed by Dutch law.  Numerous appendices detail specific aspects of the agreement, including technical specifications and billing procedures.

PhasebioPharmaceuticalsInc_20200330_10-K.summary:
This Co-Development Agreement, effective January 9, 2020, is between PhaseBio Pharmaceuticals Inc. ("PB") and SFJ Pharmaceuticals X, Ltd. ("SFJ").  It governs the co-development of PB2452 (the "Product") to reverse the effects of Ticagrelor.

The agreement outlines PB's responsibility for US and European clinical trials (with SFJ providing operational support in Europe), while SFJ leads trials in designated Asian countries (China, Japan, Hong Kong).  Both parties share responsibilities via Joint Steering (JSC), Development (JDC), and Commercialization Committees (JCC).  Key obligations include adherence to protocols, timelines (Exhibit I), and Applicable Laws; data management and reporting; and regulatory filings.  SFJ's obligations include funding up to $120 million in Development Costs (Article 4), with a detailed payment schedule contingent on milestones (e.g., Successful Phase 3 Interim Analysis).  PB agrees to pay SFJ substantial milestone payments upon Regulatory Approvals (Article 6), subject to potential buy-out options (Section 6.7).  Intellectual property ownership is largely defined, with Trial Inventions belonging to PB and the Trial Data Package initially to SFJ, but transferring to PB upon certain events (Article 11).  SFJ receives a warrant for PB common stock (Article 8).

The agreement includes extensive definitions (Article 1), indemnification clauses (Article 12), and detailed termination provisions (Article 14) covering breach, Material Adverse Events, failure to obtain Regulatory Approval, bankruptcy, and Change of Control.  The Term expires upon the last Approval Payment, unless terminated

USASYNTHETICFUELCORP_10_21_2010-EX-10.10.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 21, 2006, is between Oxbow Carbon & Minerals LLC ("Oxbow") and Global Energy, Inc. ("Global Energy").  The agreement establishes a strategic alliance focused on petroleum coke gasification projects.

Key obligations include Oxbow becoming Global Energy's preferred petroleum coke and coal supplier, and Global Energy becoming Oxbow's preferred gasification technology supplier and project operator.  Specifically regarding Global Energy's Lima Project, Oxbow commits to a contingent investment (amount redacted) for a fuel supply management agreement, receiving a percentage of project cash flow and revenues from Global Energy's affiliate, GEC.  Oxbow also secures a GEC board seat.  The fuel management agreement details Oxbow's responsibilities and commission structure.  Under certain conditions, Oxbow can assume development and management of the Lima Project.

Global Energy sells 25,000 shares to Oxbow for $5,000,000 ($200/share).  Extensive mutual representations and warranties are included, focusing on corporate authority, financial standing, and compliance.  The agreement includes price protection for Oxbow's shares.

The agreement has an initial five-year term, automatically renewing for another five years, unless terminated for material breach or bankruptcy.  The agreement specifies governing law (New York), remedies for breach, and a no-partnership clause.  A detailed definition of terms is provided.  Consequential damages are excluded.

KUBIENT,INC_07_02_2020-EX-10.14-MASTER S.summary:
This Exhibit B, dated March 26, 2020, amends the Master Services Agreement (dated February 5, 2020) between Kubient, Inc. ("Kubient") and The Associated Press ("AP").  The agreement outlines a revenue-sharing partnership where Kubient provides advertising and revenue consultation services to AP for its digital properties (websites, apps, etc.).

Kubient's key obligations include providing advertising consultation and introducing AP to third-party advertisers.  AP's key obligations include a non-circumvention clause preventing AP from working with third-parties introduced by Kubient for one year post-termination without Kubient's consent and compensation, and a non-solicitation clause preventing AP from hiring Kubient's employees for one year post-termination.

Revenue sharing is detailed in Schedule 1, varying by advertising type (programmatic, video, direct deals, etc.) and exceeding or falling below specified monthly revenue thresholds.  Below threshold, Kubient receives a guaranteed draw (expiring September 1, 2020); above threshold, revenue is split 50/50.  Reconciliation and payment are net 30 days after the end of each month.  Specific revenue exclusions exist for certain pre-existing AP relationships.

The agreement lacks explicit duration or termination clauses beyond the implied continuation from the Master Services Agreement.  Schedule 1 supersedes conflicting terms in Exhibit A of the Master Services Agreement regarding fees and payment terms.

EdietsComInc_20001030_10QSB_EX-10.4_2606.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective May 22, 2000, is between Women.com Networks, Inc. ("Women.com") and eDiets.com, Inc. ("eDiets").  The agreement establishes a co-branded "Diet Center" within Women.com's website, featuring eDiets' diet and counseling content.

eDiets grants Women.com a non-exclusive license to use its content and provides the Diet Center content, maintaining it at its own expense.  Women.com hosts the Diet Center's gateway page, provides advertising space to eDiets (with specific impression guarantees detailed in Exhibit B), and promotes the Diet Center across its channels.  eDiets is obligated to deliver content meeting Women.com's editorial guidelines.  Both parties agree to exclusivity provisions regarding competing companies.

Women.com receives a monthly fee (Exhibit C), potentially adjusted based on advertising delivery shortfalls (Section 3.1).  The agreement includes detailed provisions on trademark usage, confidentiality, warranties, indemnification, limitations of liability, and data ownership.

The initial term is two years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 60 days' notice.  Termination can also occur for material breach after a 30-day cure period (Section 10.2).  Sections regarding confidentiality, intellectual property, and dispute resolution survive termination.  Jurisdiction and governing law are California.

WESTERN COPPER - NON-COMPETITION AGREEME.summary:
This Non-Competition Agreement and Right of First Offer, dated May 3, 2006, is between Glamis Gold Ltd. and Western Copper Corporation, both British Columbia corporations.  It stems from an Arrangement Agreement where Western Copper acquired assets from Western Silver, with Glamis becoming Western Silver's sole shareholder.

The agreement's main purpose is to prevent Western Copper from competing with Glamis in Zacatecas, Mexico (and a 20km radius around Western Silver's properties) for two years.  Glamis grants Western Copper a right of first offer on any Mexican mineral properties Glamis acquired under the Arrangement Agreement, for a 30-day period following notice of intended disposition (cash sale or abandonment).  For cash sales, good faith negotiations are required; for abandonment, transfer is at no cost to Western Copper except for transfer costs.

Both parties agree that breaches are irreparable, entitling the non-breaching party to injunctive relief.  The agreement includes standard clauses on reasonable restrictions, cumulative remedies, and termination rights for insolvency or cessation of normal business operations.  The agreement is governed by British Columbia law.  No specific financial arrangements beyond the right of first offer are detailed.  The agreement may be terminated by mutual written consent.

LECLANCHÉ S.A. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AND.contract_id: LECLANCHÉ S.A. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
LECLANCHÉ S.A. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AND.contract_title: LECLANCHÉ S.A. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
LECLANCHÉ S.A. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AND.summary:
This Joint Development and Marketing Agreement, effective April 6, 2014, is between Leclanché S.A. (Switzerland) and Oak Ridge Energy Technologies, Inc. (USA).  Its purpose is to collaboratively evaluate and enter the US market for Leclanché's lithium-ion titanate battery products and services.

Oak Ridge's key obligations include market evaluation (Phase 1, completed by May 31, 2014), sales and marketing, identifying commercial opportunities, and providing first-level technical support.  Leclanché's obligations include supplying products and services, providing training and documentation, and supporting Oak Ridge's commercial efforts.  Pricing is determined after Phase 1, with case-by-case pricing for complex projects and services.  Payment terms are generally 30 days net from invoice, with potential for progress payments.

The agreement includes provisions on confidentiality, non-solicitation, intellectual property (no IP transfer, royalty-free licenses for joint development), and assignment (requiring written consent).  A standstill agreement prevents trading on each other's securities.

The initial term is one year, renewable by mutual consent. Termination may occur due to default, insolvency, change of control, or unremedied breach (30-day cure period).  Termination does not affect certain provisions (confidentiality, intellectual property, etc.).  Swiss law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in Zurich courts.

HEMISPHERX - Sales, Marketing, Distribut.contract_id: HEMISPHERX - Sales, Marketing, Distribution, and Supply Agreement
HEMISPHERX - Sales, Marketing, Distribut.contract_title: HEMISPHERX - Sales, Marketing, Distribution, and Supply Agreement
HEMISPHERX - Sales, Marketing, Distribut.summary:
This Sales, Marketing, Distribution, and Supply Agreement (SMDSA) is between Hemispherx Biopharma, Inc. (Hemispherx), a US biopharmaceutical company, and Scientific Products Pharmaceutical Co. LTD (SCIEN), a Saudi Arabian pharmaceutical company.  The agreement grants SCIEN exclusive rights to sell, market, and distribute Hemispherx's Interferon alfa-n3 (human leukocyte derived) in the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) states, contingent on a successful MERS clinical trial in Saudi Arabia.

Hemispherx's key obligations include supplying the product at a discounted "Transfer Price" and providing marketing materials and support.  SCIEN's primary responsibilities are to develop a business plan, market the product (including Direct Access/EAP and Regulatory Agency-Approved sales), obtain regulatory approvals in each GCC state, and submit sales reports.  SCIEN must purchase a minimum quantity of product within specified timelines.  The SMDSA also includes a Quality Agreement outlining quality control and reporting procedures.

Key terms include the Transfer Price (redacted), Sales Price (determined by SCIEN), and a minimum 6-month product expiry.  The agreement's duration is three years, automatically renewable for two years unless terminated. Termination clauses cover breaches of contract (e.g., failure to meet sales targets), insolvency, and uncured defaults.  Financial arrangements involve payment by SCIEN within 75 days of receipt of goods (except for the initial order), with price renegotiation annually after the second year.  Hemispherx retains ownership of intellectual property, with SCIEN receiving a license for use within the GCC.  Delaware law governs the agreement, with disputes settled through London arbitration.

CardlyticsInc_20180112_S-1_EX-10.16_1100.summary: This Maintenance Agreement, between Bank of America (BOA) and Cardlytics, governs software licensing and maintenance for Cardlytics' Offer Placement System (OPS) Version 3.0.  The agreement incorporates terms from a broader General Services Agreement.  Cardlytics licenses the software to BOA, including source code delivery under specific conditions tied to user numbers and performance metrics (detailed in Schedule B of the General Services Agreement).  These conditions trigger payment obligations from BOA, calculated based on revenue share after three years or upon reaching 10,000,000 users, whichever is later.  Initial maintenance is free, followed by a 12-month renewable term with fees payable in increments (specifics redacted).  BOA can terminate maintenance at any time without penalty and reinstate it without fees.  The agreement specifies delivery, installation, and support timelines (with installation support handled separately), training, and contact persons.  The duration is initially 120 days for warranty and acceptance, with maintenance renewing annually unless terminated by BOA.  Financial details beyond the revenue-share model and maintenance fees are redacted.  The agreement also covers source code location and other logistical details.

TomOnlineInc_20060501_20-F_EX-4.46_74970.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective August 22, 2005, involves Skype Communications S.A., Skype Technologies S.A., TOM Online (BVI) Limited, TOM Online Inc., and Tel-Online Limited.  Its purpose is to co-brand and co-market a customized version of Skype software (Company-Skype Branded Application) in the People's Republic of China (PRC).

Skype's key obligations include designing and producing the application, providing updates, and offering customer support. TOM Online (BVI) Limited and Tel-Online Limited are responsible for marketing, distribution, and first-level customer support in the PRC.  They will also develop and maintain a co-branded website (skype.tom.com).  Both parties grant each other licenses to use their respective intellectual property for the co-branded application and website.

Key terms include definitions of "Adjusted Net Revenue," "Gross Revenue," and "Direct Expenses," which govern the 50/50 revenue-sharing arrangement between Skype and Tel-Online Limited (or TOM Online (BVI) Limited under certain conditions).  Quarterly statements and audits are required.

The agreement has a five-year initial term, automatically extending for three years unless terminated. Termination clauses exist for material breach or insolvency.  A non-compete clause restricts the parties from similar ventures in the PRC for five years, subject to exceptions and early termination conditions based on customer growth or service provision.  The agreement is governed by English law, with disputes resolved in English courts.  Tom Online Inc. guarantees TOM Online (BVI) Limited's performance, and Skype Technologies S.A. guarantees Skype's performance.  Comprehensive indemnification

MphaseTechnologiesInc_20030911_10-K_EX-1.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, dated January 21, 2003, is between Lucent Technologies Inc. ("Lucent") and mPhase Technologies Inc. ("mPhase").  The agreement grants mPhase a license to use Lucent's logo and slogan ("Lucent Co-Branding Logo") on its multi-access product packaging and marketing materials.

mPhase's key obligations include adhering to strict guidelines (Schedule B) regarding logo usage, maintaining product quality comparable to current standards, and promptly notifying Lucent of any unauthorized third-party use.  Lucent retains the right to terminate the agreement if mPhase's use adversely affects Lucent's marks or if mPhase's product quality declines.  mPhase acquires no rights to the logo or marks.

The agreement is for one year, renewable annually with Lucent's written consent, and terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice.  Termination requires mPhase to cease logo use on new products, but not existing ones.  The agreement specifies that New York law governs and excludes liability for consequential damages.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed.  mPhase cannot assign the agreement without Lucent's consent.

CERES,INC_01_25_2012-EX-10.20-Collaborat.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, dated April 1, 2007, is between the Institute of Grassland and Environmental Research (IGER), later Aberystwyth University (AU), and Ceres, Inc.  Its purpose is to establish a joint research program on Miscanthus and related species for bioenergy production.  The agreement outlines specific research projects detailed in separate schedules.

Key obligations include joint research activities, with each party responsible for its own costs unless otherwise specified.  IGER (AU) grants Ceres exclusive access to its Miscanthus improvement activities, subject to exceptions for specific research collaborations with UK companies and not-for-profit entities.  Intellectual property rights are divided into Joint, Ceres, and IGER (AU) IP, with specific provisions for ownership, application, and commercialization.  Ceres holds exclusive worldwide commercialization rights for Joint IP and other research results, subject to reasonable remuneration to IGER (AU).  Confidentiality and publication clauses are included, along with provisions for dispute resolution via arbitration under ICC rules.

The agreement has a 15-year term, subject to early termination clauses based on material breach, cessation of activities, bankruptcy, or other specified events.  Financial arrangements involve quarterly invoicing by IGER (AU) for Ceres-funded activities, with payment within 30 days.  Royalties are payable to IGER (AU) based on Ceres' commercialization of Joint IP, with rates detailed in separate license agreements.  The agreement includes detailed warranties and disclaimers of liability.  Subsequent amendments modify specific terms, including the duration of the agreement and financial arrangements.

INTERSECTENT,INC_05_11_2020-EX-10.1-SUPP.summary: This Supply Agreement, dated January 20, 2020, is between Hovione Inter AG (Switzerland) and Intersect ENT, Inc. (Delaware).  The agreement concerns the supply of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (API) by Hovione to Intersect for use in Intersect's finished drug product.  Hovione's key obligations include manufacturing and supplying the API according to specified product specifications (Exhibit B), adhering to cGMPs, maintaining a US DMF, and cooperating with Intersect on regulatory matters.  Intersect's main obligations are to purchase a specified portion of its annual API needs from Hovione, provide forecasts, and pay for the API within 30 days of invoice.  The agreement includes detailed quality control provisions, including inspection rights for Intersect and a process for handling non-conforming API.  Both parties provide warranties regarding their capacity to perform and the quality of their respective contributions.  A Quality Agreement (separate document) governs quality assurance aspects.  Confidentiality and indemnification clauses are included, limiting liability (except for confidentiality breaches).  The agreement's term is five years, subject to termination for material breach (90-day cure period) or insolvency.  Pricing is detailed in Exhibit C, with delivery terms specified as DDP Menlo Park, CA (Incoterms 2010).  The governing law is New York State law, with jurisdiction in Geneva, Switzerland.  A buyout clause exists in case of acquisition of either party.

BABCOCK_WILCOXENTERPRISES,INC_08_04_2015.contract_id: BABCOCK_WILCOXENTERPRISES,INC_08_04_2015-EX-10.17-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT between THE BABCOCK _ WILCOX COMPANY and BABCOCK _ WILCOX ENTERPRISES, INC.
BABCOCK_WILCOXENTERPRISES,INC_08_04_2015.contract_title: BABCOCK_WILCOXENTERPRISES,INC_08_04_2015-EX-10.17-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT between THE BABCOCK _ WILCOX COMPANY and BABCOCK _ WILCOX ENTERPRISES, INC.
BABCOCK_WILCOXENTERPRISES,INC_08_04_2015.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated June 26, 2015, is between The Babcock & Wilcox Company ("RemainCo") and Babcock & Wilcox Enterprises, Inc. ("SpinCo"), two Delaware corporations, following SpinCo's separation from RemainCo.  The IPA governs the allocation and licensing of intellectual property (IP) between the parties, aiming to facilitate a clean business split.

Key obligations include IP assignment (detailed in Schedules 2.4(a) and 2.4(b)),  cross-licensing of shared know-how, software (including "Foundational Software"), and "Shared Library Materials" (defined in Article IV and Schedule 4.1), with specific exclusive and non-exclusive rights granted based on defined "Core Fields."  The agreement addresses trademark usage, particularly "House Marks," with a transition period for RemainCo's use of SpinCo marks (Article III).  Both parties covenant not to sue each other for infringement outside their respective Core Fields (Article V, Section 5.10).  The IPA also outlines procedures for handling potential IP ownership disputes (Article II, Section 2.4(c)) and third-party infringement (Article VIII).  

The agreement is perpetual for most licenses, subject to specific provisions regarding allocation of Shared Library Materials and sublicensing restrictions (Article V, Section 5.6).  No financial arrangements beyond cost-sharing for maintaining Shared Library Materials are explicitly detailed.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law.

TRANSPHORM,INC_02_14_2020-EX-10.12(1)-JO.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement (JVA), dated May 23, 2017, establishes a joint venture between Aizu Fujitsu Semiconductor Limited (AFSL), Fujitsu Semiconductor Limited (FSL), and Transphorm, Inc. (TPH) (through its wholly-owned subsidiary TPH-A) to operate Aizu Fujitsu Semiconductor Wafer Solution Limited (AFSW), a 150mm wafer foundry.  The JVA governs the management, operation, and eventual ownership of AFSW.

Key obligations include joint management via a five-member board (3 nominated by AFSL, 2 by TPH-A),  provision of support services by both parties, and allocation of cash requirements.  Significant decisions require unanimous board approval.  TPH-A is responsible for maintaining/procuring GaN equipment.  The agreement includes put and call options for AFSL/FSL and TPH-A, respectively, exercisable between February 1, 2020, and 180 days thereafter, with purchase price based on Net Book Value.

Important terms include confidentiality, indemnification, and dispute resolution via Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre (HKIAC) arbitration.  The JVA may be terminated before the effective date by mutual consent or upon material breach.  Post-effective date termination is possible via mutual consent, upon a single shareholder remaining, exercise of put/call options, change of control, or material breach.  Financial arrangements involve allocation of cash requirements, compensation for wafer purchase shortfalls, and the put/call option pricing mechanisms.  The agreement's duration is contingent upon the exercise of the put/call options or termination clauses.

EuromediaHoldingsCorp_20070215_10SB12G_E.summary:
This Video-on-Demand (VOD) Content License Agreement, effective July 11, 2006, is between Rogers Cable Communications Inc. ("Rogers") and EuroMedia Holdings Corp. ("EuroMedia").  EuroMedia licenses Rogers a non-exclusive right to distribute EuroMedia's entertainment programming ("Licensed Programs") in Canada via Rogers' VOD service ("ROD Service").

EuroMedia's key obligations include providing a program list with sufficient notice of additions and deletions, ensuring closed captioning, encoding programs, delivering masters, providing promotional materials, and maintaining necessary rights and clearances.  Rogers' key obligations include selecting programs for distribution, paying license fees, and adhering to technical standards.

License fees are 50% of retail revenues, less specified deductions (marketing allowances, production fund contributions, copyright royalties, and Rogers' costs).  The initial term is until June 30, 2010, renewable for two years at Rogers' option.  Either party can terminate with 60 days' notice, or immediately for material breach.  Rogers has a unilateral termination right with 60 days' notice.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, limitations of liability, confidentiality provisions, and a most-favored-nations clause.  Governing law is Ontario, Canada.

Sonos, Inc. - Manufacturing Agreement.summary:
This Manufacturing Agreement, effective September 4, 2014, is between Sonos, Inc. (Sonos) and Inventec Appliances Corporation (IAC).  It's a comprehensive OEM manufacturing agreement where IAC manufactures Sonos products according to Statements of Work (SOWs).

**Key Obligations:** Sonos provides designs, specifications, and forecasts; IAC manufactures, tests, and ships products to Sonos-designated locations, managing component procurement (Sonos-sourced and IAC-sourced) and complying with quality plans and regulatory requirements.  IAC also provides repair services and may provide extended warranties.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.  Confidential information is protected.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement defines numerous terms related to manufacturing processes, components, quality control, and delivery.  A pricing formula (Exhibit G) determines product costs, subject to quarterly updates and Purchase Price Variance (PPV) adjustments.  Lead times, cancellation guidelines (Exhibit C), and NPI processes (Exhibit D) are detailed.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement has a three-year initial term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination clauses include termination for cause (insolvency, material breach) and termination for convenience (180-day notice).  Specific survival clauses outline provisions that remain in effect post-termination.

**Financial Arrangements:** Sonos pays IAC for manufactured products based on the pricing formula, with payment terms specified.  The agreement addresses cost reductions, PPV settlements, and liability limitations (excluding certain breaches).  IAC maintains component buffer inventory, and procedures for handling excess components are defined.  The agreement also includes provisions for the ownership of Sonos Tools.  Dispute resolution is through binding arbitration in Los Angeles, California,

ASHWORTHINC_01_29_1999-EX-10.(D)-PROMOTI.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, effective June 1, 1998, is between Ashworth, Inc. ("Ashworth"), James W. Nantz III ("Nantz"), and Nantz Communications, Inc. ("Nantz Communications").  It's a three-year endorsement and promotional services agreement.

Ashworth retains Nantz and Nantz Communications to endorse Ashworth products, wear them during broadcasts, participate in promotional events (photography, speaking engagements, store appearances), assist in finding new accounts and celebrities, and help create special events.  Nantz also agrees to serve on Ashworth's Board of Directors and become a full-time employee.

Nantz Communications receives an annual consulting fee of $30,000, additional fees for extra store appearances, expense reimbursement, and Nantz receives Ashworth apparel (up to $12,000 wholesale annually) and stock options to purchase up to 120,000 shares at $6/share, exercisable over time.

The agreement includes exclusivity clauses preventing Nantz from endorsing competing brands.  Termination clauses allow for termination by mutual consent, Nantz's disability or death, misconduct, felony conviction, insolvency, or material breach (with cure periods).  California law governs, and disputes are subject to arbitration.  Ashworth provides significant insurance coverage for Nantz.

VAPOTHERM, INC. - Manufacturing and Supp.contract_id: VAPOTHERM, INC. - Manufacturing and Supply Agreement
VAPOTHERM, INC. - Manufacturing and Supp.contract_title: VAPOTHERM, INC. - Manufacturing and Supply Agreement
VAPOTHERM, INC. - Manufacturing and Supp.summary:
This Manufacturing and Supply Agreement, dated January 1, 2013, is between Vapotherm, Inc. (a Maryland corporation) and Medica S.p.A. (an Italian company).  The agreement outlines Medica's obligation to manufacture and supply vapor transfer cartridges ("Cartridges") to Vapotherm for use in Vapotherm's medical gas therapy systems.  

Key obligations include Medica's manufacturing of Cartridges based on Vapotherm's specifications (Exhibit D), adhering to cGMP, and maintaining specified inventory levels. Vapotherm is obligated to purchase Cartridges according to rolling forecasts (Exhibit A-2) and purchase orders (Exhibit B), paying within specified terms.  The agreement details quality control measures, including rejection rights for non-conforming Cartridges and a Joint Review Committee.  Both parties have indemnification obligations related to product liability and intellectual property.

The agreement's initial term is three years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with specified notice.  Termination clauses include breaches of material obligations, inaccurate representations, insolvency events, and failure to deliver Cartridges.  Financial arrangements include a price schedule (Exhibit A-1) subject to renegotiation, payment terms, and liability limitations.  Dispute resolution is through mediation and arbitration (American Arbitration Association).  The governing law is New York.  Significant confidential information, including pricing and specific quantities, has been redacted.

PLAYAHOTELS_RESORTSNV_03_14_2017-EX-10.2.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 14, 2016, is between Hyatt Franchising Latin America, L.L.C. ("Hyatt") and Playa Hotels & Resorts, B.V. ("Playa").  It replaces a Master Development Agreement and amends existing franchise agreements for several Hyatt Ziva/Zilara resorts.  The agreement's main purpose is to establish a right of first offer for development opportunities in a defined market area (Mexico, Costa Rica, Dominican Republic, Jamaica, Panama) for a specified term (ending December 31, 2018).

Key obligations include providing each other with a right of first refusal on development opportunities for Hyatt All-Inclusive Resorts.  If one party receives a third-party offer, it must notify the other, allowing them to negotiate management or franchise rights.  The agreement specifies a ten-business-day response period for the right of first offer and a sixty-day period for property acquisition.  Financial arrangements are not explicitly detailed, but involve negotiations for management and franchise agreements.

Dispute resolution is through ICC arbitration in New York, with the Federal Arbitration Act governing.  The agreement includes standard clauses on choice of law (Illinois, except for franchise regulations), entire agreement, representations and warranties, severability, and confidentiality regarding dispute resolution.  The agreement contains a waiver of non-compensatory damages.  Termination is implicit upon the expiration of the Development Term (December 31, 2018).

LIGHTBRIDGECORP_11_23_2015-EX-10.26-STRA.summary: This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective August 16, 2012, is between Lightbridge Corporation (Nevada) and Lloyds Register FNMA (Abu Dhabi).  Its purpose is to facilitate joint pursuit of nuclear consulting and strategic advisory projects in the UAE.  Lloyds acts as prime contractor, with Lightbridge having a right of first refusal for subcontracting up to 25% of project fees.  Both parties actively seek projects, jointly plan their execution, and negotiate subcontracts.  Neither party is obligated to pursue any specific project.  The agreement emphasizes compliance with all applicable laws, including the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, and includes detailed confidentiality provisions regarding the protection and return of Confidential Information.  The agreement lasts five years or until terminated by either party with 30 days' written notice, unless a party is in default.  Financial arrangements are project-specific, with Lightbridge's compensation determined through negotiated subcontracts.  English law governs the agreement.  No partnership or agency relationship is created.

XLITECHNOLOGIES,INC_12_02_2015-EX-10.02-.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 1, 2015, is between Bosch International, LLC ("Client") and Bosch Technologies, LLC ("Bosch").  The agreement establishes a distribution relationship for Bosch's "Printed LightSheets" (Nano Printed Lights) product.

Bosch grants Client exclusive distribution rights in the US and Canada (excluding US Virgin Islands) to specified automotive industry clients, requiring Bosch's written approval for each.  Bosch retains reserved rights for its existing clients.  Client is responsible for all marketing, sales, and distribution costs within the territory, while Bosch handles manufacturing and initial delivery.  Pricing is confidential but subject to minimum and maximum limits.

Client agrees to indemnify Bosch against third-party claims related to the product.  Strict confidentiality provisions protect Bosch's proprietary information regarding the product.  The agreement supersedes prior agreements.  Financial details, beyond cost based on square inch and negotiated market pricing, are confidential.  No duration or termination clause is explicitly stated.

HYPERIONSOFTWARECORP_09_28_1994-EX-10.47.summary:
This Exclusive Distributor Agreement, dated April 15, 1994, is between IMRS Operations Inc. d/b/a IMRS Inc. ("Developer") and Delteq Pte Ltd ("Distributor").  The agreement grants Distributor exclusive rights to market and distribute Developer's computer software ("Products") in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Brunei.

Distributor's key obligations include promoting and selling the Products, using a provided End-User License Agreement (Schedule B), maintaining good customer relations, and providing dedicated personnel.  Distributor is responsible for all End-User support and training, while Developer retains control over product upgrades, pricing, and source code.  Developer provides replacement media for defective delivery media within 90 days.

Financial terms stipulate that Distributor adheres to Developer's pricing (Schedule C), submits monthly sales reports (Schedule D), and pays royalties based on a tiered system (40% for revenue under $1M, 50% for revenue above $1M annually).  License renewal and maintenance fees are split 50/50.  Payment is due within 30 days, with a 1.5% late fee.

The agreement's initial term is one year, automatically renewing for two-year periods unless terminated.  Either party may terminate with 90 days' notice. Developer may terminate immediately for non-payment, breach of confidentiality (Section 4), or other material breaches.  Sections 4 (Confidentiality and Proprietary Rights), 5 (Limited Warranty), and 9 (Indemnification) survive termination.  Connecticut law governs, with jurisdiction in Stamford, Connecticut.  A non-compete clause restricts Distributor

BUFFALOWILDWINGSINC_06_05_1998-EX-10.3-F.summary:
This Franchise Agreement, dated June 5, 1998, is between BW-3 Franchise Systems, Inc. (Franchisor) and [Franchisee Name] (Franchisee).  It grants Franchisee a license to operate a Buffalo Wild Wings restaurant using the Franchisor's system and trademarks within a designated area.

**Main Purpose:**  Granting a franchise to operate a Buffalo Wild Wings restaurant.

**Key Obligations:** Franchisee must operate the restaurant according to Franchisor's standards, contribute to an advertising fund (3% of gross sales), maintain specified insurance, and adhere to quality and performance standards.  Franchisor provides training and operational assistance.  Franchisee agrees to non-compete covenants for 2 years post-termination within a 10-mile radius.

**Important Terms:**  Franchisee pays a non-refundable initial franchise fee and a monthly continuing fee (5% of gross sales).  Franchisor retains control over trademarks, advertising, and system modifications.  Specific requirements exist for restaurant location, construction, and operations.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on confidentiality, accounting, and dispute resolution (mediation).

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement lasts 10 years, renewable for two 5-year terms, subject to conditions including compliance with all terms and standards.  Termination clauses cover various defaults by the Franchisee, including non-payment, operational failures, and breaches of confidentiality.  Franchisor has the right to terminate for material breaches.

**Financial Arrangements:**  Initial franchise fee, monthly continuing fee (5% of gross sales), advertising fund contributions (3% of gross sales), and potential additional fees for training and operational assistance

ReynoldsConsumerProductsInc_20200121_S-1.summary:
This Transition Services Agreement (TSA), dated [•] 2020, is between Reynolds Group Holdings Inc. ("RGHI") and Reynolds Consumer Products Inc. ("RCP"),  following RCP's initial public offering and separation from RGHI.  The TSA facilitates this separation by outlining the provision of transitional services between the parties and their affiliates.

RGHI will provide RCP with transition services (Exhibit A), primarily IT services (hosting, support, etc.) and various business support functions (HR, finance, procurement, legal, etc.), while RCP will provide RGHI with reverse transition services (Exhibit B), largely mirroring the support provided to RCP but on a smaller scale.  Both parties are obligated to maintain service quality similar to pre-separation levels (Article III), cooperate on data migration (Section 2.1(c)), and adhere to security regulations (Article IV).  

Key terms include defined service levels, detailed fee structures (Article V, Exhibits A & B),  including pass-through costs and hourly rates for certain services.  Invoice disputes have a defined resolution process (Section 5.7).  The agreement includes indemnification clauses (Article IX) and limitations of liability.

The term of each service is generally 12 months from its commencement date (Article VI), with provisions for 30-day termination for convenience (Section 6.2) and termination for material breach (Section 6.3).  Specific services (e.g., IT migration) have different termination provisions.  The agreement specifies governing law (Illinois) and jurisdiction (Lake County, Illinois), and includes standard clauses on confidentiality, intellectual property, and assignment.  Finally, the agreement addresses the handling of letters

GWG HOLDINGS, INC. - ORDERLY MARKETING A.contract_id: GWG HOLDINGS, INC. - ORDERLY MARKETING AGREEMENT
GWG HOLDINGS, INC. - ORDERLY MARKETING A.contract_title: GWG HOLDINGS, INC. - ORDERLY MARKETING AGREEMENT
GWG HOLDINGS, INC. - ORDERLY MARKETING A.summary:
This Orderly Marketing Agreement (OMA), dated December 27, 2018, governs the sale of GWG Holdings, Inc. ("GWG") common stock held by multiple Seller Trusts (represented by Trust Advisors) and Delaware Trust Company as Trustee.  The OMA's purpose is to facilitate the orderly marketing and resale of these shares through one or more bulge bracket investment banks ("Bank").

GWG's key obligations include:  (1) cooperating with the Trust Advisors and the Bank in marketing and selling the shares; (2) providing a list of top institutional holders; (3) assisting in preparing marketing materials; and (4) potentially appointing a second bank as joint book-running manager. The Trust Advisors are responsible for directing the Trustee, overseeing the sale process, and ensuring pro-rata distribution among the Seller Trusts.  The Bank's role, detailed in a separate Engagement Letter, involves advising on sales strategy, preparing prospectus supplements, and potentially acting as lead joint-book-running manager for a best-efforts distribution (not an underwriting obligation).  The Bank's fees are the responsibility of Seller Trust affiliates.

The OMA lasts for one year or until all shares are sold, whichever comes first.  It may be terminated by mutual agreement or by the Trust Advisors at their sole discretion. The Bank can terminate its engagement with 45 days' notice, triggering potential OMA termination or replacement of the Bank under certain conditions.  The OMA is governed by New York law, and jury trial is waived.  No personal liability is assumed by Delaware Trust Company or the Trust Advisors; liability is limited to Seller Trust assets.  The agreement includes customary representations, warranties, covenants,

BLACKROCKMUNIHOLDINGSINVESTMENTQUALITYFU.summary: This Joint Filing Agreement, dated April 7, 2020, between Bank of America Corporation and Banc of America Preferred Funding Corporation, governs the joint filing of reports required under Sections 13 and 16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  The agreement mandates that both parties jointly file all required reports with the SEC and relevant exchanges, including amendments and exhibits.  Each party is obligated to cooperate in the filing, furnishing, and incorporation by reference of this agreement as an exhibit to their respective filings.  No specific financial arrangements are detailed.  The agreement remains in effect until revoked in writing by either party, with the revocation only applying to the revoking party.  The agreement's primary purpose is to streamline and coordinate regulatory filings, ensuring compliance with SEC regulations.

ALLISONTRANSMISSIONHOLDINGSINC_12_15_201.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated December 12, 2014, is between Allison Transmission Holdings, Inc. ("Company"), the ValueAct Group (including ValueAct Capital Management, L.P., and others listed in Schedule A), and Gregory P. Spivy (ValueAct Designee).  The ValueAct Group, owning approximately 10.77% of the Company's stock, seeks to place Spivy on the Company's Board.

The agreement's main purpose is to secure Spivy's appointment as a Class I director until the 2016 annual meeting, contingent on a background check and no fiduciary duty breach.  In return, the ValueAct Group agrees to a standstill provision, restricting actions like proxy solicitations, acquisitions exceeding 12% ownership, and certain public statements regarding the Company, unless specifically requested by the Company.  They also commit to voting for the Board's nominees at the 2015 annual meeting.  Spivy must meet all director independence standards.

The agreement terminates early if the ValueAct Group's ownership falls below 7.5%, Spivy violates the agreement, or his ValueAct employment ends.  Sections 1(d), 5, and 7-16 survive termination.  Spivy receives standard director compensation.  The agreement is governed by Delaware law, with exclusive jurisdiction in Delaware courts, and includes mutual representations and warranties regarding authority and the accuracy of ownership disclosures.  A confidentiality agreement (Exhibit B) governs the disclosure of confidential information.

SPOKHOLDINGS,INC_06_19_2020-EX-10.1-COOP.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated June 18, 2020, is between Spôk Holdings, Inc. ("Company") and several White Hat entities (collectively, "White Hat Parties").  The agreement addresses a situation where White Hat Parties hold a significant stake (319,708 shares) in the Company's common stock.

The main purpose is to resolve a prior director nomination dispute.  White Hat Parties withdraw their nominations for three directors in exchange for the Company appointing Brett Shockley as a new independent director and supporting his election at the 2020 Annual Meeting.  White Hat Parties commit to voting their shares in accordance with the Board's recommendations on most proposals at the 2020 Annual Meeting, with exceptions for certain proposals and the right to vote independently on other matters.  They also agree to refrain from certain actions (e.g., calling special meetings, requesting stockholder lists) for a specified period.

Key obligations include White Hat Parties' voting commitments and their agreement to not take certain actions for a period ending 30 days before the nomination deadline for the 2021 Annual Meeting. The Company commits to appointing Shockley, supporting his election, issuing a press release, and reimbursing White Hat Parties' expenses (up to $55,000).

The agreement is governed by Delaware law, with specific jurisdiction and venue provisions.  It includes standard clauses on specific performance, waivers, assignment, third-party beneficiaries, and severability. The agreement automatically terminates 30 days before the advance notice period for the 2021 Annual Meeting, unless terminated earlier for breach.

WARNINGMANAGEMENTSERVICESINC_12_10_1999-.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated May 31, 1999, is between Famous Fixins, Inc. ("Company") and Pey Dirt, Inc. ("Pey Dirt"), representing Peyton Manning.  The agreement grants Company exclusive rights to use Manning's name and likeness to advertise its cold breakfast cereals ("Products") in Indiana and Tennessee, and on its e-commerce site, for one year (May 31, 1999 – May 31, 2000).

Company's key obligations include aggressive product promotion within the designated territory, preventing sales outside it, and obtaining Pey Dirt's approval for all uses of Manning's image.  Pey Dirt grants a non-exclusive right for limited merchandise use on product packaging.  Use in premium programs or multimedia (except the e-commerce site) is prohibited.

Financial terms include an 8.5% royalty on product sales (minimum $2.50/box), an option for Pey Dirt to purchase Company stock, and 50% of gross profits from approved back-panel merchandise.  Pey Dirt also receives reimbursement for Manning's services if utilized.  Payment terms and audit rights are specified.

The agreement may be terminated by Pey Dirt if products aren't sufficiently distributed by October 1, 1999, or for Company's breach of contract (with cure periods for the first default only).  Post-termination, Company's use of Manning's image ceases, except for a 90-day grace period for existing inventory under specific conditions.  Governing law is Tennessee.  Disputes are subject to arbitration in Nashville, Tennessee.  The agreement includes standard indemnity

LinkPlusCorp_20050802_8-K_EX-10_3240252_.summary:
This Affiliate Agreement, dated July 15, 2005, is between Link Plus Corporation ("LKPL") and Axiometric, LLC.  Its primary purpose is to establish a collaborative relationship for developing and marketing Automatic Meter Reading (AMR) product suites.  LKPL provides Axiometric with free office space in its Maryland facility.

Key obligations include joint development of AMR products (specifically a water meter, with joint ownership of new IP),  defined marketing and sales territories (Axiometric for US excluding Datamatic, LKPL for international and Datamatic), and manufacturing (LKPL having first right of refusal).  Financial arrangements involve revenue sharing based on Gross and Net Proceeds, varying by product and customer (Datamatic receives special pricing and revenue split).  Payments are due quarterly, with late payment penalties and audit rights for both parties.

The agreement includes indemnification clauses protecting LKPL from Axiometric's actions related to office space use.  The agreement is perpetual unless mutually terminated in writing.  Dispute resolution occurs in Maryland courts, without a jury, with a one-year statute of limitations (two years for non-payment).  Assignment requires written consent.  Maryland law governs.

RMRGROUPINC_01_22_2020-EX-99.1-JOINT FIL.summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement (JFA), dated January 22, 2020, between ABP Trust, represented by Adam D. Portnoy, President, and an unnamed second party (implied by the plural "undersigned"), governs the filing of Schedule 13G/A and any amendments (including those on Schedule 13D) concerning The RMR Group Inc.'s Class A Common Stock.  The agreement's primary purpose is to establish a joint filing arrangement under Rule 13d-1(k) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Both parties are obligated to jointly file the Schedule 13G/A and all subsequent amendments.  The agreement specifies that filings will be made on behalf of each party.  No specific duration is stated; the agreement implicitly continues until the relevant reporting obligations cease.  No financial arrangements are detailed within the provided excerpt.  The agreement is concise and lacks provisions for dispute resolution or termination.

SMITHELECTRICVEHICLESCORP_04_04_2012-EX-.summary:
This Fleet Maintenance Agreement, dated October 13, 2005, is between Dairy Crest Limited ("DCL") and SEV Group Limited ("SEV").  It outlines SEV's provision of maintenance services for DCL's vehicle fleet.  SEV's key obligations include providing scheduled maintenance, repairs (excluding specified exceptions), breakdown response, and reporting. DCL's obligations include operating vehicles responsibly, reporting defects promptly, and providing safe working conditions for SEV personnel.

The agreement defines "Maintenance Services" and "Excepted Services" comprehensively, outlining charges for both.  Maintenance Charges are calculated monthly based on fleet size and a per-vehicle rate, subject to annual Retail Price Index adjustments. Additional Charges apply for Excepted Services and overtime work.  Specific terms address employee transfers (under TUPE regulations), liability limitations, and insurance requirements for SEV.

The initial contract term is five years, renewable or terminable with six months' notice.  Early termination clauses exist for breaches of contract, multiple VOSA notices, or insolvency.  Financial arrangements include monthly pre-paid Maintenance Charges, Additional Charges for extra services, and provisions for reimbursement of redundancy costs under specific circumstances.  The contract is governed by English law.  Significant portions of the contract, particularly schedules detailing rates and employee information, are redacted due to confidentiality requests.

CHINARECYCLINGENERGYCORP_11_14_2013-EX-1.summary:
This July 2013 Cooperation Agreement concerns a Coke Dry Quenching (CDQ) and CDQ waste heat power generation project between Xi'an Zhonghong New Energy Technology Co., Ltd. (Party A), a subsidiary of a NASDAQ-listed company, and Boxing County Chengli Gas Supply Co., Ltd. (Party B), a coal coke producer.  The agreement outlines a Build-Operate (BO) model where Party A invests in, constructs, and operates the 25MW CDQ system and power generation plant at Party B's facility.

Party A's key obligations include design, procurement, construction, operation, and maintenance of the CDQ system. Party B's main obligations are to provide land, coal coke feedstock, necessary permits, and a performance guarantee letter ensuring electricity purchase.  Party B pays Party A an energy saving service fee based on electricity generated, with tiered pricing (RMB 0.40/kWh up to 800 million kWh, then RMB 0.20/kWh).  The fee calculation considers an 8,000-hour annual operating time, with adjustments for deviations due to either party's fault.

The agreement's term is 20 years, terminable upon main equipment failure or end-of-life.  Specific clauses address payment penalties for late payments by Party B, liability for project delays, and dispute resolution through negotiation or local court action.  Intellectual property rights reside with Party A, while ownership of the CDQ system transfers to Party B upon termination.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on raw material consumption, metering, and environmental compliance.  A technical appendix and performance guarantee letter are integral

KUBIENT,INC_07_02_2020-EX-10.14-MASTER S.summary: This Master Services Agreement (MSA), dated February 5, 2020, is between Kubient Inc. ("Kubient") and The Associated Press ("AP").  The agreement outlines Kubient's provision of ad serving technology and services to AP to increase AP's advertising revenue.  Kubient grants AP a limited license to use its Auction Platform to sell advertising inventory.
