Key obligations include Kubient's provision of services (detailed in separate exhibits) and AP's cooperation.  AP is responsible for all content and compliance with applicable laws.  Revenue sharing is detailed in exhibits, with Kubient responsible for advertiser contracting and sequential payment to AP within seven days of receipt.  Kubient warrants the non-infringement of third-party rights and the security of data.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification.  The initial term is one year, automatically renewing unless terminated with 90 days' notice (after the initial term) or 30 days' notice for material breach.  The agreement includes limitations of liability, an arbitration clause, and a confidentiality provision lasting one year post-disclosure.  Governing law is Delaware, with jurisdiction in New York courts.

NeoformaInc_19991202_S-1A_EX-10.26_52245.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective November 19, 1999, is between VerticalNet, Inc. (VerticalNet) and Neoforma.com, Inc. (Neoforma).  The agreement aims to co-brand and cross-promote each other's online marketplaces for medical and laboratory products, along with career and training resources.

Key obligations include reciprocal listing of products (Medical Products by Neoforma on VerticalNet sites, and Laboratory Products by VerticalNet on Neoforma sites), co-branded career and training centers, and reciprocal linking and advertising.  VerticalNet is responsible for developing and maintaining the co-branded sites.  Neoforma provides qualified leads for job listings.

Significant terms define various product categories, revenue sharing based on transaction fees and advertising revenue, and exclusive licensing for listed products.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on advertising sales, co-marketing activities, intellectual property rights, and confidentiality.

The Initial Term is two years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' notice.  Termination for cause is also permitted.

Financial arrangements involve a one-time development fee from Neoforma to VerticalNet, promotional fees, commissions on net revenue from product listings and advertising, and revenue sharing from the co-branded career and training centers.  Dispute resolution is through negotiation and binding arbitration in Philadelphia, PA.  The agreement contains standard disclaimers of warranties and limitations of liability.

AULAMERICANUNITTRUST_04_24_2020-EX-99.8..summary:
This Servicing Agreement, dated 2020, is between Nationwide Fund Management LLC ("Nationwide"), acting for Nationwide Mutual Funds (the "Trust"), and American United Life Insurance Company and OneAmerica Securities, Inc. (collectively, the "Servicing Agent").  The agreement outlines the Servicing Agent's provision of administrative support services to customers owning shares in Nationwide Mutual Funds (listed in Appendix A).

The Servicing Agent's key obligations include processing payments, issuing statements, handling customer inquiries, and facilitating share purchases, exchanges, and redemptions, adhering to guidelines in Appendix B and Section 22(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940.  They are an independent contractor, acting as agent only for order acceptance.  The Servicing Agent must maintain robust internal controls, including anti-money laundering and privacy programs complying with relevant laws (e.g., Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, USA Patriot Act, BSA).  They must also provide shareholder information upon request.

Nationwide compensates the Servicing Agent based on the average daily net assets of shares serviced, payable monthly.  The fee rate is subject to change.  Both parties have mutual indemnification obligations.

The agreement is effective upon Nationwide's receipt of a fully executed copy.  Termination can occur by the Trust's Board of Trustees, a majority of a Fund's voting securities, or either party for material breach or with 90-day notice.  The indemnification clauses survive termination.  Governing law is Delaware.

VIOLINMEMORYINC_12_12_2012-EX-10.14-SPON.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, effective June 13, 2012, is between Forty Niners SC Stadium Company LLC ("Forty Niners SC") and Violin Memory, Inc. ("Sponsor").  It's a ten-year sponsorship agreement granting Violin Memory exclusive sponsorship rights within the "flash data storage and/or video surveillance products" category at the new San Francisco 49ers stadium.

Forty Niners SC is obligated to provide Sponsor with extensive branding, signage (both interior and exterior), digital advertising, game-day activations, hospitality (including a luxury suite), media assets (TV, radio, print, online), and various marketing and community relations opportunities detailed in Schedule 1.  Sponsor's key obligations include paying a $4,000,000 annual fee (with a $500,000 non-refundable deposit), covering the costs of producing its marketing materials, and adhering to usage guidelines for the 49ers' trademarks.  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses and a dispute resolution process via arbitration in Santa Clara, California.

The agreement's term is ten (10) years, renewable by mutual written agreement.  Termination clauses include default by either party, insolvency, harmful behavior, and the specific scenario of a stadium naming rights deal with a competitor (allowing for immediate termination and a pro-rated refund).  The agreement also addresses the potential delay in stadium opening, outlining remedies for Sponsor in case of delays impacting sponsorship benefits.  Intellectual property rights are carefully delineated, with both parties retaining ownership of their respective marks, subject to the granted licenses.  The agreement is governed by California law.

RaeSystemsInc_20001114_10-Q_EX-10.57_263.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective November 5, 1999, is between Nettaxi Online Communities, Inc. ("Nettaxi") and Solutions Media, Inc. dba SpinRecords.com ("SpinRecords").  The agreement outlines a co-branding arrangement for their respective websites, involving mutual branding and marketing efforts.

Nettaxi and SpinRecords grant each other non-exclusive, revocable, royalty-free licenses to use each other's brand features.  Key obligations include co-branding designated web pages,  joint marketing efforts to maximize website traffic (detailed in a Statement of Work, Exhibit C), and maintaining accurate records of impressions and advertising revenue.  Both parties represent and warrant their authority to enter the agreement and own their respective brand features.  Nettaxi's services are provided "as is," with limitations of liability.

SpinRecords will pay Nettaxi a percentage of advertising revenue (50% of revenue exceeding a $6.50 CPM threshold, calculated based on impressions from co-branded pages) and a 5% commission on gross sales from paying customers acquired through the co-branded site.  Payments are due quarterly.  Both parties have audit rights regarding revenue calculations.

The agreement has a one-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Either party may terminate for convenience with 60 days' notice or immediately for cause (insolvency, change of control, material breach). Sections 6 (Confidentiality) and 7 (Indemnification) survive termination.  California law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in Santa Clara County Superior Court or the Northern District of California.

QBIOMEDINC_04_08_2020-EX-99.1-JOINT FILI.summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement (dated April 8, 2020), concerning Q Biomed, Inc. equity securities, involves numerous parties: YA II PN, Ltd.; YA Global Investments II (U.S.), Ltd.; Yorkville Advisors Global, LP; Yorkville Advisors Global II, LLC; YAII GP, LP; Yorkville Advisors GP, LLC; D-Beta One EQ, Ltd.; D-Beta One Blocker EQ, Ltd.; D-Beta One Growth and Opportunity Fund Offshore, LP; D-Beta One GP, LP; D-Beta One GP, LLC; Delta Beta Advisors, LP; Delta Beta Advisors, LLC; and Matthew Beckman.  The agreement's purpose is to facilitate the joint filing of a Schedule 13G statement (and any amendments) with the SEC, complying with Rule 13d-1(k).

Each signatory is obligated to ensure the timely filing of amendments and the accuracy of their own information within the filing, but not responsible for the accuracy of others' information.  The agreement itself is to be included as an exhibit to the Schedule 13G filing.  No specific duration or termination clause is explicitly stated; the agreement is presumably operative until the relevant reporting obligations under Rule 13d-1(k) are fulfilled.  No financial arrangements are detailed.  The agreement can be executed in multiple counterparts.

ZogenixInc_20190509_10-Q_EX-10.2_1166331.summary:
This Distributorship Agreement, effective March 18, 2019, is between Zogenix Inc. (Zogenix) and Nippon Shinyaku Company, Ltd. (Distributor) for the exclusive distribution of Zogenix's Fintepla® in Japan (Territory) for treating Dravet and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes.  Zogenix retains manufacturing rights and supplies the product to Distributor under a separate Supply Agreement.

Distributor's key obligations include exclusive marketing, sales, and distribution within the Territory, adhering to a Commercialization Plan, and complying with all applicable laws, including anti-corruption regulations. Zogenix is responsible for product development, regulatory filings, and maintaining global safety standards.  A Joint Steering Committee oversees the collaboration.

Key terms include exclusivity, non-compete clauses, confidentiality provisions, intellectual property ownership and licensing, and detailed reporting requirements.  The agreement includes provisions for dispute resolution through arbitration in New York.

The agreement runs until September 1, 2045, but includes termination clauses for material breach, mutual agreement, convenience (post-Distribution Term), and specific events like a Change of Control or safety concerns.

Financial arrangements involve a substantial upfront payment ($7.5 million), development funding ($12.5 million), regulatory and sales milestone payments, and a tiered transfer price for product supply based on net sales, with annual true-ups.  Late payments accrue interest.  Detailed indemnification clauses protect both parties from third-party claims.

LeadersonlineInc_20000427_S-1A_EX-10.8_4.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, dated March 15, 2000, is between VerticalNet, Inc. (VerticalNet) and LeadersOnline, Inc. (LeadersOnline).  It's a co-branding agreement outlining a collaborative marketing and recruitment arrangement.

LeadersOnline commits to purchasing a minimum amount of banner ads and newsletter ads from VerticalNet (specific amounts redacted), receiving a discounted rate.  In return, VerticalNet grants LeadersOnline access to its resume bank, subject to restrictions on contacting candidates, and agrees to host and maintain LeadersOnline Employer Spotlights on its online communities. LeadersOnline will also display a VerticalNet Branded Link on its site.

Key obligations include LeadersOnline's advertising purchases and adherence to VerticalNet's privacy policy regarding resume bank access. VerticalNet is obligated to provide specified advertising placements and maintain the Employer Spotlights.

Financial terms include upfront fees for Employer Spotlights and resume bank access (amounts redacted), plus a revenue-sharing arrangement (redacted percentage of LeadersOnline-VerticalNet Revenue) and placement fees based on candidate salaries (amounts redacted).  VerticalNet guarantees a minimum revenue for LeadersOnline during the initial term (amount redacted).  Audits are permitted.

The agreement runs until June 15, 2001, with a potential 12-month renewal option at LeadersOnline's discretion, subject to VerticalNet's approval.  Termination is permitted for material breach after a 30-60 day cure period.  Post-termination, payment obligations continue for a period of six months.  The agreement is governed by Pennsylvania law, with dispute resolution via arbitration in Philadelphia.  Confidentiality and indemnification clauses are

PRIMEENERGYRESOURCESCORP_04_02_2007-EX-1.summary:
This Completion and Liquidity Maintenance Agreement, dated June 29, 2006, involves PrimeEnergy Corporation ("Prime"), Guaranty Bank, FSB ("Guaranty"), and Prime Offshore L.L.C. ("Offshore").  It's a support agreement related to a credit agreement between Offshore and Guaranty for a development project involving several OCS blocks.

The main purpose is to ensure project completion and maintain liquidity. Prime's key obligation is to fund costs exceeding Guaranty's loan commitments for the project, including interest.  This obligation is triggered by project completion milestones and Offshore's default under the credit agreement.  Prime must also maintain $25 million in liquidity (adjustable based on shareholder advances/repayments).

Project completion is defined in two components: (A) installation and operation of all planned facilities for each project field, including permits and approvals; and (B) completion of a specified pipeline.  Prime's funding obligation for each component expires upon its completion.

The agreement is governed by Texas law and litigated in Harris County, Texas.  The agreement remains in effect until both project completion components are satisfied.  A breach by Prime constitutes an event of default under the underlying credit agreement, allowing Guaranty to pursue remedies.  The financial arrangement centers on Prime's guarantee to cover cost overruns and maintain specified liquidity.

AgapeAtpCorp_20191202_10-KA_EX-10.1_1191.summary:
This ODM Supply Agreement, dated January 15, 2018, is between Organic Preparations Inc. (Manufacturer), Vanuatu, and Agape ATP International Holding Limited (Customer), Hong Kong.  It establishes a 10-year exclusive agency agreement (automatically renewing for 10-year terms, terminable with six months' notice), granting the Customer sole rights to promote, sell, market, distribute, and administer the Manufacturer's products (listed in Schedule A).

The Manufacturer's key obligations include supplying product documentation, complying with all relevant laws and regulations, maintaining manufacturing standards, guaranteeing packaging quality, and not selling to other parties without Customer consent.  The Customer must comply with laws, actively market the products (Schedule B outlines minimum purchase requirements), pay all shipping and insurance costs (Ex Works delivery), and maintain product liability insurance naming the Manufacturer as an additional insured.

Payment terms are 50% upon order placement and 50% before shipment.  Defective products can be rejected within seven days. Disputes are resolved through ICC arbitration in Switzerland.  The agreement is governed by English law.  The Manufacturer retains intellectual property rights but grants the Customer first right of refusal to purchase them.  The agreement includes provisions for breach, termination (including for material breach, insolvency, or change of control), force majeure, and severability.  The Manufacturer commits to providing at least four new products annually.  The Customer also receives copyright to the "How to Achieve Super Health" book under specific conditions.

ArcaUsTreasuryFund_20200207_N-2_EX-99.K5.summary:
This Blockchain Administration and Development Agreement, dated February 7, 2020, is between Arca U.S. Treasury Fund (the "Fund"), a Delaware statutory trust, and Arca Capital Management, LLC (the "Blockchain Administrator"), a Delaware LLC.  The agreement outlines the Blockchain Administrator's responsibilities in developing and administering the Fund's ERC-1404 compatible digital securities and related smart contracts.

The Blockchain Administrator's key obligations include developing the necessary infrastructure, managing relationships with custodians and other service providers, maintaining required records compliant with the Investment Company Act of 1940, and reporting to the Fund's Board of Trustees.  Importantly, the Blockchain Administrator acts as an independent contractor, not an agent of the Fund, and is not responsible for investment advice.  The Fund bears most operational costs, while the Blockchain Administrator receives an annual fee of 0.20% of the Fund's average annual net assets.

The agreement includes a broad indemnification clause protecting the Blockchain Administrator from liability, except for gross negligence or willful misconduct.  The agreement has an initial two-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated by either party with 60 days' written notice or by specified shareholder or trustee votes.  The agreement also addresses confidentiality and record-keeping requirements.  New York law governs, subject to the Investment Company Act.

BIOAMBERINC_04_10_2013-EX-10.34-DEVELOPM.summary:
This First Amendment, dated October 19, 2011, modifies a pre-existing Development Agreement (April 15, 2010) and Commercial License Agreement (April 15, 2010) between Cargill, Incorporated and BioAmber S.A.S.  The amendment addresses BioAmber's funding of two projects:  a research project with the Biotechnology Research Institute (BRI) to develop succinic acid production from methanol, and a scale-up project using a Corynebacteria biocatalyst (CB1) from Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation (MCC) at BioAmber's facilities in France and Canada.

Key obligations include BioAmber funding the BRI project until a specified succinic acid production level is reached, then ceasing funding and redirecting remaining funds.  BioAmber must also convert its production facilities to solely use the CB1 biocatalyst, per Section 5.9 of the Commercial License Agreement, and pursue regulatory approvals for CB1 globally.  Cargill's obligations are less explicitly defined but involve allowing BioAmber to pursue these projects under the specified terms.  Financial arrangements are not detailed but relate to existing compensation terms in the original Development Agreement for additional FTEs (Section 2.2) and BioAmber's self-funding of the BRI and scale-up projects.  No explicit termination clauses are mentioned beyond the BRI project's funding cessation upon achieving specified production levels.  Confidential information is redacted throughout the amendment.

XACCT Technologies, Inc.SUPPORT AND MAIN.contract_id: XACCT Technologies, Inc.SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT
XACCT Technologies, Inc.SUPPORT AND MAIN.contract_title: XACCT Technologies, Inc.SUPPORT AND MAINTENANCE AGREEMENT
XACCT Technologies, Inc.SUPPORT AND MAIN.summary:
This Support and Maintenance Agreement ("Agreement"), effective [Date], is between XACCT Technologies, Inc. ("XACCT") and [Licensee Name] ("Licensee").  It governs post-sale support and maintenance for software licensed under a separate End-User Software License Agreement (incorporated by reference).

XACCT's key obligations include providing Product Maintenance (updates, revisions) and Support Services (technical assistance for Incidents) at a level specified in Attachment 1.  Licensee must appoint a Designated Support Contact, provide necessary system access, follow XACCT's instructions, and promptly report problems. XACCT excludes support for modified or unsupported Product versions, problems caused by Licensee's negligence, and issues stemming from non-XACCT equipment.

Fees are payable within 30 days of invoice and are exclusive of taxes.  The Agreement's initial term is one year, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice. XACCT may terminate for non-payment or breach of contract (30-day cure period).  XACCT also retains the right to not renew if it no longer generally supports the Product.  The License Agreement's warranty and liability limitations apply to Product Maintenance; XACCT's liability for Support Services is capped at the prior 12 months' fees, excluding consequential damages.  Governing law is California; jurisdiction is Santa Clara County, California, or the Northern District of California.

CHANGEPOINTCORP_03_08_2000-EX-10.6-LICEN.summary:
This License and Hosting Agreement, effective December 13, 1999, is between Corio Inc. (Corio) and Changepoint Inc. (Changepoint).  It's a complex agreement covering software licensing and hosting services.  Changepoint licenses its proprietary software (primarily a PSA application) to Corio for hosting and resale to Corio's customers.

Corio's key obligations include hosting Changepoint's software on its servers, providing Level 1 & 2 customer support,  and paying revenue-sharing fees to Changepoint (redacted percentage of Application Management Revenue) and software support fees (details redacted).  Corio also agrees to joint marketing efforts and non-compete restrictions within a defined market. Changepoint's key obligations include providing software, updates, upgrades, Level 3 support to Corio, and joint marketing.  A source code escrow agreement is included.

Important terms include detailed license grants (with restrictions), warranties (limited to 120 days for performance and Y2K compliance), indemnification clauses, limitations of liability, confidentiality provisions, and a preferred relationship clause for marketing.

The agreement has an initial five-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  Termination can also occur for material breach (60-day cure period), insolvency, or certain other events.  Financial arrangements involve revenue sharing, software support fees, and other fees for services (many amounts redacted).  The governing law is California, with dispute resolution via arbitration in San Francisco.

Apollo Endosurgery - Manufacturing and S.contract_id: Apollo Endosurgery - Manufacturing and Supply Agreement
Apollo Endosurgery - Manufacturing and S.contract_title: Apollo Endosurgery - Manufacturing and Supply Agreement
Apollo Endosurgery - Manufacturing and S.summary:
This Manufacturing and Supply Agreement (MSA) between Apollo Endosurgery, Inc. ("Apollo") and Establishment Labs, S.A. ("Establishment") governs the manufacture and supply of medical device products (specified in Exhibit A) by Establishment for Apollo.  The agreement is a five-year contract with automatic one-year renewals, terminable by either party with one year's written notice or for material breach (120-day cure period).

Establishment's key obligations include manufacturing the products according to Apollo's specifications, complying with all relevant GMPs and regulations (ISO 13485, FDA 21 CFR §820), maintaining quality control, and providing certain technical assistance.  Apollo's main obligations are to provide forecasts (binding for the first three months of each rolling 12-month forecast), issue purchase orders, and pay for the products within 30 days of invoice.  Apollo retains ownership of fixtures and tooling (Exhibit C).

Pricing is detailed in Exhibit A, including tooling costs.  Apollo is responsible for certain raw materials (silicone) delivery.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, limitations of liability (excluding gross negligence or willful misconduct), and confidentiality provisions.  Dispute resolution is governed by Texas law and venue is in Austin, Texas.  A separate Quality Agreement (Exhibit B) further defines quality control procedures.

MJBIOTECH,INC_12_06_2018-EX-99.01-JOINT.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement (JVA), dated November 27, 2018, establishes a one-year joint venture between MJ Syndicated, Inc. (Florida) and Simply Herbals (Tennessee) to manufacture and sell health-related products.  The JVA operates under Florida law.

Key obligations include capital contributions (cash or property) by both parties, proportional profit/loss sharing based on capital contributions, and maintaining accurate financial records.  Unanimous consent is required for significant financial decisions, admitting new participants, amending the agreement, and dissolving the venture.  A majority vote governs operational decisions.

Important terms include provisions for withdrawal (voluntary with 30-day notice resulting in dissolution; involuntary due to specified events, also resulting in dissolution),  dissolution procedures (debt repayment prioritized before asset distribution), asset valuation (fair market value appraisal), and indemnification clauses.  The Tax Matters Participant is MJ Syndicated, Inc.

The JVA's duration is fixed, ending November 30, 2019, unless otherwise agreed.  Dissolution triggers include voluntary withdrawal by a participant or the occurrence of specified involuntary withdrawal events.  The agreement includes clauses on force majeure, duties of loyalty and accountability, and forbidden acts, with violations potentially leading to involuntary withdrawal.  Florida courts have jurisdiction.

IDREAMSKYTECHNOLOGYLTD_07_03_2014-EX-10..summary:
This Cooperation Agreement on Mobile Game Business, dated January 1, 2013, is between Dazzle Interactive Network Technologies Co., Ltd. ("Party A," a network service provider) and Shenzhen iDreamSky Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party B," a mobile game content provider).  The agreement governs Party B's provision of mobile games and technical support to Party A's users.

Party A's key obligations include providing network resources, billing services, and advertising;  Party B is responsible for game content, platform maintenance, marketing, and customer service.  Party A holds a preemptive right for nationwide service and has significant control over content review and business standards.  Party B guarantees legal compliance and intellectual property rights.

Crucially, Party A reviews and approves pricing, and revenue is shared according to specified percentages (70% to Party B in content cooperation, 40% in channel cooperation, with adjustments for bundled promotions).  A performance bond of RMB 3,000 is payable by Party B, with additional amounts for breaches.  Settlement occurs monthly.

The agreement has a one-year term, automatically renewable once unless objected to.  Termination clauses favor Party A, allowing unilateral termination for various breaches by Party B, including legal non-compliance, poor customer service, or failure to meet performance standards.  Party B is liable for all losses caused by its breaches.  Disputes are resolved through negotiation or in a court with jurisdiction over Party A's domicile.  An attached Integrity Agreement addresses anti-bribery measures.

CANOPETROLEUM,INC_12_13_2007-EX-10.1-Spo.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated December 5, 2007, is between R.C. Boyd Enterprises, LLC ("Boyd"), owner of the television show "Honey Hole," and Cano Petroleum, Inc. ("Cano").  Cano secures exclusive lead sponsorship of Honey Hole for $150,000, payable in four installments.

Boyd's obligations include producing at least 40 original episodes annually, featuring Cano's branding (30-second lead-in/trailer/commercials, signage at public appearances, logo placement on primary show vehicles), and featuring Cano-designated guests in six episodes. Cano provides pre-produced promotional materials.

Cano's primary obligation is payment.  The agreement runs for one year, from January 1, 2008, to December 31, 2008.  Boyd may cancel the agreement after 10 days' notice for non-payment, with Cano remaining liable for unpaid installments.  The contract includes standard clauses on governing law (Texas), attorney's fees, force majeure, assignment restrictions, and a complete integration clause.  A notable provision is an exculpatory clause releasing Cano from liability for injuries sustained during production.

PhoenixNewMediaLtd_20110421_F-1_EX-10.17.summary:
This Program Content License Agreement, dated November 24, 2009, is between Phoenix Satellite Television Company Limited ("Party A") and Beijing Tianying Jiuzhou Network Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party B").  Party A licenses its program content (specified in Exhibit 1) to Party B for use in Party B's online business (including websites www.ifeng.com, www.phoenixtv.com, www.phoenixtv.com.cn, and other approved sites).

Party A's key obligations include licensing the specified content and assisting Party B in obtaining similar content if Party A experiences delays. Party B's key obligations include using the content solely for its approved online business, maintaining confidentiality, protecting Party A's intellectual property rights, and indemnifying Party A for losses resulting from Party B's negligence.  Party B retains no intellectual property rights to the licensed content.

Financial arrangements are detailed in a separate agreement referenced within this contract.  The agreement has a five-year term, renewable by mutual agreement. Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach (uncured within 10 business days), bankruptcy, cessation of business, illegality under PRC law, or events impacting performance.  Applicable law is PRC law, with disputes resolved through negotiation or Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre arbitration.  Taxes are borne by the incurring party.

HOSPITALITYINVESTORSTRUST,INC_04_07_2014.summary:
This Franchise Agreement, dated March 21, 2014, is between Homewood Suites Franchise LLC ("Franchisor," a Hilton Worldwide subsidiary) and ARC Hospitality TRS Stratford LLC ("Franchisee").  The agreement grants Franchisee a non-exclusive license to operate a Homewood Suites by Hilton hotel in Stratford, Connecticut, for 15 years.

**Key Obligations:** Franchisor provides training, reservation services, and marketing support. Franchisee operates the hotel according to Franchisor's standards, pays monthly fees (program and royalty fees based on Gross Rooms Revenue), maintains required insurance, and complies with all laws and regulations.  Significant renovations are detailed in Exhibit A (Product Improvement Plan).

**Important Terms:**  Franchisee cannot compete with Hilton, transfer the franchise without consent (except for specified permitted transfers), or make unauthorized changes to the hotel.  Franchisor retains proprietary rights and can inspect the hotel.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on reporting, audits, confidentiality, and indemnity.

**Termination:**  Franchisor can terminate for breach (with or without cure period), including non-payment, non-compliance with standards, bankruptcy, or becoming a competitor.  Franchisee pays liquidated damages upon early termination, calculated based on remaining term and revenue.  Upon termination, Franchisee must cease using the brand and return all proprietary information.

**Financial Arrangements:** Franchisee pays monthly fees (percentage of Gross Rooms Revenue), other fees for services, and reimburses Franchisor for certain taxes.  Liquidated damages are substantial and vary depending on the timing of termination.  The agreement also includes provisions for interest on late payments and attorney's fees.  The Addendum specifies the

FulucaiProductionsLtd_20131223_10-Q_EX-1.summary: This Content Distribution and License Agreement, effective November 15, 2012, is between ConvergTV, Inc. (Delaware corporation) and Fulucai Productions Ltd. (Canada).  Fulucai grants ConvergTV perpetual, worldwide rights to distribute its program, "Inevitable," across all media (including but not limited to streaming, broadcast, and VOD) for a revenue-sharing arrangement detailed in Exhibit B.  Fulucai warrants ownership and freedom from infringement. ConvergTV has exclusive distribution rights during the initial two-year term, after which the license becomes perpetual.  ConvergTV is responsible for creating various versions (e.g., subtitled, closed-captioned) at its own expense.  Fulucai receives no upfront payment; revenue sharing is subject to a 30-day dispute window.  Fulucai indemnifies ConvergTV against any claims arising from the program.  Florida law governs, with Brevard County as the venue.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties and may only be modified in writing.  No termination clause is explicitly stated beyond the initial two-year period.

ONEMAINHOLDINGS,INC_02_20_2020-EX-99.D-J.summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement (dated February 20, 2020), executed by OneMain Holdings, Inc. and various Värde entities (including Uniform InvestCo LP, several Värde Funds, and Värde Partners, L.P. and Inc.),  complies with Rule 13d-1(k) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  The agreement's sole purpose is to establish a framework for the joint filing of a Schedule 13D statement (and subsequent amendments) regarding OneMain Holdings, Inc. securities.

The key obligation is the collective filing of the Schedule 13D, representing the signatory parties' combined holdings.  No individual responsibilities beyond this joint filing are specified.  The agreement doesn't detail financial arrangements or a specific duration; it's implicitly tied to the ongoing requirements of Schedule 13D filings.  No termination clause is explicitly stated; the agreement's purpose is fulfilled upon completion of the filing and any subsequent amendments.  The agreement is considered executed upon signature by all parties, with multiple counterparts deemed original.

MPLXLP_06_17_2015-EX-10.1-TRANSPORTATION.summary:
This Transportation Services Agreement, dated June 11, 2015, is between Marathon Petroleum Company LP ("Shipper") and Marathon Pipe Line LLC ("MPL").  It governs the transportation of specialty petroleum products (condensate, natural gasoline, diluent, potentially butane) via MPL's pipeline system (including assets of Ohio River Pipe Line LLC).

The agreement's main purpose is to secure Shipper's multi-year commitment to transport a specified volume of product, detailed in Exhibit C, in exchange for pre-determined rates (Exhibit B) subject to annual FERC-based indexing.  Shipper's key obligations include meeting quarterly volume commitments (or paying deficiency charges), paying transportation charges monthly, and providing financial assurances as needed. MPL's main obligations include transporting the product and maintaining the pipeline system.

Key terms include definitions of "Compliance Costs," "Quarterly Deficiency Payment," and "Prepaid Transportation Credits."  The agreement has a 15-year initial term, automatically renewable for two 5-year periods unless terminated with six months' notice.  Force majeure provisions allow for temporary suspension or termination under specified circumstances.  Financial arrangements involve monthly payments based on Tariff Rates, deficiency payments, and prepayment credits.  Shipper's early termination before service commencement triggers pro-rata reimbursement of MPL's construction costs (liquidated damages).  The agreement is governed by Ohio law.

LOGANSROADHOUSEINC_03_27_1998-EX-10.17-S.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated February 24, 1998, is between Southern Racing Promotions, Inc. ("SRP") and Logan's Roadhouse, Inc. ("Logan's"), both Tennessee corporations.  The agreement concerns Logan's primary sponsorship of SRP's NASCAR Late Model Stock Car racing team for the 1998 season at Nashville Motor Speedway.

SRP's key obligations include providing driver Brad Baker (or an approved alternate), managing the team's public image, designing and maintaining the race car, providing uniforms with Logan's branding, securing credentials for Logan's representatives, building a show car for Logan's use, and potentially lettering a transporter.  Logan's receives extensive branding rights on the car and driver, and the right to use Baker's likeness for advertising.  SRP can secure secondary sponsorships, subject to Logan's approval, but these cannot exceed 25% of Logan's branding space and cannot compete with Logan's products.

The agreement runs from February 24, 1998 to November 30, 1998, and may be terminated by either party for material breach (30-day cure period), serious misconduct by the other party or its driver, or cancellation of the LMSC series.  Logan's pays SRP $80,000: $40,000 upon execution and the remainder in eight monthly installments.  SRP is responsible for liability insurance ($5,000,000).  The agreement includes confidentiality, non-compete, and independent contractor clauses.  Tennessee law governs.

FuelcellEnergyInc_20191106_8-K_EX-10.1_1.summary:
This Joint Development Agreement (JDA), effective October 31, 2019, is between FuelCell Energy, Inc. ("FCE") and ExxonMobil Research and Engineering Company ("ExxonMobil").  Its purpose is collaborative research and development of Molten Carbonate Fuel Cells (MCFCs) for carbon dioxide emission reduction in power and industrial applications.

Key obligations include FCE's exclusive collaboration with ExxonMobil on specified projects (Project Descriptions),  data disclosure and confidentiality (20-year term), and intellectual property assignment to ExxonMobil. ExxonMobil manages patent applications and retains ownership of Program Results, granting FCE licenses for specific applications (Power, Hydrogen, and potentially Carbon Capture, subject to negotiation).  A Steering Committee oversees the program.

Important terms include confidentiality provisions, limitations on liability (except for gross negligence or willful misconduct), and dispute resolution via arbitration in New York.

The agreement's term is two years, terminable by either party with 60 days' notice or for material breach (with cure period).  Termination clauses address bankruptcy and change of control at FCE.

Financial arrangements include an upfront exclusivity fee ($5 million), reimbursement of FCE's research costs (up to $45 million total, with monthly invoicing), and milestone payments ($5 million each for Milestones 1 and 2).  ExxonMobil bears its own Steering Committee costs.  Post-termination, certain obligations, including confidentiality and licensing, survive.

THERAVANCEBIOPHARMA,INC_05_08_2020-EX-10.summary:
This Service Agreement, dated April 1, 2020, is between Theravance Biopharma UK Limited ("Employer") and Brett Haumann ("Executive").  It constitutes an employment contract appointing Haumann as Chief Medical Officer and Senior Vice President, Development.

Haumann's key obligations include devoting full time and attention to the Employer's business, complying with all reasonable directions, protecting confidential information, assigning intellectual property rights created during employment to the Employer, and refraining from competing activities for one year post-termination.

The agreement outlines a £448,903 annual salary, an annual bonus plan (up to 50% of base salary, discretionary), and other benefits.  The employment is terminable by either party with six weeks' notice, or longer as required by law.  The Employer retains the right to terminate without notice for gross misconduct or serious breach of contract, and may place the Executive on garden leave.  A payment in lieu of notice (PILON) may be offered at the Employer's discretion.

The contract includes extensive clauses regarding confidentiality, intellectual property, post-termination restrictions, and governing law (English law and jurisdiction).  Haumann's continuous employment for statutory purposes commenced October 29, 2013.  The agreement also details holiday entitlement, sick pay, expenses, and pension arrangements.

BerkshireHillsBancorpInc_20120809_10-Q_E.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated May 14-17, 2012, is between Geno Auriemma ("Auriemma") and Berkshire Bank ("Berkshire").  The agreement grants Berkshire exclusive rights to use Auriemma's name, likeness, and endorsement services to advertise its financial services from June 1, 2012 to May 31, 2016 (Contract Period), with services rendered until May 31, 2014 (Services Period).

Auriemma's key obligations include specified appearances and promotional activities detailed in Schedule A (e.g., recording ads, photo shoots, customer events).  Berkshire's main obligations are to pay Auriemma $480,000 in four installments ($90,000 cash and $30,000 worth of Berkshire Hills Bancorp, Inc. stock per year), reimburse expenses, and obtain Auriemma's approval for all marketing materials.  Berkshire must provide at least 15 days' notice for appearances.

The agreement includes exclusivity clauses preventing Auriemma from endorsing Berkshire competitors during the Contract Period.  Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach (payment or other obligations) or insolvency. Berkshire may also terminate if Auriemma dies, is convicted of a felony, or disparages Berkshire.  Governing law is Connecticut.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration in accordance with the American Arbitration Association's Commercial Rules.  The agreement contains standard confidentiality, indemnity, and waiver provisions.

DYNAMEXINC_06_06_1996-EX-10.4-TRANSPORTA.summary:
This Marketing and Transportation Services Agreement, dated November 20, 1995, is between Purolator Courier Ltd. ("Purolator") and Parcelway Courier Systems Canada Ltd. (a Dynamex Inc. subsidiary, "Dynamex").  The agreement establishes a cooperative, independent contractor relationship for marketing and providing courier services.  Purolator primarily offers next-day/multi-day service, while Dynamex focuses on same-day service.

Key obligations include reciprocal tendering of service requests (same-day for Purolator, next-day/multi-day for Dynamex), joint marketing efforts, and provision of each other's services to their respective customers according to service standards detailed in Schedules A & B.  Each party commits to a minimum 90% on-time performance, with penalties for repeated failures.  Non-solicitation clauses restrict each party from directly soliciting the other's existing customers for their core service type.

Financial arrangements involve bi-monthly invoicing, net 15-day payment terms, and interest on overdue amounts.  Rates are specified in Schedules D & E.  Liability for loss or damage to freight is capped, and indemnification clauses protect each party from certain claims.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on insurance, dangerous goods handling, record-keeping, and contingency plans.

The agreement is indefinite but terminable by either party with 120 days' notice for default (defined extensively) or two years' notice without cause.  A change in control allows for immediate termination.  Disputes are subject to arbitration in Ontario.  The agreement is governed by Ontario law.  Non-competition clauses restrict the defaulting

VALENCETECHNOLOGYINC_02_14_2003-EX-10-JO.summary:
This Joint Venture Contract, dated November 8, 2002, establishes Fengfan Group Limited Liability Company (Party A, PRC) and Valence Technology, Inc. (Party B, USA) as joint venturers in Fengfan-Valence Battery Company, Ltd. (the Joint Venture Company), a limited liability company in Baoding, China, to manufacture and sell advanced batteries.  The total investment is US$29.9 million, with Party A contributing US$14.651 million (49%) in cash and Party B US$15.249 million (51%) through technology (US$5.9 million) and equipment (US$9.349 million).

Party A's key obligations include obtaining necessary licenses and permits in China, assisting with site acquisition and construction, and recruiting personnel. Party B's obligations include providing technology, training personnel, and purchasing equipment.  The Joint Venture Company's management is structured with a 7-member Board of Directors (3 appointed by Party A, 4 by Party B), a CEO (nominated by Party B), and other senior management.

Key terms include confidentiality provisions, intellectual property rights allocation (with Valence retaining ownership of its trademarks), and dispute resolution through arbitration in Singapore.  The contract term is 50 years, renewable with mutual agreement. Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach, non-payment of capital contributions, bankruptcy, or significant adverse regulatory changes.  Financial arrangements detail capital contributions, profit distribution (proportional to registered capital), and tax obligations.  The contract is governed by PRC law.

ULTRAGENYXPHARMACEUTICALINC_12_23_2013-E.summary:
This Supply Agreement, dated November 19, 2012, is between Cremer Oleo GmbH & Co KG ("Cremer"), a German oleo chemical producer, and Ultragenyx Pharmaceutical Inc. ("Ultragenyx"), a US biotechnology company.  The agreement concerns the exclusive worldwide supply of Triheptanoin ("Product") by Cremer to Ultragenyx, limited to a specified field (redacted).  Ultragenyx will process the product into a pharmaceutical product.

Cremer's key obligations include supplying defect-free Product meeting specifications (Annex A), providing documentation (Certificate of Analysis, Drug Master File), and potentially undertaking development work under separate Statements of Work. Ultragenyx's obligations include exclusive purchase from Cremer, timely payment (in Euros, within a redacted timeframe), and indemnification of Cremer against third-party claims (except for Cremer's gross negligence or intentional misconduct).  Ultragenyx performs final release testing.

Pricing is agreed annually, with a maximum price increase capped (redacted).  Title transfers upon full payment.  Cremer's liability is limited, excluding personal injury and product liability claims.  Indirect damages are excluded.

The agreement has a three-year initial term, automatically renewing for two-year periods unless terminated with three months' notice.  Material breach allows for immediate termination.  Governing law is German, with exclusive jurisdiction in Hamburg.  General terms and conditions of either party are excluded.

NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16- AMENDME.contract_id: NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16- AMENDMENT #2 TO THE DISTRIBUTION AGREEMENT
NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16- AMENDME.contract_title: NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16- AMENDMENT #2 TO THE DISTRIBUTION AGREEMENT
NETGEAR,INC_04_21_2003-EX-10.16- AMENDME.summary: This document comprises two amendments to a Distribution Agreement between NETGEAR, Inc. ("NETGEAR") and Ingram Micro ("Ingram").  The first amendment (October 1, 1996) modifies the agreement's territory to the United States (with unspecified regions redacted) and grants Ingram exclusive distribution rights in those redacted regions for one year, contingent on agreed-upon marketing activities.  After the initial year, NETGEAR retains the right to appoint additional distributors.  The second amendment (July 15, 1998) further amends the territory clause (again with redacted regions) and extends the amended terms to cover the current and any future terms of the underlying agreement.  Both amendments supersede conflicting terms in the original agreement, leaving other provisions unchanged.  Financial details are redacted.  The amendments do not specify a termination clause beyond the standard terms of the original (unseen) agreement.  The key obligations involve Ingram's distribution of NETGEAR products within the specified territories, subject to marketing plan compliance in the first amendment.

SFGFINANCIALCORP_05_12_2009-EX-10.1-SOFT.summary:
This Software License and Maintenance Agreement, dated April 27, 2009, is between SFG Financial Corp. (Licensor) and 551 FX IB Associates, LLC (Licensee), both Delaware entities.  The agreement grants Licensee a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use Licensor's "E-Path FX Trading Platform" software solely for spot FX transactions.

Licensee's key obligations include paying a tiered monthly user fee based on trading volume, providing quarterly usage reports, maintaining records subject to audit, and adhering to strict restrictions on software use, disclosure, and modification.  Licensee also agrees to pay for technical support services and to indemnify Licensor against liabilities arising from Licensee's use of the software.  Licensor's main obligations include providing the software and technical support.

The agreement includes a 36-month initial term, renewable for seven years at Licensor's option.  Termination clauses exist for breach of contract, insolvency, change of control, and cessation of Licensee's business.  Financial arrangements include an initial payment of $35,000, monthly user fees, a stock purchase option for Licensee, and a share-based rebate program.  The agreement contains a significant disclaimer of warranties and limitations on Licensor's liability.  New York law governs the agreement, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.

VAXCYTE,INC_05_22_2020-EX-10.19-SUPPLY A.summary:
This Supply Agreement, effective May 29, 2018, is between Sutro Biopharma, Inc. ("Sutro") and SutroVax, Inc. ("SutroVax"), both Delaware corporations.  The agreement governs Sutro's manufacture and supply of Extracts and Custom Reagents to SutroVax for non-clinical research and Phase I/II clinical trials of vaccine compositions.

Sutro's key obligations include manufacturing products according to specifications, meeting delivery timelines (with liability for third-party penalties for delays),  maintaining quality control (including filing DMFs), and cooperating with regulatory inspections. SutroVax's main obligations are purchasing products, paying invoices within specified timelines, and conducting testing to verify conformance.  A quality agreement is to be separately executed.

Important terms include detailed definitions (e.g., "Fully Burdened Manufacturing Costs"), provisions for product testing and acceptance/rejection,  SutroVax's right to select a CMO and potentially an alternate supplier (with a process transfer addendum to be negotiated), and allocation of supply in case of shortages.  Pricing is based on Sutro's fully burdened manufacturing costs, with a cap.

The agreement's term lasts until July 31, 2021, or the execution of a Phase 3/Commercial Supply Agreement, and may be terminated by mutual consent, material breach, or by SutroVax for any reason with notice.  Dispute resolution involves escalation to senior management and then binding arbitration, including a "baseball arbitration" clause for the Phase 3 agreement and alternate supplier qualification.  Confidentiality provisions are incorporated by reference from a separate License Agreement.  Significant

OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INT.contract_id: OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT by and among UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORPORATION, OTIS WORLDWIDE CORPORATION and CARRIER ~1
OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INT.contract_title: OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT by and among UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORPORATION, OTIS WORLDWIDE CORPORATION and CARRIER ~1
OTISWORLDWIDECORP_04_03_2020-EX-10.4-INT.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated April 2, 2020, is among United Technologies Corporation (UTC), Otis Worldwide Corporation (Otis), and Carrier Global Corporation (Carrier).  Its purpose is to clarify and govern intellectual property rights (IPR) ownership and licensing among the three parties following UTC's separation into independent companies.

The agreement assigns solely owned IPR to the respective successor companies based on origin (Requester/Performer roles in prior projects).  It grants royalty-free, perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide licenses for certain IPR necessary for each company's ongoing business, subject to field restrictions and sublicensing limitations.  Trademarks (especially those containing "UTC") are specifically addressed, with UTC retaining sole ownership and Otis & Carrier receiving limited, temporary usage rights for transition purposes.  Excluded agreements remain unaffected.

Key obligations include assignment of specified IPR, granting of licenses, maintaining confidentiality of received information, and cooperation regarding trademark usage and transition.  The IPA is non-terminable, with remedies limited to monetary damages or equitable relief (including specific performance), excluding rescission.  No financial arrangements beyond royalty-free licensing are detailed.  Governing law is Delaware, with dispute resolution via negotiation and arbitration.

GIGGLESN_HUGS,INC_06_23_2016-EX-10.2-STR.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated May 17, 2016, is between Giggles N' Hugs, Inc. (Company) and Kiddo, Inc. (Consultant).  The agreement outlines a consultancy relationship where Kiddo, Inc. will provide services to Giggles N' Hugs, Inc. focusing on investor relations, branding, marketing, licensing, merchandising, and entertainment to expand Giggles N' Hugs' brand and market presence.  Kiddo's responsibilities include securing investors, celebrity endorsements, and media coverage, developing a brand strategy, and facilitating strategic partnerships across various sectors.

Key obligations for Kiddo include a detailed timeline for service delivery, culminating in a 2017 rollout plan.  In consideration, Kiddo receives warrants to purchase 4,400,000 shares of Giggles N' Hugs' common stock at $0.075 per share, vesting incrementally upon achievement of specified milestones (e.g., securing investment, achieving stock price targets, securing celebrity partnerships, launching product lines).

The agreement designates Kiddo as an independent contractor, includes confidentiality and non-solicitation clauses, and addresses intellectual property ownership, assigning all innovations created by Kiddo to Giggles N' Hugs. The agreement is terminable by either party after three years or upon earlier specified events, including material breach or failure to achieve milestones.  California law governs, with disputes resolved through negotiation or litigation in Los Angeles County.  Sections regarding confidentiality, non-solicitation, and general provisions survive termination.  The agreement includes provisions for equitable relief in case of breach.

ExactSciencesCorp_20180822_8-K_EX-10.1_1.summary:
This Cologuard® Promotion Agreement, effective August 21, 2018, is between Exact Sciences Corporation ("Exact") and Pfizer Inc. ("Pfizer").  It's a co-promotion agreement for Cologuard in the US, leveraging Pfizer's sales and marketing expertise.

Exact retains ownership and responsibility for manufacturing, pricing, regulatory compliance, and product liability. Pfizer is exclusively responsible for co-promotion within the defined "Co-Promote Field," committing to a minimum number of details annually (with financial penalties for shortfalls).  Both parties share marketing expenses (Shared M&P Expenses), with Exact contributing a baseline amount (Baseline M&P Expenses) and Pfizer matching a portion of the Shared M&P Expenses.  A Promotion Fee, calculated as a percentage of incremental revenue, is payable to Pfizer quarterly.

Governance is structured through a Joint Steering Committee (JSC), Joint Operations Committee (JOC), and Joint Review Committee (JRC) to manage the co-promotion activities.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on confidentiality, indemnification, and dispute resolution.

The agreement runs through December 31, 2021, with a potential one-year renewal.  Termination clauses exist for cause (material breach, non-payment, non-compliance) and without cause (after 18 months with 6-month notice).  A royalty payment to Pfizer is stipulated for a 12-quarter "Tail Period" following expiration or certain terminations, based on cumulative incremental revenue.  The agreement specifies detailed reporting and audit rights for both parties.

Quaker Chemical Corporation - NON COMPET.contract_id: Quaker Chemical Corporation - NON COMPETITION AND NON SOLICITATION AGREEMENT
Quaker Chemical Corporation - NON COMPET.contract_title: Quaker Chemical Corporation - NON COMPETITION AND NON SOLICITATION AGREEMENT
Quaker Chemical Corporation - NON COMPET.summary: This Non-Competition and Non-Solicitation Agreement, dated August 1, 2019, involves Quaker Chemical Corporation ("Buyer") and several Gulf Oil entities (collectively, "Sellers").  The agreement's purpose is to protect Quaker Chemical's interests following its acquisition of Global Houghton Ltd.  Sellers are obligated to maintain confidentiality regarding Buyer and Global Houghton's information.  Key obligations include non-competition (two years post-closing, worldwide except India, with exceptions for passive investment and pre-existing businesses under certain thresholds) and non-solicitation of employees (three years post-closing, with exceptions for general solicitations and employees terminated at least six months prior).  Gulf Oil and Gulf India have additional restrictions on acquiring competing businesses.  The agreement specifies notice procedures, governs law (Pennsylvania), and includes clauses for injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and severability.  Financial arrangements are implied, referencing consideration paid to Sellers under a separate Share Purchase Agreement.  The agreement is binding on successors and assigns, subject to consent.  No explicit termination clause is mentioned; the non-compete and non-solicit periods define the duration of key obligations.

GlobalTechnologiesGroupInc_20050928_10KS.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated July 13, 2005, is between Global Music International, Inc. d/b/a Independent Music Network (IMNTV) and MobileVision Communications Ltd.  It governs MobileVision's distribution of IMNTV's music video programming ("Programming") in China.  The agreement incorporates Master Terms of Service (MTS) defining key terms like "Subscriber," "Subscription Fee," and "Programming Bundle Fee."

MobileVision's key obligations include marketing, distributing, and providing customer support for the Programming via its mobile platform in China, including hosting services and providing usage reports. IMNTV grants MobileVision a non-exclusive license to distribute the Programming and use IMNTV marks for promotional purposes.  IMNTV is responsible for providing and maintaining the Programming content.

The agreement's term is one year from launch, renewable annually by mutual agreement.  Termination clauses allow either party to terminate for material breach after 30 days' notice or for bankruptcy/insolvency.  MobileVision can also terminate for Programming deficiencies after a cure period.

Financial arrangements stipulate MobileVision pays IMNTV 55% of net subscriber revenue for IMNTV content, quarterly, after receiving payment from carriers.  Specific payment timing and currency exchange details are outlined.  Both parties provide warranties and indemnification clauses covering their respective responsibilities.  The agreement is governed by Florida law.  A pilot program with China Unicom Tianjin is mentioned, with revenue sharing commencing October 1, 2005.

GpaqAcquisitionHoldingsInc_20200123_S-4A.summary:
This Sponsorship and Services Agreement, dated December 19, 2018, is between HOF Village, LLC and National Football Museum, Inc. (collectively, "HOF Entities") and Constellation NewEnergy, Inc. ("Constellation").  The agreement combines a sponsorship deal with a supply agreement for energy products and services at the Johnson Controls Hall of Fame Village.

HOF Entities agree to purchase energy products and services from Constellation at market prices, subject to separate Second Level Agreements (SLAs) governing specific purchases.  Constellation provides these products and services and obtains exclusive rights to supply electricity and gas to HOF Entities (with exceptions).  Constellation also secures sponsorship rights, including advertising and promotional opportunities, at the Village, subject to HOF Entities' approval.  Financial terms, including sponsorship fees and an activation fund, are detailed in Exhibit H (redacted).  Constellation bears upfront service costs; HOF Entities cover energy consumption costs and a minimum amount of EME financing (amount redacted).

Key terms include exclusivity provisions for Constellation's energy supply, mutual indemnification clauses, and intellectual property licensing for both parties' marks (detailed in Exhibits F & G).  The agreement runs until December 31, 2028, but contains termination clauses for default (60-day cure period), reputational damage, and Constellation's failure to recover its investment by December 31, 2023.  Ohio law governs, with venue in Canton, Ohio.  Numerous exhibits (mostly redacted) detail specific products, services, sponsorship rights, and financial arrangements.

HertzGroupRealtyTrustInc_20190920_S-11A_.summary: This Trademark License Agreement, dated September 2019, is between Hertz Investment Group, LLC (Licensor) and Hertz Group Realty Trust, Inc. (Licensee), both located in Woodland Hills, CA.  The agreement grants Licensee a non-exclusive, non-transferable, royalty-free license to use the stylized "H" trademark (USPTO Registration No. 5,283,875) and the "Hertz Group" trade name solely in connection with Licensee's corporate name.  Licensee is obligated to use the mark in accordance with sound trademark practice, not challenge its validity or Licensor's ownership, and cooperate in protecting the mark.  Licensor retains all ownership rights and benefits from goodwill generated by the Licensee's use.  The agreement is terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice, or automatically upon Licensee's acquisition by a third party or cessation of management by Licensor or its affiliate.  Licensee indemnifies Licensor for claims arising from Licensee's actions.  The agreement contains standard disclaimers of warranties and limitations of liability.  No financial consideration is explicitly stated.  Governing law is California.

QuantumGroupIncFl_20090120_8-K_EX-99.2_3.summary:
This e-business Hosting Agreement is between International Business Machines Corporation ("IBM") and The Quantum Group Inc. ("Customer").  It's a service agreement for IBM to provide hosting and related services to Customer for a 36-month term, commencing after the Hosting Service Ready Date.

IBM's key obligations include providing hosting infrastructure (servers, SAN storage, network connectivity, etc., as specified in Attachment B),  managing specified components (fully managed servers, SAN fabric, firewalls),  providing backup and restore services, and offering various levels of monitoring and support (Basic, Advanced).  Specific services and SLAs are detailed in Attachment A.  IBM warrants reasonable care and skill but disclaims most other warranties.  Liability is capped.

Customer's key obligations include providing Customer Components (software, data), complying with the Acceptable Use Policy, and paying all charges (detailed in Attachment C).  Customer is responsible for Content, application support, and capacity planning.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.

The agreement includes detailed definitions of key terms (bandwidth, Committed Bandwidth, Managed Servers, etc.).  Termination can occur for cause (material breach) or convenience (with early termination charges in Attachment C).  Financial arrangements include one-time charges, monthly recurring charges, and usage-based charges (hourly support, bandwidth overages).  New York law governs, and jury trials are waived.  Several provisions survive termination.

SUCAMPOPHARMACEUTICALS,INC_11_04_2015-EX.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated August 26, 2015, involves Sucampo Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (SPI), its wholly-owned subsidiary Sucampo Pharma, LLC (Acquiror), and R-Tech Ueno, Ltd. (Company).  The agreement facilitates Acquiror's tender offer to acquire all outstanding shares and stock options of the Company, creating a combined biopharmaceutical entity.

Acquiror's key obligations include launching a tender offer at JPY1,900 per share, subject to conditions including the Company's truthful representations and warranties, unanimous board approval of the offer, and securing financing (via a Jefferies commitment letter). The Company must support the offer, recommend tendering to shareholders, and cooperate with Acquiror.  Both parties have reciprocal indemnification obligations.

Important terms include definitions of "Material Adverse Effect," "Superior Offer," and various regulatory compliance requirements under Japanese law (FIEL, PAL).  The agreement includes restrictive covenants on the Company's actions during the offer period.

The agreement's duration is contingent on the success of the tender offer.  Termination can occur before the offer period's end if specified conditions are met.  SPI guarantees Acquiror's performance.  Financial arrangements center on the tender offer price and the debt financing commitment from Jefferies.  Governing law is Japanese, with specified jurisdiction clauses for disputes.  The agreement also includes confidentiality and non-liability clauses for lenders.

KENTUCKYUTILITIESCO_03_25_2003-EX-10.65-.summary: This Gas Transportation Agreement, dated November 1, 2002, is between Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company ("Transporter") and Louisville Gas and Electric Company ("Shipper").  The agreement outlines the transportation of a maximum of 51,000 dekatherms of natural gas daily from three receipt points (specified in Exhibit A) to one delivery point.  The Transporter's key obligation is firm transportation, subject to minimum pressure requirements (500-600 psi) at the delivery point, as detailed in Article IV, and limitations in Transporter's FERC Gas Tariff.  Shipper's main obligation is payment for transportation services according to Transporter's Rate Schedule FT-A, incorporated by reference, and the General Terms and Conditions of Transporter's FERC Gas Tariff.  The agreement includes provisions for rate changes, billing, and dispute resolution as per the FERC Gas Tariff.  The term is from November 1, 2002, to October 31, 2012, subject to early termination under specific conditions outlined in Exhibit B (requiring notice by October 31, 2006, for termination effective November 1, 2007, or upon termination of a separate July 8, 2002 agreement).  The agreement is governed by Texas law.  Financial arrangements are based on the FT-A rate schedule and include provisions for incidental charges.  The agreement also contains warranties, indemnification clauses, and assignment restrictions.

PHREESIA,INC_05_28_2019-EX-10.18-STRATEG.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective December 10, 2015, is between Allscripts Healthcare, LLC ("Allscripts") and Phreesia, Inc. ("Phreesia").  The agreement establishes a reseller relationship where Allscripts will market and resell Phreesia's software services (Eligibility & Benefit Services, POS Dashboard) and Merchant Processing Services to its customers (Sublicensed Customers).

Allscripts' key obligations include marketing Phreesia's offerings, executing Customer Agreements (with terms no less protective than Allscripts' own), and providing implementation services. Phreesia's key obligations include providing software, updates, and support services, as well as maintaining compliance with relevant laws (HIPAA, HITECH).  A HIPAA Business Associate Agreement is executed concurrently.

Important terms include detailed definitions of key concepts (e.g., "Change of Control," "Confidential Information"),  intellectual property licensing provisions granting Allscripts broad sublicensing rights, and stringent confidentiality obligations.  The agreement also includes detailed indemnification and limitation of liability clauses, with exceptions for gross negligence and intellectual property infringement.

Financial arrangements involve revenue sharing on Merchant Processing Services and fees for implementation and other services, detailed in Exhibit F.  Allscripts provides a sales forecast.  Audit rights are granted to both parties.

The initial term is five years, automatically renewing for successive terms unless terminated. Termination clauses exist for convenience, cause, insolvency, force majeure, Change of Control (particularly to a competitor), and exclusion/termination of Merchant Processing Services.  The agreement is governed by Illinois law and includes a dispute resolution clause specifying arbitration under CPR rules.

Array BioPharma Inc. - LICENSE, DEVELOPM.contract_id: Array BioPharma Inc. - LICENSE, DEVELOPMENT AND COMMERCIALIZATION AGREEMENT
Array BioPharma Inc. - LICENSE, DEVELOPM.contract_title: Array BioPharma Inc. - LICENSE, DEVELOPMENT AND COMMERCIALIZATION AGREEMENT
Array BioPharma Inc. - LICENSE, DEVELOPM.summary:
This License, Development, and Commercialization Agreement (May 31, 2017) is between Array BioPharma Inc. ("Array") and Ono Pharmaceutical Co., Ltd. ("Ono").  The agreement concerns the development and commercialization of pharmaceutical products containing Binimetinib or Encorafenib.

**Purpose:**  Array grants Ono exclusive rights to develop and commercialize these products in Japan and Korea (Ono Territory), while retaining rights for the rest of the world (Array Territory).  Ono leads development and commercialization in its territory.

**Key Obligations:** Ono is responsible for development (subject to JDRC oversight), regulatory filings, and commercialization in the Ono Territory. Array retains development rights outside the Ono Territory and provides Ono with necessary know-how and data.  Both parties cooperate on joint clinical studies.  Ono must use diligent efforts to maximize sales.

**Terms & Conditions:**  Detailed definitions govern key terms (e.g., "Diligent Efforts," "Net Sales").  Royalty payments to Array are tiered based on Ono's net sales, subject to adjustments for generic competition.  Milestone payments are also payable to Array upon achievement of specified milestones.  Intellectual property ownership and licensing are clearly defined.  Strict confidentiality provisions apply.  Dispute resolution involves escalation to senior executives, expert determination, and ultimately, arbitration under ICC rules.

**Financial Arrangements:** Ono pays Array an upfront fee, milestone payments, and tiered royalties on net sales.  Specific financial details are redacted in the provided text.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement's duration is tied to the Secondary Royalty Term for each product in each country. Ono may terminate without cause after a specified

MERCATAINC_03_09_2000-EX-10.21-SPONSORSH.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated July 12, 1999, is between Football Northwest LLC ("FNW"), holder of exclusive Kingdome advertising rights, and Mercata, Inc. ("Sponsor").  The agreement grants Mercata various sponsorship benefits for the 1999 Seattle Seahawks preseason, including television commercials, Kingdome promotions (DiamondVision), Seahawks.com advertising, and VIP access.

Mercata's key obligations include paying a $40,000 sponsorship fee in two installments and providing creative content for its advertising. FNW's obligations include providing the specified sponsorship benefits and defending Mercata against claims arising from FNW's actions.  Both parties agree to indemnify each other for certain liabilities.

The agreement's term runs from July 19, 1999, until completion of the sponsorship benefits, but no later than the end of the 1999 season.  Termination is possible with 45 days' written notice due to Kingdome closure, franchise relocation, or material breach.  A pro-rata refund is provided to Mercata upon termination initiated by them.  The agreement includes clauses on trademark usage, confidentiality, governing law (Washington), arbitration, and attorneys' fees.  FNW's liability is limited to a refund of unpaid consideration.

MEDALISTDIVERSIFIEDREIT,INC_05_18_2020-E.summary: This Consulting Agreement, effective March 1, 2020, is between Gunston Consulting, LLC ("Consultant") and Medalist Diversified REIT, Inc. ("REIT").  The agreement outlines Consultant's engagement as an independent contractor to provide consulting services to REIT, as detailed in a separate Statement of Work.  Key obligations include providing consulting services in a timely and professional manner, maintaining confidentiality of REIT's proprietary information, and assigning all intellectual property rights created during the consultancy to REIT.  The agreement includes restrictive covenants prohibiting solicitation of REIT's employees, customers, and engagement with competitors for 12 months post-termination.  Consultant is responsible for all taxes and expenses, except for pre-approved travel.  Compensation includes a $200,000 annual fee and annual stock grants. The agreement has a 12-month term, automatically renewing unless terminated by either party with 90 days' written notice or immediately for cause (fraud, dishonesty, breach of contract).  Sections 3, 5, 6, and 7 survive termination.  Virginia law governs, with jurisdiction in the Eastern District of Virginia or Chesterfield County Circuit Court.  Mutual indemnification clauses are included.  A change of control provision triggers a 12-month termination fee if Consultant's services are terminated without cause within 12 months of the change.

FOUNDATIONMEDICINE,INC_02_02_2015-EX-10..summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, dated February 2, 2015, is between F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd (Roche Basel) and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. (Roche US) (collectively, "Roche") and Foundation Medicine, Inc. ("FMI").  The agreement outlines a research and development collaboration focused on genomic testing platforms (molecular information, immunotherapy, ctDNA, and companion diagnostics).

Roche and FMI have reciprocal license grants for background and foreground intellectual property (IP) necessary for collaborative activities.  FMI's key obligations include developing and testing these platforms, adhering to performance specifications and quality standards, and providing Roche with access to its molecular information database. Roche's main responsibilities involve funding FMI's FTEs, providing samples and data, and collaborating on development and regulatory approvals (subject to related commercialization agreements).  FMI retains commercialization rights for most products, except where otherwise specified.

The agreement establishes a Joint Management Committee (JMC) and Joint Research & Development Committee (JRDC) to govern the collaboration.  FMI retains decision-making authority over its ctDNA platform, while Roche has final say on other aspects.  Specific financial arrangements vary by platform, including FTE funding, milestone payments, and fees for services rendered.  The agreement's term is tied to completion of R&D plans, with termination clauses for breach, insolvency, and Roche's option to terminate without cause (except for the ctDNA platform).  Dispute resolution is via arbitration under AAA rules.  Confidentiality and IP ownership are extensively detailed.  The agreement is governed by New York law.

RevolutionMedicinesInc_20200117_S-1_EX-1.summary:
This Collaborative Research, Development, and Commercialization Agreement, dated June 8, 2018, is between Revolution Medicines, Inc. ("RevMed") and Aventis, Inc. ("Sanofi").  The agreement outlines a collaboration to research, develop, and commercialize SHP2 inhibitor drug candidates for cancer treatment.

RevMed grants Sanofi an exclusive, royalty-bearing license to the RevMed Licensed Technology for worldwide commercialization.  Sanofi is primarily responsible for development, regulatory filings, and commercialization, while RevMed contributes research expertise and certain technology transfers.  Joint committees (JSC, JRDC, JCC, JPC, JMC) govern the collaboration, with Sanofi holding final decision-making power in many instances.  RevMed retains certain rights not explicitly licensed.

Key terms include definitions of various intellectual property rights,  "Commercially Reasonable Efforts," and detailed cost-sharing and royalty structures.  Sanofi makes a $50 million upfront payment, plus milestone payments (up to $520 million total), and pays royalties on net sales outside the US, with a profit/loss share agreement for US sales.  The agreement also addresses confidentiality, publication, and indemnification.

The agreement's term continues until Sanofi's payment obligations under Article IX or the Profit/Loss Share Agreement conclude.  Termination clauses exist for convenience, material breach, insolvency, competing products, and safety concerns, with specific provisions outlining the effects of termination, including technology transfer and royalty obligations.  An amendment dated August 24, 2018, clarifies Sanofi's sponsorship of the first clinical trial in Section 6.5.

AFSALABANCORPINC_08_01_1996-EX-1.1-AGENC.summary:
This Agency Agreement (AFSALABANCORPINC_08_01_1996-EX-1.1) governs the relationship between AFSALA Bancorp, Inc. ("Company"), Amsterdam Federal Savings and Loan Association ("Association"), and Capital Resources, Inc. ("Capital Resources") concerning the Association's conversion to a stock savings bank and the subsequent public offering of the Company's common stock.  The agreement appoints Capital Resources as agent to assist with the stock sale.

Capital Resources' key obligations include advising the Company and Association on the conversion and public offering, potentially assembling a selling group of broker-dealers.  The Company and Association warrant the accuracy of the registration statement and conversion application filings.  They also covenant to cooperate with Capital Resources in fulfilling all regulatory requirements.

Capital Resources' compensation includes a marketing fee (2% of shares sold, excluding broker-dealer sales and employee stock ownership plan sales) and a management fee (1.5% of broker-dealer sales).  Reimbursement for reasonable out-of-pocket expenses is also provided.  The Company and Association are responsible for broker-dealer commissions.

The agreement terminates upon completion, termination, or abandonment of the conversion plan, or substantial adverse amendment to the plan materially changing Capital Resources' role, but no later than 45 days after the offering's completion.  If the Company fails to sell a minimum of 935,000 shares, the agreement terminates, and subscribers receive full refunds plus interest.  Extensive indemnification and contribution clauses allocate liability among the parties.  The agreement is governed by District of Columbia law.

ETELOS,INC_03_09_2004-EX-10.8-DISTRIBUTO.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective July 1, 1998, between Tripath Technology, Inc. ("Tripath") and Uniquest Corporation ("Distributor"), establishes a non-exclusive distributorship for Tripath semiconductor products in Korea.  The Distributor is obligated to use best efforts to market and sell Tripath products within the designated territory, maintaining adequate sales and technical support staff, and sufficient inventory.  Tripath retains the right to make direct sales to certain accounts.

Tripath provides pricing, technical and marketing information, and handles warranties directly to end-users.  Financial terms include a distributor price list subject to change, payment upon shipment, and specific procedures for credits, returns, and special pricing allowances (requiring DPAs).  Purchase orders are only binding upon Tripath's issuance of a Sales Order Acknowledgment.  Inventory is price-protected for a limited period.
