The agreement includes provisions for reporting, audits, use of Tripath trademarks (non-exclusive license), confidentiality, export controls, and intellectual property indemnity (with limitations on Tripath's liability).  Both parties are independent contractors.

The agreement has a one-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with one month's written notice.  Either party may terminate immediately for insolvency.  Termination clauses detail procedures for inventory buyback by Tripath, with potential restocking fees.  Governing law is California, with disputes resolved through ICC arbitration in Santa Clara County.  Incidental and consequential damages are excluded from liability.

LifewayFoodsInc_20160316_10-K_EX-10.24_9.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, effective March 14, 2016, is between Lifeway Foods, Inc. ("Lifeway") and Ludmila Smolyansky ("Individual").  It grants Lifeway perpetual, worldwide, non-exclusive rights to use Smolyansky's name, image, and likeness in marketing Lifeway products.  Smolyansky waives inspection and approval rights.

Lifeway's key obligations include paying Smolyansky a royalty of $0.02 per product sold bearing her identifying characteristics, capped at $50,000 monthly, until her death.  Lifeway is responsible for all taxes. Smolyansky's key obligations include not endorsing competing products and indemnifying Lifeway against misrepresentations in marketing materials.  Smolyansky warrants her testimonials are truthful and reflects her bona fide use of Lifeway products.

The agreement includes standard clauses on ownership of marketing materials (Lifeway retains ownership), confidentiality, non-assignment without consent, choice of law (Illinois), force majeure, and a general survival clause.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties and can only be amended in writing.  No specific termination clause is explicitly stated, but the royalty payments cease upon Smolyansky's death.

LEGACYTECHNOLOGYHOLDINGS,INC_12_09_2005-.summary:
This Exclusive Distributor Agreement, effective December 8, 2005, is between Sierra Mountain Minerals, Inc. (SIERRA), a Canadian manufacturer of "SierraSil" (a joint health product), and LifeUSA/Envision Health, Inc. (ENVISION), a nutritional supplement manufacturer.  ENVISION is appointed as the exclusive worldwide distributor of SierraSil blended with Krill Oil (the Finished Product).

ENVISION's key obligations include best-efforts marketing, providing sales projections to SIERRA, and being responsible for Finished Product development and manufacturing costs. SIERRA's obligations include supplying the Product to ENVISION, referring interested customers to ENVISION, and maintaining sufficient production to meet demand.  SIERRA retains ownership of the "SierraSil" trademark, granting ENVISION a non-exclusive license.

Financial terms stipulate a purchase price based on SierraSil's wholesale price list, with payment terms of 1/3 upon order placement and 2/3 net 30 days.  Shipping costs are ENVISION's responsibility.  Both parties provide warranties and indemnification clauses regarding product defects and liability.  SIERRA warrants ownership of patents and grants ENVISION a royalty-free sub-license.

The agreement has a two-year term with automatic annual renewals unless terminated with 60 days' notice. Termination clauses include material breach, bankruptcy, confidentiality breach, government interference, or force majeure events lasting over 60 days.  Colorado law governs the agreement.  Attorney's fees are awarded to the prevailing party in litigation.  The agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties.

DeltathreeInc_19991102_S-1A_EX-10.19_622.summary:
This Co-Branding and Services Agreement, effective October 1, 1999, is between RSL COM PrimeCall, Inc. ("PrimeCall") and deltathree.com, Inc. ("DeltaThree"), both Delaware corporations.  The agreement's main purpose is to co-brand a prepaid IP telephony calling card and establish an online sales platform for PrimeCall's calling cards.

PrimeCall's key obligations include negotiating printing and distribution of the co-branded card, procuring a toll-free number, providing pricing and marketing services, and handling sales and customer service (outsourced on DeltaThree's behalf).  DeltaThree's responsibilities encompass developing and maintaining PrimeCall's e-commerce website, providing online advertising (500,000 impressions monthly), and handling online billing and fulfillment.  Both parties will share reciprocal website links and limited licenses to use each other's trademarks.  All revenues from the calling card accrue to DeltaThree.

Financial arrangements involve monthly reimbursements to PrimeCall for services rendered and payments to DeltaThree for online sales.  Payment is due within 25 business days of monthly reports.

The agreement lasts three years, unless terminated earlier by PrimeCall if RSL Communications, Ltd. and/or its affiliates hold less than 50% of DeltaThree's voting shares, or for material breach (30-day cure period) or bankruptcy of either party (10-day notice period).  Both parties disclaim warranties and limit liability to direct damages.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  Confidentiality clauses are included, and the agreement cannot be modified except in

SPRINGBANKPHARMACEUTICALS,INC_04_08_2020.summary: This Joint Filing Agreement, dated April 7, 2020, between UBS Oncology Impact Fund L.P., Oncology Impact Fund (Cayman) Management L.P., and MPM Oncology Impact Management LP/MPM Oncology Impact Management GP LLC (collectively, "the Parties"), governs the joint filing of a Schedule 13G statement (and amendments) regarding Spring Bank Pharmaceuticals, Inc. common stock.  The agreement's primary purpose is to allow the Parties to jointly report their beneficial ownership, pursuant to Rule 13d-1(k) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  Each Party authorizes others to file amendments on their behalf.  Key obligations include the joint filing and mutual authorization for amendment filings.  No specific duration or termination clause is explicitly stated; the agreement is implicitly tied to the ongoing Schedule 13G reporting requirements.  No financial arrangements are detailed within this agreement.  The agreement allows for execution in counterparts.

ImineCorp_20180725_S-1_EX-10.5_11275970_.summary:
This Non-Exclusive Distributor Agreement, dated July 19, 2018, is between iMine Corporation ("JRVS"), an Indiana company, and Sunwai Technology, a Taiwanese company.  JRVS appoints Sunwai as a non-exclusive distributor of its cryptocurrency mining rigs and components in Taiwan.

Sunwai's key obligations include aggressive marketing, sales, and reporting; maintaining sufficient inventory; complying with all applicable laws; and referring certain customers and business opportunities to JRVS.  JRVS's main obligations involve supplying products at its current price (subject to change),  processing orders (minimum 5 units), and providing reasonable delivery times.  Orders are generally non-cancelable and non-returnable.  JRVS retains ownership of all proprietary rights.

The agreement lasts two years, renewable by mutual written consent, and is terminable by either party with 90 days' written notice or for cause (30 days' notice, except for immediate termination for breach of confidentiality).  Financial terms include net 30 payment terms in USD, with a 1.5% monthly late fee.  JRVS's liability is capped at the amount received for the relevant product, excluding consequential damages.  Indiana law governs, with disputes resolved through arbitration in Hamilton County, Indiana.  Confidentiality and indemnification clauses are included.

CCAINDUSTRIESINC_04_14_2014-EX-10.1-OUTS.summary:
This Services Outsourcing Agreement, dated January 20, 2014, is between CCA Industries, Inc. ("Company") and Emerson HealthCare, LLC ("Contractor").  The agreement outsources logistical and administrative services for CCA's products (listed in Exhibit A).  Contractor's key obligations include performing services detailed in Exhibit B, monthly meetings with the Company, providing access to its records, and acting as a collection agent for Accounts Receivable, which remain Company property.

Contractor receives a percentage ([*]%) of Company's Gross Invoiced Sales as Service Fees, paid within five days of month-end.  Contractor also handles remittances to the Company, less specified deductions (detailed in Section 4.02), and may retain funds for a 24-month Withholding Period to cover potential deductions.  The agreement includes confidentiality, indemnification, and insurance clauses.

The initial term is six months, automatically renewing unless terminated with six months' written notice.  Either party can terminate for material breach (30-day cure period) or non-payment (3-day cure period).  The Company can terminate with less than six months' notice, subject to a Termination Fee.  New products can be added.  Governing law is New Jersey, with disputes resolved through arbitration.  Sections regarding Intellectual Property, Confidentiality, Records Management, and financial obligations survive termination.

Microgenics Corporation - Collaborative.contract_id: Microgenics Corporation - Collaborative Development and Commercialization Agreement
Microgenics Corporation - Collaborative.contract_title: Microgenics Corporation - Collaborative Development and Commercialization Agreement
Microgenics Corporation - Collaborative.summary:
This Collaborative Development and Commercialization Agreement, effective April 26, 2016, is between Microgenics Corporation (Microgenics) and Achaogen Inc. (Achaogen).  The agreement concerns the joint development and commercialization of a therapeutic drug monitoring assay for Plazomicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic developed by Achaogen.

Microgenics is responsible for research, development, manufacture, and sale of the assay, using Achaogen's provided materials and know-how. Achaogen provides Plazomicin materials, data, and know-how; shares commercialization plans; and provides volume forecasts (with the first [***] months binding).  Microgenics is obligated to meet these forecasts and maintain sufficient supply, potentially utilizing a backup supplier.  Achaogen retains the right to develop and commercialize other Plazomicin assays, subject to limitations.  Both parties have responsibilities regarding regulatory submissions and approvals.

The agreement includes provisions for intellectual property ownership and licensing, confidentiality, indemnification, dispute resolution (arbitration in Delaware), and audit rights.  Achaogen makes milestone payments to Microgenics for development phases.  The agreement's term lasts until Achaogen ceases Plazomicin development and commercialization, with termination clauses allowing for termination at will (60-day notice) or for cause (material breach).  In case of termination for cause by Achaogen, a Transfer License is granted to Achaogen with royalty payments.  Significant portions of the contract, including financial details, are redacted.

SigaTechnologiesInc_20190603_8-K_EX-10.1.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, effective May 31, 2019, is between Siga Technologies, Inc. ("SIGA") and Meridian Medical Technologies, Inc., a Pfizer company ("MMT").  The agreement grants MMT exclusive rights to promote SIGA's TPOXX® (tecovirimat) product outside the U.S., South Korea, and certain restricted markets.

MMT's key obligations include promoting the product using commercially reasonable efforts, adhering to all applicable laws and Pfizer's policies, and reporting sales data to SIGA. SIGA's responsibilities include providing certain assistance to MMT, maintaining intellectual property rights, and supplying the product.  A Joint Steering Committee governs the collaboration.

MMT receives a tiered percentage of yearly collected revenue as a promotion fee, deducted from quarterly payments to SIGA.  Audits are permitted by SIGA.  Both parties provide mutual representations and warranties, including compliance with laws and regulations.  Detailed indemnification clauses protect both parties from certain liabilities.

The agreement has an initial five-year term, automatically renewable for three-year periods unless terminated. Termination clauses exist for material breach, certain changes of control, and convenience, with provisions for handling existing customer contracts upon termination.  Several provisions, including indemnification and confidentiality, survive termination.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with a waiver of jury trial.

VgrabCommunicationsInc_20200129_10-K_EX-.summary:
This Mobile Application Development Agreement (Agreement No: VAL/MAD/PVTINV/DC/190305/1), dated March 5, 2019, is between VGrab Asia Ltd. ("VAL"), a Hong Kong company, and three individual developers (collectively, "Developer") in P.R. China, led by Ms. Chen Weijie.  The agreement concerns the development of a Chinese mobile application ("Project") for Duesey Coffee, encompassing iOS and Android platforms, WeChat integration (including store, social media, and payment), and backend software.

VAL's key obligations include providing necessary graphics and design elements and making payments.  The Developer's key obligations are to design and develop the application according to specifications, meeting defined milestones within a six-month period (renewable), and ensuring WeChat compliance.  The total payment is $200,000 USD, distributed among the three developers.  Milestones are detailed, with a bug-fixing warranty period.

The agreement specifies that all intellectual property rights vest in VAL upon completion.  It includes clauses on confidentiality, change orders (requiring written agreement), termination (with two weeks' notice and pro-rata compensation), governing law (Hong Kong), and dispute resolution (arbitration, then Hong Kong courts).  Electronic signatures are recognized, and the agreement is governed by Hong Kong law.

AIRTECHINTERNATIONALGROUPINC_05_08_2000-.summary: This is a Franchise Agreement dated May 8, 2000, between Airsopure International Group, Inc. ("AIRSOPURE"), a Nevada corporation, and an individual or corporate Franchisee.  The agreement grants the Franchisee the exclusive right to operate an Airsopure Center within a defined territory for 10 years, renewable for two additional 10-year terms.  The Franchisee's key obligations include paying an initial franchise fee ($25,000), monthly royalties (5% of gross sales), and advertising fees (4% of gross sales), adhering to AIRSOPURE's operating procedures (detailed in the Operations Manual), maintaining insurance, and not competing with AIRSOPURE post-termination.  AIRSOPURE's obligations include providing training, initial product supply, and ongoing support.  The agreement contains detailed provisions regarding the use of Licensed Marks, transfer of interest (including a right of first refusal for AIRSOPURE), confidentiality, default and termination (with specific grounds for immediate termination and 30-day cure periods for others), and indemnification.  The agreement specifies Texas law and Dallas County, Texas as the governing law and jurisdiction, with a mediation requirement prior to litigation.  Failure to comply with the agreement's terms, particularly those concerning payments, operating procedures, and confidentiality, can lead to termination and potential legal action.

IMMUNOMEDICSINC_08_07_2019-EX-10.1-PROMO.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, dated April 5, 2019, is between Janssen Biotech, Inc. (Janssen) and Immunomedics, Inc. (Company).  It's a non-exclusive agreement engaging Company to promote Janssen's product, BALVERSA™ (erdafitinib), for a specific indication (locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma) in the United States.

Company's key obligations include detailing the product to a target list provided by Janssen, adhering to specified detailing requirements (minimum number of details, reach, etc.), and using only Janssen-approved promotional materials.  Company must maintain a minimum sales force size and comply with all applicable laws and regulations, including stringent healthcare compliance provisions (detailed in Exhibit D).  Janssen retains all rights regarding product development, regulatory matters, sales, and distribution.

Janssen's key obligations include providing promotional materials, training, and a target list.  Financially, Janssen pays Company service fees (percentage of net sales exceeding a baseline) and milestone payments based on cumulative net sales.  Weekly prescriber-level sales data (subject to agreement on cost allocation) will be provided to Company.

The agreement runs until March 31, 2020 (with financial obligations extending beyond), but contains numerous termination clauses, including for failure to meet detailing requirements, material breach, insolvency, and certain regulatory events.  Detailed dispute resolution procedures (mediation and arbitration) are included.  Both parties provide extensive representations and warranties regarding compliance, authority, and non-infringement.  Confidentiality and non-solicitation clauses are also present.  Significant indemnification provisions protect both parties from certain liabilities.

HPILHOLDING_01_07_2015-EX-99.1-COOPERATI.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated January 5, 2015, is between HPIL ENERGYTECH Inc. (HPIL ET), a Nevada corporation, and GINARES GROUP AG, a Swiss private company.  The agreement's purpose is to foster cooperation in expanding GINARES' renewable energy projects utilizing its NCT technology.  

HPIL ET's obligations include monitoring GINARES' progress and collaborating as needed; GINARES must keep HPIL ET informed and similarly collaborate.  Both parties provide mutual representations and warranties regarding their authority to enter the agreement and compliance with laws.  A key provision establishes mutual indemnification for losses arising from breaches of representations, warranties, or covenants.  No financial compensation is exchanged.

The agreement's term is one year, terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration under the ICC Rules in Paris.  Nevada law governs.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties, requiring any amendments to be in writing and signed.  Confidentiality is maintained except as legally required or with prior written consent.

BravatekSolutionsInc_20170418_8-K_EX-10..summary:
This Reseller Agreement, effective April 7, 2017, is between i3 Integrative Creative Solutions, LLC ("i3 ICS") and Bravatek Solutions, Inc. ("Bravatek").  i3 ICS acts as a reseller of Bravatek's cybersecurity email software and telecom services to US Federal Government agencies.  The agreement's primary purpose is to establish a reseller relationship for Bravatek's products within a defined territory.

i3 ICS's key obligations include soliciting orders, using Bravatek's marketing materials, and providing sales assistance (introductions, proposals, etc.) for "Registered Referrals" and "Registered Opportunities." Bravatek's obligations include providing pricing quotes, support (training, marketing materials, technical resources), and paying i3 ICS a referral fee (25% of net revenue for Registered Referrals, plus discounts for Registered Opportunities and Fulfillment Transactions, as detailed in Exhibit B).  Exclusivity is granted to i3 ICS for Registered Referrals and Opportunities for six months post-termination.

The agreement lasts one year and is renewable.  Either party can terminate with 60 days' written notice.  Termination clauses detail procedures and consequences, including the return of proprietary information.  Financial arrangements center around referral fees and discounts based on the type of sale (Registered Referral, Registered Opportunity, Fulfillment Transaction).  Both parties are independent contractors, and indemnification clauses cover patent/copyright infringement and other liabilities.  Virginia law governs the agreement.

SPORTHALEYINC_09_29_1997-EX-10.2-10-ENDO.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated 1997, is between Sport-Haley, Inc. (a Colorado corporation) and a professional golfer (the "Professional") playing on the PGA or Senior PGA Tour.  The agreement's purpose is to secure the Professional's endorsement of Sport-Haley's "Haley" brand golf apparel.

The Professional's key obligations include exclusively endorsing and wearing Haley apparel during play and public appearances; granting Sport-Haley exclusive worldwide rights to use their name, likeness, etc., for advertising; and participating in promotional events (one per year).  Sport-Haley must provide reasonable expenses for these events. The Professional receives a wardrobe of Haley apparel and unspecified compensation (details omitted from provided text).

Sport-Haley receives exclusive worldwide rights to use the Professional's image for advertising and promotion, subject to a clause preventing portrayal in an unfavorable light. The Professional retains endorsement rights for non-golf apparel.

The agreement's term is unspecified, ending on a date to be determined, unless extended or terminated.  Termination can occur if the Professional becomes a non-exempt PGA player, or if either party breaches the agreement and fails to cure the breach within 30 days of notice.  Post-termination, Sport-Haley has 90 days to use existing promotional materials.  The agreement is governed by Colorado law and disputes are subject to binding arbitration in Denver.  Assignment by the Professional is prohibited; Sport-Haley's assignment requires the Professional's consent, except in certain corporate transactions.

XENCORINC_10_25_2013-EX-10.24-COLLABORAT.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, effective February 10, 2012, is between Xencor, Inc. ("XENCOR") and Boehringer Ingelheim International GmbH ("BII").  The agreement concerns the development and manufacture of XENCOR's anti-TNF monoclonal antibody, XmAb6755 ("Product"), using XENCOR's cell line ("Material").

BII's main obligation is to develop a fed-batch production process for the Product, sufficient for preclinical and Phase 1 clinical testing,  delivering the product according to specified quality and delivery terms (QAA). XENCOR's key obligations include providing the Material and using commercially reasonable efforts to complete Phase 1 clinical trials and secure a business partner for further development.

BII receives a first right to negotiate manufacturing for Phase 2/3 clinical trials and commercial supply (Principal Supplier), contingent on successful Phase 1.  Financial arrangements include Project Fees paid by XENCOR to BII,  payable upon achieving certain milestones (e.g., Business Partner agreement, Phase 1 completion) or after a five-year period. A Technology Access Fee is payable if XENCOR uses the process outside the agreement.  Payment terms are detailed, with potential for no payment under certain circumstances.

The agreement's duration is tied to project completion, with termination clauses for material breach (30-day cure period) or if the project becomes infeasible (180-day notice).  Specific termination consequences are outlined, including payment obligations and intellectual property rights.  New intellectual property rights are allocated based on contribution, with joint ownership of certain improvements.  Confidentiality and indemnification clauses are included,

NETGROCERINC_07_31_1998-EX-10.15-SPONSOR.summary: This Sponsorship Agreement, dated December 15, 1997, is between Excite, Inc. (Excite) and NetGrocer, Inc. (NetGrocer).  NetGrocer seeks to promote its online supermarket service on Excite's website.  The agreement outlines extensive banner advertising and promotional link placement on Excite's various channels and search results pages, targeting specific keywords.  Excite guarantees a minimum number of "Click-throughs" (user clicks on NetGrocer links) over two years, with make-good provisions for shortfalls.  NetGrocer's obligations include payment of a one-time initiation fee and annual sponsorship/advertising fees, plus additional fees per click exceeding guaranteed amounts.  NetGrocer retains customer data rights.  Excite grants NetGrocer exclusivity against specified competitors (listed in Exhibit A) for online supermarket advertising on Excite's site, with exceptions for search results and directories.  The agreement includes clauses on trademark usage, confidentiality, warranties, indemnities, limitations of liability, dispute resolution (mediation and arbitration), and termination (for material breach after 60-day notice). The term is two years or until Excite delivers all guaranteed click-throughs, with payment terms detailed for each year.  Governing law is California.

CoherusBiosciencesInc_20200227_10-K_EX-1.summary:
This License and Development Agreement, effective November 2, 2019, is between Bioeq IP AG (Bioeq) and Coherus BioSciences, Inc. (Coherus).  The agreement grants Coherus an exclusive license to commercialize Bioeq's Ranibizumab biosimilar products (Licensed Products) in the United States.

Bioeq's key obligations include developing and obtaining regulatory approval for the Licensed Products, and manufacturing and supplying them to Coherus.  Coherus is solely responsible for commercialization, including marketing, sales, and distribution.  Both parties have diligence obligations and must use commercially reasonable efforts.  A Manufacturing and Supply Agreement, based on an attached term sheet, will govern manufacturing and supply details.  A Pharmacovigilance Agreement will address post-market safety.

Key terms include definitions of "Commercially Reasonable Efforts," "Net Sales," and "Gross Margin," which are crucial for royalty calculations.  Coherus pays Bioeq an upfront fee, milestone payments, and royalties based on Gross Margin.  The royalty rate is tiered.  Detailed reporting and audit rights are included.

The agreement lasts for ten years after the first commercial sale, automatically renewing unless terminated.  Termination clauses cover material breach, underperformance (market share thresholds), development of competitive products by Coherus, patent challenges, and insolvency.  Licensee has a right to terminate for convenience and for development delays.  Specific provisions address intellectual property ownership, patent dance procedures under the BPCIA, and indemnification.  Dispute resolution is through negotiation and then binding arbitration.

FEDERATEDGOVERNMENTINCOMESECURITIESINC_0.summary:
This Limited Power of Attorney (LPOA), dated January 1, 2004, appoints Federated Advisory Services Company (FASC) as attorney-in-fact for Federated Investment Management Company (Adviser).  The Adviser acts as investment advisor/subadviser for numerous funds (listed in Schedule 1), and this LPOA grants FASC authority to execute documents related to acquiring, disposing of, and reinvesting fund assets under the Adviser's supervision, as detailed in a separate Services Agreement (dated January 1, 2004) and Investment Advisory Contracts for each fund.

FASC acts solely as the Adviser's agent, assuming no personal liability for fund obligations.  The Adviser indemnifies FASC against losses (excluding gross negligence or willful misconduct) arising from the LPOA's execution.  All parties dealing with FASC are notified that they must look solely to the relevant fund's assets for enforcement of claims.  The LPOA's duration is tied to the Services Agreement and individual Investment Advisory Contracts; it can be revoked by the Adviser with written notice to FASC.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed beyond the indemnification clause.  The LPOA is governed by Pennsylvania law and contains severability and integration clauses.

DIVERSINETCORP_03_01_2012-EX-4-RESELLER.summary:
This Reseller Agreement, dated January 11, 2011, is between Diversinet Corp. (licensor) and 2205925 Ontario Limited (reseller).  Diversinet licenses its mobile device security software ("Products") to the reseller for sale within a defined Canadian territory to specified customer types (Canadian headquartered companies and government/public sector entities).  The reseller is granted an exclusive license, contingent upon meeting an Annual Minimum Commitment (AMC) of escalating amounts over five years.  Failure to meet AMC payments or sales targets (post-AMC termination) constitutes grounds for termination.

Key reseller obligations include marketing and selling the Products, adhering to Diversinet's branding guidelines, providing customer support (levels 1 & 2), and reporting sales data. Diversinet's obligations include providing the Products, technical support (level 3), and training.  Pricing is based on a tiered discount structure linked to annual revenue.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on intellectual property ownership, warranties (limited to substantial accordance with documentation), liability limitations (excluding foreseeable damages), indemnification clauses, and a confidential information clause.  The agreement has a five-year initial term with automatic one-year renewals unless terminated by the reseller with 60 days' notice.  Termination triggers a phase-out period and the return/destruction of all Products and documentation.  The agreement specifies Ontario law and Toronto courts as the governing jurisdiction and forum.  An escrow agreement for source code is also mandated.

NmfSlfIInc_20200115_10-12GA_EX-10.5_1194.summary:
This Trademark License Agreement, effective [date], is between New Mountain Capital, L.L.C. (Licensor) and NMF Senior Loan Fund I, Inc. (Licensee), with New Mountain Finance Advisers, BDC, L.L.C. as a third-party beneficiary.  The agreement grants Licensee a perpetual, non-exclusive, royalty-free license to use the "NMF" trademark in specified territories solely as part of its company name and in connection with licensed financial services.

Licensee's key obligations include maintaining quality standards consistent with Licensor's, complying with all applicable laws, notifying Licensor of any trademark infringements, and assigning any goodwill generated to Licensor.  The Licensor retains ownership of the trademark and the right to use it independently.  The agreement includes representations and warranties of due authorization and execution by both parties, disclaiming any warranties regarding the trademark's validity.

The agreement is terminable by either party under specific conditions, including upon notice of a third-party claim or if the Investment Advisor ceases to serve Licensee.  Upon termination, Licensee must cease using the "NMF" mark and provide specified public notice for 24 months.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed beyond the royalty-free nature of the license.

CURAEGISTECHNOLOGIES,INC_05_26_2010-EX-1.summary:
This Corporate Sponsorship Agreement, effective May 18, 2010, is between Phoenix Performance, LLC ("Vendor") and Torvec Inc. ("Torvec").  The agreement concerns sponsorship of a racing vehicle (T-1 C5 Corvette) in various racing events (World Challenge, SCCA National Racing, SCCA Runoffs) through October 31, 2010, unless renewed or terminated.

Vendor's key obligations include preparing, maintaining, and racing the vehicle. Torvec's main obligation is financial sponsorship, detailed in Exhibit A, which allows Torvec to cancel participation with two weeks' notice.  Torvec receives primary sponsorship rights, approval rights over branding and driver selection (John Heinricy), and use of two differential units.

The agreement grants each party a non-exclusive license to use the other's trademarks for promotional purposes, subject to approval.  Termination is permitted for bankruptcy or insolvency of either party.  Crucially, consequential damages are excluded.  Governing law is New York State law, with exclusive venue in Monroe County, NY courts.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties.  A detailed payment schedule is outlined in Exhibit A.

KALLOINC_11_03_2011-EX-10.1-STRATEGIC AL.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated October 24, 2011, is between KALLO Inc. (Canada), Petro data Management Services Limited (Nigeria), and Gateway Global Fabrication Ltd. (Nigeria).  The agreement establishes a sales agency relationship for KALLO's Mobile Care suite of products in Nigeria.

PDMS and Gateway (jointly "Agent") are appointed as exclusive sales agents for Kallo's products in Nigeria, subject to achieving sales targets (Schedule D).  Key Agent obligations include completing Kallo's training program, submitting a marketing plan, reporting sales activity, maintaining insurance, protecting Kallo's intellectual property, and adhering to Kallo's branding guidelines. Kallo's responsibilities include providing training, marketing materials, and product warranties (limited by the EULA and the contract).  BASCIC is appointed as project manager by all parties.

The agreement grants Kallo ownership of all intellectual property.  Agent owns its "Book of Business" (sales commissions) for 36 months post-sale or until EULA termination.  Financial terms include a training fee ($10,000 plus potential additional training costs), product transfer prices (Schedule A), and payment terms (50% upfront, 35% upon shipping, 15% upon installation).  Taxes and freight are the customer's responsibility.

The agreement's term is indefinite, terminable by either party for material breach (10 business days cure period) or non-material breach (60-day cure period), bankruptcy, or "cause" (3 months' written notice, subject to arbitration).  Upon termination, Kallo manages the Agent's Book of Business,

GridironBionutrientsInc_20171206_8-K_EX-.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, effective October 30, 2017, is between Gridiron BioNutrients (Company), National Football League Alumni, Inc. (NFLA), and NFLA-Northern California Chapter (NFLA-NC).  The agreement grants Gridiron BioNutrients a three-year license (terminable for breach) to use NFLA's "Pro Football Legends" logo for advertising and promoting specified products.

Gridiron BioNutrients' key obligations include paying NFLA-NC a $35,000 license fee and NFLA a $10,000 promotional fee, plus a $0.05 per unit royalty on licensed product sales to NFLA-NC (with 15% sub-donation to NFLA).  They must also provide products to NFLA for member benefits and marketing, and maintain liability insurance.  NFLA's obligations include logo licensing, promotional activities (e-blasts, newsletters, social media), and providing members for promotional appearances (at Gridiron's expense).  Both parties must approve all marketing materials.

The agreement includes clauses for default (10-day payment cure, 30-day performance cure), bankruptcy termination, and a 90-day post-termination period for product liquidation.  California law governs, with arbitration as the dispute resolution method.  NFLA's liability is capped at the remuneration paid, excluding expenses.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties.

MOSSIMOINC_04_14_2000-EX-10.14-ENDORSEME.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated January 1, 2000, is between Mossimo, Inc. ("Company") and David Duval Enterprises, Inc. ("Licensor"), granting Mossimo the right to use professional golfer David Duval's name and likeness to advertise its men's casual apparel ("Products") worldwide for four years (2000-2003).

Mossimo's key obligations include paying Licensor an annual fee ($850,000 base, escalating annually, plus performance bonuses), a substantial upfront payment ($1.5 million), and reimbursing expenses related to Duval's services (modeling, appearances).  Mossimo must obtain Licensor's approval for all uses of Duval's image and aggressively promote the endorsement.  Duval must maintain PGA Tour status and participate in a minimum number of tournaments.

Licensor's main obligations include granting Mossimo exclusive rights to use Duval's image for the specified Products and ensuring Duval's cooperation (wearing Mossimo apparel, consulting on product lines).  Licensor is responsible for ensuring Duval meets minimum performance requirements.

The agreement includes clauses for default (termination for non-payment or breach),  Duval's conduct impacting the agreement (allowing Mossimo to terminate under specific circumstances),  and limitations on Mossimo's use of Duval's image post-termination.  Financial terms are detailed, including payment schedules, interest on late payments, and performance-based bonuses.  The agreement is governed by Ohio law and provides for arbitration in Cleveland, Ohio.

FEDERATEDGOVERNMENTINCOMESECURITIESINC_0.summary:
This March 30, 2009 Amendment modifies a January 1, 2004 Services Agreement between Federated Investment Management Company ("Adviser") and Federated Advisory Services Company ("FASC"), both Delaware statutory trusts.  The amendment pertains solely to Accounts not registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940.

The amendment expands FASC's existing administration and risk management services to include coordination of client portfolios and fixed income trade execution for non-1940 Act Accounts.  FASC's responsibilities now encompass risk management program development, report production, client portfolio coordination, trade execution implementation, documentation completion, operational procedure development, proxy voting coordination, and technical support.  The original Services Agreement remains in effect for 1940 Act Accounts.

The amendment's key terms include the revised scope of FASC's services as detailed above and its governing law (Pennsylvania).  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed in this amendment; those would be found in the underlying Services Agreement.  No termination clause is included; the amendment simply modifies an existing agreement, leaving its original termination provisions intact.

RandWorldwideInc_20010402_8-KA_EX-10.2_2.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, dated November 14, 2000, is between Dassault Systemes (and its affiliates) and PlanetCAD Inc.  Its purpose is to co-brand and jointly offer an internet-based service (Co-Branded Service) built upon PlanetCAD's 3Dshare.com technology and Dassault Systemes' CBD Software.

PlanetCAD owns the Server Software and 3Dshare.com; Dassault Systemes owns the CBD Software.  PlanetCAD initially hosts the service and provides second-level customer support, while Dassault Systemes provides first-level support and access via its websites.  Revenue sharing is dependent on who hosts:  redacted percentages are allocated to each party.  Net Revenue is defined and reporting/payment obligations are detailed, including audit rights for the Non-Billing Party.  PlanetCAD maintains and updates Dassault Systemes' customer databases, subject to confidentiality obligations.  Both parties have competitive restrictions and indemnification clauses.

The agreement has an initial three-year term from the Launch Date, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with six months' notice.  Termination can also occur for material breach after a 60-day cure period.  Revenue sharing is renegotiated after the initial term; failure to agree terminates the contract after six months.  New York law governs, with Delaware venue and jury trial waivers.  The agreement includes standard clauses on confidentiality, assignment, and force majeure.

GOLDRESOURCECORP_12_11_2008-EX-10.1-STRA.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 5, 2008, is between Gold Resource Corporation ("GRC"), a Colorado corporation, and Hochschild Mining Holdings Limited ("HOC"), a UK company.  The agreement facilitates HOC's investment in GRC and establishes a strategic alliance focused on GRC's Mexican gold and silver properties.

Key obligations include HOC's option to purchase additional GRC shares (Additional Shares) at $3.00/share within 80 days of closing, with a pre-emptive right to participate in future equity offerings (subject to a 40% ownership cap within two years).  GRC commits to using a portion of the proceeds to fund exploration and development of the El Aguila project.  If HOC exercises its option and maintains a sufficient shareholding, it gains board representation (one director initially, potentially two if ownership reaches 40%).  HOC also receives a right of first offer on joint ventures concerning GRC's properties.  A standstill agreement prevents HOC from making acquisition proposals exceeding 40% ownership, except under specific circumstances (material breach by GRC, competing offers).  The agreement includes mutual representations and warranties, indemnification clauses, and standard provisions regarding notices, governing law (New York), and termination (based on HOC's shareholding falling below 14.5% or selling over 20% of its holdings).  The agreement also includes provisions for consulting geologists and access to GRC's information for HOC.

Loop Industries, Inc. - Marketing Agreem.summary:
This Marketing Agreement, effective September 2018, is between Loop Industries, Inc. ("Loop") and Indorama Loop Technologies, LLC ("Joint Venture Company").  It governs the sale of Loop-branded recycled PET resins ("Products") produced using Loop's proprietary technology.  Loop retains the exclusive right to enter into sales contracts, but can assign certain contracts to the Joint Venture Company.

The agreement outlines a process for Loop to propose sales contracts ("Proposed Contracts") to the Joint Venture Company.  Eligible contracts are automatically accepted; others are subject to a 10-day review period.  Upon acceptance ("Transferred Contracts"), Loop assigns its rights and obligations to the Joint Venture Company, which then manages sales, invoicing, and collections.  The Joint Venture Company is restricted from independently marketing Products unless Loop's assigned sales fall below a certain threshold of the Joint Venture Company's production capacity.

The agreement includes limitations on liability, confidentiality provisions protecting disclosed information, and standard clauses regarding representations and warranties, independent contractor status, and governing law (Delaware).  The agreement has an indefinite term, terminable for material breach or upon dissolution of the Joint Venture Company or termination of a related license agreement.  Specific financial arrangements are redacted but relate to the value of the transferred contracts and potential damages.

BloomEnergyCorp_20180321_DRSA (on S-1)_E.summary:
This Master Operation and Maintenance Agreement (MOMA), dated April 13, 2012, is between Bloom Energy Corporation ("Bloom" or "Operator") and Diamond State Generation Partners, LLC ("Owner").  The agreement governs the operation and maintenance of Bloom's solid oxide fuel cell power generating systems (Bloom Systems) owned by Owner, with a total nameplate capacity up to 30 MW.

Bloom's key obligations include operating and maintaining the Bloom Systems to meet specified performance (Power Performance and Efficiency Warranties) and efficiency standards.  This includes scheduled and unscheduled maintenance,  establishing a spare parts inventory, and providing qualified personnel.  Owner is responsible for service fees, detailed in Exhibit A, payable annually.  The agreement includes provisions for warranty claims, with limitations on Bloom's liability (Maximum Liability).  An Efficiency Bank mechanism offsets potential shortfalls.

Important terms include definitions of "Warranty Specifications," "Minimum kWh," "Minimum Efficiency Level," and various performance metrics.  The agreement also addresses indemnification, data access, dispute resolution, and confidentiality.

The agreement's term begins upon the first Bloom System's commencement of operation and ends on the last system's warranty period expiration, unless terminated earlier due to default by either party (detailed termination clauses exist).  Financial arrangements include annual service fees and provisions for warranty payments and reimbursements, subject to the Maximum Liability limits.  The governing law is New York State law.

AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_259958.contract_id: AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_2599586_EX-10.32_Co-Branding Agreement_ Marketing Agreement_ Investment Distribution Agreement
AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_259958.contract_title: AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_2599586_EX-10.32_Co-Branding Agreement_ Marketing Agreement_ Investment Distribution Agreement
AudibleInc_20001113_10-Q_EX-10.32_259958.summary:
This Co-Branding, Marketing, and Distribution Agreement, dated January 30, 2000, is between Amazon.com Commerce Services, Inc. ("ACSI") and Audible Inc. ("Company").  The agreement establishes a co-branded online sales channel for Audible's spoken-word audio products on Amazon's website (ACSI Site).

**Main Purpose:** To create a dedicated "Spoken-Word Audio Sub-Section" on the ACSI Site, linked to Audible's mirror site (Mirror Company Site).  Audible maintains the Mirror Company Site, ensuring links back to Amazon and product consistency across both platforms.

**Key Obligations:** ACSI creates and maintains the Sub-Section, incorporating Audible branding. Audible provides products for sale, maintains its site, and complies with Amazon's technical and customer service standards.  ACSI undertakes promotional activities (emails, advertising).

**Important Terms:**  Detailed definitions of intellectual property, including ownership and licensing provisions, are included.  ACSI grants Audible a non-exclusive license to use its intellectual property, and vice versa.  Confidentiality and non-disparagement clauses are present.  A robust dispute resolution process is outlined.

**Financial Arrangements:** Audible pays ACSI annual fees and royalties based on revenue exceeding a threshold.  Initial payments are offset by stock considerations.  Specific amounts are redacted in the provided excerpt.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement lasts three years, terminable for material breach by either party.  Specific termination events include consistent failure to meet customer service standards, insolvency, or harmful conduct.  Termination provisions detail return of intellectual property and financial settlements.  A post-termination transition period is included.

**

HOLIDAYRVSUPERSTORESINC_04_15_2002-EX-10.summary: This Endorsement Agreement, dated March 20, 2002, is between Holiday RV Superstores, Inc. (d/b/a Recreation USA) and Affinity Group, Inc. (AGI), granting Holiday RV a non-exclusive license to use the Good Sam name and logo for three years in connection with RV sales.  Holiday RV pays AGI a $1,500,000 upfront fee and further fees mutually agreed upon.  Holiday RV must obtain AGI's prior approval for all uses of the trademarks.  AGI warrants its right to grant the license and indemnifies Holiday RV against third-party infringement claims (excluding misuse by Holiday RV).  Holiday RV indemnifies AGI against claims arising from unauthorized use.  The agreement includes provisions for a joint marketing program (detailed in a separate agreement),  public disclosure requirements, and a clause preventing either party from assigning the agreement without consent.  Termination can occur for material breach (after 30-day notice) or insolvency, with AGI retaining earned royalties and outstanding payments.  California law governs.

WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10..summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated October 13, 1999, is between Square Two Golf Inc. (Company) and Kathy Whitworth (Professional).  It's a five-year (renewable) endorsement agreement for a signature line of women's golf clubs and other promotional activities.

The Professional grants the Company exclusive rights to use her name, likeness, and image for marketing and sales.  Her obligations include participation in golf clinics, merchandise shows, promotional events, and exclusive use of the Company's products.  The Professional also provides an unqualified endorsement of the products.

The Company's key obligations include paying a $36,000 annual base fee, plus a 2% royalty on product sales (if products are created and marketed), and stock options based on sales.  The Company also reimburses reasonable travel expenses.  Crucially, the Company has no obligation to create or market the products; the base fee satisfies obligations if no products are produced.

The agreement includes a two-year non-compete clause post-termination.  Termination can occur due to death, disability, or material breach (with a 30-day cure period for curable breaches).  The Company's use of the Professional's likeness ceases upon termination, except for existing inventory disposal (for six months).  Governing law is New Jersey.  The agreement includes standard clauses on independent contractor status, intellectual property rights, confidentiality, and assignability.

NeuroboPharmaceuticalsInc_20190903_S-4_E.summary:
This Manufacturing and Supply Agreement, dated September 28, 2018, is between Dong-A ST Co., Ltd. (Korea) and NeuroBo Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (Delaware).  It governs the manufacture and supply of Licensed Products (DA-9801) and matching placebo for NeuroBo's research and development, including Phase III clinical trials.

Dong-A's key obligations include manufacturing and supplying the Licensed Products, meeting specified quality control (KGMP compliant) and adhering to detailed product and API specifications (Exhibits A, B, C, D).  NeuroBo is responsible for supplying the active pharmaceutical ingredient (API), conducting API and product testing, and paying for the products according to the Firm Order (with payment terms specified in Schedule 4.2, including interest on late payments).  A future, separate agreement will cover commercial supply.

Important terms include inspection rights for NeuroBo, dispute resolution mechanisms for product quality issues (independent testing laboratory), and a detailed ordering process with minimum order quantities.  The agreement incorporates by reference key clauses from a related License Agreement.

The agreement lasts for [***] years, unless terminated earlier due to material breach (with a cure period), termination of the License Agreement, bankruptcy, or assignment for the benefit of creditors.  New York law governs.  Financial arrangements involve payment in KRW or USD, with NeuroBo responsible for all taxes related to payments.

SONUSCORP_03_12_1997-EX-10.11-SPONSORSHI.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated March 13, 1996, is between Healthcare Capital Corp. ("Issuer") and C.M. Oliver & Company Limited ("Sponsor"), an investment dealer.  The agreement concerns the Issuer's offering of securities (Units) in British Columbia and Alberta.

The Sponsor's main obligation is to conduct due diligence on the Issuer and, at its sole discretion, sign the Prospectus' certificate, certifying the accuracy of material facts.  The Issuer must provide the Sponsor with access to its business and affairs for this review.  The Issuer represents and warrants the accuracy of information in the Prospectus and its compliance with securities laws.  The Issuer also covenants to take all necessary actions to complete the offering and promptly notify the Sponsor of any material changes.

The Sponsor's fee is $32,100.  The Issuer bears all other costs and expenses related to the offering.  A crucial indemnity clause protects the Sponsor and its affiliates from liability arising from misrepresentations in the Prospectus or non-compliance with securities laws.  The agreement may be terminated by the Sponsor before Prospectus issuance if material misrepresentations, adverse changes, breaches by the Issuer, regulatory actions, or unmet conditions in Section 5 occur.  The indemnity and fee provisions survive termination.  British Columbia law governs.

RangeResourcesLouisianaInc_20150417_8-K_.summary:
This Transportation Services Agreement (TSA), effective April 14, 2015, is between PennTex North Louisiana Operating, LLC ("Carrier") and MRD Operating LLC ("Shipper").  The agreement governs the transportation of Shipper's natural gas liquids ("Product") via Carrier's pipeline system ("System").

The Carrier's key obligations include designing, constructing, and operating the System, including specified facilities (Exhibit B), and transporting Shipper's Product according to the Tariff (Exhibit A), a FERC-filed document incorporated by reference.  The Shipper's main obligations are to deliver Product to the System, comply with the Tariff, and pay transportation fees (Dedicated Rates, initially $1.68/barrel, subject to annual increases and potential adjustments based on regulatory changes).  Shipper dedicates all its Product to the System (subject to the AMI/MEA Agreement), though there's no minimum volume requirement.

The agreement includes detailed provisions on defaults and remedies, including financial assurances (Article XIII) and dispute resolution (Article XII, specifying Texas jurisdiction).  The term is 15 years, renewable unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  The agreement extensively addresses liability limitations, waivers of certain damages (consequential, etc.), force majeure events, and confidentiality.  Taxes are the responsibility of the respective parties (Article XVII).  Assignment is restricted, except for certain permitted transfers (Article XVI).

CHAPARRALRESOURCESINC_03_30_2000-EX-10.6.summary:
This Transportation Contract, dated January 31, 2000, is between JSC NOC KazakhOil ("Company") and JSC Karakudukmunay ("Principal") for the export of crude oil ("Commodity").  The Company arranges transportation and related services for the Principal's oil,  primarily from the Karakuduk Field.

The Principal's key obligations include delivering oil to a specified metering point, obtaining export permits, and making payments for transportation and the Company's fees. The Company's main responsibilities involve handling export permits, arranging transportation (via various delivery bases depending on the period), customs formalities, and delivering the oil to the buyer (STASCO).

Key terms define delivery points (DAF and FOB),  crucial dates (CPC Pipeline Operational Date), and oil quality specifications (REBCO and CPC Blend).  The contract specifies a fee of $1.00 per net tonne for the Company's services, payable within 30 days of delivery.

The Initial Term lasts until the fifth anniversary of the Offtake Agreement's effective date, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 65 days' notice.  Either party can terminate for breach after a 30-day cure period.  Force majeure clauses excuse performance delays due to unforeseen circumstances. Disputes are resolved through negotiation, then court action in the defendant's location, under Kazakhstani law.  Assignment of rights requires written consent.

ScansourceInc_20190509_10-Q_EX-10.2_1166.summary:
This Addendum, dated February 4, 2019, amends a pre-existing Zebra PartnerConnect Distributor Agreement between Zebra Technologies International, LLC (and its affiliates, including Zebra Brazil and Xplore Technologies Corporation of America), collectively "Zebra," and ScanSource, Inc. (and its affiliates, including ScanSource Latin America, ScanSource Brazil, and ScanSource Mexico), collectively "Distributor."  The Addendum's main purpose is to incorporate Xplore Products (acquired by Zebra) into the existing agreement, allowing Distributor to purchase and resell them.

Zebra (specifically Xplore) is obligated to sell Xplore Products to Distributor under the terms of the original agreement, except as modified by this Addendum and Exhibit B.  Distributor is obligated to purchase and resell these products.  Exhibit B details purchase order procedures, including cancellation and modification rights (with limitations), inventory maintenance, and delivery terms (DDP Incoterms 2010).  Specific financial details, including pricing and discounts, are redacted as confidential.  Warranties for Xplore Products differ from Zebra's standard warranty.

The Addendum incorporates future amendments to the original agreement unless conflicting.  It can be terminated by either party according to the original agreement's termination provisions.  The governing law and dispute resolution clauses of the original agreement apply.  The Addendum itself has no specified term.

AURASYSTEMSINC_06_16_2010-EX-10.25-STRAT.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective March 18, 2010, is between Aura Systems Inc. (Delaware) and Zanotti East Inc. (Massachusetts).  The agreement establishes an exclusive supply relationship for all-electric transport refrigeration systems (AETRU Systems) in the US and Canada.  Aura, the inventor of the AuraGen power system, appoints Zanotti as its exclusive supplier of refrigeration systems (Products) for integration into the AETRU System.

Zanotti's key obligations include meeting minimum order quantities (1000 units in 24 months, then 750 annually), providing a minimum initial order, and adhering to pricing terms (subject to Most Favored Nation clause and CPI adjustments).  Aura is responsible for sales, invoicing, and customer relations.  Pricing is detailed in Exhibit B, subject to annual renegotiation. Payment terms require Aura to remit payment within 15 business days of receiving customer payment or 45 calendar days of shipment.

The agreement includes provisions for warehousing, warranties (36-month minimum, with optional 24-month extension), intellectual property licensing (limited, non-exclusive), joint marketing, and confidentiality.  The term is five years, automatically renewing unless terminated with 90 days' notice.  Termination clauses allow for termination due to breach of contract, failure to meet minimum orders, force majeure, or by either party with 60 days' notice.  The agreement specifies dispute resolution via arbitration in Los Angeles, California, and includes indemnification clauses.  Consequential damages are excluded.

IpassInc_20181203_8-K_EX-99.1_11445874_E.summary:
This Channel Partner Reseller Agreement, effective April 25, 2018, is between iPass Inc. ("iPass") and Pareteum Corporation ("Channel Partner").  It governs Channel Partner's non-exclusive right to resell iPass's mobile access services ("Services") to business entities ("Business Entities") and end-users.

Channel Partner's key obligations include:  selling the Services, providing end-user support (per Exhibit D), adhering to iPass's acceptable use policy, entering into end-user agreements (materially similar to Exhibit E), and paying iPass monthly for service usage (per Exhibit C).  iPass's obligations include providing the Licensed Software,  supporting Channel Partner's technical issues (third-level support), and managing the iPass network.  Pricing is detailed in Exhibit C, with a tiered structure based on the number of users.  Both parties have indemnification obligations (Section 8).

The agreement has a 12-month initial term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 60 days' written notice.  Termination may also occur for material breach (30-day cure period) or bankruptcy.  iPass may terminate for economic hardship after a 30-day attempt at resolution.  Upon termination, all outstanding fees are immediately due, and licenses terminate.  California law governs, with jurisdiction in San Mateo County.  The agreement includes standard disclaimers of warranty and limitations of liability.  Specific details regarding service fees, support, and intellectual property rights are contained in various exhibits.

VERSOTECHNOLOGIESINC_12_28_2007-EX-99.3-.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated December 20, 2007, assigns intellectual property rights from NMS Communications Corp. ("Seller," Delaware corporation) to Verso Backhaul Solutions, Inc. ("Backhaul," Georgia corporation).  The assignment is pursuant to a broader Asset Purchase Agreement between NMS and Verso Technologies, Inc. ("Buyer," Minnesota corporation), with Backhaul designated as Buyer's designee.

The IPA's main purpose is to transfer all right, title, and interest in specified intellectual property (detailed in omitted Schedules A and B, likely listing Trademarks and Patents) to Backhaul.  Seller's key obligation is to execute any further documents necessary to vest title in Backhaul upon request.  The IPA is explicitly subordinate to the Asset Purchase Agreement; it does not supersede any obligations within that agreement.  No financial arrangements are detailed in this excerpt; those are presumably within the Asset Purchase Agreement.  The IPA's governing law is Georgia, and it contains standard provisions for execution and delivery of multiple counterparts.  No duration or termination clause is explicitly stated; the agreement's duration is implicitly tied to the underlying Asset Purchase Agreement.

SoupmanInc_20150814_8-K_EX-10.1_9230148_.summary: This addendum, part of a franchise agreement between Soupman, Inc. (Franchisor) and The Grilled Cheese Truck, Inc. (Master Franchisee),  and Kiosk Concepts, Inc., mandates disclosures required by the New York Department of Law.  The agreement concerns a franchise relationship, the specifics of which are not detailed in this addendum.  Key obligations center on disclosure of legal and financial history.  The Franchisor, its predecessors, affiliates, officers, and general partners must disclose any pending or past litigation involving felonies, franchise violations, fraud, or similar offenses within the preceding ten years.  Similarly, any bankruptcy filings or discharges within the same timeframe must be disclosed.  The addendum doesn't specify the duration of the underlying franchise agreement or financial arrangements, focusing solely on mandated disclosures to comply with New York law.  No termination clauses are present in this addendum.  The addendum's purpose is purely to ensure compliance with New York's disclosure requirements, not to define the core terms of the franchise agreement itself.

EhaveInc_20190515_20-F_EX-4.44_11678816_.summary:
This License and Reseller Agreement, dated October 30, 2018, is between Ehave Inc. (Ontario, Canada) and Companion Healthcare Technologies Corp. (Ontario, Canada).  The agreement grants CHT an exclusive (subject to certain conditions) license to resell Ehave's software platform ("Ehave Companion Solution") for use in the animal healthcare market.

CHT's key obligations include marketing and sublicensing the Ehave Companion Solution to end-users, adhering to specified branding guidelines, and maintaining detailed records.  Ehave's main obligations involve operating, maintaining, and supporting the Ehave Companion Solution,  meeting specified service levels, and providing source code escrow.  Both parties have responsibilities regarding data security and confidentiality.

Key terms include definitions of "Confidential Information," "End User Data," and "Objectionable Content," along with detailed provisions on acceptance testing, change control, and intellectual property ownership.  Royalties payable by CHT to Ehave are detailed in Schedule 6.

The agreement is perpetual unless terminated by either party for material breach (with specified cure periods) or insolvency, or by CHT without cause upon 30 days' notice and payment of a termination fee (Schedule 6).  A transition-out period is included.  Dispute resolution involves negotiation, mediation, and arbitration (with exceptions).  Liability is limited, with exceptions for certain damages and willful misconduct.  Both parties are obligated to maintain specified insurance coverage.

BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP.contract_id: BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP WEB SITE BUILDING AND HOSTING AGREEMENT
BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP.contract_title: BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP WEB SITE BUILDING AND HOSTING AGREEMENT
BOLIVARMININGCORP_05_23_2003-EX-2.1-VISP.summary:
This May 12, 2003 agreement between YourNetPlus.com, Inc. ("Provider") and Kingdom Connect, Inc. ("KCI") is a five-year web site building and hosting agreement, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 90 days' written notice.  Provider will build and maintain 5,000 VISP websites for KCI's customers (churches) over five years, including setup, maintenance, technical support, and sales collateral.  KCI is responsible for marketing the service and maintaining ethical business practices.  Provider's obligations include a fully staffed backend with billing, technical support, and a private-labeled portal.

KCI's consideration is 750,000 shares of its Series A Preferred Stock (adjusted proportionally based on total outstanding shares).  Failure to deliver the required opinion letter for stock transfer within 20 days of request incurs 10% interest per 30 days on the share value as liquidated damages.  The agreement is governed by New York law and includes an arbitration clause.  Both parties acknowledge the agreement's materiality under Regulation FD and authorize a press release.  Assignment requires prior written consent, except for affiliates or in cases of asset acquisition.  The agreement is the complete and final understanding between the parties.

UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-O.contract_id: UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-Outsourcing Agreement with the BISYS Group, Inc.
UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-O.contract_title: UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-Outsourcing Agreement with the BISYS Group, Inc.
UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-O.summary:
This outsourcing agreement, dated February 18, 1999, is between United National Bancorp (UNB), through its subsidiary United National Bank, and BISYS Group, Inc.  The agreement outlines the outsourcing of United National Bank's integrated information processing, item processing, and deposit services to BISYS.  BISYS will utilize its TOTALPLUS system to provide these services.  

UNB's key obligation is to transition its services to BISYS, liquidating its interest in its current provider, United Financial Services, in the first half of 1999.  BISYS's main obligation is to provide the specified services.  The agreement's duration is multi-year, though specific termination clauses are not detailed in the provided text.  Financial arrangements, including pricing and payment terms, are not specified.  The agreement aims to improve UNB's efficiency and align its technology with future needs.  The press release lacks specifics on contract details, requiring review of the full contract for a complete legal understanding.

GALERATHERAPEUTICS,INC_02_14_2020-EX-99..summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement, dated February 14, 2020, governs the joint filing of required reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) regarding Galera Therapeutics, Inc.  The parties are several Clarus LPs (Clarus IV-A, B, C, D, Clarus IV GP, L.P.), Blackstone entities (Blackstone Clarus GP L.P., Blackstone Clarus GP L.L.C., Blackstone Holdings II L.P., Blackstone Holdings I/II GP L.L.C., The Blackstone Group Inc., Blackstone Group Management L.L.C.), and Stephen A. Schwarzman.

The agreement's purpose is to facilitate the joint filing of Section 13 reports under the Exchange Act concerning Galera Therapeutics securities.  Each party is responsible for the timely filing of its own information and its accuracy, but not for the accuracy of others' information unless they know or have reason to believe it is inaccurate.  The agreement itself is filed as an exhibit to the SEC reports.

The agreement remains in effect until revoked in writing by any party, with the revocation only affecting the revoking party.  No financial arrangements are detailed.  The agreement is executed in counterparts, all constituting one instrument.

VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6.contract_id: VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11933379_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_License Agreement
VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6.contract_title: VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11933379_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_License Agreement
VirtuosoSurgicalInc_20191227_1-A_EX1A-6.summary:
This Non-Exclusive License Agreement, dated May 3, 2016, is between The Johns Hopkins University ("JHU") and Virtuoso Surgical, Inc. ("Company").  JHU licenses to the Company its non-exclusive rights to manufacture, use, and sell products and services related to "Active Cannulas for Bio-Sensing and Surgical Intervention" (the Licensed Products and Services) worldwide.  The agreement covers patents listed in Exhibit C.

Company's key obligations include paying a $2,000 license fee plus 5% of its outstanding common stock to JHU,  minimum annual royalties ($3,000), and running royalties (detailed in Exhibit A) based on net sales and service revenues.  Quarterly royalty reports are required.  JHU retains ownership of the patents and the right to enforce them.  Company must maintain product liability insurance and indemnify JHU against liabilities.  Company cannot sublicense.

The agreement lasts until the expiration of the last-to-expire patent in each country.  Company may terminate with 60 days' notice. JHU may terminate if no sales occur for four consecutive quarters after initial commercial sale.  Upon termination, all rights revert to JHU.  Governing law is Maryland.  The contract includes standard clauses on severability, warranties (JHU disclaims most), and dispute resolution (waiver of jury trial).  A liquidity event (e.g., sale or IPO) triggers an additional 1% fee for JHU based on the aggregate consideration received.

ROCKYMOUNTAINCHOCOLATEFACTORY,INC_12_23_.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 20, 2019, involves Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory, Inc. ("Company"), Farids & Co. LLC ("Farids"), and Edible Arrangements, LLC ("EA").  The agreement's main purpose is to establish a strategic alliance, including a share purchase and supply agreement.

Farids purchases 126,839 shares of Company common stock for $999,998.68.  Concurrently, the Company issues warrants to EA for the purchase of additional shares.  EA enters into an exclusive supplier operating agreement with the Company (terms redacted).  Farids, through its designated representative Tariq Farid ("TF"), gains a springing nomination right for a board seat upon owning 5% or more of the Company's outstanding stock, contingent on EA's revenue performance over several years.

Key provisions include restrictions on share transfers by Farids (with exceptions for permitted transfers), registration rights for Farids, a right of first refusal for the Company on significant share sales by Farids (especially to competitors), and mutual non-disparagement and non-solicitation clauses.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  The agreement's duration is not explicitly stated but is tied to Farids' share ownership and EA's performance, with certain provisions surviving termination.  Financial arrangements primarily involve the share purchase price and the cost of registration expenses, with some costs allocated to Farids.

VITAMINSHOPPECOMINC_09_13_1999-EX-10.26-.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated September 23, 1998, is between Excite, Inc. (Excite) and Vitamin Shoppe Industries Inc. (Vitamin Shoppe).  The agreement outlines a comprehensive online marketing and advertising campaign for Vitamin Shoppe on Excite's network of websites (including Excite.com and WebCrawler.com).

Vitamin Shoppe's main obligation is payment of significant fees (detailed in Exhibit C, amounts redacted) for guaranteed impressions across various Excite platforms, including banner ads, sponsored links, and email campaigns (DeliverE).  Excite's key obligation is to provide Vitamin Shoppe with prominent placement on its websites, particularly within health and shopping channels, ensuring Vitamin Shoppe is the dominant vitamin reseller, subject to exceptions for Excite's own products and general search results.  Excite also guarantees minimum impression delivery (Exhibit C), with a make-good period and potential termination clause if targets aren't met.  A revenue-sharing component is included, with Vitamin Shoppe paying Excite a percentage of net revenue from referrals.

Key terms include definitions of "Confidential Information," "User Data," and "Client's Competitors" (Exhibit D).  The agreement addresses trademark usage, confidentiality, indemnity, limitation of liability, and dispute resolution (mediation and arbitration).  The contract's duration is tied to the delivery of a specified number of impressions and emails, with a minimum term, and can be terminated for material breach after a 30-day cure period.  Governing law is California.  Numerous exhibits detail specific placements, keywords, and performance metrics.

SOLUTIONSVENDINGINTERNATIONAL,INC_03_31_.summary:
This Services Agreement, dated March 31, 2020, is between StartEngine Crowdfunding, Inc. ("Company") and Solutions Vending International, Inc. ("Customer").  The agreement governs the Company's provision of crowdfunding services to the Customer, enabling the Customer to present its securities offering to users on the Company's platform.

The Customer's key obligations include payment of fees (monthly fees, transaction fees (ACH $1, Wire $15), AML fees ($2-$5 per user), and reimbursable expenses (credit card charges, transaction fees, escrow fees, return fees)).  The Company's main obligation is to provide the platform and related services.  The Company can adjust fees after the initial term with 30 days' notice. Unpaid amounts accrue a 1.5% monthly finance charge.  The Customer is liable for all reversals and return fees associated with user transactions.

The agreement's term is the duration of the Company's offering (Initial Term), renewable unless terminated with 30 days' notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach (15-30 days' cure period), untrue representations, bankruptcy, regulatory action, material adverse change in financial condition, or force majeure events lasting over 10 business days.  The Customer warrants the agreement's validity and binding nature.  Disputes regarding billing must be reported within 60 days.

InnerscopeHearingTechnologiesInc_2018110.summary:
This Exclusive Distributor Agreement, dated November 9, 2018, is between Erchonia Corporation ("Erchonia"), a low-level laser developer, and InnerScope Hearing Technologies Inc. ("Distributor"), a medical products seller.  The agreement grants Distributor exclusive rights to promote, distribute, and sell Erchonia's hearing-related laser products (specified in Exhibit A) within a worldwide territory (Exhibit B) to licensed healthcare professionals only.

Distributor's key obligations include best-effort sales, meeting minimum performance goals (Exhibit C, to be determined post-FDA clearance), providing sales reports, timely payment (50% pre-shipment, 50% within 30 days), and adhering to Erchonia's product use recommendations and intellectual property rights.  Distributor cannot sell competing products or export without consent.  Erchonia retains the right to modify products and pricing (90-day notice for price changes).

The agreement's initial term is three years, automatically renewing for three-year periods with mutual agreement on new performance goals.  Termination can occur due to material breach (10-day cure period), insolvency, or bankruptcy.  Specific clauses address confidentiality, intellectual property protection, warranties (with Erchonia disclaiming most implied warranties and limiting liability), indemnification, and dispute resolution (binding arbitration).  Financial terms include payment schedules, Distributor's responsibility for shipping, taxes, and expenses, and a 1.5% late payment fee.  Governing law is Florida.

SmartRxSystemsInc_20180914_1-A_EX1A-6 MA.contract_id: SmartRxSystemsInc_20180914_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11351705_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Distributor Agreement
SmartRxSystemsInc_20180914_1-A_EX1A-6 MA.contract_title: SmartRxSystemsInc_20180914_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11351705_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Distributor Agreement
SmartRxSystemsInc_20180914_1-A_EX1A-6 MA.summary:
This Exclusive Distributor Agreement, dated May 17, 2017, is between Smart RX Systems, Inc. (Florida) ("Company") and A3 Development Group, LLC (Texas) ("Distributor").  The agreement appoints A3 as the exclusive distributor of Smart RX's Smart Pharm Assist Kiosk™ in Texas, with exclusive distribution opportunities in other states (excluding Florida) either through the Company or A3.

A3's key obligations include marketing the Kiosk to various customers, entering into pharmacy management services agreements, and arranging kiosk placement.  Smart RX's obligations include supplying medications, providing training and support, and managing the Kiosk's operations.  

Financial terms stipulate A3 receives 10% of the Master Distributor Override (MDO) per Kiosk location (if EBITDA exceeds 10% of revenue) and a 40% management fee of Net Income per Kiosk.  Payments are subject to a 90-day delay.  Both parties are responsible for their own expenses and taxes.  Detailed financial arrangements are further defined in Class A Series Agreements for each Kiosk location.

The agreement includes provisions on intellectual property rights, confidentiality, termination (for cause or non-renewal after the initial 5-year term), dispute resolution (arbitration in Dallas, Texas), and governing law (Texas, with jurisdiction in Orange County, Florida).  Sections regarding intellectual property, confidentiality, and post-termination obligations survive termination.

Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporat.contract_id: Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated - A_R REMARKETING  AGREEMENT
Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporat.contract_title: Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated - A_R REMARKETING  AGREEMENT
Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporat.summary:
This Amended and Restated Remarketing Agreement, dated February 15, 2011, governs the remarketing of Preferred Securities issued by RGA Capital Trust I (the "Trust") and guaranteed by Reinsurance Group of America, Incorporated (the "Company").  Barclays Capital Inc. ("Barclays") is appointed as the exclusive remarketing agent.

The agreement's main purpose is to establish the framework for Barclays to remarket the Trust's Preferred Securities (or underlying debentures) on behalf of their holders.  Barclays' key obligations include using commercially reasonable efforts to remarket the securities at a price no less than their accreted value (or principal amount at maturity).  Failure to remarket all tendered securities constitutes a "Failed Remarketing," triggering specific interest rate adjustments and payment obligations for the Company.

Key terms include "Accreted Value," "Reset Rate," and "Remarketing Settlement Date."  The agreement extensively details representations and warranties from the Company and Trust regarding the accuracy of the registration statement and prospectus, compliance with securities laws, and the financial health of the Company and its subsidiaries.
