The agreement's duration is tied to the remarketing process, terminating upon successful remarketing, failure to remarket, or the appointment of a new remarketing agent.  Financial arrangements include a fee for Barclays equal to 0.25% of the remarketed securities' accreted value, plus reimbursement for expenses incurred by the Company.  Extensive indemnification and contribution clauses allocate liability between the parties.  New York law governs the agreement.

BIOFRONTERAAG_04_29_2019-EX-4.17-SUPPLY.summary:
This Supply Agreement, effective March 2018, is between Cutanea Life Sciences, Inc. (Delaware) and Ferrer Internacional, S.A. (Spain).  It governs the manufacture and supply of pharmaceutical products ("Products") by Ferrer to Cutanea, succeeding Medimetriks' rights under a prior License and Supply Agreement (LSA).

Cutanea's key obligations include providing forecasts of product needs, issuing purchase orders, conducting product inspections, and paying the Supply Price. Ferrer's main obligations are manufacturing the Products according to specifications, ensuring quality (including providing certificates of analysis), and timely delivery.  Both parties have responsibilities regarding regulatory compliance, adverse event reporting, and product recalls.  Ferrer is responsible for initial FDA filings and related fees.

Key terms include detailed specifications for the Products, a defined Supply Price (subject to annual adjustment based on Ferrer's direct manufacturing costs), and procedures for product acceptance/rejection.  The agreement also addresses intellectual property rights, confidentiality, indemnification, and force majeure events.

The agreement's duration is tied to the LSA; termination occurs upon LSA termination or material breach by either party (with a 45-day cure period).  Financial arrangements involve payment in US dollars, with terms detailed in Schedule A, including provisions for handling EUR/USD exchange rate fluctuations.  Payment is typically due upon receipt and acceptance of the products.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  Both parties waive their right to a jury trial.

CORALGOLDRESOURCES,LTD_05_28_2020-EX-4.1.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated February 1, 2020, is between Coral Gold Resources Ltd. ("Company") and Intermark Capital Corp. ("Consultant").  The agreement engages the Consultant to provide management and financial consulting services to the Company for five years, ending January 31, 2025.  The Consultant's principal, David Wolfin, will act as the Company's President and CEO.

Key obligations include providing advisory services (detailed in Schedule A), enhancing the Company's business interests, reporting to the Company, and maintaining confidentiality of the Company's information.  The Consultant's compensation is a $10,000 monthly fee, plus expenses, potentially subject to increases by the Company's Compensation Committee.

The agreement may be terminated by either party with three months' notice (Company must also pay a termination payment equal to the annual consulting fee).  The Consultant has the right to immediate termination and a CDN$750,000 payment if a change of control occurs within six months of the Effective Date (defined as a change in beneficial ownership of 20% or more of the Company's voting securities resulting in a change of the board majority, or a substantial asset sale/merger not resulting in the original shareholders retaining >50.1% voting power).  Automatic termination occurs upon expiry of the term, Consultant's inability to provide services through Wolfin, Wolfin's death/incapacity, or a material breach by the Consultant.

The agreement includes clauses on confidentiality, non-solicitation of employees, intellectual property ownership assignment to the Company, indemnification, and governing law (British Columbia).  The Consultant is considered

Cerus Corporation - FIRST AMEND TO SUPPL.contract_id: Cerus Corporation - FIRST AMEND TO SUPPLY AND MANUFACTURING AGREEMENT
Cerus Corporation - FIRST AMEND TO SUPPL.contract_title: Cerus Corporation - FIRST AMEND TO SUPPLY AND MANUFACTURING AGREEMENT
Cerus Corporation - FIRST AMEND TO SUPPL.summary: This First Amendment, dated June 22, 2018, modifies the April 1, 2017 Supply and Manufacturing Agreement between Cerus Corporation and Porex Corporation.  The amendment revises specifications for Platelet Wafers (Exhibit AA-1-AA-4), temporarily altering pricing (Exhibit D-1) until Cerus discontinues Protocol EPP-029-886.  Porex's manufacturing capacity is limited (Section 1.3).  A new payment term for Porex's monthly invoices is established (Section 1.5.3), including a process for dispute resolution.  The amendment introduces a new section (3a) outlining terms for "Non-Production Related Work," including development activities, with pricing detailed in Exhibit D.  This work is governed by separate Statements of Work (Schedule 3), subject to the overall Agreement.  The original Agreement remains in effect except as amended.  Confidential pricing and quantity details are redacted and filed separately with the SEC.  No specific duration or termination clause is explicitly mentioned beyond the existing agreement's terms.  Financial arrangements include revised pricing for Platelet Wafers and a new payment schedule for both wafer production and non-production services.

OLDAPIWIND-DOWNLTD_01_08_2016-EX-1.3-AGE.summary:
This Agents' Certificate (Exhibit I to Schedule A of an Agency Agreement dated May 22, 2015) concerns the sale of Tribute Pharmaceuticals Inc. ("Corporation") common shares to accredited investors in the U.S.  The parties are the Corporation, an Agent (unnamed), and the Agent's U.S. registered broker-dealer affiliate (unnamed, referred to as "U.S. Affiliate").

The main purpose is to certify compliance with U.S. securities laws regarding the share offering under Regulation D Rule 506(b).  Key obligations include the U.S. Affiliate's certification of its proper registration and standing, that all offers were made in accordance with applicable laws, that all offerees were reasonably believed to be accredited investors, and that no general solicitation or advertising was used.  The Agent certifies no disqualifying events exist for those receiving remuneration for solicitation, and that no other persons (besides those covered by the exception) received remuneration.

The certificate references a pre-existing Agency Agreement and Subscription Agreement, incorporating their terms unless otherwise defined.  No duration or termination clauses are explicitly stated within this exhibit; these would be found in the referenced Agency Agreement.  Financial arrangements are not detailed in this certificate but are implied to be governed by the underlying agreements.  The certificate is a representation of compliance, not a standalone agreement.

ATENTOSA_07_06_2020-EX-99.1-JOINT FILING.summary: This Joint Filing Agreement (JFA), dated July 6, 2020, governs the joint filing of a Schedule 13D statement by several HPS Investment Partners entities (HPS Investment Partners, LLC; HPS Mezzanine Partners II, LLC; HPS Mezzanine Partners II Offshore GP, L.P.; Mezzanine Partners - Offshore Investment Master Fund II, L.P.; Mezzanine Partners II Offshore Lux S.À R.L; Mezzanine Partners II Offshore Lux S.À R.L II; HPS Mezzanine Partners II GP, L.P.; Mezzanine Partners II, L.P.; Mezzanine Partners II Onshore Lux S.À R.L; Mezzanine Partners II Onshore Lux S.À R.L II), all signed by John Madden as Authorized Signatory.  The agreement's main purpose is to facilitate the joint filing of the Schedule 13D and any amendments, under Rule 13d-1(k)(1) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  The key obligation is the joint filing;  no admission of acting as a group is implied.  The agreement allows for multiple counterparts and specifies that amendments can be filed without additional JFA filings. No specific duration or termination clause is explicitly stated; the agreement is seemingly tied to the life of the Schedule 13D filing. No financial arrangements are detailed.

HealthcentralCom_19991108_S-1A_EX-10.27_.summary:
This Co-Branding Content Agreement, dated June 30, 1999, is between MediaLinx Interactive, L.P. ("MLX") and HealthCentral.com Inc. ("HCI").  The agreement concerns the co-branding and integration of HCI's health content into MLX's "HealthyWay" section on the Sympatico website (the "Co-Branded Site"), launching September 1, 1999.

MLX's key obligations include hosting and moderating discussion forums, promoting the Co-Branded Site (per Schedule 1), granting HCI non-exclusive use of certain content and trademarks, ensuring third-party e-commerce compliance, and striving to increase traffic (per Schedule 2).  HCI's obligations include providing reliable service, integrating content (subject to MLX approval), maintaining Canadian content levels (per Schedule 3), providing usage statistics (per Schedule 4), and ensuring e-commerce compliance.  Both parties have rights to sell advertising (Canadian and US advertisers respectively), with revenue sharing outlined in Section 6 (specific figures redacted).

The agreement lasts two years from the launch date. Termination can occur with 30 days' notice for material breach or lack of mutual agreement, or immediately for insolvency or material ownership changes.  HCI pays MLX a guaranteed annual fee (amount redacted), with revenue sharing on Canadian advertising revenue exceeding a specified threshold (amount redacted).  Both parties provide mutual indemnities for intellectual property infringement.  The agreement is governed by Ontario law.  Specific financial details are redacted in the provided excerpt.

GAINSCOINC_01_21_2010-EX-10.41-SPONSORSH.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, effective January 1, 2010, is between Stallings Capital Group Consultants, Ltd. dba Bob Stallings Racing ("Racing") and GAINSCO, Inc. ("Sponsor").  It governs the primary sponsorship of Racing's Daytona Prototype Series racing team by GAINSCO for the 2010 season.

Racing's key obligations include providing GAINSCO with customary sponsorship benefits (signage, driver endorsements, facility access, use of a show car, car likeness rights),  actively participating in the Rolex 24 at Daytona, and refraining from endorsements conflicting with GAINSCO's interests.  GAINSCO's main obligation is payment of a $750,000 sponsorship fee ($350,000 upfront, then ten $40,000 monthly installments).  GAINSCO has approval rights over additional sponsors.

Important terms include GAINSCO's maximum obligation limited to the sponsorship fee plus collection costs, Racing's indemnification of GAINSCO for liabilities exceeding this amount,  retention of rights by both parties regarding their respective intellectual property, and comprehensive insurance requirements for Racing.

The agreement runs from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2010, but GAINSCO may terminate at any time before December 31, 2010, with no further payment obligations.  Governing law is Texas.  The agreement is confidential and requires written consent for assignment or amendment.

TURNKEYCAPITAL,INC_07_20_2017-EX-1.1-Str.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated June 30, 2017, is between Turnkey Capital Inc. ("TKCI") and a Seminole Indian Company ("SIC") to be formed by James E. Billie and Craig Talesman.  The agreement aims to combine resources to generate revenue streams leveraging tribal sovereignty, minimizing capital requirements and risk.

TKCI's key obligations include establishing a wholly-owned subsidiary to manage the alliance, acting as CFO, and recruiting capital. SIC's obligations involve providing information, assisting in transaction closings, and providing access to business opportunities.  SIC retains the right to independently seek investors.

The agreement's duration is 24 months, renewable by mutual written consent.  Termination can occur by mutual agreement or for cause (e.g., criminal conviction, bad faith).  Indemnification clauses protect both parties from claims arising from the other's actions.

Financially, a 50/50 revenue split between TKCI and SIC is stipulated, with TKCI reserving 10% of its shares for SIC upon exclusivity agreement.  A monthly fee is to be negotiated later.  TKCI receives a finder's fee and remuneration for services.  TKCI has first right of refusal on any sale of alliance-related companies or projects.  Florida law governs, with arbitration as the primary dispute resolution method.  Confidentiality and non-compete clauses are included, lasting one year post-termination.

IVILLAGEINC_03_17_1999-EX-10.16-SPONSORS.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated December 18, 1998, is between Ford Motor Media (FMM), a division of J. Walter Thompson, and iVillage, Inc.  The agreement outlines a 24-month sponsorship for Ford's automotive products on iVillage's website and AOL network, with a potential 3-month extension for make-good on undelivered impressions and a renewal option.

iVillage's key obligations include creating and hosting a Ford-branded website ("Bridge Site"), delivering specified advertising units and impressions, conducting online conferences, polls, surveys, and focus groups, and providing marketing consultation.  FMM's main obligation is payment.

Financially, FMM pays an upfront fee plus quarterly payments totaling [redacted amounts].  Failure by iVillage to deliver impressions may result in a term extension or a refund.  iVillage grants FMM exclusive automotive manufacturer sponsorship on its network.

The agreement includes standard clauses on confidentiality, limitation of liability (excluding consequential damages), mutual indemnification, intellectual property assignment (Bridge Site content to FMM, iVillage retains underlying software), and governing law (New York).  Termination can occur due to material breach (30-day cure period), insolvency, or material underperformance (90-day notice).  Specific numbers of pages, advertising units, impressions, etc., are redacted in the provided text.

PaperexchangeComInc_20000322_S-1A_EX-10..summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective September 30, 1999, is between VerticalNet, Inc. (VerticalNet) and PaperExchange.com, LLC (PaperExchange).  It's a co-branding agreement establishing a strategic alliance to jointly market online career centers and equipment listings for the pulp and paper industry via their respective websites (PulpandPaperOnline.com and PaperExchange.com).

VerticalNet's key obligations include designing, hosting, and maintaining co-branded sites, marketing these sites, and managing advertising sales (with PaperExchange's approval and revenue sharing). PaperExchange provides content (job and equipment listings) and links to the co-branded sites from its homepage.  Both parties agree to non-compete clauses within specified parameters.

Key terms include definitions of revenue streams (Career Center Net Revenue, Equipment Listings Net Revenue, Net Advertising Revenue),  exclusive licensing of content, and mutual marketing responsibilities.  Financial arrangements involve revenue sharing based on percentages of various revenue streams, plus one-time fees paid by PaperExchange to VerticalNet.

The agreement has an initial term of four years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' notice.  Termination for cause is also permitted, with specific cure periods and consequences outlined, including liquidated damages.  Dispute resolution is through negotiation and then binding arbitration in New York, under the AAA rules.  The agreement includes standard disclaimers of warranties, limitations of liability ($1,000,000 cap except for confidentiality breaches), and indemnification clauses.  Pennsylvania law governs.

IPAYMENT,INC_05_14_2007-EX-10.1-SPONSORS.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated January 29, 2007, is between iPayment, Inc. ("ISO"), First Data Merchant Services Corporation ("FDMS"), and Wells Fargo Bank, N.A. ("Bank") (collectively, "Servicers").  The agreement governs ISO's merchant processing program, sponsored by FDMS and Bank.

The main purpose is to establish a merchant processing program where ISO solicits merchants, and FDMS/Bank provide processing and sponsorship services.  ISO is responsible for sales, marketing, underwriting, and compliance with all applicable rules and regulations.  FDMS/Bank provide processing, clearing, sponsorship (including Visa and Mastercard registration), and risk management services.  ISO must maintain adequate underwriting staff and comply with Servicers' Program Standards.  Servicers retain ultimate approval rights over ISO's procedures and materials.

Key terms include definitions of various merchant categories, fees, and account structures (Offset Account, Reserve Account, Termination Reserve Account).  Financial arrangements involve Program Participation Fees, Merchant Discount Rates, and ISO's responsibility for chargebacks and losses.  Servicers have rights of setoff and recoupment.

The agreement has a four-year initial term, automatically renewing unless terminated with six months' notice.  Either party can terminate for cause (material breach, non-compliance, insolvency, etc.), with varying notice periods.  Upon termination, Servicers will transfer the merchant portfolio to a third party designated by ISO, subject to certain conditions, including full payment of all amounts due and adequate funding of the Termination Reserve Account.  Extensive indemnification clauses exist, with limitations on liability.  The agreement is governed by New York law.

BIOPURECORP_06_30_1999-EX-10.13-AGENCY A.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated March 29, 1999, is between Biopure Corporation (Company) and The Butler Company (Agent).  It establishes an agency relationship for the Agent to promote, sell, and collect payments for Biopure's Oxyglobin veterinary products within the contiguous 48 United States, Alaska, and DC.

The Agent's key obligations include meeting sales targets outlined in a jointly developed annual Business Plan, marketing the products, forwarding customer complaints, maintaining adequate staff, and adhering to Biopure's credit policy.  The Company's obligations include filling orders, providing training and promotional materials, and compensating the Agent with a 10% discount on sales plus a 2% quarterly incentive based on achieving mutually agreed-upon goals.

The agreement's term is indefinite, terminable by either party with 90 days' notice after January 31, 1999, or for material breach (30 days' notice for non-payment related breaches).  Other termination grounds include failure to agree on a Business Plan, material changes in the Agent's organization, negative publicity, or Biopure's sale of its veterinary products business (all with varying notice periods).  Payment terms are net 30 days (or 45 with EFT), with the Agent responsible for customer creditworthiness.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, confidentiality provisions, and a governing law clause specifying Massachusetts law and jurisdiction.  The agreement also includes provisions on warranties, product returns, and force majeure.

RISEEDUCATIONCAYMANLTD_04_17_2020-EX-4.2.summary:
This Service Agreement, dated 04/17/2020, is between Rise (Tianjin) Education Information Consulting Co., Ltd. ("Service Provider") and an unnamed Service Recipient, both operating in the children's English education sector in China.  The agreement outlines the Service Provider's provision of comprehensive operational support services to the Service Recipient, including academic, enrollment, HR, financial, legal, customer, IT, and administrative support.

The Service Provider's obligations center around providing these customized services, while the Service Recipient's main obligation is payment of service fees, calculated either based on Service Provider's costs plus a markup or a percentage of the Recipient's revenue (details in Schedule 1).  The agreement is non-exclusive for the Service Provider.  Intellectual property rights related to the services remain solely with the Service Provider.

Key terms include confidentiality clauses, representations and warranties by both parties regarding their legal standing, a liquidated damages clause (0.5% daily penalty for late payments, termination after 15 days), and dispute resolution via the Beijing Arbitration Commission.  The agreement has a five-year term, automatically renewing for another five unless terminated in writing by either party.  Termination by the Service Provider due to Service Recipient default results in no refund of prepaid fees.  Payment is quarterly via bank remittance to a specified account.

STARTECGLOBALCOMMUNICATIONSCORP_11_16_19.summary:
This Construction and Maintenance Agreement (C&MA), dated September 2, 1998, governs the TAT-14 submarine cable network connecting points in North America and Europe.  Numerous International Telecommunications Entities (ITEs), including AT&T, BT, Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom, KPN, Sprint, and Telia (listed fully in Schedule A), are parties.  The agreement outlines the construction, operation, and maintenance of the TAT-14 system, divided into segments (submarine Segment S and terrestrial Segments T1-T7).

The main purpose is to establish a framework for shared ownership, operation, and maintenance of TAT-14. Key obligations include: Terminal Parties' responsibility for their respective Segments T and portions of Segment S; a Procurement Group's responsibility for procuring Segment S; a Managing Group's oversight of the project; and a Central Billing Party's handling of financial matters.  Capacity is allocated based on initial investment (Schedule B), with future acquisition via Purchase Contracts.

Important terms include definitions of capacity types (Allocated, Purchased, Sold, CRC), ownership pricing, and procedures for capacity reassignment.  The agreement specifies operation and maintenance cost allocation and billing procedures, including financial charge rates (Annex 7) and extended payment charges.  Dispute resolution is via binding arbitration in Geneva under ICC rules.

The agreement has an initial 25-year term (Initial Period) post RFCS Date, terminable thereafter by agreement or with one year's notice.  Financial arrangements involve pro-rata cost sharing for capital and operational expenses based on ownership percentages (Schedule B).  A defaulting party risks capacity reclamation.  The agreement also includes clauses on confidentiality

LejuHoldingsLtd_20140121_DRS (on F-1)_EX.summary: This Mutual Termination Agreement, dated 2009, is between Beijing SINA Internet Information Service Co. ("Beijing SINA") and Shanghai SINA Leju Information Technology Co. Ltd. ("SINA Leju").  Its purpose is to terminate a prior Domain Name License Agreement (dated May 8, 2008) between the parties.  The key obligation is the mutual agreement to terminate the original agreement, rendering it null and void upon execution of this Termination Agreement.  No provisions of the original agreement survive.  The agreement is complete and integrated, modifiable only by written consent of both parties.  Governing law is the PRC, without regard to conflicts of law.  The agreement is binding on successors and assigns.  No financial arrangements are detailed; the consideration is described as mutual covenants and other good and valuable consideration.  The agreement's duration is effectively instantaneous, terminating the prior agreement upon its execution.

TRIZETTOGROUPINC_08_18_1999-EX-10.17-TEC.summary:
This Technical Infrastructure Maintenance Agreement, dated March 1, 1998, is between Medical Manager Midwest, Inc. ("MMMW") and MTS, Inc. ("Customer").  MMMW agrees to provide technical infrastructure maintenance services for Customer's hardware and software, excluding certain items (e.g., diskettes, printer ribbons).

The agreement outlines two service options: a retainer plan with capped hours and hourly billing for exceeding the cap, or strictly hourly billing.  MMMW's obligations include on-call service (7 AM - 5 PM CST, with a 3-hour guaranteed response time), 24/7 pager support for emergencies, and repair or exchange of faulty hardware.  Customer is responsible for providing a suitable environment, removing non-MMMW supplied materials before service, and implementing data safeguards.  MMMW's liability is limited to repair/exchange or actual direct damages, excluding incidental or consequential damages.

The initial term is 12 months, renewable annually.  Either party may cancel with 30 days' written notice, except for non-payment by Customer, which allows MMMW to cancel immediately.  Charges are invoiced monthly, payable within 30 days, subject to annual CPI adjustments with a 30-day notice period.  The agreement is governed by Indiana law and has a two-year statute of limitations on legal action.  Confidentiality clauses protect MMMW's proprietary information.

FIBROGENINC_10_01_2014-EX-10.11-COLLABOR.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, effective June 1, 2005, is between Astellas Pharma Inc. (Astellas) and FibroGen, Inc. (FibroGen).  It's a joint development and licensing agreement concerning FibroGen's small molecule prolyl hydroxylase inhibitors for treating anemia (the "Field").

FibroGen grants Astellas an exclusive license to develop and commercialize these inhibitors in Japan.  FibroGen retains worldwide rights outside Japan and for uses outside the defined "Field."  Astellas is responsible for development in Japan, including clinical trials and regulatory filings, while FibroGen handles development elsewhere and supplies the product.  A Joint Development Committee (JDC) oversees the collaboration.

Key obligations include Astellas's due diligence in development and commercialization in Japan, and FibroGen's manufacturing and supply.  Transfer pricing is based on a percentage of the Listed Price (Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare pricing) with adjustments for generic competition.  Significant financial arrangements involve milestone payments to FibroGen upon achieving various development and commercialization milestones, plus royalties based on net sales.  Intellectual property ownership is primarily with FibroGen, with exceptions for certain Astellas-developed inventions.

The agreement has a term until terminated.  Termination clauses include material breach by either party, technical product failure, failure to meet development milestones, generic competition reaching a certain threshold, and Astellas's right to terminate with six months' notice.  Upon termination, specific financial obligations and intellectual property transfer provisions apply.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration under the ICC rules.

KNOWLABS,INC_08_15_2005-EX-10-INTELLECTU.summary: This Intellectual Property Agreement, dated June 16, 2004, is between Visualant Incorporated (Company) and Kenneth Turpin.  The agreement assigns all intellectual property rights (IPR) related to Turpin's research and development work for the Company's color technology business to Visualant.  Turpin's key obligations include assigning all present and future IPR related to the "Work Product" (defined broadly to include inventions, software, etc. related to the Company's business), maintaining records of this work, assisting the Company in protecting these rights, and returning all Company property upon termination.  The Company's main obligation is to cover expenses related to protecting the IPR.  The agreement stipulates that monetary damages would be inadequate for breach, allowing for injunctive relief.  The agreement is effective until terminated by either party upon Turpin's employment termination with written notice.  Nominal consideration ($10.00 each) was exchanged.  Governing law is British Columbia.  The agreement supersedes any prior agreements between the parties.

UAGHINC_04_14_2004-EX-10.18-MAINTENANCE.summary:
This Maintenance Agreement, dated July 23, 2003, is between Universal Access, Inc. ("Company") and CityNet Telecommunications, Inc. ("Provider").  It governs maintenance of Fiber Ring Assets transferred from Provider to Company under a separate Stock Purchase Agreement.  The Provider is obligated to provide 24/7 maintenance services (excluding specified repairs and modifications), including emergency response.  The Company must provide access to the assets and operate them in compliance with City Rights Agreements (listed in Schedule 3.2),  prohibiting transfer of assets without Provider consent (unless transferee assumes obligations).

The initial term is five years, automatically extending monthly unless terminated with 30-day notice.  Either party can terminate with 180-day notice.  The Company pays a monthly Service Fee ($40,000 initially, subject to annual cost-of-service adjustments), plus additional fees for repairs outside the scope of the agreement.  The Provider warrants commercially reasonable efforts and maintains $1,000,000 liability insurance naming the Company as an additional insured.  Liability is limited, excluding bodily injury/death and willful misconduct; consequential damages are excluded.  Delaware law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in Delaware courts; jury trial is waived.  The agreement supersedes prior agreements.

ARMSTRONGFLOORING,INC_01_07_2019-EX-10.2.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated December 31, 2018, governs the transfer of intellectual property (IP) between Armstrong Flooring, Inc. ("Seller"), AFI Licensing LLC, and AHF Holding, Inc. (formerly Tarzan HoldCo, Inc.) and Armstrong Hardwood Flooring Company ("Buyer Entities").  The agreement's purpose is to facilitate the transfer of IP rights related to a stock purchase agreement (SPA) between Seller and Buyer Entities.

The IPA assigns certain IP (Copyrights, Patents, Trademarks, Know-How) exclusively used by the Buyer Entities' business ("Company Field") to the Buyer Entities.  Conversely, it grants perpetual, non-exclusive, royalty-free licenses to the Seller for certain Buyer Entities' IP used in the Seller's business ("Arizona Field").  Specific trademarks ("Arizona Licensed Trademarks," "Diamond Licensed Trademarks") are licensed for limited terms (24 and 18 months respectively), with quality control provisions to protect the Seller's brand.  The agreement also addresses sublicensing, IP ownership, prosecution, maintenance, and enforcement responsibilities.  Both parties are obligated to indemnify the other for breaches or misconduct.

The agreement's term is perpetual for most IP rights, except for the specified trademarks and "Phase-Out Marks" (24-month phase-out period). Termination is possible for material breach unremedied within 30 days.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed in the provided excerpt; those are likely addressed in the referenced SPA.  Delaware law governs, with jurisdiction in Delaware courts, and both parties waive jury trials.

SPIENERGYCO,LTD_07_10_2014-EX-10-Coopera.contract_id: SPIENERGYCO,LTD_07_10_2014-EX-10-Cooperation Agreement of 50MWp Photovoltaic Grid-connected Power Generation Project in Yangqiao of~1
SPIENERGYCO,LTD_07_10_2014-EX-10-Coopera.contract_title: SPIENERGYCO,LTD_07_10_2014-EX-10-Cooperation Agreement of 50MWp Photovoltaic Grid-connected Power Generation Project in Yangqiao of~1
SPIENERGYCO,LTD_07_10_2014-EX-10-Coopera.summary: This Cooperation Agreement, dated June 25, 2014, concerns a 50MWp photovoltaic grid-connected power generation project in Yangqiao Town, Fenyi County.  Parties involved are the People's Government of Fenyi County (Party A) and Xinyu Xinwei New Energy Co., Ltd. (Party B).  The agreement outlines Party A's commitment to support Party B's project development through preferential policies, streamlined approvals, and coordination with relevant departments.  Party B commits to invest, construct, and operate the project, prioritizing local employment, using local materials, and engaging in sustainable agricultural practices alongside the power generation.  Party B also agrees to register a foreign-funded company in Fenyi County to benefit from local investment incentives.  Party A accepts a pre-existing agreement between Party B and Yangqiao Town.  The agreement focuses on project facilitation and development, with no explicit financial arrangements or termination clauses detailed in the provided text.  The success of the project hinges on Party A's effective support and Party B's timely execution and adherence to sustainable development principles.

VitalibisInc_20180316_8-K_EX-10.2_111001.summary:
This Services and Hosting Agreement, effective March 7, 2018, is between Vitalibis Inc. (Licensee) and Votocast, Inc. (Votocast).  It governs Votocast's provision of hosting and technical services, including iOS and Android mobile applications, APIs, SDKs, and an admin module, to Vitalibis.

Votocast's key obligations include providing the services (detailed in Exhibit A), maintaining systems, providing support (Exhibit C), protecting user privacy, and responding to service interruptions (with credits for excessive downtime). Vitalibis must provide content, comply with a user terms of use agreement, and pay fees (Exhibit A).  Fees include one-time implementation fees and monthly license and hosting fees based on video views, with a 10% maximum annual increase.  Late payments accrue interest and can lead to service suspension or termination.

The agreement includes warranties from both parties, indemnification clauses, limitations of liability (excluding consequential damages), and confidentiality provisions.  Intellectual property rights are clearly delineated, with Votocast retaining ownership of its materials.

The initial term is one year, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 180 days' written notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach (30-day cure period) or certain events like insolvency.  Sections regarding payment, intellectual property, indemnification, limitations of liability, and confidentiality survive termination.  Governing law is California.  The agreement is non-exclusive.

SoupmanInc_20150814_8-K_EX-10.1_9230148_.summary:
This Master Franchise Agreement, dated August 14, 2015, is between Kiosk Concepts, Inc. (Franchisor) and The Grilled Cheese Truck, Inc. (Master Franchisee).  The agreement grants the Master Franchisee the exclusive right to sell and service "The Original Soupman" sub-franchises (Unit Franchises) within a defined North American territory.

The Master Franchisee's key obligations include:  selling a minimum number of Unit Franchises (Minimum Development Quota), providing initial and ongoing training to Unit Franchisees, adhering to the Franchisor's system and operational manuals, paying ongoing royalties (25% of Unit Franchisee royalties and 25% of initial franchise fees), submitting monthly revenue reports, maintaining required insurance, and complying with a non-compete clause for three years post-termination.  The Franchisor's obligations include providing manuals, training, and ongoing support.

The agreement's duration is ten years, renewable for four additional ten-year terms, subject to conditions including continued compliance and payment of a renewal fee.  Termination clauses include automatic termination for bankruptcy and immediate termination for various breaches (e.g., non-compliance, misrepresentation), with or without opportunity to cure.  Upon termination, the Master Franchisee must cease operations, return confidential information, and pay liquidated damages.  The agreement includes a security interest granted to the Franchisor over the Master Franchisee's assets to secure payment of all fees and obligations.  New York law governs the contract, with a non-binding mediation clause.

HEALTHGATEDATACORP_11_24_1999-EX-10.1-HO.summary:
This Escrow Agreement, dated March 12, 1998, involves HealthGate Data Corp ("Owner") and Blackwell Science Ltd ("Licensee"), utilizing NCC Escrow International Limited as the escrow agent.  Its purpose is to safeguard the source code ("Material") of the "HealthGate Electronic Journal Proprietary Software" package.

The Owner's key obligations include depositing the source code with NCC, ensuring its up-to-date functionality, and providing necessary documentation.  The Licensee's main responsibility is notifying NCC of any changes requiring updated source code deposits. NCC's role is secure storage and verification of the Material, subject to a limited liability of £500,000.

Release of the Material to the Licensee is triggered by specific events, including insolvency of the Owner, material breach of the License Agreement by the Owner, or failure of the software due to year 2000 compliance issues.  Disputes are resolved through arbitration or expert determination.

The agreement includes various fees for NCC's services, including initial, annual, update, storage, and release fees, payable according to Schedule 4.  The agreement terminates upon release of the Material or under specific circumstances detailed in Clause 11, including non-payment of fees or upon termination of the underlying License Agreement.  English law governs the contract.

BNLFINANCIALCORP_03_30_2007-EX-10.8-OUTS.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated May 1, 2006, is between Virtual Item Processing Systems, Inc. ("VIP") and Brokers National Life Assurance Company ("BNL").  VIP provides electronic data processing (EDP) services using its proprietary VIP System, which includes various modules for policy administration, claims, and financial management. BNL will use the VIP System to process its insurance policies.

BNL is responsible for acquiring and maintaining all necessary hardware and software compatible with the VIP System. VIP provides system access, maintenance, and (at its discretion) enhancements.  Scheduled and unscheduled downtime are acknowledged, with VIP providing a backup facility for extended outages.

VIP's fees are detailed in Schedules A & B, including a minimum monthly fee of $5,000.  Fees are based on policy counts, renewals, and additional services. Late payments incur a 1.5% monthly charge.  Additional services are billed hourly at rates specified in Schedule A.

VIP warrants the system's functionality but disclaims other warranties and limits its liability to 12 months of fees paid by BNL, excluding certain claims.  BNL similarly limits its liability.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.

The initial term is one year, renewable annually unless terminated with six months' written notice.  Early termination by BNL during an extended term incurs a significant cancellation fee.  The agreement includes clauses on confidentiality, arbitration (AAA rules), choice of law (Oklahoma), and limitations of actions (two years).  Both parties are independent contractors.

IntegrityMediaInc_20010329_10-K405_EX-10.summary: This Co-Branding Agreement, dated January 10, 2000, is between Integrity Incorporated ("Integrity") and Time Life, Inc. d/b/a Time Life Music ("TL") for the creation and marketing of a "Songs 4 Worship" praise and worship music series.  The agreement outlines joint responsibilities for product development (repertoire selection, artwork, manufacturing),  with Integrity handling master/print agreements and manufacturing, and TL responsible for artwork and mastering.  Distribution rights are divided geographically and by market segment (Christian retail vs. general market), with TL holding exclusive US television rights.  Pricing, including suggested retail prices and wholesale costs to TL, are specified, along with minimum purchase guarantees from TL.  Royalty structures are detailed for both parties, based on sales volume and location, with specific recoupment clauses for Integrity on songbook sales.  The agreement includes mutual data sharing of customer lists, simultaneous retail release, and provisions for accounting, auditing, and trademark licensing.  The term runs until December 31, 2004, with potential mutual extension.  Termination clauses address force majeure events and assignment of rights to unrelated third parties.  The agreement specifies Tennessee law and jurisdiction.  Both parties warrant their authority to enter the agreement and indemnify each other against claims.

IOVANCEBIOTHERAPEUTICS,INC_08_03_2017-EX.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective April 17, 2017, is between Lion Biotechnologies, Inc. ("LBIO") and The University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center ("MD Anderson").  The agreement establishes a collaboration for research studies (Studies), governed by a Joint Steering Committee (JSC) with equal representation from each party.

The main purpose is collaborative research on specified cancers using TILs.  MD Anderson is responsible for conducting the research, adhering to all applicable laws, regulations, and good clinical practices, and providing regular reports to LBIO. LBIO provides funding (up to $14,211,864), materials, and oversight.  Intellectual property rights related to inventions arising from the research are assigned to LBIO, with MD Anderson retaining rights for internal use.  MD Anderson grants LBIO licenses to certain background intellectual property.

Key terms include confidentiality obligations, publication protocols requiring LBIO's pre-approval, and dispute resolution mechanisms (unanimous JSC decisions, with LBIO CEO as tie-breaker).  The agreement's term is four years or until completion/termination of the research.  Termination clauses allow for termination due to material breach or insolvency.  Financial arrangements detail payment milestones tied to patient enrollment and deliverables.  The agreement specifies that MD Anderson is an independent contractor and includes disclaimers of liability for special damages, except for breaches of confidentiality, intellectual property provisions, gross negligence, or willful misconduct.  Texas law governs, with jurisdiction in Texas courts.

NEONSYSTEMSINC_03_01_1999-EX-10.5-DISTRI.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated January 1, 1996, is between Peregrine/Bridge Transfer Corporation (Licensor) and Neon Systems, Inc. (Licensee), both Delaware corporations.  The agreement grants Licensee exclusive worldwide rights to sublicense Licensor's software products (listed in Exhibit A) and related documentation.

Licensee's key obligations include marketing and sublicensing the software, complying with warranty obligations to customers and redistributors (whose agreements must be approved by Licensor), maintaining accurate records, providing monthly reports, and adhering to Licensor's branding guidelines.  Licensee is responsible for all costs except for Licensor's Master Copy delivery and initial training.

Licensor's key obligations include providing Master Copies, technical support, and marketing materials.  Licensor retains ownership of all intellectual property.

Financial arrangements stipulate a 50% royalty to Licensor on all Licensee's revenues from sublicensing and maintenance/support services. Payment terms vary based on invoice date.

The agreement's initial term is two years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 60 days' written notice or if a minimum annual revenue quota (starting at $50,000) isn't met.  Early termination clauses exist for insolvency, breach of contract, and certain corporate actions.  Significant indemnification and confidentiality clauses are included, along with provisions for audits.  The agreement is governed by Texas law.

TELKOMSALTD_01_30_2003-EX-10-LICENCE AND.summary:
This Licence and Maintenance Agreement (LMA), dated March 31, 2001, is between Systems Applications Products (Africa) (Pty) Limited ("SAP Africa") and Telkom South Africa Limited ("Telkom").  The LMA grants Telkom a non-exclusive, non-transferable license to use SAP Africa's software to establish and operate an internet-based e-commerce platform ("Marketplace").

Telkom's key obligations include payment of a substantial license fee (US$5,000,000) and a quarterly revenue share (initially 10%, potentially decreasing based on Telkom's procurement via the software),  installation and maintenance of the software on designated units, and adherence to usage restrictions preventing unauthorized third-party access or sublicensing.  SAP Africa's main obligations include software delivery, maintenance services (detailed in Annexure 2), and warranty support (with limitations).

The LMA includes provisions regarding proprietary rights, modifications, termination (by either party with 30 days' notice or for material breach), limitations of liability (capped at aggregate license fees paid), indemnification, and dispute resolution via arbitration (AFSA rules).  The license is perpetual unless terminated as specified.  Annexures detail specific software components, payment terms, and escrow arrangements for the source code.  The agreement is governed by South African law.

FIDELITYNATIONALINFORMATIONSERVICES,INC_.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (June 30, 2001) governs the transfer and licensing of intellectual property assets between Equifax Inc. ("Equifax") and its wholly-owned subsidiary, Certegy Inc. ("Certegy"), in conjunction with a tax-free spin-off (Section 355 of the Internal Revenue Code).  The agreement details the transfer of specified assets (Exhibits B & E) and third-party agreements (Exhibits C & F) between the two entities, along with reciprocal licenses for continued use of certain remaining intellectual property (Exhibits J & K).  

Key obligations include the assumption of liabilities associated with transferred assets (Section 2.3), obtaining necessary third-party consents (Article III), and granting reciprocal, non-exclusive, perpetual licenses for specified intellectual property (Article IV).  Ownership of enhancements created post-closing is assigned to the developing party (Sections 4.2 & 4.5).  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses (Article VII) with detailed procedures (Article VIII).  Confidentiality obligations are extensive (Article IX).  Continued assistance with the transition is required (Article X).  Financial arrangements are referenced but not detailed, linking to a separate Distribution Agreement.  The agreement's duration is perpetual, with termination only implied upon the cessation of the relationship between Equifax and Certegy.  Expenses are primarily borne by Equifax (Article XI).  Governing law is Georgia.

WatchitMediaInc_20061201_8-K_EX-10.1_414.summary: This Content License Agreement, effective September 1, 2006 – August 31, 2007, between Oceanic Time Warner Cable and Watchit Media, grants Oceanic Time Warner Cable a license to air Watchit's "Watchit Gaming Guides" and "Lunchtime with Ira" segments on its Las Vegas channel (777).  Watchit provides content in BetaSP format, retaining advertising rights and branding control, including a screen "bug."  Oceanic Time Warner Cable agrees not to edit the content but may reject inappropriate material.  A disclaimer regarding gambling is mandated.  Oceanic Time Warner Cable must provide viewership data to Watchit.  The agreement automatically terminates at the end of 2006, subject to renewal discussions.  Early termination by Oceanic Time Warner Cable before December 31, 2006, incurs a $5,000 monthly cancellation fee for the remaining term.  Both parties agree to mutually discuss the use of gathered data before public dissemination.  The agreement's primary purpose is the licensing of gaming-related content for broadcast on a specific cable channel.

TRUENORTHENERGYCORP_02_08_2007-EX-10.1-D.summary:
This Development Agreement, effective January 1, 2007, is between BP America Production Company ("BP"), a Delaware corporation, and True North Energy Corp. ("Company"), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement concerns the development of oil and gas leases (the "BP Interests") in a specified Contract Area in Louisiana.

The main purpose is to allow Company to earn an 8.75% working interest in the BP Interests.  Company's primary obligation is to pay 11.67% of the Initial Well's drilling costs (~$1.7M).  BP's key obligations include drilling the Initial Well with due diligence, providing well information, and potentially drilling a Substitute Well if the Initial Well is unsuccessful.  If the Initial Well is successful, BP assigns Company the 8.75% interest.  If unsuccessful, but produces hydrocarbons, BP assigns a limited interest ("Partial Interest").  BP operates all wells.

Important terms include definitions of "Objective Zone," "Casing Point," and various cost allocations.  Company has options to participate in well completion and subsequent wells but faces penalties for non-participation.  Financial arrangements involve Company's cost-sharing for drilling, completion, and operations, with specific percentages outlined.

The agreement terminates one year from the Rig Release Date unless the Initial Well is successful, a Substitute Well is drilled with Company participation, or a Partial Interest is earned, in which case it continues under an Operating Agreement.  Sections related to disclaimers, limitations of liability, and governing law (Louisiana) survive termination.  Company cannot assign its rights without BP's consent.  BP has a preferential right to purchase Company's interest should Company seek

GentechHoldingsInc_20190808_1-A_EX1A-6 M.contract_id: GentechHoldingsInc_20190808_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11776814_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Distributor Agreement
GentechHoldingsInc_20190808_1-A_EX1A-6 M.contract_title: GentechHoldingsInc_20190808_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_11776814_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Distributor Agreement
GentechHoldingsInc_20190808_1-A_EX1A-6 M.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective August 1, 2019, is between B & C General Warehouse Corporation LLC ("Company") and an unnamed Distributor.  The agreement grants the Distributor exclusive rights to sell and distribute specified Arte Café coffee products within the USA.  The Company imports the products from a Brazilian farm.

The Company's key obligations include supplying products at prices detailed in Schedule A (initially $9/kg ex-works Brazil, subject to annual 5% maximum price increases with 90-day notice), providing limited training and promotional materials, and fulfilling orders within seven business days of acceptance.  The Distributor's main responsibilities are diligent product distribution within the USA, timely payment (25% upon order acceptance, balance upon receipt of documents), and customer acquisition (subject to Company approval).  The Distributor is an independent contractor.

The agreement includes provisions for confidentiality of proprietary information (surviving termination for three years), indemnification, limitation of liability (excluding consequential damages), force majeure clauses, and trademark protection for the Company.  The initial term is three years, renewable for another three years with 90-day prior written notice. Termination can occur due to insolvency or material breach (with 90-day cure period).  Disputes are resolved through binding arbitration under the American Arbitration Association rules.  Florida law governs the agreement.

TICKETSCOMINC_06_22_1999-EX-10.22-SPONSO.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated February 17, 1999, is between Tickets.com, Inc. ("Tickets") and MP3.com, Inc. ("MP3.com").  Tickets becomes MP3.com's exclusive partner for sports, entertainment, and travel tickets, placing a portal on MP3.com's website.

MP3.com's key obligation is to deliver a minimum of 3,000,000 monthly impressions of the Tickets portal. Tickets' main obligation is payment of undisclosed sums in six installments over five months, subject to a 1.5% late fee.  Tickets has the right to audit MP3.com's impression counts, with adjustments made if overstated by more than 5%.

The agreement lasts one year, renewable for another year with a capped fee increase. Tickets may terminate with 30 days' notice within 60 days of the effective date.  Both parties provide mutual representations and warranties regarding their website content and indemnify each other for liabilities arising from breaches. Consequential damages are excluded (except for breaches of representations and warranties).  California law governs, with jurisdiction in San Diego County.  The agreement is assignable by Tickets only with MP3.com's consent (unless a substantial asset acquisition occurs).

ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC - Amendment.contract_id: ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC -  Amendment #3 to Manufacturing Agreement
ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC - Amendment.contract_title: ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC -  Amendment #3 to Manufacturing Agreement
ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC - Amendment.summary: Amendment #3, dated December 21, 2017, amends a Manufacturing Agreement between ADMA BioManufacturing, LLC ("ADMA") and Sanofi Pasteur S.A. ("Sanofi Pasteur") for the production of Rabies Fraction II Paste from human plasma.  This amendment revises the supply terms, specifying a reduced quantity of batches (exact numbers redacted) to be produced between Q3 2018 and Q3 2019, detailed in Exhibit A (redacted).  ADMA is obligated to supply a minimum volume (redacted) with significant liquidated damages (redacted USD) for failure to meet this minimum or the detailed supply plan.  Sanofi Pasteur pays ADMA a $7,000,000 compensation fee in installments for the reduced production volume.  The agreement also revises liability limitations (capped at a redacted amount), risk of loss provisions for source plasma, and amends the Quality Agreement.  Sanofi Pasteur may terminate the agreement immediately if ADMA's FDA compliance status negatively impacts production.  The amendment includes mutual releases upon full payment of the compensation fee.  Specific financial details and batch quantities are redacted due to confidentiality.

OFGBANCORP_03_28_2007-EX-10.23-OUTSOURCI.summary:
This Technology Outsourcing Agreement, dated January 26, 2007, is between Oriental Financial Group Inc. (Customer), a Puerto Rico financial holding company, and Metavante Corporation (Metavante), a Wisconsin corporation.  The agreement outlines Metavante's provision of technology services and licenses to Oriental Financial Group and its affiliates (listed in Exhibit A), encompassing various banking functions (deposit, loan processing, card services, ACH).

Metavante's key obligations include providing specified services detailed in several schedules (Current Capabilities, Conversion Plan, Services & Charges, etc.),  system conversion by November 5, 2007,  and ongoing maintenance and support.  Oriental Financial Group is responsible for data submission, compliance, payment of fees, and maintaining its own equipment and network infrastructure.  Metavante acts as Oriental Financial Group's attorney-in-fact for IRS/Treasury filings.

The initial term is until November 30, 2014, automatically renewing annually unless either party provides notice.  Early termination is possible for cause (material breach, uncured within 60 days) or for convenience (with a significant termination fee based on remaining contract value).  Liquidated damages are specified for conversion delays.  Metavante's liability is limited, excluding consequential damages.  Financial arrangements involve monthly fees detailed in the Services and Charges Schedule, subject to annual adjustments, plus additional charges for specific services and potential termination fees.  Governing law is New York.  Several clauses address confidentiality, dispute resolution, and indemnification.  Significant portions of the schedules are redacted due to confidentiality requests.

OMINTO,INC_03_29_2004-EX-10-RESELLER AGR.summary:
This Reseller Agreement, dated March 19, 2004, is between MediaNet Group Technologies, Inc. ("MediaNet") and International Direct Response, Inc. ("Reseller").  It governs Reseller's rights to market and resell MediaNet's Brand-A-Port portals and other products/services.

The agreement's main purpose is to establish a reseller relationship, defining compensation and responsibilities.  Reseller's key obligations include marketing MediaNet's products to various businesses and individuals (Buyers), subject to MediaNet's approval. MediaNet's obligations include paying Reseller commissions as detailed in the attached Compensation Schedule (20% on product sales, 10% on hosting fees), remitting payments within specified timeframes, and maintaining records.  MediaNet retains all intellectual property rights except for Reseller or Buyer-provided content.

The agreement includes confidentiality clauses, disclaimers of warranties, and limitations of liability.  The initial term is one year, renewable annually with mutual written consent. Either party may terminate with 60 days' written notice during a renewal term.  Termination for breach allows for offsetting payments due against costs incurred.  Sections regarding intellectual property, confidentiality, limitations of liability, and termination survive the agreement's expiration or termination.  Florida law governs the agreement.  Both parties are independent contractors.

DUOSTECHNOLOGIESGROUP,INC_04_21_2009-EX-.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective April 15, 2009, is between Information System Associates, Inc. ("ISA"), a Florida corporation, and Rubicon Software Group plc ("Rubicon"), a UK company.  The agreement establishes a strategic alliance encompassing reseller services and software development.

ISA's key obligations include reselling Rubicon's software and services (Rubicon Offerings) in the US, subject to exclusivity clauses and specified commission rates (Exhibit D, subject to annual review).  Rubicon's main obligations involve providing software development and implementation services (Contract Services) to ISA and its clients (SOWs, Exhibit A), conducting due diligence services for ISA's potential acquisitions, and adhering to confidentiality obligations.  Financial terms include commission payments to ISA based on Rubicon Offerings sales, fees for Contract and Due Diligence Services, and profit sharing (30% of ISA's profits exceeding £100,000 in start-up costs).  A target revenue of £1 million annually for Rubicon is set, but failure to meet it doesn't constitute a breach.

The agreement includes detailed Intellectual Property provisions assigning ownership to the respective creators (with "works for hire" stipulations for Rubicon's work for ISA), non-competition clauses (worldwide for ISA, Europe for Rubicon, for two years post-termination), and robust confidentiality clauses (3-year post-termination survival).  The initial term is three years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 90 days' notice. Termination for cause (material breach), bankruptcy, or intellectual property disputes is also provided.  Florida law governs, with non-exclusive jurisdiction in Palm City, Florida, except for IP

OLDAPIWIND-DOWNLTD_01_08_2016-EX-1.3-AGE.summary:
This Agency Agreement (OLDAPIWIND-DOWNLTD_01_08_2016-EX-1.3-AGENCY AGREEMENT1), dated May 21, 2015, governs the private placement of up to 13,043,695 common shares of Tribute Pharmaceuticals Canada Inc. ("Corporation") by Dundee Securities Ltd. (Lead Agent), Kes 7 Capital Inc., and Bloom Burton & Co. Ltd. (collectively, "Agents").  The Agents act solely as agents, not purchasers, of the Offered Shares, priced at $0.92 each.

The Corporation's key obligations include paying Agents a 7% cash fee (Agents' Fee) and issuing 3.5% of the Offered Shares as Compensation Options (exercisable for 24 months at the Offering Price).  The Agents' responsibilities include soliciting subscriptions, delivering Subscription Agreements, and ensuring compliance with securities laws (including US Regulation D and Canadian exemptions).  The Agents' Fee is payable upon closing, deductible from gross proceeds.  The Lead Agent receives all fees and options related to US Regulation D sales.

The agreement contains extensive representations and warranties from the Corporation concerning its financial condition, legal compliance, and business operations.  Closing is conditional upon the accuracy of these representations, receipt of legal opinions, and other specified conditions.  Agents may terminate the agreement under various circumstances, including regulatory actions, unforeseen events, material adverse changes, or Corporation's non-compliance.  The Corporation indemnifies the Agents against certain liabilities.  Contribution rights are also outlined, apportioning liability between the parties.  Ontario law governs the agreement.  The agreement is considered the entire

ADIANUTRITION,INC_04_01_2005-EX-10.D2-RE.summary:
This Reseller Agreement, dated 2004, is between PivX Corporation (California) and Detto Technologies (Washington).  It grants Detto a non-transferable, exclusive license to distribute PivX's Qwik-Fix Pro software in North America and a non-exclusive license outside North America, solely to third-party licensees.  Detto is obligated to comply with PivX's licensing agreements, provide customer support, protect PivX's intellectual property, and adhere to all applicable laws and regulations.  Detto cannot reverse engineer Qwik-Fix Pro.

Detto must pay PivX per-copy fees, subject to a 45-day notice period for price increases, within 30 days of invoicing.  Late payments incur a 1.5% monthly charge. PivX retains ownership of all intellectual property.  PivX provides a 30-day warranty on the CD-ROM media.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.  PivX's liability is capped at the amount received in the preceding six months.

The agreement lasts six months and can be terminated by PivX with 30 days' notice or by either party for material breach (with a 30-day cure period).  Upon termination, Detto must return all software and documentation, erase all copies, and pay outstanding amounts.  Specific clauses regarding intellectual property, indemnification, and confidentiality survive termination.  California law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in Orange County, California.

ATHENSBANCSHARESCORP_11_02_2009-EX-1.2-A.summary:
This 2009 Agency Agreement governs the relationship between Athens Bancshares Corporation ("Company"), Athens Federal Community Bank ("Bank"), and Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc. ("Agent") concerning the Bank's conversion from a mutual to a stock savings bank and a subsequent stock offering.  The Agent acts as the exclusive financial advisor and marketing agent for the Company and Bank in the offering of up to [Unspecified Number] shares of the Company's common stock.

The Agent's key obligations include best efforts solicitation of subscriptions, advising the Company and Bank, and participating in market making and syndicate formation (if needed).  The Company and Bank warrant the accuracy of all filings (SEC Form S-1, OTS Form AC, Holding Company Application) and provide extensive representations and warranties regarding their financial condition, legal compliance, and the accuracy of the prospectus.

The Agent's compensation includes a $30,000 management fee and a success fee (minimum $200,000, 1.125% of the aggregate purchase price of shares sold, excluding certain categories).  Additional fees apply for a potential syndicated community offering.  The Company and Bank reimburse the Agent's reasonable out-of-pocket expenses (up to $50,000 for legal counsel).

The agreement terminates upon completion of the offering, but no later than 45 days after the subscription offering, unless extended.  Termination also occurs if the Company fails to sell a minimum number of shares.  Extensive indemnification and contribution clauses protect the parties from liabilities arising from untrue statements or omissions in the offering documents.  The agreement is governed by New York law and includes a jury

GSITECHNOLOGYINC_11_16_2009-EX-10.2-INTE.contract_id: GSITECHNOLOGYINC_11_16_2009-EX-10.2-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT between SONY ELECTRONICS INC. and GSI TECHNOLOGY, INC.
GSITECHNOLOGYINC_11_16_2009-EX-10.2-INTE.contract_title: GSITECHNOLOGYINC_11_16_2009-EX-10.2-INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY AGREEMENT between SONY ELECTRONICS INC. and GSI TECHNOLOGY, INC.
GSITECHNOLOGYINC_11_16_2009-EX-10.2-INTE.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated August 28, 2009, is between Sony Electronics Inc. ("SONY") and GSI Technology, Inc. ("PURCHASER").  The IPA supplements a concurrently executed Asset Purchase Agreement (APA), transferring certain assets and intellectual property related to SRAM product manufacturing.

The main purpose is to assign certain patents (listed in Exhibit A) from SONY to PURCHASER and grant reciprocal, worldwide, non-exclusive, royalty-free licenses. SONY licenses its remaining SRAM-related patents to PURCHASER for use in competing products.  PURCHASER grants SONY a similar license under the assigned patents, contingent on SONY's adherence to a non-compete clause in the APA.  Crucially, SONY trademarks are not licensed, and PURCHASER must remove them from products except as specified for certain mask works.

Key obligations include patent assignment and license grants, removal of SONY branding, and non-affiliation representations.  Representations and warranties from SONY cover patent ownership, validity, and non-infringement.

The agreement's term lasts until the expiration of the licensed IP rights.  Termination clauses exist for material breach (30-day cure period), assertion of claims based on patents by either party (30-day notice), and insolvency.  Financial considerations are incorporated into the APA's purchase price; no additional payments are required under the IPA.  Governing law is California.

MusclepharmCorp_20170208_10-KA_EX-10.38_.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective July 26, 2013, is between MusclePharm Corporation ("MusclePharm") and the Arnold Schwarzenegger Parties (Marine MP, LLC, Arnold Schwarzenegger, and Fitness Publications, Inc.) ("AS Parties").  The agreement centers on Arnold Schwarzenegger's endorsement and co-branding of MusclePharm products.

MusclePharm's key obligations include:  developing and marketing a co-branded product line ("AS Product Line"),  paying royalties (10% of net sales) and a guaranteed minimum royalty to the AS Parties,  providing marketing funds ($3-5 million annually), obtaining AS Party approval for marketing materials and product samples, and maintaining product quality and safety.  Schwarzenegger commits to appearances, endorsements, and providing online content.

The agreement initially runs for three years, automatically renewing for two further three-year terms contingent on achieving specified sales thresholds ($20 million and $50 million).  Termination clauses allow for termination by either party for material breach or specific events (e.g., felony conviction of Schwarzenegger, MusclePharm insolvency).  MusclePharm also issued 780,000 shares of restricted stock to the AS Parties upon signing.  California law governs, with disputes resolved through JAMS arbitration.  Both parties provide mutual indemnities.  Exclusivity clauses restrict Schwarzenegger's endorsement of competing products for the duration of the agreement and one year thereafter.

PAXMEDICA,INC_07_02_2020-EX-10.12-Master.summary:
This Master Service Agreement (MSA), dated May 25, 2018, is between CRO Consulting (Pty) Limited ("CRO"), a South African company, and Purinix Pharmaceuticals LLC ("Client"), a US company.  The MSA governs CRO's provision of clinical research services in South Africa for Client's projects, detailed in project-specific addenda.

CRO's key obligations include performing services professionally, adhering to GCP guidelines and relevant laws, providing weekly reports, and obtaining Client approval for subcontracting.  Client's obligations include providing necessary information and paying CRO according to the addenda, within 30 days of invoice.  Payment terms are detailed in project-specific addenda, with a schedule outlined in an addendum for a Phase 2B study.

The MSA includes warranties from CRO regarding professional performance, limitations of liability capped at amounts received from Client (excluding gross negligence/willful misconduct), and mutual indemnification clauses.  CRO must assign inventions and deliverables to Client.  The agreement is governed by Connecticut law.

The MSA has an indefinite duration, terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice for material breach (with a cure period) or by Client without cause (with payment for completed work and reasonable termination costs).  Immediate termination is allowed for insolvency.  A five-year limitation period applies to legal actions.  All intellectual property developed by CRO in relation to the project belongs to the Client.

SoupmanInc_20150814_8-K_EX-10.1_9230148_.summary: This addendum to a Soupman, Inc. Master Franchise Agreement addresses California-specific legal issues concerning a multi-state franchise.  The parties are Soupman, Inc. (franchisor) and a California franchisee.  The main purpose is to clarify the agreement's compliance with California franchise laws.  Key obligations include the franchisor's duty to provide a disclosure document (per California Corporation Code §31125) before material modifications and the franchisee's potential right to challenge unenforceable provisions under California law.  Important terms include potentially unenforceable clauses regarding termination (bankruptcy, covenants not to compete), choice of law (New York), venue (New York), and liquidated damages.  The addendum highlights the potential invalidity of waivers of rights under California's Franchise Investment Law and Franchise Relations Act.  No specific duration or financial arrangements are detailed in this addendum; those are presumably contained within the Master Franchise Agreement.  The addendum emphasizes the need for independent legal counsel for the franchisee.

MOVADOGROUPINC_04_30_2003-EX-10.28-ENDOR.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated April 4, 2003, amends a prior Split Dollar Agreement between Movado Group, Inc. ("Company") and the Grinberg Family Trust ("Trust").  The agreement addresses concerns regarding Sarbanes-Oxley Act compliance related to loans to executive officers.  The Trust transfers ownership of a New York Life Insurance Company policy (Policy No. 45660373) to the Company as partial repayment of a $5,186,860 loan (Demand Note), with the Company receiving the policy's cash surrender value ($4,595,591).

The Company becomes the policy owner, responsible for future premiums, but requires Trust consent for policy loans, withdrawals, or surrender. Upon the death of the insured(s), the death benefit is split: the Company receives its aggregate premiums paid less the outstanding Demand Note balance; the Trust receives any excess.  The Company's failure to pay premiums or unauthorized policy actions constitutes a "Company Default," allowing the Trust to reclaim the policy.

The agreement specifies notice procedures, designates New York law as governing (except where preempted by ERISA), and includes detailed claims procedures if subject to ERISA.  The agreement terminates upon the Trust's full repayment of the remaining Demand Note balance ($591,269) plus aggregate premiums paid, at which point the Company transfers the policy back to the Trust.  The agreement explicitly states it is not a contract of employment.

StaarSurgicalCompany_20180801_10-Q_EX-10.summary:
This Distributorship Agreement, effective [Effective Date], is between STAAR SURGICAL AG (STAAR), a Swiss corporation, and [Distributor Name], a [State] corporation.  The agreement appoints [Distributor Name] as the exclusive distributor (subject to STAAR's right to direct sales) of specified ophthalmic products (listed in Exhibit A-1) within a defined territory ([Territory]).

[Distributor Name]'s key obligations include actively promoting and selling the products, providing annual marketing plans and quarterly reports, maintaining adequate inventory and staff, complying with all applicable laws and regulations, and adhering to STAAR's post-market surveillance requirements (including product recalls).  STAAR's obligations include providing product training and literature, technical assistance, and invoicing.

Pricing is detailed in Exhibit A-1, payable in USD within 30 days.  Minimum purchase quantities are specified in Exhibit B.  STAAR retains title to products until full payment.  The agreement includes provisions for warranties, indemnification, confidentiality (of STAAR's proprietary information), and limitations of liability.

The agreement's term is [Duration], renewable annually by mutual written consent.  Termination clauses allow for immediate termination due to insolvency, breach of contract (after 30-day notice), failure to meet minimum purchase quantities, or upon 90-day written notice without cause.  Upon termination, STAAR has the option to repurchase inventory.  California law governs, with disputes resolved through binding arbitration in Los Angeles, except for injunctive relief.  The agreement also includes provisions regarding data protection and compliance with US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

EmeraldHealthBioceuticalsInc_20200218_1-.summary:
This Consulting and Licensing Agreement, effective September 1, 2016, involves Emerald Health Sciences Inc. (EHS), Emerald Health Nutraceuticals Inc. (EHN), and Dr. Michael T. Murray.  The agreement outlines Dr. Murray's consulting services to both EHS (pharmaceutical development of cannabinoid products) and EHN (product development, marketing, and advocacy).  EHS and EHN bear all product development and marketing costs.  Dr. Murray agrees to exclusivity, not assisting competitors.  Intellectual property rights for developed products belong to EHS and EHN, excluding Dr. Murray's name and likeness.

Dr. Murray receives $8,333 monthly from EHN for the first year, stock options in EHS, and tiered royalties (up to $2.5 million) based on net sales of products he develops for EHN.  He also receives 5% equity ownership in EHN and reimbursement for pre-approved expenses.  The initial service term is until December 31, 2018, automatically renewing biennially unless terminated with 90 days' notice.  Either party can terminate a service term with 60 days' notice; EHS/EHN can terminate immediately for breach.  Royalty payments continue perpetually.  The agreement is governed by Arizona law, with dispute resolution via mediation and then arbitration in Phoenix, Arizona.  Confidentiality clauses protect proprietary information.

DRIVENDELIVERIES,INC_05_22_2020-EX-10.4-.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated May 1, 2019, is between Driven Deliveries, Inc. (Company), a Nevada corporation, and TruckThat LLC (Consultant).  The agreement engages the Consultant as an independent contractor to provide strategic marketing and fundraising consulting services to the Company for a monthly fee of $18,000.  The Consultant's responsibilities include strategic business expansion planning, fundraising, stock promotion, and marketing support (graphics, web, social media, branding), along with updating investor and sales decks.

Key obligations include maintaining confidentiality of the Company's information, assigning all intellectual property rights created during the consultancy to the Company, and a non-compete/non-solicitation clause for five years post-termination.  The Consultant warrants non-infringement of third-party rights.  The Company is obligated to reimburse reasonable, pre-approved expenses.

The initial term is six months, terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice, or immediately by the Company for cause.  Several clauses survive termination, including confidentiality, intellectual property assignment, non-compete, and indemnification.  The Company's liability is capped at the amounts paid to the Consultant. Disputes are subject to arbitration in San Diego County, California, with exceptions for injunctive relief regarding confidentiality and intellectual property breaches.  California law governs.

STAMPSCOMINC_06_24_1999-EX-10.18-SPONSOR.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated May 14, 1999, is between Intuit Inc. and Stamps.com Inc.  Its purpose is to establish a comprehensive advertising and sponsorship campaign for Stamps.com on Intuit's websites (including Quicken.com, QuickBooks.com, and affiliated sites) and Quicken software.

Stamps.com's key obligations include providing advertising materials and paying fees. Intuit's key obligations include displaying Stamps.com's advertisements and graphics in specified locations and quantities (with impression guarantees), maintaining its websites, and providing monthly reports.  Key terms define "Impressions," "New Customer," and "Net Transaction Revenues."  Intuit grants Stamps.com exclusivity for electronic postage advertising on certain sites.

The agreement includes detailed specifications for advertising placement and size across various Intuit platforms.  Intuit estimates, but doesn't guarantee, specific impression numbers; failure to meet these within 12 months requires renegotiation of placement.

The term lasts for 12 months from the Launch Date or until 176,717,916 impressions are served, whichever is later.  Termination can occur for material breach after a 30-day cure period.  Stamps.com pays Intuit a significant upfront fee ($2,644,010 + $661,003 exclusivity fee) plus a percentage of Net Transaction Revenues after a minimum customer threshold is met.  Both parties have audit rights regarding fee calculations.  The agreement includes standard clauses on confidentiality, warranties, indemnities, limitation of liability, and governing law (California).  A list of Stamps.com's competitors is included

BEYONDCOMCORP_08_03_2000-EX-10.2-CO-HOST.summary:
This Co-Hosting Agreement, dated September 21, 1998, is between Networks Associates, Inc. ("NAI") and Software.Net Corporation (a.k.a. Beyond.com) ("Co-Host").  It governs the co-hosting of Beyond.com's software sales on NAI's websites.  Co-Host pays a significant upfront fee ($2.5 million) plus quarterly payments contingent on revenue targets.

The agreement grants Co-Host exclusive online reseller rights for NAI's software on specified NAI websites ("Originating Locations"), with exceptions for NAI's own sales and strategic partners.  Co-Host is obligated to provide marketing materials and comply with NAI's branding guidelines.  NAI provides designated website space and placement for Co-Host's "hot links."  NAI has a limited duty to promote Co-Host's products.

Key terms include definitions of "Competitor's Goods," "NAI Goods," and revenue targets.  The agreement includes provisions on proprietary rights, confidentiality, indemnification, limitations of liability ($15 million cap on direct damages, excluding third-party claims), and force majeure.

The agreement's term is three years from the Effective Date (September 21, 1998), subject to earlier termination for material breach by either party (30-day cure period), termination of related agreements, insolvency, or 90-day notice by Co-Host after June 30, 2000, under specific conditions.  Termination clauses specify consequences, including liquidated damages for Co-Host's breach.  The agreement is governed by California law

CHEETAHMOBILEINC_04_22_2014-EX-10.43-Coo.summary:
