This Cooperation Agreement, dated April 2013, is between Beike Internet (Beijing) Security Technology Co., Ltd. ("Party A") and Baidu Online Network Technology (Beijing) Co., Ltd. ("Party B").  The agreement governs Party A's integration of Baidu's search engine into its Kingsoft internet site navigation website and Cheetah Browser software.

Party A's key obligations include displaying Baidu's search engine box prominently, using Baidu as the default search engine in Cheetah Browser, and adhering to Baidu's Union Membership Agreement and "Blue Sky 365" Action Plan.  Party A is prohibited from cooperating with Qihoo 360 without Baidu's consent. Party B's obligations include providing search engine services, accurate traffic data, and timely revenue settlements.  Baidu retains the right to adjust service pricing and content with advance notice.

The agreement's duration is two years (May 1, 2013 – April 30, 2015), renewable by mutual agreement.  Termination can occur due to breach, bankruptcy, or force majeure lasting over 30 days.  Financial arrangements involve revenue sharing based on search traffic, with specific percentages dependent on default vs. non-default traffic volume.  A minimum revenue threshold exists before payment is due.  Party A bears taxes on its share of revenue.  Baidu's liability is limited per Annex 1.  Governing law is PRC law, with dispute resolution via negotiation or court action in Baidu's location.  Confidentiality and intellectual property rights are addressed.

ClickstreamCorp_20200330_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT.contract_id: ClickstreamCorp_20200330_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_12089935_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Development Agreement
ClickstreamCorp_20200330_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT.contract_title: ClickstreamCorp_20200330_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_12089935_EX1A-6 MAT CTRCT_Development Agreement
ClickstreamCorp_20200330_1-A_EX1A-6 MAT.summary:
This Application Development Agreement, dated March 20, 2020, is between Clickstream Corporation (Client) and InfinixSoft Global LLC (Developer).  The agreement outlines the development of a social betting mobile application (iOS and Android) and responsive website.  The Developer's key obligations include designing and developing the application according to specifications in Exhibit A, assisting with deployment, providing 90-day warranty support, and ensuring the application is free from defects. The Client's obligations include providing necessary information, cooperation, and acceptance testing.  Intellectual property rights vest exclusively with the Client.

The agreement's term is until the end of the 90-day warranty period, but either party can terminate with 7 days' notice (except for Client's unilateral right to cancel with 7 days' notice and Developer's right to cancel for non-payment after a 30-day cure period).  Material breach allows termination with 3 days' notice.  The total compensation is $480,000, with $180,000 paid via stock and the remaining $300,000 paid in installments detailed in Exhibit A.  The Developer is classified as an independent contractor, and indemnification clauses protect both parties against certain liabilities.  Florida law governs the agreement.  All work is considered "work for hire" for the Client.

NEOMEDIATECHNOLOGIESINC_12_15_2005-EX-16.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective December 1, 2005, appoints NeoMedia Micro Paint Repair (Florida, USA) ("Distributor") as a non-exclusive distributor of PPG Paints Trading (Shanghai) Co., Ltd.'s ("PPG Shanghai") "Deltron" and "ACS" automotive refinish products in specified regions of P.R. China (Territory), with exclusive rights to sell to Beijing Sino-US Jinche Yingang Auto Technological Services Limited.  Upon establishment of a Chinese subsidiary, the distributorship will transfer to that entity.

Distributor's key obligations include promoting sales, meeting sales targets (Appendix 3), providing customer service and technical support, complying with all relevant laws and regulations, and using PPG Shanghai's trademarks only as permitted.  PPG Shanghai's responsibilities include supplying products (subject to availability), providing marketing support, and offering training.  Financial arrangements involve prepayment by Distributor at prices set by PPG Shanghai (Appendix 5), with potential rebates (Appendix 3).  PPG Shanghai bears transportation costs to its warehouse.

The agreement's term is until December 31, 2006, with a potential renewal subject to written agreement 30 days prior to expiry.  Termination may occur for default (10-day cure period), insolvency, fraudulent conduct, or cancellation of Distributor's business license.  Dispute resolution is through arbitration in China under the rules of the China International Economic and Trade Arbitration Committee.  Governing law is that of the People's Republic of China.  Damages are limited; consequential damages are excluded.  The agreement contains extensive provisions regarding product warranties, liability, and responsible care guidelines.

ADUROBIOTECH,INC_06_02_2020-EX-10.7-CONS.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated June 1, 2020, and effective July 1, 2020, is between Aduro Biotech, Inc. (Aduro) and Ireya B.V., represented by Andrea van Elsas (Consultant).  The agreement outlines Consultant's provision of consulting services to Aduro regarding research, clinical development, and business matters.

Consultant's key obligations include providing advice and consultation as directed by Aduro, maintaining confidentiality of Aduro's information, and assigning all intellectual property rights created during the consultancy to Aduro.  Aduro's main obligations are to compensate Consultant at €500/hour, reimburse reasonable expenses (up to €5,000 individually and €20,000 in aggregate without prior written consent), and pay invoices within 30 days.  Aduro retains exclusive ownership of all work product.

The agreement includes a non-solicitation clause prohibiting Consultant from soliciting Aduro employees for 12 months post-termination.  Aduro's Insider Trading and Trading Window Policy applies to Consultant.  The agreement is governed by California law and is effective until December 31, 2020, unless terminated earlier by either party with written notice or mutually extended.  Breach of confidentiality provisions survives termination.  Consultant is classified as an independent contractor.  The agreement contains standard clauses regarding intellectual property assignment, confidentiality, and dispute resolution.

LejuHoldingsLtd_20140121_DRS (on F-1)_EX.summary:
This Domain Name and Content License Agreement, effective upon Closing Date (defined in a separate Share Purchase Agreement), is between Beijing SINA Internet Information Service Co., Ltd. ("Licensor") and Beijing Yisheng Leju Information Services Co., Ltd. ("Licensee"), both PRC entities.  The agreement grants Licensee an exclusive, non-transferable license (with limited exceptions for affiliates) to use specified Sina domain names (Exhibit A) and content for an online real estate platform ("Business") in China.

Licensee has exclusive control over the Business's operation and content, subject to content monitoring and censorship obligations to comply with PRC laws and remove offensive material.  Licensor retains ownership of the licensed domain names and content.  Financial arrangements are primarily royalty-free, except for a potential future fee adjustment if E-House claims become payable by Licensee.

The agreement's initial term is ten years, renewable through good-faith negotiation.  Termination clauses include breach (30-day cure period), insolvency, a "Change of Control" at CRIC, and automatic termination if a related Agency Agreement terminates under specific clauses.  Upon termination (but not expiration), Licensee has a 90-day transition period.  Both parties have mutual indemnification obligations.  The agreement is governed by PRC law and disputes are resolved through arbitration in Beijing.

VISIUMTECHNOLOGIES,INC_10_20_2004-EX-10..summary:
This Distributor Agreement, effective April 7, 2003, is between Wireless Links Inc. ("WLI"), a Pennsylvania corporation, and Jaguar Investments, Inc. ("Power2Ship"), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement appoints Power2Ship as a non-exclusive distributor of WLI's G3001 GPSLink mobile terminal and associated MidLink middleware software in North America.

Power2Ship's key obligations include purchasing and distributing the Products, paying monthly license fees (minimum 36 months per unit, with exceptions for unit relocation), providing WLI with weekly reports on unit sales, suspensions, and reactivations, and maintaining a service inventory.  WLI's main obligations include providing products, software, training, and warranty support.  Pricing is tiered based on order quantity, with a minimum order of 1000 units at a discounted price.  WLI retains title to the software and imposes strict confidentiality and usage restrictions.

The agreement has a three-year initial term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 120 days' written notice.  Termination for cause is permitted for material breach by either party.  WLI's liability is capped at the total amount payable by Power2Ship in the preceding six months.  The governing law is New Jersey.  The agreement includes detailed provisions on payment terms, warranty, indemnification, intellectual property rights, and dispute resolution.

HALITRON,INC_03_01_2005-EX-10.15-SPONSOR.summary:
This Sponsorship and Development Agreement, dated August 6, 2004 (amended December 10, 2004), is between Teknik Digital Arts Inc. ("TDA") and Rick Smith ("Smith").  The agreement concerns the development and marketing of TDA's golf instruction software.

Smith grants TDA exclusive rights to use his name, likeness, etc., for TDA's golf instruction software and related marketing for three years (the "Term").  Smith agrees to cooperate in development and promotion.  TDA commits to featuring Smith as the featured instructor on all packaging and promotional materials.  TDA's use of Smith's likeness is limited to its golf instruction products.  Smith agrees to exclusivity regarding golf instruction software endorsements during the Term, with exceptions for existing PGA arrangements.

TDA's compensation to Smith includes 25,000 restricted common shares, a 33% royalty on net sales (or $1 per subscription, whichever is greater for handheld products), and a one-time option to convert royalties to TDA stock (limited to 25,000 shares, terminating future royalties).  TDA also covers Smith's reasonable travel and related expenses.  An audit clause allows Smith to review TDA's sales records.

The agreement terminates after three years, but TDA can continue distributing existing products incorporating Smith's likeness for 180 days post-termination, provided TDA is not in default.  The agreement includes standard clauses on representations, warranties, indemnification, governing law (Arizona), and dispute resolution (Arizona courts, waiver of jury trial).  Smith is not liable to TDA beyond amounts received, excluding expenses.

INNOVIVA,INC_08_07_2014-EX-10.1-COLLABOR.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, dated November 14, 2002, is between Theravance, Inc. (Theravance) and Glaxo Group Limited (GSK).  It's a worldwide, exclusive (except for Theravance) license agreement for the joint development and commercialization of long-acting β2 adrenoceptor agonists (LABAs) for respiratory diseases.

GSK assumes primary responsibility for development (funding, clinical trials, regulatory filings) and commercialization (marketing, sales, distribution). Theravance licenses its patents and know-how.  A Joint Steering Committee and Joint Project Committee govern the collaboration, resolving disputes through consensus or escalation to designated officers.  GSK retains final decision-making authority in most cases, except for commercial conflicts, which are resolved by mediation.

Key terms include definitions of "Collaboration Product," "Technical Failure," "Commercial Failure," and "Net Sales."  The agreement outlines milestone payments to both parties upon achieving development milestones (e.g., Phase III initiation, registration) and tiered royalties to Theravance based on net sales (15% up to $3B, then 5%; different rates for other combination products).  GSK is responsible for obtaining and maintaining regulatory approvals.

The agreement's term is country-specific and product-specific, lasting until the later of patent expiration or 15 years post-first commercial sale. GSK has rights to terminate development or commercialization under specified conditions.  Termination clauses address material breach, discontinuation of all products, and GSK's right to terminate development or commercialization.  Financial provisions detail upfront payments, milestone payments, and royalty structures.  Detailed provisions address intellectual property ownership, confidentiality, indemnification

SoupmanInc_20150814_8-K_EX-10.1_9230148_.summary: This is a Guarantee agreement (Attachment B to a Master Franchise Agreement) where unnamed Guarantors jointly and severally guarantee the performance of an unnamed Master Franchisee under a Master Franchise Agreement with Soupman, Inc. ("Franchisor").  The Guarantors' primary obligation is to ensure payment of all monies owed by the Master Franchisee to the Franchisor and to guarantee full performance of all Master Franchisee obligations under the Master Franchise Agreement.  This guarantee covers all losses, damages, costs, and expenses incurred by the Franchisor due to the Master Franchisee's defaults.  Crucially, the Franchisor is not required to pursue remedies against the Master Franchisee before pursuing the Guarantors.  The Franchisor can modify or release the Master Franchisee's obligations without notifying the Guarantors, and the Guarantors waive notice of such actions. The Guarantors' obligations remain in effect regardless of the Master Franchisee's bankruptcy, insolvency, or termination of the Master Franchise Agreement.  The agreement's governing law is determined by the Franchisor's principal place of business, with exceptions for enforceability based on the Master Franchisee's business location.  Venue for any action is specified as the Franchisor's principal place of business.  No specific duration or termination clause is explicitly stated beyond the implicit termination tied to the underlying Master Franchise Agreement.  Financial arrangements are implicitly tied to the underlying Master Franchise Agreement's terms.

ADUROBIOTECH,INC_06_02_2020-EX-10.7-CONS.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated June 1, 2020, and effective July 1, 2020, is between Aduro Biotech, Inc. (Aduro) and Ireya B.V., represented by Andrea van Elsas (Consultant).  The agreement outlines Consultant's provision of consulting services to Aduro regarding research, clinical development, and business matters.

Consultant's key obligations include providing advice and consultation as directed by Aduro, maintaining confidentiality of Aduro's Confidential Information (defined broadly), and assigning all intellectual property rights related to the work performed to Aduro.  Aduro's main obligations are to compensate Consultant at €500/hour, reimburse reasonable expenses (up to €5,000 individually and €20,000 in aggregate without prior written consent), and pay invoices within 30 days.  A non-solicitation clause prevents Consultant from soliciting Aduro employees for 12 months post-termination.

The agreement runs from July 1, 2020, to December 31, 2020, and is terminable by either party with written notice.  Extension requires mutual written agreement.  California law governs.  The agreement includes standard clauses on independent contractor status, intellectual property assignment, confidentiality, and dispute resolution (implied through the governing law clause).  Breach of confidentiality provisions may result in injunctive relief and damages.  The agreement is not assignable by the Consultant.

CybergyHoldingsInc_20140520_10-Q_EX-10.2.summary:
This Marketing Affiliate Agreement, dated May 8, 2014, is between Birch First Global Investments Inc. (Company), a U.S. Virgin Islands corporation, and Mount Knowledge Holdings Inc. (MA), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement governs MA's marketing and sale of Company's "Technology" (English Communications Online platform and content) to corporate, government, and educational clients.

MA's key obligations include best-efforts marketing, client license agreement execution, providing first-line technical support, maintaining accurate sales records, and complying with all applicable laws.  Company's obligations include providing the Technology at discounted prices (detailed in Schedule A), marketing materials, training, and updates.  MA is an independent contractor, not an employee.

Schedule A details pricing, quotas, discounts, and territory (worldwide).  Financial arrangements include a quarterly service fee of $15,000 (even without sales) and net 30-day payment terms for Technology sales.  Company retains title to the Technology; MA is prohibited from reverse engineering or unauthorized use.  Company provides limited warranties, disclaiming liability for consequential damages.

The agreement has an initial term ending at year-end, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination can occur with 30-days' notice or for material breach.  Upon termination, MA must return all Company materials and cease using the Technology and related intellectual property.  Nevada law governs, with the prevailing party entitled to attorney fees.  The agreement contains strong confidentiality and intellectual property protection clauses.

MANAKOASERVICESCORP_11_21_2007-EX-7.5-ST.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated June 14, 2006, is between UTEK Corporation (UTEK), a Delaware corporation, and Manakoa Services Corporation (MKOS), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement outlines a 12-month (renewable) alliance where UTEK will identify technology acquisition opportunities for MKOS from research institutions.  UTEK's obligations include identifying opportunities, making itself available for consultations, and (at MKOS's request and UTEK's discretion) negotiating licenses and proposing equity financing plans. MKOS has a 30-day review period for each opportunity; UTEK can then offer the technology to others.  MKOS agrees not to directly acquire presented technologies for 24 months post-termination.

UTEK is an independent contractor, with MKOS responsible for its own liabilities.  UTEK's compensation is either $120,000 in unregistered MKOS common stock (vesting monthly) or $10,000/month.  Additional compensation is payable upon successful technology transfer via a stock-for-stock exchange of a UTEK subsidiary.  Either party can terminate with 30 days' written notice.  The agreement includes confidentiality, indemnification, non-solicitation, and legal compliance clauses, specifying disclosure requirements and the need for mutual consent on press releases.  The agreement also contains provisions for injunctive relief and attorney's fees in case of breach.

WestPharmaceuticalServicesInc_20200116_8.summary: This Global Master Supply Agreement (GMSA), effective January 1, 2019, and expiring December 31, 2023, governs the sale of butyl products by ExxonMobil Chemical Company (and its affiliates, "Seller") to West Pharmaceutical Services, Inc. (and its affiliates, "Buyer").  The GMSA outlines minimum and maximum annual purchase quantities, with Buyer issuing purchase orders subject to Seller's approval.  Pricing is based on a base price, crude oil adjustments, and freight costs (EXW Incoterms 2010).  A crude trigger clause adjusts pricing based on Brent crude oil price fluctuations.  Payment is via EFT, with terms detailed in Attachment E.  Title and risk of loss transfer vary depending on location and shipping method, with specific provisions for US exports to Mexico and other non-US locations.  The agreement includes provisions for quality assurance, technical support, safety, audits, supply security, and collaboration planning.  Significant changes in Buyer's ownership or structure require notification to Seller, who may adjust payment terms or terminate the agreement.  Dispute resolution for warranty issues involves independent laboratory testing.  The agreement includes force majeure and change in circumstances clauses.  Governing law varies by ExxonMobil affiliate (specified in Attachments A, G, and H), with the GMSA prevailing in case of conflict.  The contract contains standard clauses on set-off, liability limitations, and termination for material breach (after a 30-day cure period).  Attachments detail specific terms and conditions for different ExxonMobil affiliates and locations.

PANDIONTHERAPEUTICSHOLDCOLLC_05_22_2020-.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated March 27, 2017, is between Immunotolerance, Inc. (Company) and Alan Crane (Consultant).  The agreement outlines Crane's provision of consulting services in the field of tissue-specific immunosuppression drugs and cell-based therapies (Schedule A).  Crane's key obligations include providing requested services, maintaining confidentiality (Section 6), and refraining from soliciting Company employees for one year post-termination (Section 7).  The Company's obligations include reimbursing Crane's expenses and providing necessary information and access.

The agreement grants Crane 1,990,000 shares of Company common stock at $0.0001 per share (plus existing 10,000 shares), subject to a separate Restricted Stock Agreement.  The initial four-year term automatically renews annually unless terminated with 90 days' notice by the Company. The Company may terminate for cause (e.g., breach of contract, misconduct) or immediately for certain Consultant breaches.  Crane may terminate with 30 days' notice.  Section 6 contains extensive provisions regarding proprietary information and invention ownership, assigning all inventions related to the Company's business to the Company.  The Consultant is classified as an independent contractor.  Massachusetts law governs the agreement.  Breach of Sections 1, 6, or 7 allows the Company to seek specific performance and injunctive relief.  Sections 4-20 survive termination.

FLOTEKINDUSTRIESINCCN_05_09_2019-EX-10.1.summary:
This Supply Agreement, dated February 28, 2019, is between Florida Chemical Company, LLC ("FCC") and Flotek Chemistry, LLC ("Flotek").  FCC agrees to supply Flotek with citrus terpene product ("Terpene Product") meeting specified quality standards (Exhibit A).  The agreement runs until December 31, 2023, with a possible one-year extension.

Flotek provides non-binding quarterly forecasts, places purchase orders (Exhibit A), and arranges transportation (FOB Winter Haven, FL). FCC must confirm or reject orders within three days, fulfilling them unless exceeding pre-defined maximum quantities or exceeding quarterly forecasts by more than 25%.  FCC invoices upon shipment; payment is due within 60 days.  Minimum annual purchase quantities are stipulated.  The price is based on Terpene Cost plus a defined Margin.

FCC warrants product quality, compliance with regulations, and good title.  It indemnifies Flotek against third-party claims related to product defects and liability arising from FCC's operations, including providing $5,000,000 in liability insurance naming Flotek as an additional insured.  Both parties agree to environmental compliance and mutual indemnification for environmental liabilities.  The agreement includes provisions for inspection, audit, force majeure, confidentiality, and dispute resolution.  Either party may terminate for material breach (with a 30-day cure period) or bankruptcy.  Governing law is Delaware.  The agreement is the entire understanding of the parties.  Specific financial details (Margin, Maximum/Minimum Quantities) are redacted.

EUROPEANMICROHOLDINGSINC_03_06_1998-EX-1.summary:
This Distributor Agreement, dated November 5, 1997, is between WatchGuard Technologies, Inc. ("WGT"), a Delaware corporation, and European Micro ("Distributor").  The agreement appoints Distributor as a *non-exclusive* distributor of WatchGuard products (Hardware, Software, Documentation) in Europe.

Distributor's key obligations include aggressive sales development, maintaining inventory, marketing the product, providing reseller support (including a support center and training), maintaining sales records, and obtaining necessary import/export licenses.  WGT's obligations include providing 60-day discontinuation notice, training and support services, and promotional materials.

Distributor must meet Guaranteed Minimum Purchases (GMPs) outlined in Exhibit A, with a significant liquidated damages clause (50% of unpaid GMP balance) for failure to meet these targets.  Pricing is based on WGT's price list, subject to discounts in Exhibit A.  Distributor pays a yearly support fee ($25,000).

The initial term is until September 30, 1997, with automatic one-year renewals contingent on meeting GMPs and marketing requirements, and 30-day non-renewal notice.  WGT may terminate for Distributor's breach (30-day cure period), material changes in Distributor's management, insolvency, or sales outside the Territory. Distributor may terminate for WGT's breach (30-day cure period), WGT's insolvency, or for convenience (with a 50% of unpaid GMP balance payment).  Termination clauses detail consequences, including return of products and cessation of trademark use.  The agreement includes standard distributor terms (Exhibit B) addressing intellectual property rights

BizzingoInc_20120322_8-K_EX-10.17_750449.summary:
This Celebrity Endorsement Agreement, effective March 1, 2012, is between Bizzingo, Inc. (Bizzingo) and Joseph Theismann.  Bizzingo secures worldwide rights to use Theismann's name, likeness, etc. ("Property") to advertise its B2B interactive platform ("Network") for one year, renewable annually.

Bizzingo's key obligations include paying Theismann an initial bonus and quarterly royalties (detailed in Schedule A, based on "Activated Users" of the Network),  providing royalty statements, securing liability insurance naming Theismann as an additional insured, and obtaining prior approval for all uses of Theismann's Property.  Theismann must cooperate with Bizzingo's promotional efforts, including four 8-hour photo/media sessions and four 2-hour public appearances.  He agrees to not use his Property to promote competing networks for one year post-termination.

The agreement includes clauses for inspection of Bizzingo's records by Theismann,  mutual indemnification,  termination rights (by either party for cause or by Theismann with 30-day notice), and dispute resolution via arbitration.  Theismann retains all rights to his Property except as explicitly granted.  Financial arrangements involve a royalty of one common stock purchase warrant per Activated User per quarter and an initial bonus of warrants for 1,000,000 shares, all subject to restrictive legends.  Theismann acknowledges the investment risks involved.  The agreement is governed by a separate Confidentiality and Non-Disparagement Agreement.

KitovPharmaLtd_20190326_20-F_EX-4.15_115.summary:
This Product Manufacturing Agreement, dated March 26, 2019, is between DEXCEL Ltd. (Israel) and KITOV Pharma Ltd. (Israel).  The agreement governs the manufacturing and packaging of Kitov's Celecoxib/Amlodipine tablets ("Product") by Dexcel for Kitov.

Kitov grants Dexcel a limited, exclusive license to use its intellectual property for manufacturing.  Kitov is responsible for product specifications, regulatory approvals, and marketing; Dexcel for manufacturing, packaging (using materials supplied by Kitov), and quality control (per a separate Quality Agreement).  Kitov provides Dexcel with forecasts and purchase orders; Dexcel manufactures and delivers the product according to confirmed orders.  Supply prices are specified per pack size and strength, subject to annual adjustment. Payment terms are net 30 days from delivery.  A detailed product acceptance process is outlined, including provisions for shortfalls and defects.

The agreement has an initial term plus renewable terms, terminable for material breach, insolvency, or change of control.  Both parties provide warranties and indemnities regarding their respective responsibilities.  The agreement is governed by Israeli law, with exclusive jurisdiction in Tel Aviv courts.  Confidential information provisions are included, along with clauses regarding intellectual property rights and force majeure.

BellringBrandsInc_20190920_S-1_EX-10.12_.summary:
This Second Amendment, effective October 1, 2018, modifies a Manufacturing Agreement between Stremick's Heritage Foods, LLC ("Heritage") and Premier Nutrition Corporation ("Premier").  The amendment extends the agreement to December 31, 2021, after which the original agreement's terms revert, though enforcement rights survive.  The core purpose is for Heritage to manufacture products for Premier, now including aseptic plastic bottled products in addition to previously agreed-upon items (detailed in Schedules A, A-1, and C/C-1).

Heritage's key obligations include manufacturing products according to specifications (Schedules A & A-1), using materials purchased by Heritage (up to required amounts), and delivering them to Premier. Premier's main obligation is to order and pay for the manufactured products according to pricing and terms outlined in Schedules C and C-1.  The amendment significantly alters sections regarding production quantities, pricing, billing, and notification addresses.  Financial arrangements are detailed in the undisclosed Schedules C and C-1, which define pricing and payment terms for both product types.  The amendment specifically addresses the inclusion of aseptic plastic bottles as a new product line.

GOCALLINC_03_30_2000-EX-10.7-Promotion A.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, dated March 12, 1999, is between Go Call, Inc. (Canada) and PageMaster Corporation (California).  The agreement outlines a joint promotion to increase Go Call's sales and PageMaster's paging service contracts.  PageMaster will provide up to 500,000 Motorola pagers (or equivalent) free to customers purchasing 12 months of PageMaster's numeric paging service through MetroCall Inc. (airtime provider).  PageMaster is responsible for fulfillment, customer service, and establishing a toll-free number. Go Call will create and distribute advertising materials, subject to PageMaster's approval.

Go Call provides a $100,000 deposit, refundable at $1 per pager delivered (up to the deposit amount).  PageMaster pays Go Call $3 per pager plus 5% of airtime renewal revenue.  The promotion runs from June 1, 1999, to June 1, 2000, with a one-year extension contingent on distributing 3,000 pagers monthly.  The agreement includes mutual indemnity clauses, a detailed dispute resolution process (negotiation, then arbitration in Los Angeles), and a choice-of-law clause specifying California law and venue.  The agreement terminates automatically if not signed by March 26, 1999.  Both parties warrant against unauthorized use of trademarks and logos.  Confidentiality regarding exchanged information is also stipulated.

LEJUHOLDINGSLTD_03_12_2014-EX-10.34-INTE.summary:
This Internet Channel Cooperation Agreement (dated April 29, 2010), between Beijing Baidu Netcom Science and Technology Co., Ltd. (Party A), China Online Housing (Hong Kong) Co., Ltd. (Party B), and Beijing Yisheng Leju Information Services Co., Ltd. (Party C), establishes a four-year joint venture to create a real estate and home furnishing channel ("Baidu Leju") on Baidu's website (baidu.com).

Party B is solely responsible for constructing, operating, and maintaining Baidu Leju, including content, advertising, and user services.  Party A provides exclusive rights to use specified subdomains, promotional resources (RMB 10 million annually), and preferential keyword placement in Baidu search results.  Party C is jointly and severally liable with Party B.

Party B pays a total cooperation fee of RMB 200 million in four installments.  The agreement grants Party B exclusivity for real estate and home furnishing content on Baidu's platform during the term.  Confidentiality and dispute resolution clauses are included, with governing law being PRC law.  The agreement can be terminated by Party B with three months' notice before the four-year anniversary, requiring settlement of outstanding fees and transfer of channel operations to Party A.  Other termination events include breach, bankruptcy, and mutual agreement.

BLACKSTONEGSOLONG-SHORTCREDITINCOMEFUND_.summary:
This Service Agreement, dated January 26, 2011, governs transfer agent services between Blackstone/GSO Long-Short Credit Income Fund (Client), a Delaware statutory trust, and Mellon Investor Services LLC (Agent), a New Jersey limited liability company.  The agreement appoints the Agent as the Client's transfer agent, registrar, and dividend disbursing agent for all authorized shares (Exhibit A).

The Agent's key obligations (Exhibit B) include account maintenance, security issuance, dividend disbursement, escheatment services, proxy and annual meeting services, and web services.  The Client warrants its legal existence and the validity of its shares (Section 4), while the Agent warrants its registration as a transfer agent (Section 5).  The Agent acts solely as the Client's agent (Section 6).

The agreement includes indemnification and limitation of liability clauses favoring the Agent (Sections 7 & 8),  a force majeure clause (Section 9), and confidentiality provisions (Section 13).  The initial term is three years, automatically renewing for successive three-year terms unless terminated with 60 days' written notice (Section 2).  Termination may also occur due to material breach by either party (Section 11), with significant termination fees payable by the Client (Section 11(c)).  Compensation is detailed in Exhibit B, including monthly administrative fees and reimbursement for expenses.  Late payment penalties apply (Section 16).  New York law governs (Section 19).  Jurisdiction is in New York courts (Section 18).

PHLVARIABLEINSURANCECOCT_08_17_2009-EX-1.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, effective upon SEC registration statement effectiveness, involves PHL Variable Insurance Company (PHLVIC & PLIC), Phoenix Equity Planning Corporation (PEPCO), and Investors Capital Corporation (ICC).  The agreement governs the sale of PHLVIC's Group Indexed Annuity (GIE) by ICC to its customers.

Key obligations include PHL Variable's responsibility to administer the GIE and provide administrative services (detailed in Exhibit A), and ICC's obligation to market and sell the GIE, provide administrative services (Exhibit B), and comply with regulatory requirements.  Both parties make representations and warranties regarding their organizational status, legal compliance, and the accuracy of information in the registration statement.  Significant intellectual property licensing provisions (Section 9, Exhibit C) govern the use of each party's trademarks.  A detailed indemnification clause (Section 12) allocates liability between the parties.

The agreement's duration is tied to the existence of GIE certificates, with termination provisions (Section 15) allowing for termination by either party with 120 days' notice or immediately for material breach or insolvency.  No direct financial compensation is exchanged between PHL Variable and ICC; however, ICC benefits from GIE sales.  The agreement is governed by Connecticut law and disputes are resolved through arbitration (Section 14).

MEETGROUP,INC_06_29_2017-EX-10.1-COOPERA.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated June 27, 2017, is between The Meet Group, Inc. ("Company") and Harvest Capital Strategies LLC and its affiliates (collectively, "Investors"), who beneficially own approximately 6.3% of the Company's outstanding stock.  The agreement's main purpose is to address board composition and investor relations.

Key obligations include the Company appointing two new independent directors (New Director A and B) to its board, with New Director A appointed immediately and New Director B within 90 days.  Investors agree to a standstill period until the 2018 Annual Meeting, during which they commit to voting in accordance with the Board's recommendations (except for certain defined "Opposition Matters" and as modified by ISS recommendations).  The Investors also agree to a mutual non-disparagement clause.  Both parties are responsible for their own expenses.

Important terms include definitions of "Affiliate," "Associate," "beneficial owner," "economic owner," and "Related Person," all consistent with SEC regulations.  A "Change of Control" triggers automatic termination of Sections 1, 2, and 3, provided the acquiring party doesn't condition the closing on such termination.  The Standstill Period lasts until the 2018 Annual Meeting's vote certification.  The agreement includes representations and warranties from both parties regarding their authority and the agreement's validity.  Specific performance is stipulated as a remedy for breach.  Delaware law governs the agreement, with Delaware courts having exclusive jurisdiction.  The agreement is the complete understanding between the parties and cannot be amended except in writing signed by all parties.  No third-party beneficiaries are created.

GluMobileInc_20070319_S-1A_EX-10.09_4366.summary:
This Amendment No. 2, dated March 27, 2006, modifies a pre-existing Wireless Content License Agreement between Glu Mobile, Inc. (formerly Sorrent, Inc.) ("Licensee") and Fox Mobile Entertainment, Inc. ("Fox"), acting for Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation.  The amendment grants Glu Mobile a limited, non-exclusive license to distribute "Ice Age: The Meltdown" (IA2) audio and video wireless products in the US and internationally.

Glu Mobile's key obligation is to pay Fox a royalty (percentage redacted) of its gross receipts from sales of these IA2 products.  The royalty calculation excludes any revenues Fox earns through direct-to-consumer distribution.  Specific product grants include voicetones and videos, with differing quantities for US and international distribution.  Accounting for payments from various carriers mirrors the original agreement.  The amendment does not alter the original agreement except as explicitly stated.  The duration is not explicitly stated but is tied to the underlying agreement's terms.  No termination clause is detailed in this amendment.  The financial arrangement centers on a royalty payment based on a percentage of Glu Mobile's gross receipts from the licensed products.

ADAPTIMMUNETHERAPEUTICSPLC_04_06_2017-EX.summary:
This Strategic Collaboration Agreement, effective September 23, 2016, is between The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center ("MD Anderson") and Adaptimmune LLC and Adaptimmune Limited ("Adaptimmune").  The agreement establishes a strategic alliance for preclinical and clinical studies of Adaptimmune's T-cell therapies.

**Purpose:**  To conduct jointly funded studies using Adaptimmune's SPEAR technology platform. Adaptimmune sponsors the clinical studies; MD Anderson conducts them.

**Key Obligations:** Adaptimmune provides funding (at least $19,644,000), Study Drug, and support services. MD Anderson provides personnel, facilities, and conducts studies according to protocols, adhering to GCP, IRB, and applicable laws.  Both parties are obligated to maintain confidentiality and comply with all applicable regulations, including HIPAA.  A Joint Steering Committee (JSC) oversees the alliance.

**Important Terms:**  Intellectual property rights are allocated based on inventorship; Adaptimmune receives a broad license to MD Anderson inventions.  MD Anderson retains ownership of its records and has publication rights subject to Adaptimmune's review and potential delay for patent filings.  Both parties have indemnification obligations.

**Financial Arrangements:** Adaptimmune commits at least $19,644,000, payable according to a schedule in Exhibit II, contingent upon milestone achievement.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement lasts five years or until study completion, whichever is later.  Either party may terminate for material breach (30-day cure period).  Study Orders may be terminated for various reasons, including safety concerns or regulatory issues.  MD Anderson has a limited

ENTRUSTINC_07_24_1998-EX-10.5-STRATEGIC.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated December 31, 1996, is between Northern Telecom Limited ("NTL"), a Canadian corporation, and Entrust Technologies Inc. ("ETI"), a Maryland corporation.  The agreement stems from an asset transfer of Entrust Technology from NTL to ETI.  Its main purpose is to establish a cross-licensing arrangement for intellectual property related to Entrust Technology and to govern the parties' ongoing relationship.

Key obligations include reciprocal, non-exclusive, royalty-free patent licenses (Article VI), with limitations on liability for pre-existing defects and third-party claims.  NTL receives a perpetual license to use Entrust Products (Article III), potentially expanding to reseller (Article IV) and source code access (Article V) rights under separate agreements.  ETI is obligated to comply with NTL's technology licenses and pay a portion of associated fees (Article II).  Both parties agree to information exchange (Article VIII) with confidentiality provisions.  Financial arrangements include a $300,000 annual support fee for 1997 and beyond (Article III), subject to inflation adjustments.  Liability is capped at $5,000,000, except for breaches of Article II ($10,000,000).

The agreement's duration is tied to ETI's status as an NTL subsidiary, terminating three years after the Effective Date or upon ETI ceasing to be a subsidiary (Article X).  Termination for material breach allows a 60-day cure period.  Surviving provisions include intellectual property licenses and confidentiality clauses.  Governing law is Ontario, Canada, with jury trial waived.  Assignment of rights requires

SYKESHEALTHPLANSERVICESINC_04_24_1998-EX.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated January 1, 1998, is between Sykes HealthPlan Services, Inc. ("SHPS") and HealthPlan Services, Inc. ("HPS"), both Florida corporations.  The agreement outlines the outsourcing of Care Management Services (CMS) by HPS to SHPS.  SHPS becomes the exclusive provider of CMS to HPS's existing and new clients.  

SHPS's key obligations include providing CMS, defined as utilization review, case management, and disease management services, directly to clients according to existing client agreements. HPS is responsible for paying SHPS based on a tiered percentage of Care Management Revenues (82.5% of the first $500,000, then 80% of the excess).  Revenue calculation is based on per-employee-per-month fees, with new client rates subject to mutual agreement.  Cost allocation for facility use and certain expenses is also detailed.  HPS retains audit rights.

The initial term is one year (1998), automatically renewing annually unless either party provides 90-day notice.  Termination for cause is permitted for material breaches not cured within 30 days.  The agreement includes standard clauses on indemnification, confidentiality, assignment restrictions, and governing law (Florida).  Both parties are independent contractors.

NATIONALPROCESSINGINC_07_18_1996-EX-10.4.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, effective June 30, 1996, is between National Processing Company ("NPC") and National City Bank of Kentucky ("NCB").  It's an agency agreement where NPC acts as NCB's sole agent for providing merchant processing, settlement, and authorization services for Visa and MasterCard transactions.

NPC's key obligations include performing all merchant processing services, complying with Visa/MasterCard rules, and managing all credit and fraud risks associated with merchant contracts. NCB appoints Joint Officers from NPC with authority to represent NCB in matters related to merchant processing.

NCB's responsibilities include providing banking services to facilitate NPC's operations, making timely payments to merchants and NPC based on Payment Instructions from NPC, and conducting due diligence on NPC's credit and pricing standards.  NPC receives all merchant fees, but reimburses NCB for certain expenses and fees.  NPC indemnifies NCB for losses arising from NPC's breaches or Joint Officer actions.

The agreement has a five-year term, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  Termination clauses include mutual agreement, breach (with cure period), bankruptcy, or material impairment of NCB's Visa/MasterCard relationship.  Sections regarding indemnification, expense reimbursement, and confidentiality survive termination.  The agreement is governed by US and Kentucky law.  NCB retains the right to monitor NPC's compliance.

MFAFINANCIAL,INC_07_06_2020-EX-99.D-JOIN.summary: This Joint Filing Agreement, dated July 6, 2020, governs the joint filing of a Schedule 13D statement and subsequent amendments by multiple parties regarding securities of MFA Financial, Inc.  The agreement involves numerous entities, primarily Athene-affiliated companies (Athene Annuity & Life Company, Athene Annuity & Life Assurance Company, Athene USA Corporation, Athene Life Re Ltd., Athene Holding Ltd.) and Apollo-affiliated entities (Apollo Insurance Solutions Group LP, AISG GP Ltd., Apollo Life Asset, L.P., Apollo Life Asset GP, LLC, etc.).  The core obligation is the joint filing of the Schedule 13D, representing a unified reporting of their collective holdings in MFA Financial, Inc.  The agreement specifies that it can be executed in counterparts, each considered an original.  No specific duration, termination clause, or financial arrangements are detailed within the provided text; the agreement solely focuses on the joint filing requirement under Rule 13d-1(k) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  The agreement's purpose is purely procedural, facilitating compliance with securities regulations.

SimplicityEsportsGamingCompany_20181130_.summary:
This Master Franchise Agreement, dated November 20, 2018, is between Smaaash Entertainment Private Limited (India) ("Franchisor") and I-AM Capital Acquisition Company (USA) ("Franchisee").  It grants Franchisee exclusive rights to establish and operate "Smaaash Centres" (virtual reality/sports simulation entertainment centers) and sub-franchise in North and South America.

Franchisee's key obligations include establishing at least six Smaaash Centres within the first contract year, adhering to Franchisor's operational standards, and actively marketing the centers.  Franchisee receives revenue from each center, plus a 5% sign-on fee and 5% annual commission from sub-franchisees.  Franchisor retains ownership of all intellectual property and grants a royalty-free license to Franchisee for use within the defined territory.  Franchisor retains the right to operate outside the territory.

The agreement includes provisions for Franchisor's approval on location selection, pricing, marketing materials, and sub-franchisees.  Termination can occur by mutual agreement, by Franchisor with 30-day notice for breaches (non-payment, abandonment, marketing failure), or by either party for cause (material breach, insolvency).  Upon termination, all rights revert to Franchisor.  Governing law is New York State law, with jurisdiction in New York courts; jury trial is waived.  The agreement is comprehensive and includes standard clauses on confidentiality, indemnification, force majeure, and assignment.

QIWI_06_16_2017-EX-99.(D)(2)-COOPERATION.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated June 2, 2015, is between Otkritie Investments Cyprus Limited ("OICL") and QIWI plc ("QIWI").  It's a strategic cooperation agreement stemming from a prior share subscription agreement where OICL acquired QIWI shares, and QIWI acquired CIHRUS (parent company of NKO Rapida).  The main purpose is to foster cooperation in digital payments and related areas.

Key obligations include forming a Steering Committee (six members, three from each party) to explore joint projects (e.g., banking partnerships, data sharing, settlement banking for NKO Rapida, prepaid cards).  QIWI commits to routing at least half of Contact money transfer system transactions through Otkritie's bank for two years post-completion, with a termination fee capped at RUB 50,000,000.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality provisions.

Important terms include definitions of "Affiliate," "Confidential Information," and detailed dispute resolution via arbitration under the LCIA Rules in London, governed by English law.  The agreement lasts for five years or until OICL's QIWI shareholding falls below 2,237,216 Class B shares, with certain clauses surviving termination.  No financial arrangements beyond the settlement banking obligation and potential future commercial agreements arising from Steering Committee discussions are explicitly detailed.

RemarkHoldingsInc_20081114_10-Q_EX-10.24.summary:
This Content License Agreement, effective September 17, 2008, is between World Book, Inc. (World Book) and HSW International, Inc. (HSWI).  It grants HSWI a perpetual, irrevocable, limited license to use World Book's content (including reference content, images, and "Affinities"—articles organized by subject) on its websites and in promotions.  HSWI's use is restricted; it cannot resell or license substantially all the content, display it as an "encyclopedia," or use the World Book brand for promotion (except as specified).  HSWI can sublicense for non-commercial, private use and limited business development purposes, subject to restrictions and a list of excluded competitors.

World Book's key obligations include creating and delivering the Affinities, providing updating services (subject to limitations), and maintaining ownership of its intellectual property. HSWI's main obligations are payment of royalties (calculated as a percentage of net revenue from advertising generated by the content), subject to a schedule of non-refundable advances and a buy-out option.  Royalties are due only if they exceed the advances.  HSWI must maintain accurate records for audit purposes.

The agreement has a defined delivery period, but certain licenses are perpetual.  Termination can occur for material breach (after a 60-day cure period) or bankruptcy.  Upon termination, HSWI must cease display of non-perpetually licensed content and return or destroy it.  The agreement includes standard confidentiality, indemnification, limitation of liability, and dispute resolution (arbitration) clauses.  Governing law is New York.  Significant portions of the contract,

CnsPharmaceuticalsInc_20200326_8-K_EX-10.summary:
This Development Agreement, dated March 20, 2020, is between CNS Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (a Nevada corporation) and WPD Pharmaceuticals (a Polish corporation).  The agreement concerns the development and commercialization of antiviral pharmaceutical drug products.  WPD, under a sublicense with Moleculin Biotech, Inc., is responsible for development, using commercially reasonable efforts, aiming for approval in the defined territory.  CNS will fund this development.

CNS's obligations include an upfront payment of $225,000 and a further $775,000 upon completion of a Phase II milestone.  WPD will pay CNS a Development Fee, 50% of Net Sales (defined similarly to the Sublicense Agreement) in the Development Territory (initially the Sublicensed Territory, excluding Poland after the Approval Achievement Date).  The Approval Achievement Date is the earlier of marketing approval in half the Sublicensed Territory or WPD's $1 million payment to CNS.

The agreement includes provisions for quarterly progress reports, mutual data exchange, confidentiality (5 years post-termination), and indemnification of CNS by WPD for certain liabilities.  WPD warrants compliance with the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.  The agreement lasts until the Sublicense Agreement expires, unless terminated earlier for material breach (30-day cure period) or mutual agreement.  If WPD fails to use commercially reasonable efforts after three years, CNS can terminate and reclaim payments.  Texas law governs, with Houston, Texas as the designated jurisdiction.

GluMobileInc_20070319_S-1A_EX-10.09_4366.summary:
This Amendment No. 1, dated November 11, 2005, modifies a Wireless Content License Agreement between Glu Mobile, Inc. (formerly Sorrent, Inc.) ("Licensee") and Fox Mobile Entertainment, Inc. ("Fox"), replacing Twentieth Century Fox Licensing & Merchandising.  The amendment concerns the licensing of intellectual property rights for the development and distribution of mobile games and content based on Fox's films ("In Her Shoes," "Idiocracy," "Ice Age 2," "Kingdom of Heaven").

Licensee's key obligations include developing specified wireless products (games, applications, etc.) for each film, adhering to exclusivity periods where applicable, and paying royalties to Fox based on gross receipts, with percentages redacted.  A significant financial component involves a guarantee forfeiture payment by Licensee, partially recoupable through sales of certain products, and additional minimum guarantees for specific titles.  Fox retains rights to distribute products through its own channels, receiving a distribution fee.  Fox retains ownership of music used in the products.

The amendment includes specific royalty rates (redacted), minimum guarantees (redacted), and a distribution fee (redacted) for Fox's direct-to-consumer distribution.  The agreement's duration is not explicitly defined in this amendment but is subject to the original agreement's terms.  The amendment includes a mutual release clause, except for ongoing royalty obligations and those specifically outlined within the amendment.  The amendment significantly alters the financial terms and product scope of the original agreement.

PROFOUNDMEDICALCORP_08_29_2019-EX-4.5-SU.summary:
This Supply Agreement, dated July 31, 2017, is between Profound Medical Inc. (Customer) and Philips Medical Systems Nederland B.V. (Philips).  It's a temporary contract manufacturing agreement where Philips supplies Sonalleve MR-guided HIFU devices to Profound Medical until Profound can transition manufacturing in-house.

Philips' key obligations include manufacturing and supplying products according to Purchase Orders (subject to a Production Plan and Forecasts provided by Profound), adhering to specifications (Schedule 1), and ensuring product quality (governed by a separate Quality Agreement).  Profound's main obligations are to provide timely Forecasts, place Purchase Orders within lead times (Schedule 2), and accept delivery.  Profound assumes all liabilities as the legal manufacturer from the Effective Date, cooperating with Philips in transferring regulatory approvals.

Pricing is detailed in Schedule 1, payable in Euros within specified terms (redacted).  The agreement includes detailed warranty provisions (redacted duration) and indemnification clauses (redacted specifics).  Intellectual Property Rights are addressed, with Philips granting a non-exclusive license to use Profound's IP for manufacturing, and Profound owning any "New Technology" developed.  Confidentiality obligations are stipulated.

The agreement's term is [redacted], terminable by Profound with six months' notice or by Philips for non-compliance with regulatory transfer timelines (clause 2.3).  Other termination grounds include bankruptcy, material breach, and certain events (redacted).  A transition plan (Schedule 5) is to be negotiated for the transfer of manufacturing activities.  Governing law is Netherlands law, excluding the CISG.  Dispute resolution is per the related Asset and Share Purchase

TRICITYBANKSHARESCORP_05_15_1998-EX-10-O.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated February 16, 1998, is between Tri City National Bank ("Customer") and Marshall & Ilsley Corporation ("M&I"), acting through M&I Data Services.  The agreement outsources Tri City's data processing and other IT services to M&I.

M&I's key obligations include providing various banking application processing services (detailed in Schedule 6.2), adhering to performance standards (Article 9), and maintaining a disaster recovery plan (Article 20).  Tri City is responsible for providing accurate data, following proper instruction procedures (Section 3.3), and paying fees as outlined in Schedule 8.1.  The agreement includes provisions for conversion of Tri City's systems to M&I's (Article 4),  detailed service level agreements, and indemnification clauses (Article 14).

The initial term is eight years from the Commencement Date (anticipated November 16, 1998), with renewal options (Article 2).  Termination can occur for convenience (Article 11.1, with significant fees), for cause (Article 11.2), or following a change in control (Article 11.3).  Financial arrangements include a fee structure detailed in Schedule 8.1, covering one-time conversion fees, monthly base fees, and usage-based charges.  Significant liquidated damages are stipulated for early termination (Articles 11.1, 11.2).  The agreement specifies Wisconsin law as governing law and Milwaukee County, Wisconsin as the venue.  Source code escrow arrangements are also included (Article 23).

BLUEHILLSBANCORP,INC_05_20_2014-EX-1.1-A.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated May 14, 2014, governs the relationship between Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc. ("Agent") and Blue Hills Bancorp, Inc., Hyde Park Bancorp, MHC, Hyde Park Bancorp, Inc., and Blue Hills Bank (collectively, "Blue Hills Parties").  The agreement concerns the conversion of Hyde Park Bancorp, MHC from a mutual to a stock holding company and the subsequent offering and sale of up to 27,772,500 shares of Blue Hills Bancorp, Inc. common stock.

The Agent's key obligations include acting as exclusive financial advisor and conversion agent, utilizing best efforts to solicit subscriptions, and potentially acting as sole book-running manager in an underwritten offering.  Blue Hills Parties warrant the accuracy of the registration statement and prospectus, comply with all applicable regulations, and indemnify the Agent against liabilities arising from untrue statements or omissions.

The Agent's compensation includes a $50,000 management fee, a success fee of 0.85% of the shares sold (excluding insider purchases), and additional fees for a syndicated or underwritten offering (up to 5.25%).  Expense reimbursement is also provided for.

The agreement terminates upon completion of the offering, no later than 45 days after the subscription offering, unless extended.  Termination also occurs if fewer than 17,850,000 shares are sold, requiring refunds to subscribers.  The agreement includes detailed indemnification and contribution clauses allocating liability between the parties.  New York law governs.

GarrettMotionInc_20181001_8-K_EX-2.4_113.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated September 27, 2018, is between Honeywell International Inc. ("Honeywell") and Garrett Motion Inc. ("SpinCo"),  in connection with SpinCo's spin-off from Honeywell.  The IPA governs the allocation and licensing of intellectual property (IP) rights between the parties following the separation.

The main purpose is to clarify IP ownership and grant cross-licenses for shared IP used by both entities prior to the spin-off.  Honeywell and SpinCo grant each other non-exclusive, royalty-free, perpetual licenses to use certain shared IP (excluding trademarks and certain confidential materials) for purposes consistent with their pre-separation business.  Additional licenses for new projects can be negotiated, with a right to challenge IP validity if negotiations fail.  Both parties agree not to initiate infringement actions against each other for a five-year period regarding IP used in the pre-separation business.  Each party is responsible for policing its own IP.  Specific provisions address confidential information, including Honeywell Content, licensed for 10 years with limitations on transfer.

The agreement includes detailed definitions of various IP rights (patents, trademarks, copyrights, etc.), and requires execution of formal IP assignment agreements for recordation.  The IPA contains standard clauses on limitation of liability (excluding consequential damages), warranty disclaimers, assignment restrictions (with exceptions for mergers and acquisitions), and dispute resolution (New York law and jurisdiction, waiver of jury trial).  The agreement may be terminated by mutual written agreement or by Honeywell prior to the distribution date, subject to the Separation Agreement.  Financial arrangements primarily relate to the allocation of pre- and post-distribution expenses.

TheglobeComInc_19990503_S-1A_EX-10.20_54.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective March 1999, is between theglobe.com, Inc. ("theglobe") and The Boxlot Company ("Boxlot").  The agreement establishes a co-branded online person-to-person auction service (the "Service") hosted on auctions.theglobe.com.

**Key Obligations:** theglobe controls advertising and branding on the Co-Branded Pages, providing Boxlot with ad serving code. Boxlot develops and operates the Service, provides customer support, and delivers user data to theglobe.  Both parties grant each other non-exclusive licenses to use their respective trademarks and content.  Boxlot is responsible for complying with all applicable laws and regulations.

**Important Terms:**  theglobe retains control over the Service's look and feel.  Boxlot must maintain service availability and response time standards (detailed in Exhibit B).  Both parties have indemnity obligations.  Liability is limited, excluding payment and indemnity claims.  User data usage is restricted to prevent user targeting based on their status as users of either platform.

**Financial Arrangements:**  Boxlot pays theglobe placement fees (schedule in Exhibit A), and theglobe shares Net Revenues with Boxlot.  Boxlot also retains a portion of transaction revenues.  theglobe has audit rights.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement lasts for two years after the Launch Date.  Either party may terminate for material breach (15-day cure period), Boxlot content non-compliance (12-hour cure period),  Boxlot's failure to comply with laws, or certain ownership changes at Boxlot (specified companies).  theglobe may also terminate based on Boxlot's business model changes

EmbarkComInc_19991008_S-1A_EX-10.10_6487.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, dated June 8, 1999, is between Snap Technologies, Inc. ("Snap") and United Airlines, Inc. ("Sponsor").  The agreement establishes a co-branding relationship to promote Snap's college-related website (collegedge.com) and United Airlines' travel services.

Snap's key obligations include creating co-branded web pages featuring both parties' branding and content, providing user data for marketing purposes (subject to user agreements), and generally promoting United Airlines.  United Airlines' obligations include providing content for the co-branded pages, promoting Snap's website, and making specified financial payments.  These payments include an upfront fee and quarterly fees (specific amounts redacted).  United Airlines also commits to providing advertising placements and travel awards for Snap's promotional use.

Key terms define intellectual property rights usage, exclusivity within the "travel services" category for Snap, and confidentiality provisions.  Both parties grant each other non-exclusive licenses to use each other's trademarks and content within specified parameters.

The agreement runs from June 8, 1999, to December 31, 2000, unless terminated earlier for breach by either party (with 60 days' notice) or certain events like bankruptcy.  Upon termination, certain provisions (confidentiality, indemnity, ownership) survive.  A right of first refusal is granted to United Airlines for similar sponsorship rights after the initial term, provided there is no material breach by United Airlines.  The agreement is governed by California law, with jurisdiction in San Francisco courts.  Liability is limited, excluding consequential damages.

HC2HOLDINGS,INC_05_14_2020-EX-10.1-COOPE.summary:
This Cooperation Agreement, dated May 13, 2020, is between HC2 Holdings, Inc. ("HC2") and MG Capital Management Ltd., Percy Rockdale LLC, and Rio Royal LLC (collectively, "MG Capital Parties").  The agreement resolves a proxy contest regarding the composition of HC2's Board of Directors.

The main purpose is to settle the dispute by appointing four new directors (two MG Capital designees and two previously nominated by HC2) to the Board, with Avram Glazer becoming Chairman.  MG Capital Parties withdraw their nomination notice and consent solicitation.

Key obligations include: MG Capital Parties' agreement to vote in accordance with the Board's recommendations at the 2020 Annual Meeting (with exceptions for say-on-pay if ISS and Glass Lewis recommend otherwise); HC2's commitment to nominate the agreed-upon slate of seven directors for the 2020 Annual Meeting; and a standstill agreement preventing MG Capital Parties from certain actions for a defined period.

Important terms include a standstill period lasting until 30 days before the 2021 Annual Meeting's nomination deadline,  mutual non-disparagement, and specific performance clauses.  HC2 reimburses MG Capital Parties' expenses up to $650,000.

The agreement terminates upon the conclusion of the standstill period or upon a material breach uncured after 10 days' notice.  Sections regarding notices, expenses, and governing law survive termination.  Delaware law governs the agreement, with exclusive venue in the Delaware Court of Chancery.

TRANSMONTAIGNEPARTNERSLLC_03_13_2020-EX-.summary:
This Services Agreement, effective August 2019, is between TransMontaigne Management Company, LLC ("EmployeeCo") and TLP Management Services, LLC ("Operating Company"), both Delaware LLCs.  EmployeeCo provides management, operational, and administrative services to the Operating Company and its affiliates ("Services").

EmployeeCo's key obligation is providing the Services.  The Operating Company's main obligation is to reimburse EmployeeCo for all direct and indirect costs associated with providing the Services, including employee salaries, benefits, and taxes.  Additionally, the Operating Company pays EmployeeCo a 1% fee on the total reimbursements.  Financial settlements follow the Parties' normal inter-affiliate processes.

The agreement is governed by Colorado law, with jurisdiction in Colorado courts.  It may be terminated by mutual written agreement or with 5 days' written notice by either party.  Payment obligations survive termination.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties, and amendments require written consent from both parties.  Assignment of rights or obligations requires consent, except for collateral assignments to secure financing.  Severability and further assurances clauses are included.

COOLTECHNOLOGIES,INC_10_25_2017-EX-10.71.summary:
This Strategic Alliance Agreement, dated May 26, 2017, is between Cool Technologies Inc. ("COOL TECH," Nevada) and Veteran Technology Group, LLC ("VET TECH," Missouri).  The agreement establishes a strategic alliance for marketing and performing complementary business consulting services.

COOL TECH will market and provide its "COOL TECH Services" (including its Mobile Generation Program) to clients referred by VET TECH,  billing either directly or through VET TECH at pre-agreed rates, adhering to FAR guidelines for government sales.  VET TECH will similarly market and provide its "VET TECH Services" (including GAIT Software and AI services), billing clients directly or through COOL TECH under pre-agreed terms.  Both parties must reference the other in contracts and proposals involving the respective services.  Intellectual property rights remain with the originating party.

The agreement includes a non-disclosure agreement (Exhibit A), explicitly denies a partnership or joint venture, and outlines indemnification clauses for negligence or willful misconduct.  Non-solicitation of each other's personnel is also included for the agreement's duration and six months thereafter.

The agreement lasts for five years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  Early termination is possible via mutual agreement or 60 days' written notice.  Financial arrangements involve pre-agreed fees for services, with billing methods varying depending on client relationships and government contracts.  Missouri law governs the agreement.

Monsanto Company - SECOND A_R EXCLUSIVE.contract_id: Monsanto Company - SECOND A_R EXCLUSIVE AGENCY AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
Monsanto Company - SECOND A_R EXCLUSIVE.contract_title: Monsanto Company - SECOND A_R EXCLUSIVE AGENCY AND MARKETING AGREEMENT
Monsanto Company - SECOND A_R EXCLUSIVE.summary:
This Second Amended and Restated Exclusive Agency and Marketing Agreement, effective September 30, 1998 (amended August 31, 2017), governs the relationship between Monsanto Company ("Monsanto") and The Scotts Company LLC ("Scotts").  The agreement establishes Scotts as Monsanto's exclusive agent for marketing and distributing Roundup Products (defined broadly to include existing and future products) within specified markets (primarily North America, with potential expansion clauses).

Scotts' key obligations include sales, merchandising, warehousing, order processing, and customer service for Roundup Products, guided by an annually approved business plan.  Monsanto's responsibilities encompass R&D, regulatory compliance, and medical response.  Both parties have detailed reporting obligations.

Crucial terms include definitions of "Roundup Products," "Included Markets," and various financial metrics.  The agreement outlines a complex commission structure based on Program EBIT, including a tiered commission rate and a fixed contribution from Scotts.  It also addresses termination scenarios, including Monsanto's right to terminate for Scotts' material breach, fraud, or willful misconduct, and Scotts' right to terminate for Monsanto's material breach, fraud, or willful misconduct, or upon a Roundup Sale.  A substantial termination fee is payable under certain circumstances.  Dispute resolution is primarily through arbitration.  The agreement includes non-competition clauses for both parties and detailed provisions regarding intellectual property rights.  The agreement's duration is ongoing unless terminated according to the specified provisions.

ALLIANCEBANCORPINCOFPENNSYLVANIA_10_18_2.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated November 2006, governs the sale of up to 2,812,006 shares of common stock (the "Securities") by Alliance Bancorp, Inc. of Pennsylvania ("Company"), a federal stock holding company in formation, and related entities (Greater Delaware Valley Holdings, Alliance Mutual Holding Company, and Greater Delaware Valley Savings Bank d/b/a Alliance Bank) to Sandler O'Neill & Partners, L.P. ("Sandler O'Neill").  The sale involves a complex reorganization, including a mutual-to-stock conversion.

Sandler O'Neill acts as agent, assisting with the sale through subscription, community, and potentially syndicated and public offerings.  The Company provides extensive representations and warranties regarding its financial condition, regulatory compliance, and the accuracy of offering documents.  Sandler O'Neill's obligations are conditional upon these representations and warranties remaining true.

Sandler O'Neill's responsibilities include consulting, marketing, and assisting with investor relations.  Compensation includes a percentage of the sale proceeds (1% for Subscription and Community Offerings, up to 6% for Syndicated Community Offerings, plus a management fee).  Expenses are shared.  Sandler O'Neill receives the first right of refusal for a potential public offering.

The agreement terminates 45 days after the Subscription and Community Offering (unless extended), upon sale of all Securities, or completion of the Syndicated Community Offering.  Termination clauses exist for material adverse changes, non-fulfillment of conditions precedent, and failure to meet minimum sale targets.  Extensive indemnification and contribution provisions protect both parties.  The agreement is governed by New York law.

XpresspaGroupInc_20190401_10-K_EX-10.28_.summary:
This Product Sale and Marketing Agreement, effective November 12, 2018, is between Calm.com, Inc. ("Calm") and XpresSpa Group, Inc. ("XSPA").  The agreement governs the sale and marketing of Calm's branded products in XSPA's airport stores ("Stores") within the United States.

XSPA is obligated to display, market, and sell Calm's products at a pre-agreed retail price, with a right for Calm to add up to five more products.  XSPA agrees to exclusivity for digital meditation/sleep products for six months post-termination. Calm has a right of first refusal for expansion outside the initial territory.  XSPA must meet specific marketing and display requirements (signage, co-branded materials, etc.).  Both parties commit to joint marketing efforts.

Calm is the sole supplier of product collateral.  Financial terms include XSPA paying Calm 50% of the retail price (less commissions) for products sold, and Calm paying XSPA a commission for digital subscriptions generated through in-store promotions.  Detailed audit and dispute resolution procedures are included.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification for specific liabilities.

The initial term is until July 31, 2019, automatically renewing for six-month terms unless terminated with 30 days' notice.  Termination can also occur due to material breach, insolvency, or failure by Calm to meet a specific financial obligation.  Sections regarding intellectual property rights, confidentiality, and dispute resolution (arbitration in New York) survive termination.  Liability is capped at $2,000,000 per party (excluding payments under Section 8).

ElPolloLocoHoldingsInc_20200306_10-K_EX-.summary:
This Franchise Development Agreement (FDA) is between El Pollo Loco, Inc. ("El Pollo Loco" or "Franchisor") and a Developer.  The FDA grants the Developer (non-exclusive or exclusive) rights to develop a specified number of El Pollo Loco restaurants within a defined territory (Exhibit A).  The Developer's key obligations include meeting a development schedule (Exhibit B), securing approved sites (subject to El Pollo Loco's Real Estate Site Approval Committee), executing individual Franchise Agreements for each restaurant, and adhering to El Pollo Loco's operational standards.  El Pollo Loco retains proprietary rights to its trademarks and system.

The Developer pays a non-refundable development fee ($20,000 per restaurant, with subsequent fees reduced) applied against the franchise fee.  The FDA includes covenants not to compete, indemnification clauses heavily favoring El Pollo Loco, and detailed insurance requirements.  The agreement's term (Exhibit B) ends upon the opening of the last scheduled restaurant or an earlier termination date.  Termination can occur due to Developer's default (missed deadlines, breaches, insolvency), with El Pollo Loco retaining all development rights and fees.  Dispute resolution involves negotiation and mediation, except for certain fee disputes or intellectual property issues.  Applicable law is the state where El Pollo Loco's headquarters are located (currently California), with a waiver of jury trial.

BellringBrandsInc_20190920_S-1_EX-10.12_.summary: Amendment No. 1, dated June 11, 2018, amends a Manufacturing Agreement between Stremick's Heritage Foods, LLC ("Heritage") and Premier Nutrition Corporation ("Premier").  The amendment primarily revises the minimum purchase requirement for Premier.  Premier is obligated to purchase a specified Minimum Annual Order Volume (MAOV) of units from Heritage for defined contract periods, starting July 1, 2018, with the volume contingent upon Heritage's facility approval by Premier.  The MAOV varies by contract period, with specific quantities redacted.  All other terms of the original July 1, 2017, Manufacturing Agreement remain in effect unless otherwise specified in this amendment.  The amendment doesn't detail the original agreement's duration or termination clauses, nor does it specify pricing or other financial arrangements beyond the MAOV.  The amendment is signed by the Presidents of both companies.  The specific quantities of the MAOV are redacted in the provided text.

IdeanomicsInc_20160330_10-K_EX-10.26_951.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated December 21, 2015, is between Beijing Sun Seven Stars Culture Development Limited ("Licensor") and You On Demand Holdings, Inc. ("Licensee").  It grants Licensee a non-exclusive, royalty-free license (with specified limitations detailed in Schedule A) to exploit certain video programming ("Titles") in mainland China via VOD platforms for 20 years.  Licensee's consideration is the issuance of IP Common Shares as defined in a separate securities purchase agreement.

Licensor's key obligations include delivering Titles and promotional materials, providing customer service assistance, and ensuring all necessary rights clearances.  Licensee's main obligations are to use the Titles as permitted, display them without material alteration (except for technical modifications with Licensor's approval), and remove Titles if Licensor loses the rights.  Specific limitations on distribution rights vary by Title, as detailed in Schedule A.  For certain projects (Schedule A6), a profit-sharing arrangement is outlined.

The agreement includes standard indemnification clauses, confidentiality provisions (2-year post-termination), disclaimers of warranties, and a limitation of liability excluding consequential damages (except for indemnification and confidentiality breaches).  Dispute resolution is through binding arbitration in New York under New York law.  Termination can occur for insolvency, bankruptcy, or material breach (30-day cure period).  Several sections, including license grants, survive termination.  The agreement is governed by New York law and contains a jury trial waiver.

BIOAMBERINC_04_10_2013-EX-10.34-DEVELOPM.summary: This Development Agreement, dated April 15, 2010, is between Cargill, Incorporated (Cargill) and Bioamber S.A.S. (Bioamber).  The agreement concerns the development of Cargill's yeast strain (CB1) to produce succinic acid.  Cargill's key obligations include modifying CB1 according to a detailed work plan (Exhibit A),  maintaining necessary permits, and ensuring workmanlike performance. Bioamber's obligations include paying Cargill an upfront fee of $250,000, annual FTE fees, milestone payments totaling $1,050,000 (with penalties for missed milestones), and expenses.  Bioamber receives an exclusive, royalty-free license to Cargill Improvements for use in the field of succinic acid production (with a commercial license detailed in Exhibit D).  Intellectual property rights are carefully delineated, with ownership and licensing provisions for Improvements (defined as inventions conceived during the agreement).
