The agreement includes extensive confidentiality clauses, indemnification provisions limiting liability to gross negligence or willful misconduct, and a non-compete clause for Bioamber.  The agreement lasts four years unless terminated earlier due to bankruptcy, material breach, or mutual agreement.  The governing law is Minnesota law.  Several exhibits detail the work plan, patents, toolkits, and a commercial license agreement.

ACCELERATEDTECHNOLOGIESHOLDINGCORP_04_24.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement, dated April 24, 2003, establishes a non-partnership joint venture between Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. ("CCGI") and Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc. ("PVSS") to market batteries and related products ("Products") under the name MightyCell Batteries.  The venture's principal place of business is in Doylestown, PA.

CCGI's key obligations include obtaining licenses for product branding, preparing artwork, appointing sales agents, creating marketing materials, and providing fulfillment services. PVSS is responsible for providing Products according to specifications, negotiating favorable supplier pricing, and offering alternative fulfillment services.  Both parties share profits and losses equally (50/50).  No capital contributions are required, but expenses are reimbursed.  Neither party receives compensation for services rendered to the JV.

Major decisions, such as incurring debt or disposing of assets, require mutual written consent. The Joint Venture's term is from March 1, 2003, to February 28, 2004, renewable by mutual written agreement.  Distributions of profits are permitted only if assets exceed liabilities, and are made proportionally to each party's 50% share.  The agreement explicitly states it is not a partnership for tax purposes, electing out of Subchapter K of the Internal Revenue Code.  Transfer of interest requires the other party's consent.  Pennsylvania law governs the agreement.  Upon termination, debts are paid, and remaining assets are distributed proportionally.

PrudentialBancorpInc_20170606_8-K_EX-10..summary:
This Split-Dollar Endorsement Agreement, dated June 1, 2017, is between Prudential Bank ("Employer") and Jeffrey Hanuscin ("Employee").  Its purpose is to establish a split-dollar life insurance arrangement, where the Employer pays premiums on policies (Mass Mutual #39132041 and Midland National #755073) covering the Employee's life.

The Employer holds ownership rights, including the right to borrow against the policy's cash value, up to its interest (cash value less outstanding loans).  The Employee designates the beneficiary for a portion of the death benefit (lesser of twice annualized base salary + $100,000 (less group life insurance) or the net amount at risk), with the Employer receiving the remainder.  The Employee is responsible for any taxes on the insurance coverage's value.

The agreement supersedes prior split-dollar agreements.  It terminates upon the Employee's death or employment termination.  The Employer is the named fiduciary and plan administrator under ERISA.  A detailed claims procedure is outlined.  The agreement is governed by Pennsylvania law.  The Employer retains possession of the policies but must make them available for beneficiary changes.

SEASPINEHOLDINGSCORP_10_10_2018-EX-10.1-.summary:
This Supply Agreement, dated May 15, 2013, is between Integra LifeSciences Corporation ("Integra"), a Delaware medical device company, and PcoMed, LLC ("PcoMed"), a Colorado surface modification technology firm.  The agreement concerns PcoMed's application of its proprietary osteoconductive surface modification technology to Integra's implantable spinal devices for preclinical, clinical, and commercial use.

Integra's key obligations include making milestone and ongoing royalty payments to PcoMed based on Net Sales of treated Integra Products.  These payments include a percentage of Net Sales (specific percentages redacted) and per-run fees (amounts redacted). Integra also commits to commercially reasonable efforts to achieve minimum annual sales targets (amounts redacted).  Failure to meet minimum payment targets allows PcoMed to convert Integra's exclusive rights to non-exclusive.

PcoMed grants Integra exclusive worldwide rights to sell and commercialize the treated devices for a 36-month period following the initial product order acceptance, potentially extending to exclude China under certain conditions. PcoMed retains ownership of its technology and is responsible for patent prosecution.  Both parties have indemnification obligations related to intellectual property infringement and product liability.

The agreement's initial term ends after seven one-year minimum payment periods.  Termination can occur for material breach (60-day cure period), bankruptcy, or by mutual agreement.  Confidentiality and intellectual property ownership provisions are significant.  The agreement is governed by New Jersey law and includes a dispute resolution clause specifying arbitration in Denver, Colorado.  Numerous redacted sections indicate confidential financial and technical details.

BERKELEYLIGHTS,INC_06_26_2020-EX-10.12-C.summary:
This Collaboration Agreement, effective September 13, 2019, is between Ginkgo Bioworks, Inc. ("Ginkgo") and Berkeley Lights, Inc. ("BLI").  The agreement outlines a collaboration to develop workflows on BLI's Beacon Platform for engineering microbial organisms and mammalian cell lines.

**Key Obligations:** Ginkgo commits to purchasing a target of $150 million in products and services from BLI over the term, subject to minimum annual purchase commitments.  BLI is obligated to provide services and products, including personnel,  to support workflow development and meet Ginkgo's purchase orders, subject to specified service levels and remedies for failure to supply.  Both parties have responsibilities in a jointly managed Joint Review Committee (JRC) to oversee workflow development plans.  Intellectual property ownership is largely divided between the parties based on origin and development, with specific provisions for Headstart Inventions.  Confidentiality obligations are extensive.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement details pricing, payment terms, and dispute resolution (arbitration).  BLI's standard terms and conditions apply where not superseded by this agreement.  Excluded fields of use for the Beacon Platform are defined.  The agreement includes provisions for milestone payments based on Ginkgo's commercial success using certain BLI workflows.

**Duration/Termination:** The initial term is seven years from the Effective Date, potentially extending based on Ginkgo's purchases.  Termination clauses exist for material breach, insolvency, and Ginkgo's option to buy down remaining obligations.  Termination effects vary depending on the cause, impacting license grants, royalty payments, and restrictions on BLI's activities.

**Financial Arrangements:**  Ginkgo pays

UnionDentalHoldingsInc_20050204_8-KA_EX-.summary:
This Business Affiliate Agreement, effective October 15, 2004, is between Dr. George D. Green ("Business Affiliate") and UNION DENTAL CORP. ("UDC").  The agreement governs the exchange of confidential information between the parties to facilitate UDC's dental office management and the Business Affiliate's services.

Key obligations include the confidential handling of information,  reporting unauthorized disclosures, maintaining information security, and complying with applicable laws.  Both parties must implement safeguards and require their employees and agents to adhere to the same confidentiality restrictions.  The agreement mandates the return or destruction of confidential information upon termination.  Mutual indemnification is included for losses arising from unauthorized disclosures.

The agreement is terminable by either party with 30 days' written notice, or immediately by UDC for material breach or legal violation.  UDC may also provide a 10-day cure period for material breaches.  Sections 3(g) (return/destruction of confidential information) and 3(h) (mitigation of harmful effects), and the indemnification clause survive termination.  No financial arrangements are explicitly detailed.  The Business Affiliate is explicitly classified as an independent contractor, not an employee of UDC.  The agreement incorporates UDC's Business Affiliate manual by reference.

WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10..contract_id: WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10.13-ENDORSEMENT AGREEMENT - Intellectual Property Rights                 Confidentiality and Non-Use Obligations Agreement
WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10..contract_title: WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10.13-ENDORSEMENT AGREEMENT - Intellectual Property Rights                 Confidentiality and Non-Use Obligations Agreement
WOMENSGOLFUNLIMITEDINC_03_29_2000-EX-10..summary:
This agreement, dated March 29, 2000, is an endorsement agreement between Square Two Golf, Inc. (Company) and Kathy Whitworth (Recipient).  It incorporates an Intellectual Property Rights, Confidentiality, and Non-Use Obligations Agreement (Exhibit A).  The main purpose is to establish Whitworth's endorsement obligations and protect Square Two Golf's confidential information.

Whitworth's key obligations include using the Company's confidential information (including marketing plans, designs, and software) solely for work with the Company and not disclosing it without written permission.  Exhibit A details specific exceptions to this confidentiality clause (e.g., pre-existing knowledge, publicly available information).  Whitworth assigns all intellectual property created during her work to the Company, agreeing to execute necessary documentation to facilitate this transfer.  The confidentiality and non-use obligations survive the termination of the endorsement agreement.  The agreement designates New Jersey courts as having jurisdiction.  Financial arrangements are not detailed in the provided excerpt.  The duration and termination clauses of the main endorsement agreement are not specified, but Exhibit A's obligations are perpetual.

SPHERE3DCORP_06_24_2020-EX-10.12-CONSULT.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, dated June 1, 2020, is between Sphere 3D Corp. ("Company") and Groupe Parameus Corp. ("Consultant").  The agreement engages the Consultant as an independent contractor to provide business development services, including investor relations and financial public relations, as detailed in Exhibit A.  The Consultant's compensation includes a US$150,000 pre-payment (already received), 100,000 restricted common shares (subject to Board approval), 50,000 stock options (vesting monthly over six months, priced at Nasdaq closing price on Board approval date), and 100,000 immediately vesting RSAs (subject to Board approval).

The Company's obligations include providing necessary materials, disclosing the agreement in filings (10-K and 10-Q), and advising the Consultant of promotional activities.  The Consultant is obligated to perform services efficiently and professionally, maintain confidentiality, and indemnify the Company against third-party claims arising from its performance (excluding Company negligence/willful misconduct).  The Consultant makes several representations and warranties, including accredited investor status and absence of conflicting obligations.

The agreement's term is 12 months (June 1, 2020 – May 31, 2021), automatically extending by one month unless the Company provides 5-day notice.  Termination requires information transfer.  Governing law is New York State law.  Amendments require written agreement.  The agreement includes standard severability and confidentiality clauses.

ENTERPRISEPRODUCTSPARTNERSLP_07_08_1998-.summary:
This Transportation Contract, dated June 1, 1998, is between Enterprise Transportation Company (Carrier), a division of Enterprise Products Company, and Enterprise Products Operating L.P. (Shipper), a Delaware limited partnership.  The agreement outlines the terms for the Carrier's provision of specialized transportation services for the Shipper's chemical and petroleum products (Commodities) in interstate and foreign commerce.

The Shipper's key obligations include tendering at least 10,000 pounds of Commodities annually and designating origin/destination points for each shipment. The Carrier must transport the Commodities and maintain necessary licenses, insurance (meeting DOT standards), and equipment.  The Carrier acts as an independent contractor, responsible for its own employees and contractors.

Payment is based on rate appendices and Carrier's Contract Carriage Rules and Regulations (Exhibit A), incorporating various charges for services, including detention, stop-offs, and special services.  Late payments accrue interest.  The Carrier indemnifies the Shipper for losses due to its negligence, excluding acts of God, etc.

The contract lasts one year, automatically renewing unless terminated with 30 days' written notice.  Either party may terminate immediately if the other makes a general assignment for the benefit of creditors or a receiver is appointed due to insolvency (7 days' notice).  The contract is governed by Texas law, with jurisdiction in Harris County, Texas, or the Southern District of Texas.  Confidentiality provisions protect business information shared between the parties.

HerImports_20161018_8-KA_EX-10.14_976570.summary:
This Software Maintenance Agreement, dated October 13, 2016, is between EZJR, Inc. and Leader Act Ltd HK, both Nevada corporations.  The agreement extends Leader's maintenance of EZJR's CRM software for five years, commencing October 13, 2016.  Leader's compensation is 3,000,000 shares of EZJR's unregistered restricted common stock issued upon closing.

Key obligations include Leader's maintenance of the software and representations/warranties regarding its corporate status, authority, and absence of undisclosed liabilities.  EZJR provides similar representations and warranties.  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses, with Leader indemnifying EZJR for any material misrepresentation or breach.

The agreement is governed by Nevada law, waives jury trials, and designates Nevada state courts as the exclusive venue.  Representations and warranties survive closing for one year unless notice of a breach is given earlier.  The agreement is the entire agreement between the parties and may only be amended in writing.  No specific termination clause is explicitly stated, implying the agreement runs for the five-year term.  The financial arrangement consists solely of the equity compensation to Leader.

PROLONGINTERNATIONALCORP_03_23_1998-EX-1.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated December 19, 1997, is between SABCO Racing, Inc. (Sabco) and Prolong Super Lubricants (Prolong).  Prolong becomes a major associate sponsor for Sabco's three NASCAR Winston Cup Series entries (Nos. 40, 42, and 46) for the 1998, 1999, and 2000 seasons.

Sabco's key obligations include providing designated decal space on its race cars, five aggregate hours of driver appearances (with additional appearances at a discounted rate), one free day of driver services for commercial use, and media/public relations assistance.  Sabco also agrees to provide five days of show car appearances (with additional days at a discounted rate).

Prolong's main obligation is payment of $[ * ] (redacted) in installments over the three-year period.  Prolong is responsible for travel expenses related to driver appearances and show car usage.

The agreement includes exclusivity clauses preventing Sabco from sponsoring Prolong's competitors, confidentiality provisions, mutual indemnification clauses, and a statement establishing Sabco as an independent contractor.  The contract is governed by North Carolina law, with jurisdiction and venue in North Carolina courts.  The agreement's term runs from the first 1998 race to the final 2000 race.  Assignment requires written consent.

DYNTEKINC_07_30_1999-EX-10-ONLINE HOSTIN.summary:
This Online Hosting Agreement, effective June 1, 1999, is between Diplomat Direct Marketing Corp. (Diplomat) and Tadeo E-Commerce Corp. (Tadeo), both Delaware corporations.  The agreement outlines Tadeo's provision of online hosting services to Diplomat, primarily for Diplomat's apparel order website, supplementing a concurrent Web Design and Consulting Agreement.

Tadeo's key obligations include providing online hosting services (specified in Exhibit A), including development and maintenance of Diplomat's Commerce Web Subsites.  Diplomat's main obligation is payment of a monthly fee per Commerce Web Subsite (detailed in Exhibit A and A-1).  Late payments accrue 15% annual interest.

The agreement lasts 12 months, renewable for an additional year with 60-day notice.  Either party may terminate for material breach (uncured within 5 days of notice), bankruptcy of the other party, dissolution, insolvency, or with 60-day advance written notice.  Tadeo may also terminate upon Diplomat's acquisition by a non-permitted entity or exceeding a 20% threshold of beneficial ownership of Diplomat's voting securities.

Dispute resolution is via American Arbitration Association (AAA) rules in New York, with a single arbitrator.  The agreement is governed by New York law, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  Confidentiality and proprietary rights clauses protect Tadeo's materials.  Assignment of the agreement requires the other party's consent, except for Tadeo assigning to affiliates.

ALAMOGORDOFINANCIALCORP_12_16_1999-EX-1-.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated circa 2000, involves Alamogordo Financial Corporation ("Company"), AF Mutual Holding Company ("MHC"), Alamogordo Federal Savings and Loan Association ("Bank"), and Charles Webb & Company (Agent).  Its purpose is to facilitate the offering and sale of up to 1,101,643 shares of Company common stock.

The Agent's key obligations include consulting, advising, training Bank employees, managing a stock information center, and preparing marketing materials.  The Company's primary obligation is to offer and sell the shares, initially to Bank depositors and employees, then to the general public on a best-efforts basis, potentially through a broker-dealer syndicate.  The Bank and MHC are jointly and severally liable with the Company.

Important terms include a minimum share sale threshold (708,050 shares) triggering termination and refunds;  purchase price of $10.00 per share; and maximum and minimum purchase limitations as described in a separate Stock Issuance Plan.

The Agent's compensation includes a $25,000 management fee and a $75,000 success fee, plus a potential additional fee (up to 5.5% of the aggregate purchase price) if a broker-dealer syndicate is used.  The Company bears customary issuer expenses.

The agreement terminates upon completion, termination, or abandonment of the Stock Issuance Plan, or 45 days after the Closing Date, unless extended.  Termination clauses also exist for failure to meet the minimum share sale threshold and for breaches by either party.  Extensive mutual representations, warranties, indemnification, and contribution clauses are included, addressing potential liabilities under securities

StampscomInc_20001114_10-Q_EX-10.47_2631.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective April 27, 1999, is between iShip.com, Inc. ("Company") and Mail Boxes Etc. USA, Inc. ("MBE").  The agreement centers on iShip providing MBE with an internet-based shipping system integrated with MBE's retail manifest system for use in MBE Centers.  This involves co-branding activities on the internet, listing MBE Centers as drop-off locations, and granting MBE a warrant to purchase Company stock.

Key obligations include iShip developing and maintaining the integrated system (the "Service"), providing updates and support, and MBE facilitating Subscription Agreements with individual MBE Centers.  MBE is obligated to provide Listings of its Centers and participate in co-marketing efforts.  Exclusivity provisions exist, limiting both parties' dealings with competitors, subject to specific exceptions and termination clauses based on package volume thresholds.

Financial arrangements include a Basic Fee per package shipped (excluding USPS First Class), and a tiered Bounty Fee and eBay Fee structure based on package volume.  Payments are handled through various methods, including direct carrier payments and MBE Center direct payments.  The agreement includes detailed indemnification and limitation of liability clauses.

The initial term is five years, renewable for two-year periods upon mutual agreement on fees.  Termination can occur for material breach (after cure period), insolvency, or by either party under specific volume-based conditions.  The agreement includes provisions for data ownership, confidential information, and dispute resolution via arbitration in San Diego, California.  Several sections, including fee amounts and volume thresholds, are redacted in the provided text.

Capsugel will pay Cardax royalties (a percentage of Adjusted Net Sales) following sales.  The agreement details intellectual property ownership and licensing, with joint ownership of inventions directly resulting from the collaboration.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification.

The agreement's duration is not explicitly stated but includes termination clauses for breach, bankruptcy, commercial non-viability, and force majeure.  A dispute resolution mechanism via JAMS expedited arbitration in New York is included.  The agreement is governed by New York law.  Confidentiality is governed by a separate agreement.

TALCOTTRESOLUTIONLIFEINSURANCECO-SEPARAT.summary:
This Service Agreement, dated September 28, 2004, is between The Victory Portfolios (a Delaware statutory trust, acting for various Funds) and Hartford Life Insurance Co., Inc. (the Administrator).  The agreement governs the purchase and redemption of Victory Portfolios' shares by the Administrator on behalf of various retirement plans' separate accounts.

The primary purpose is to establish a framework for the Administrator to provide administrative services (recordkeeping, reporting, processing) related to the investment of plan assets in the Funds.  The Trust's key obligation is to make Fund shares available for purchase and redemption at net asset value (NAV), primarily through the NSCC's DCC&S platform. ArmstrongFlooringInc_20190107_8-K_EX-10..summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated December 31, 2018, governs the transfer and licensing of intellectual property between Armstrong Flooring, Inc. ("Seller"), AFI Licensing LLC, and AHF Holding, Inc. (formerly Tarzan HoldCo, Inc.) and Armstrong Hardwood Flooring Company ("Buyer Entities").  The agreement's purpose is to facilitate the transfer of intellectual property related to a stock purchase agreement (SPA) between the parties.

Seller assigns certain intellectual property ("Arizona Assigned IP") to Buyer Entities.  Both parties grant each other perpetual, non-exclusive, royalty-free licenses to other intellectual property for use in their respective fields (Arizona Field and Company Field, defined within).  The agreement also grants limited, non-exclusive, royalty-free licenses for specific trademarks (Arizona Licensed Trademarks and Diamond Licensed Trademarks) for defined periods.  Buyer Entities are obligated to maintain quality control over the use of Seller's licensed trademarks.

Key terms include detailed definitions of various intellectual property rights, including copyrights, patents, trademarks, and know-how.  The agreement specifies responsibilities for prosecution and enforcement of the licensed IP.  Both parties provide indemnification for breaches or misconduct.

The agreement's duration varies depending on the intellectual property: perpetual for copyrights, know-how, and patents; and specific terms for trademarks (24 months for Arizona Licensed Trademarks, 18 months for Diamond Licensed Trademarks, and 24 months for Phase-Out Marks).  Termination is possible for material breach.  No financial arrangements beyond cost reimbursements for litigation cooperation are detailed.  Delaware law governs, with a waiver of jury trial.

PFSFUNDS_06_26_2020-EX-99.H OTH MAT CONT.summary:
This Services Agreement, dated June 24, 2020, is between PFS Funds (a Massachusetts business trust) and Potomac Fund Management, Inc. (a Florida corporation).  The agreement outlines Potomac's provision of administrative and operational services to PFS Funds' four investment funds (Conquer Risk Managed Volatility Fund, Conquer Risk Tactical Rotation Fund, Conquer Risk Tactical Opportunities Fund, and Conquer Risk Defensive Bull Fund).

Potomac's key obligations include providing non-investment related data, a Chief Compliance Officer, executive and administrative services, and assistance with regulatory filings and reporting.  PFS Funds retains ultimate control and direction.  Potomac is responsible for accurate information in fund prospectuses and indemnifies PFS Funds against liabilities arising from its negligence or misconduct.

Financial arrangements stipulate that each fund pays Potomac a tiered annual fee based on average daily net assets (0.65% up to $25M, 0.35% from $25M to $100M, 0.25% above $100M).  Operating expenses are allocated between Potomac and the funds, with brokerage fees, taxes, and certain other expenses borne by the funds.

The agreement has a two-year initial term, renewable annually subject to trustee approval, and is terminable by either party with 60 days' written notice.  Automatic termination occurs if the related Management Agreement is terminated.  Massachusetts law governs the agreement.  Liability for Potomac is limited except for willful misconduct or gross negligence.

WaterNowInc_20191120_10-Q_EX-10.12_11900.summary:
This Exclusive Distributor Agreement, effective November 12, 2019, is between Water Now, Inc. and its subsidiary Hydraspin USA, Inc. (collectively, "Hydraspin"), and Bestev Management, LLC ("Distributor").  The agreement grants Distributor exclusive rights to distribute Hydraspin's oil and gas separation products within a defined territory (Exhibits A & B) for five years, renewable for successive five-year terms.

Hydraspin's key obligations include supplying products, obtaining necessary licenses, providing support services, and sharing revenue.  Distributor's main responsibilities are marketing and sales within the territory, meeting performance benchmarks (25 new locations annually, generating 7,500 barrels/day), and providing customer support.  Failure to meet benchmarks can result in loss of exclusivity.

Revenue is shared between Hydraspin and Distributor (initially 92.5%/7.5%, increasing to 85%/15% after 10 installations), with the exact split negotiable per installation.  The agreement includes detailed definitions of key terms like "Net Revenue" and "Performance Benchmarks."

Termination can occur by mutual agreement, for breach of contract (30-day cure period), failure to meet performance benchmarks, Hydraspin's change of control, or insolvency.  Upon termination due to a change of control, Distributor receives a significant one-time payment.  The agreement specifies governing law (Texas) and arbitration as the dispute resolution mechanism.  Confidentiality and intellectual property rights are also addressed.

Financial arrangements are not explicitly detailed but involve revenue targets ($500,000 annualized) for Premier Reseller status and associated benefits.  The agreement incorporates a Premier Addendum, specifying MTI's product provider (Tidal Wire initially), and outlining additional obligations, including restrictions on price advertising.  The agreement has a one-year initial term, automatically renewing annually, and includes termination clauses for cause (material breach, uncured within 30 days), without cause (60-day notice), and insolvency.  Significant limitations of liability and disclaimers of warranty are included, with dispute resolution via arbitration in Denver, Colorado.  Confidentiality provisions are in place for a period of three years post-termination.

The Company may terminate after the initial term with five days' notice. New York law governs, and disputes are subject to New York state courts.  The agreement is binding on successors and assigns, and any amendments must be in writing.

PharmagenInc_20120803_8-KA_EX-10.1_76932.summary:

**Important Terms:**  The agreement is non-exclusive, meaning the Franchisor can operate competing businesses.  The Franchisor retains ownership of all data generated by the Franchisee.  Relocation requires Franchisor's consent and a fee.  The Franchisee must maintain detailed accounting records subject to Franchisor audits.

Comware must also market and sell the products, provide marketing feedback, and train customers. The agreement includes tiered discounts based on purchase volume, with higher discounts for larger orders. MORPHO is responsible for proper equipment use and maintenance, prompt error reporting, and timely payment.  The agreement specifies a $24,502 annual maintenance fee for the first year, with subsequent renewals at XIMAGE's prevailing rates.  Additional charges apply for on-site visits (minimum $2,000) and exceeding 40 hours of telephone support ($100/hour).

The agreement includes confidentiality clauses, indemnification provisions (reciprocal, with limitations), and limitations of liability (capped at 60 days of maintenance charges, excluding consequential damages).  Termination can occur with 60 days' written notice for material breach or non-payment, or immediately for bankruptcy events. The agreement's duration is initially one year, automatically renewing annually unless terminated.  XIMAGE provides no warranties beyond those explicitly stated.
