ParatekPharmaceuticalsInc_20170505_10-KA.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated December 30, 2016, is between Paratek Pharmaceuticals, Inc. ("Customer") and CARBOGEN AMCIS AG ("Supplier").  The agreement outlines the manufacturing and supply of a pharmaceutical product ("Product") by Supplier for Customer.  

Supplier's key obligations include manufacturing the Product according to specifications in the Quality Agreement and cGMP requirements,  performing release testing, and shipping the Product as ordered by Customer via Purchase Orders.  Customer is responsible for supplying certain materials ("Customer Materials"), providing forecasts, and accepting shipments.  Both parties have detailed responsibilities regarding quality control, testing, and intellectual property.  Supplier's liability is capped, except for specific exceptions related to recalls.

The agreement includes provisions for confidentiality, indemnification, dispute resolution (ICC arbitration in Delaware), and termination.  Termination can occur for material breach, insolvency, or by notice within specified timeframes (Initial Term and Renewal Term).  Financial arrangements involve fees detailed in Exhibit C, subject to adjustment under certain conditions.  Invoices are to be paid within a specified timeframe.  The agreement's duration is initially until [redacted date], with an automatic renewal for [redacted period] unless a new agreement is reached.  Many key details, including specific fees, quantities, and liability limits, are redacted due to a confidentiality request.

JOINTCORP_09_19_2014-EX-10.15-FRANCHISE.summary: This Franchise Agreement (dated 09/19/2014), between The Joint Corp. (Franchisor) and [Franchisee Name] (Franchisee), grants a 10-year franchise to operate a "The Joint…The Chiropractic Place" chiropractic clinic.  The Franchisee's key obligations include adhering to the Franchisor's system, paying initial and ongoing fees (including a 7% royalty on gross revenue, minimum $700/month, plus advertising fees), maintaining the clinic's appearance and standards, and complying with operating manuals and reporting requirements.  If the Franchisee is not a licensed chiropractor, a management agreement with a professional corporation is required.  The agreement includes non-compete and confidentiality clauses.  The Franchisor retains the right to approve site selection, lease terms, advertising, and transfers of the franchise.  The agreement may be renewed for an additional 10 years under specified conditions.  Termination clauses allow for termination by either party for various breaches, including non-payment, non-compliance, or unauthorized use of trademarks.  The Franchisor has a right of first refusal on any transfer of the franchise and an option to purchase the franchise's assets upon termination.  The agreement specifies late payment penalties, interest accrual, and a detailed indemnification clause.  Disputes are subject to arbitration in Maricopa County, Arizona.

VnueInc_20150914_8-K_EX-10.1_9259571_EX-.summary:
This Promotion Agreement, effective September 10, 2015, is between VNUE, Inc. (a Nevada corporation) and BookingEntertainment.com.  It's a services agreement engaging BookingEntertainment.com as an independent contractor to secure 30 music venue contracts for VNUE.

BookingEntertainment.com's key obligations include using its industry expertise to secure these contracts.  VNUE's main obligations are to pay BookingEntertainment.com $2,500 per one-year venue contract, $5,000 per two-year contract (within 30 days of contract execution), and 3,000,000 shares of VNUE common stock (600,000 shares for every 5 venues secured, plus a 300,000 share bonus if 10 venues are secured by January 16, 2016).  VNUE will also reimburse BookingEntertainment.com's expenses.

The agreement is for one year, renewable annually.  Both parties are independent contractors; neither assumes liability for the other's actions except as specifically indemnified.  The agreement is governed by Nevada law.  BookingEntertainment.com warrants it has the right to enter into this agreement and will not disclose VNUE's confidential information.  The agreement includes standard clauses regarding notice, enforceability, and severability.  A breach of the non-disclosure clause automatically terminates the agreement.

NEXSTARFINANCEHOLDINGSINC_03_27_2002-EX-.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, dated November 28, 2001, is between WYZZ, Inc. and WYZZ Licensee, Inc. (collectively "WYZZ"), licensee of WYZZ-TV, and Nexstar Broadcasting of Peoria, L.L.C. ("Nexstar"), licensee of WMBD-TV, both operating in the Peoria-Bloomington, Illinois market.  The agreement outlines Nexstar's provision of non-programming operational and managerial services to WYZZ-TV.

Nexstar's key obligations include sales of advertising time, administrative functions, programming consultation, accounting services, technical equipment maintenance, and retransmission consent negotiation. WYZZ retains exclusive control over programming, personnel, and finances.  Crucially, WYZZ remains solely responsible for all programming decisions and FCC compliance.

Financial arrangements center on a complex revenue-sharing model based on "Broadcast Cash Flow" (BCF).  Nexstar receives a percentage of BCF after certain deductions, including equipment maintenance costs, with the percentage varying based on whether BCF exceeds a minimum threshold (adjusted annually for inflation).  Additional payments are stipulated for specific services and rent.  Detailed financial reporting and reconciliation mechanisms are included, along with dispute resolution via arbitration.

The agreement's term is seven years from December 1, 2001, subject to early termination by either party with six months' notice, or for material breach by the other party, or upon certain events like insolvency or FCC rule changes.  Post-termination provisions address employee hiring, equipment allocation, and facility use.  Comprehensive representations and warranties are provided by both parties, and detailed indemnification clauses protect each from liabilities arising from the other's breach or misconduct

SUNTRONCORP_05_17_2006-EX-10.22-MAINTENA.summary:
This Maintenance Agreement, dated March 28, 2006, is between Thayer Equity Investors IV, L.P. ("Investor") and U.S. Bank National Association, as agent for itself and other lenders ("Agent/Lenders"), concerning Suntron Corporation and its affiliates ("Borrowers").  The agreement's purpose is to ensure the Borrowers meet financial covenants under a separate Financing Agreement.

The Investor, a Suntron shareholder, is obligated to make Required Capital Contributions (up to $5,000,000) to the Borrowers within 45-90 days of each fiscal quarter-end, to maintain compliance with the Financing Agreement's Section 2 of Schedule 10.28.  Failure to contribute constitutes a Maintenance Event of Default, triggering liquidated damages (the lesser of the unpaid contribution or the outstanding loan balance) and allowing the Agent/Lenders to seek specific performance.  The Investor irrevocably waives various defenses and agrees to unconditional obligations.

The agreement includes representations and warranties from the Investor regarding its financial capacity and the legality of the agreement.  It specifies a Special Account for capital contributions and addresses expenses, governing law (Minnesota), jurisdiction (Minnesota courts), and waiver of jury trial.

The agreement is a continuing agreement until all obligations under the Financing Agreement are paid and any commitment to extend further credit is terminated.  However, the Investor can request release after March 31, 2007, subject to specified financial conditions (Adjusted Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio ≥ 1.25) and absence of defaults.  The agreement terminates upon the earliest of $5,000,000 in contributions, the

SPIENERGYCO,LTD_03_09_2011-EX-99.5-OPERA.summary:
This Operations and Maintenance Agreement (OMA), effective December 11, 2009, is between Solar Tax Partners 1, LLC ("Owner") and Solar Power, Inc. ("Service Provider") for a 3.6 MW solar energy facility (SEF) located in Rancho Cordova, CA, serving Aerojet as the host customer.  The agreement outlines Service Provider's responsibility for the SEF's operation and maintenance, encompassing preventative maintenance, system testing, cleaning, and operational management to meet performance objectives and applicable warranties.  Specific services are detailed in Exhibit C.

Service Provider acts as an independent contractor.  The OMA specifies non-covered services and their billing procedures (Exhibit D), with a time and materials basis for additional work beyond the initial semi-annual fee of $41,000 (escalating 3% annually).  Payment terms are 30 days from invoice date, with 1.5% monthly interest on overdue balances.  Aerojet has no payment obligation under this agreement.

The OMA includes detailed insurance requirements for Service Provider (Article 4), indemnification clauses (Article 5), and a dispute resolution process involving negotiation, mediation, and a waiver of jury trial (Article 6).  The initial term is 10 years, automatically renewing annually unless terminated with 30 days' written notice, or immediately for material breach uncured after 30 days' notice.  The agreement addresses confidentiality (Article 7), assignment restrictions (Article 9), and force majeure events (Article 10).  California law governs.

SteelVaultCorp_20081224_10-K_EX-10.16_30.summary:
This Marketing Affiliate Agreement, effective October 1, 2008, is between Equidata, Inc. (Virginia) and National Credit Report.com, LLC (Florida).  Equidata provides credit services, and National Credit Report (Affiliate) will market these services via various channels (including online, direct mail, and telemarketing).

The Affiliate's key obligations include marketing Equidata's services, collecting payments from consumers, and remitting payments to Equidata according to Exhibit A's schedule (bi-monthly, due within 30 days).  The Affiliate is responsible for all non-payment by consumers and will reimburse Equidata for collection costs.  A development fee (amount TBD in Exhibit A) is also due.  The Affiliate agrees to not solicit Equidata's existing clients and to comply with FCRA, FDCPA, HIPAA, and other relevant laws.  Equidata retains audit rights.

Important terms include a dispute resolution clause mandating arbitration in Newport News, Virginia, and a non-solicitation clause.  Equidata provides services "as is" with no warranties, and liability is limited.  The Affiliate's principal/owner personally guarantees payment.

The agreement lasts one year, automatically renewing unless superseded.  Either party may terminate with 30 days' written notice; Equidata may terminate immediately for non-payment or other breaches.  Upon termination, the Affiliate must remove all Equidata-related URLs; failure to do so results in Affiliate liability for removal costs.  Equidata may also terminate immediately if credit reporting agencies cease service to the Affiliate.  The agreement includes indemnification and confidentiality clauses.

PRECIGEN,INC_01_22_2020-EX-99.1-JOINT FI.summary: This Joint Filing Agreement (JFA), dated January 7, 2019, involves Ares Trading SA (Designated Filer), Merck Serono SA (an affiliate of Merck KGaA), and Merck KGaA.  The agreement concerns reporting obligations related to Intrexon Corporation (CUSIP: 46122T102) securities.  The main purpose is to establish a framework for the joint filing of Schedule 13D/G reports with the SEC.  Ares Trading SA is designated as the filer, responsible for submitting the reports.  Merck Serono SA and Merck KGaA are obligated to provide Ares Trading SA with necessary information for accurate and timely filings.  The agreement doesn't specify a duration or termination clause, implying it remains in effect until the underlying reporting obligations cease.  No specific financial arrangements are detailed within this excerpt of the agreement.  The agreement is signed by authorized representatives of each party, including CFOs and treasury/finance managers.

PhotronicsInc_20171219_10-QA_EX-10.28_10.summary:
This Outsourcing Agreement, effective May 16, 2017, governs the outsourcing of photomask production between Photronics, Inc. ("Photronics"), Dai Nippon Printing Co., Ltd. ("DNP"), Photronics DNP Photomask Corporation ("PDMC"), and Xiamen American Japan Photronics Mask Co., Ltd. ("Company").  Photronics and DNP are shareholders in the Company and, along with PDMC, are Suppliers under this agreement.  The agreement's primary purpose is to establish an outsourcing model for the Company's photomask production, allocating orders between PDMC and the Company based on a phased approach detailed in the agreement.

Key obligations include the Suppliers' good-faith effort to fulfill Company purchase orders, adhering to specifications and lead times.  The agreement outlines detailed procedures for purchase order issuance, acceptance, rescheduling, and cancellation.  Pricing is specified in Schedule 2 (redacted).  Payment terms require payment within a specified timeframe after shipment.  The Suppliers provide limited warranties on the Products, with remedies for breach.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses protecting each party from certain liabilities.  Liability is limited, excluding breaches of confidentiality and license grants.  The agreement's term continues as long as Photronics and DNP remain shareholders in the Company, with termination provisions for material breach.  The agreement incorporates by reference sections of a related Joint Venture Operating Agreement.  Significant portions of the agreement, including pricing and specific allocation rules, are redacted.

KIROMICBIOPHARMA,INC_04_08_2020-EX-10.28.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement (JVA), dated April 2, 2020, is between Kiromic Biopharma Inc. (Delaware) and Molipharma S.r.l. (Italy).  The purpose is to collaborate on two clinical trial programs: one for ovarian cancer, and one for COVID-19 countermeasures (vaccines and therapeutics).

Kiromic's primary obligations involve funding the oncology research, including R&D and clinical development costs, post-IPO.  Molipharma provides tissue samples (oncology) and biological samples (COVID-19), utilizing Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore (UCSC) facilities for clinical trials.  Molipharma funds the COVID-19 research, potentially leveraging grants.  Kiromic shares patents and know-how for the COVID-19 program.

Intellectual property rights are jointly owned (50/50 initially, subject to written agreement for adjustments based on contribution).  Commercial rights are primarily assigned to Kiromic for oncology (with royalties to Molipharma for Italian and European sales) and split between the parties for COVID-19 (Molipharma for Europe, Kiromic for the US, split for the rest of the world).

The JVA has a [redacted] year term, renewable for a further [redacted] years, terminable by serious reason, mutual consent, or breach of contract.  Breach triggers expense reimbursement and potential damages.  A Steering Committee and Technical Committee oversee the JV.  The agreement is governed by Italian law, with arbitration in Paris under ICC rules.  Confidentiality and anti-corruption clauses are included.

EMERALDHEALTHTHERAPEUTICSINC_06_10_2020-.contract_id: EMERALDHEALTHTHERAPEUTICSINC_06_10_2020-EX-4.5-CONSULTING AGREEMENT - DR. GAETANO MORELLO N.D. INC.
EMERALDHEALTHTHERAPEUTICSINC_06_10_2020-.contract_title: EMERALDHEALTHTHERAPEUTICSINC_06_10_2020-EX-4.5-CONSULTING AGREEMENT - DR. GAETANO MORELLO N.D. INC.
EMERALDHEALTHTHERAPEUTICSINC_06_10_2020-.summary:
This Consulting Agreement, effective January 10, 2019, is between Emerald Health Naturals Inc. ("Emerald") and Dr. Gaetano Morello N.D. Inc. ("Contractor").  The agreement engages the Contractor as an independent consultant to Emerald for a 24-month term, renewable by mutual agreement.  The Contractor's primary responsibility is to lead Emerald's business strategy, product development, and operations, reporting to Avtar Dhillon.  

The Contractor's annual fee is $240,000 plus applicable taxes, with Emerald reimbursing reasonable expenses.  Crucially, Emerald is not responsible for tax deductions or remittances from the Contractor's fee. The Contractor may engage in other business activities provided they don't conflict with Emerald's interests.  The Contractor may be seconded to Emerald's subsidiaries.

The Contractor can terminate with 30 days' written notice; Emerald can terminate for cause immediately or without cause with 30 days' notice.  Upon termination, Emerald owes only accrued fees (payable within 30 days), and the Contractor must return Emerald's property (excluding personal devices).  The agreement includes confidentiality clauses protecting Emerald's information for five years post-termination.  The agreement is governed by British Columbia law.

PlayboyEnterprisesInc_20090220_10-QA_EX-.contract_id: PlayboyEnterprisesInc_20090220_10-QA_EX-10.2_4091580_EX-10.2_Content License Agreement_ Marketing Agreement_ Sales-Purchase Agreement1
PlayboyEnterprisesInc_20090220_10-QA_EX-.contract_title: PlayboyEnterprisesInc_20090220_10-QA_EX-10.2_4091580_EX-10.2_Content License Agreement_ Marketing Agreement_ Sales-Purchase Agreement1
PlayboyEnterprisesInc_20090220_10-QA_EX-.summary:
This Content License, Marketing, and Sales Agreement, effective January 15, 2008, is between eFashion Solutions, LLC ("EFS") and Playboy.com, Inc. ("Client").  The agreement licenses EFS to operate Playboy's e-commerce business (Playboy Commerce Business), encompassing website (PlayboyStore.com, BunnyShop.com) and catalog sales of merchandise.

EFS's key obligations include website and catalog design, operation, maintenance, fulfillment services (order processing, shipping, customer service), marketing, and procurement of merchandise, all subject to Client's approval.  Client provides content and branding assets.  EFS must maintain 99.5% website uptime.  All female models must be Playboy models.

Client's obligations include providing content, promoting the Playboy Commerce Business on its own website, and assisting EFS in securing favorable terms with licensees.

Financial terms include royalties based on Merchandise Gross Margin (with a minimum annual royalty), advertising fees, and a purchase price for existing Playboy inventory.  Royalty calculations are detailed, including provisions for shipping and international sales.  EFS is responsible for most taxes.  Client has audit rights.

The initial term is five years from the first website launch (no later than February 28, 2013), automatically renewing for three years if sales targets are met. Termination clauses exist for material breach, bankruptcy, and Force Majeure events.  Specific provisions address confidentiality, intellectual property ownership, indemnification, and limitations of liability.  Illinois law governs.

NlsPharmaceuticsLtd_20200228_F-1_EX-10.1.summary:
This License and Development Agreement (LDA), dated February 28, 2020, is between NLS-1 Pharma AG ("NLS") and Eurofarma Laboratórios S.A. ("Eurofarma").  The LDA grants Eurofarma an exclusive license to develop, register, and commercialize NLS's Nolazol® (Mazindol CR) for ADHD treatment in Latin America.

**Key Obligations:** NLS grants the license and provides know-how; Eurofarma pays upfront fees ($2.5M USD), milestone payments (tied to clinical trial success, regulatory approvals, and sales targets), and royalties (7-10% of net sales). Eurofarma is responsible for commercialization, regulatory filings, and post-market surveillance in Latin America.  NLS retains responsibility for certain development work and provides regulatory support.  A Joint Steering Committee advises on development and commercialization.

**Important Terms:**  The agreement includes detailed provisions on intellectual property rights, confidentiality, representations and warranties, liability limitations, indemnities, and dispute resolution (ICC arbitration in The Hague).  Eurofarma must submit quarterly reports and allow audits.

**Duration/Termination:** The agreement lasts for ten years from the first commercial sale or the expiry of the last relevant patent, whichever is later.  Termination clauses exist for change of control, bankruptcy, material breach, and specific performance failures by either party, with varying consequences including financial penalties and asset transfer.

**Financial Arrangements:**  Eurofarma's financial obligations include a significant upfront payment, milestone payments linked to development and regulatory success, and tiered royalties based on net sales.  Late payments incur penalties.  The agreement specifies payment currency and tax implications.  The governing law is

TubeMediaCorp_20060310_8-K_EX-10.1_51392.summary:
This Affiliation Agreement, effective March 6, 2006, is between The TUBE Music Network, Inc. ("Network") and Tribune Broadcasting Company ("Affiliate").  The agreement governs Affiliate's broadcast of Network's television programming service, "The TUBE," on Affiliate's stations (listed in Exhibit A).

The main purpose is to grant Affiliate exclusive broadcast rights for "The TUBE" via Broadcast Television within specified Designated Market Areas (DMAs), in exchange for revenue sharing.  Affiliate's key obligations include broadcasting the service on its stations (with specified launch dates), promoting the service (minimum 10 30-second spots weekly), and providing local advertising time.  Network's key obligations include providing the service signal,  maintaining insurance, and sharing revenue (detailed in Exhibit D).

Key terms include definitions of "Affiliate Advertising Share" and "Affiliate Transactional Share" (both calculated per Exhibit D),  provisions for local programming and advertising, and clauses regarding content preemption, children's programming compliance (FCC regulations), and signal delivery specifications.

The initial term is until March 31, 2011, automatically renewing for four years unless Affiliate provides six months' prior notice of termination.  Either party may terminate for material breach (with cure periods), and Network may terminate if the service is discontinued.  Financial arrangements involve a revenue-sharing model, with Affiliate receiving a percentage of Network's advertising and transactional revenue, as defined and calculated in Exhibit D.  The agreement also includes indemnification clauses and a limitation of liability clause excluding incidental, consequential, punitive, or special damages.  New York law governs.

MARSHALLHOLDINGSINTERNATIONAL,INC_04_14_.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, dated November 1, 2003, is between Bruce Jenner ("Celebrity") and The Right Solution ("Company"), a Nevada corporation.  The agreement outlines a one-year engagement where Jenner will endorse Company products and speak at company events (six speeches, five monthly conference calls).  Jenner will also assist in establishing a distributorship, retaining ongoing involvement contingent on annual membership fees.

The Company's obligations include providing Jenner with free products, a $10,000 upfront payment, a $6,000 monthly fee, and stock options tied to sales volume (300,000 shares at $300,000, 600,000 at $600,000, 1,000,000 at $1,000,000).  The Company will also cover first-class travel. Jenner's responsibilities include developing a business strategy, creating recruiting materials, and participating in company meetings and calls.  Both parties are independent contractors.

The agreement includes confidentiality clauses, indemnification provisions protecting both parties from liabilities related to the agreement (except for product liability, which rests with the Company), and termination clauses allowing either party to terminate for breach of contract or non-payment.  Nevada law governs the contract.  The agreement is considered the complete understanding between the parties.

PcquoteComInc_19990721_S-1A_EX-10.11_637.summary:
This Co-Branding Agreement, effective October 11, 1996, is between PC Quote, Inc. ("PCQ") and A.B. Watley, Inc. ("ABW").  PCQ licenses its PC Quote 6.0 software and proprietary Hyperfeed (market data) to ABW for co-branding and integration onto ABW's website.

ABW's key obligations include subscriber signup, execution of service agreements, payment of monthly fees (detailed in Schedule A), and providing client lists.  ABW must also display PCQ's attribution and disclaimers. PCQ's main obligations are providing the Hyperfeed, authorizing client access, and offering technical support (secondary to ABW's initial support).  Both parties retain their respective copyrights and proprietary rights.

The agreement includes limitations of liability, excluding warranties except as explicitly stated, and mutual indemnification clauses.  ABW's liability is capped at the previous 12 months' fees.  Illinois law governs, with jurisdiction in Illinois courts.

The agreement's term is redacted, but it includes provisions for termination for material breach (30-day notice and cure period) and non-payment (45-day notice).  Upon termination, ABW pays for the entire month's service.  The agreement also addresses confidentiality, assignment (requiring PCQ's consent for ABW), and severability.  All communications must be in writing.

BLACKBOXSTOCKSINC_08_05_2014-EX-10.1-DIS.summary: This Distributor Agreement, dated August 1, 2013, is between Snotarator LLC (Texas) and SMSA Ballinger Acquisition Corp. (Nevada).  The agreement grants SMSA Ballinger exclusive distribution rights for Snotarator™ Nasal Aspirators in South America until May 31, 2015, with a possible two-year extension.  SMSA Ballinger is obligated to market and distribute the product using commercially reasonable efforts, purchasing via written purchase orders with net cash terms upon delivery.  Snotarator LLC warrants the product against defects for 90 days.  Snotarator LLC indemnifies SMSA Ballinger against patent infringement claims.  SMSA Ballinger indemnifies Snotarator LLC against trademark infringement claims related to the Snotarator™ mark.  The agreement includes FOB shipping terms, with transportation costs borne by SMSA Ballinger.  Termination can occur for material breach (30-day cure period), unacceptable changes in Distributor's control, bankruptcy, or non-payment (30-day cure period), or by mutual written consent.  Pricing is tiered based on order volume (Exhibit A), ranging from $3.95 to $4.50 per unit.  Texas law governs.

ALCOSTORESINC_12_14_2005-EX-10.26-AGENCY.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated November 9, 2005, appoints Duckwall-Alco Stores, Inc. ("Company") as the agent of General Electric Capital Corporation ("Lessor") to order and accept equipment on Lessor's behalf for leasing under a separate Master Lease Agreement.  The Company acts without fee.  The Company's authority is subject to Lessor's modifications.

The Company's key obligations include ordering equipment per jointly approved purchase orders, ensuring compliance with specified conditions (including disclosure of agency, equipment specifications, price limits, delivery dates, and tax benefits), maintaining accurate records, and providing Lessor with purchase documentation. Lessor is obligated to purchase and lease the equipment upon satisfaction of conditions precedent.  The Company is responsible for all purchaser obligations in purchase orders. Lessor reimburses the Company or pays the supplier for the equipment.

Key terms include a $14,500,000 maximum aggregate capitalized lessor's cost, with the lease rate and term to be mutually agreed upon. The agreement expires October 31, 2006. Either party may terminate with 30 days' notice, except in case of default by the Company, where Lessor may terminate immediately.  The Master Lease Agreement governs in case of conflict.  The agreement facilitates the leasing of equipment under the Master Lease but does not obligate either party to enter into future equipment schedules.

WARNERCHILCOTTPLC_12_31_2003-EX-4.36-DEV.summary:
This Development Agreement, dated April 2003, is between LEO Pharma A/S ("LEO") and Galen (Chemicals) Limited ("GALEN") concerning the development and marketing of a combination pharmaceutical product (Dovobet®, containing Calcipotriene and Betamethasone Dipropionate) in the United States.  GALEN holds options to acquire Bristol-Myers Squibb's (BMS) rights to Dovonex® and related agreements.

The agreement outlines LEO's responsibility for obtaining US FDA approval (including conducting necessary clinical trials, except for 50% of a potential second Phase III trial cost, to be shared with GALEN), while GALEN commits to providing marketing expertise and financial support (a $5 million non-refundable payment for past development costs).  GALEN will be the exclusive distributor of Dovobet® upon FDA approval.  Both parties have mutual indemnification obligations.  The agreement includes detailed confidentiality provisions regarding technical and marketing information.

The agreement's term is contingent on the execution and effectiveness of related agreements (Co-promotion and Option Agreements) and the Dovobet® and Dovonex® agreements. Termination clauses exist for material breach (60-day notice) and specific events related to the Dovonex® Agreement, including generic competition.  Upon termination, intellectual property and data are to be transferred to LEO, with cost-sharing provisions depending on the termination reason.  New York law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in New York courts.  A jury trial waiver is included.

VertexEnergyInc_20200113_8-K_EX-10.1_119.summary:
This Joint Supply and Marketing Agreement (JSMA), effective May 1, 2020, is between Bunker One (USA) Inc. and Vertex Energy Operating, LLC.  The JSMA governs the supply and marketing of a feedstock/product (Output) produced by Vertex's Marrero, LA facility, primarily for use as bunker fuel.

Vertex's key obligations include sourcing/producing the Output and selling it to Bunker One at a price based on Platts indices, less a discount.  Bunker One is responsible for blending, marketing, selling, and delivering the Output in Texas, Louisiana, and Alabama (the Area), managing risk (hedging), and securing storage and transportation.  Both parties cooperate through a Joint Decision-Making Body to maximize profits and minimize losses.

Profit/loss is shared between the parties based on a percentage split of the "Remaining Exposure," calculated monthly and quarterly, with settlements occurring within three business days of statement issuance.  The JSMA includes detailed definitions of financial terms (e.g., Hedging Profit, Inventory Market Value, Total Realized P/L) and accounting procedures.

The JSMA's term is initially five years (May 1, 2020 – April 30, 2025), with automatic five-year renewals unless either party provides 120-day written notice of non-renewal. Termination can also occur due to an Event of Default (e.g., non-payment, breach of contract) or a Change in Control, with specific consequences outlined for each scenario.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses, confidentiality provisions, and a non-competition clause for two years post-termination.

NETZEEINC_11_14_2002-EX-10.3-MAINTENANCE.summary:
This Maintenance Agreement, dated March 1, 2001, between Netzee, Inc. ("Netzee") and Bankers Bank (a Georgia banking corporation), covers continued service and maintenance of computer systems, software, and interfaces following the initial one-year term of a separate License/Services Schedule.  Netzee's obligations include standard maintenance upgrades, 5x12 call-in support, correction of material discrepancies, and 99% system uptime (excluding scheduled maintenance and force majeure events). Bankers Bank agrees to pay $40 per month for each participating bank.

The agreement lasts one year, renewable annually at Bankers Bank's option, with Netzee permitted to increase fees by up to 5% with 60 days' notice.  The agreement incorporates by reference the terms and conditions of a master agreement between the parties, including limitations of liability and warranties.  The key terms are governed by the master agreement, which includes all licenses granted.  The commencement date for maintenance under this addendum is March 1, 2001.  The agreement was signed by Richard S. Eiswirth (SEVP & CFO) for Netzee and Kevin Tweddle (SVP & CFO) for Bankers Bank.

REGANHOLDINGCORP_03_31_2008-EX-10-LICENS.summary:
This License and Hosting Agreement, effective October 17, 2007, is between Transaction Applications Group, Inc. ("TAG") and Legacy Marketing Group, Inc. ("LMG").  It governs the licensing and hosting of LMG's software (LMG Tools, CSC Software, Other Third Party Software) and related services ("LMG Services") by LMG to TAG,  supporting TAG's provision of TPA services to new customers.

LMG's key obligations include providing software access, hosting, support, maintenance, and specified personnel ("Retained Employees") until a "Conversion Date" (initially expected by October 31, 2009, but potentially extendable by TAG).  TAG's main obligation is reimbursement of LMG's costs for Retained Employee salaries (capped at $783,367 quarterly), software expenses, and other specified items.  TAG receives a non-exclusive, perpetual license for the LMG Tools.  Both parties provide mutual indemnities for intellectual property infringement.

The agreement includes warranties regarding software functionality and freedom from defects.  Termination can occur for material breach (30-day cure period) or insolvency.  Upon termination, LMG provides transition assistance, including data transfer and employee recruitment support.  Georgia law governs, excluding the UN Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods.  The agreement explicitly excludes consequential damages from liability, except for willful misconduct or gross negligence by LMG regarding continued service performance.  LMG must maintain specified insurance coverages.

INGEVITYCORP_05_16_2016-EX-10.5-INTELLEC.summary:
This Intellectual Property Agreement (IPA), dated May 14, 2016, is between WestRock Company ("Parent") and Ingevity Corporation ("SpinCo"), both Delaware corporations, ancillary to a contemporaneous Separation and Distribution Agreement.  The IPA governs the allocation of intellectual property (IP) assets and liabilities upon SpinCo's separation from Parent.

Key obligations include the transfer of SpinCo IP assets to SpinCo and the assumption of related liabilities by SpinCo.  Parent and SpinCo grant each other non-exclusive, perpetual, royalty-free licenses to use certain IP within their respective fields of business (Parent Field and SpinCo Field, defined within).  SpinCo controls IP enforcement actions, unless Parent requests and obtains consent to enforce within the Parent Field.  The agreement includes mutual releases of pre-separation claims, subject to exceptions for assumed liabilities and indemnification obligations.  Detailed definitions of various IP categories (e.g., Licensed SpinCo IP, Mill Recovery Technology) are crucial to interpreting the scope of the transfers and licenses.

The IPA is terminable by Parent pre-separation, and only by mutual written agreement post-separation.  No financial arrangements beyond cost-sharing for information exchange and IP enforcement are explicitly detailed; however, indemnification provisions are extensive and incorporated by reference from the Separation Agreement.  The "as is, where is" transfer of assets is explicitly stated.

MidwestEnergyEmissionsCorp_20080604_8-K_.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated June 2, 2008, is between Digicorp, Inc. ("COMPANY") and New China Media LLC, YGP, LLC, and TWK Holdings, LLC (collectively, "CONTENT PROVIDER").  The agreement licenses internet content (specified in Exhibit A, including film content from AVP, Inc.) for use on COMPANY's websites in mainland China.

CONTENT PROVIDER grants COMPANY exclusive rights in China to use, reproduce, distribute, and display the content.  COMPANY agrees to pay CONTENT PROVIDER in Series A Convertible Preferred Stock ($31,200 total) and to pay Licensors a royalty, capped at 50% of Net Advertising Revenue from relevant web pages.  COMPANY is responsible for website hosting and maintenance; CONTENT PROVIDER for content delivery and updates.  Both parties retain ownership of their respective intellectual property.

CONTENT PROVIDER warrants its right to license the content and indemnifies COMPANY against related claims.  COMPANY similarly indemnifies CONTENT PROVIDER.  The agreement has a two-year initial term, automatically renewing unless terminated with 90 days' notice.  Either party can terminate with 30 days' notice for material breach (curable within that period). COMPANY can terminate with 10 days' notice.  Payment obligations survive termination.  California law governs, with disputes resolved through arbitration in Los Angeles.

NOVOINTEGRATEDSCIENCES,INC_12_23_2019-EX.summary:
This Joint Venture Agreement (dated December 19, 2019) establishes a partnership between Novo Integrated Sciences Inc. ("NVOS"), a Nevada corporation, and Harvest Gold Farms Inc. ("HGF"), a New Brunswick corporation, to develop, manage, and operate hemp and medicinal cannabis farming projects (the "Primary Project").  The joint venture entity will be Novo Earth Therapeutics Inc.

NVOS's key obligations include providing business plans, financing arrangements, construction management, product purchase contracts, and operational staff.  HGF's responsibilities encompass land provision, farming expertise, securing necessary permits and approvals, and supplying biomass.

Financial arrangements stipulate a 70/30 net profit split in favor of NVOS, with HGF receiving an additional 30% of net income annually after the first year. NVOS will purchase products at cost plus 5%.  Upon reaching $25M in net profit, HGF receives 2 million NVOS common shares via exchangeable preferred shares.

The agreement has an initial five-year term, renewable for another five years by mutual agreement.  Both parties may initiate buyout negotiations.  Disputes will be resolved through negotiation, mediation, and ultimately arbitration.  The agreement includes mutual indemnification clauses and confidentiality provisions.  All financial records are maintained under US GAAP.  The agreement is governed by the laws of the jurisdiction where the joint venture company is incorporated (Canada).

HYDRONTECHNOLOGIESINC_03_31_1997-EX-10.4.summary:
This Sponsorship Agreement, dated January 1, 1997, is between Hydron Technologies, Inc. (Hydron) and Miami Dolphins, Ltd. (Dolphins).  Hydron, in exchange for $96,000 payable in four installments, secures sponsorship rights with the Dolphins for sunscreen/skin care products.  The agreement runs until the week after the Dolphins' 2000 regular season, but Hydron can terminate between November 1 and December 15, 1997, ending after the Dolphins' last 1997 game.

Key obligations include Hydron's payment and the Dolphins' provision of advertising and promotional benefits (detailed in Exhibit A), including stadium signage, product sampling, and a "Defensive Play of the Week" sponsorship.  Both parties grant limited use of each other's marks, subject to prior written approval and NFL Properties' consent.  The agreement incorporates NFL rules and stadium policies.

Significant terms include mutual indemnification clauses, insurance requirements ($1,000,000 minimum liability for each party), and provisions for dispute resolution via arbitration.  Termination can occur for breach of contract (with cure periods), conflicts with NFL exclusivity rights, or force majeure events.  In case of termination, financial adjustments are subject to negotiation or arbitration.  The agreement is governed by Florida law, with exclusive jurisdiction in Broward County.

CcRealEstateIncomeFundadv_20181205_POS 8.summary:
This Wholesale Marketing Agreement, effective August 24, 2018, is between ALPS Distributors, Inc. (Distributor) and S2K Financial LLC (S2K).  The agreement outlines S2K's role in marketing the Distributor's Funds (specified in Exhibit A) to Intermediaries (broker-dealers and investment advisors).

S2K's key obligation is to market the Funds to registered Intermediaries who will enter into Selling Agreements with the Distributor.  S2K's activities include seminars, distributing sales literature (subject to Distributor approval via AdLit system), and other marketing efforts.  The Distributor's responsibilities include coordinating Selling Agreements, reviewing marketing materials (with expedited review options for a fee), and making necessary FINRA filings.  S2K is an independent contractor with no authority to bind the Distributor.

S2K's compensation is a portion of the sales load (as detailed in the Fund Prospectus and Exhibit B), facilitated by the Distributor.  Compensation is contingent on the Distributor receiving payments from the Funds and is capped to comply with FINRA rules.  S2K reimburses the Distributor for certain expenses.  Both parties provide mutual indemnification, except for willful misconduct.  The agreement includes confidentiality clauses and survives termination.

The agreement lasts until terminated by either party with 60 days' written notice, or upon termination of the applicable Distribution Agreement for a specific Fund.  Termination of the agreement for one Fund doesn't affect others.  Colorado law governs, with exclusive jurisdiction in Denver, Colorado courts.

BLUEROCKRESIDENTIALGROWTHREIT,INC_06_01_.summary:
This Agency Agreement, dated May 25, 2016, governs the sale of up to 400,000 shares of Bluerock Residential Growth REIT, Inc.'s (the "Company") 8.250% Series A Cumulative Redeemable Preferred Stock.  Parties involved are the Company (and its related entities Bluerock Residential Holdings, L.P. and BRG Manager, LLC), and Compass Point Research & Trading, LLC (the "Agent").

The agreement's main purpose is to appoint Compass Point as the sales agent for the preferred stock offering.  The Company's key obligations include delivering the shares to the Agent, ensuring compliance with securities laws, providing representations and warranties regarding its financial condition and operations, and indemnifying the Agent against certain liabilities.  The Agent's main obligation is to use commercially reasonable efforts to sell the shares.  The Agent's fee is 3.15% of gross proceeds from sales to non-affiliates.

Key terms include the Registration Statement, Prospectus, and various representations and warranties concerning the Company's financial health, legal compliance, and ownership of assets.  The agreement contains extensive representations and warranties from the Company, its affiliates, and the Manager, covering compliance with securities laws, financial reporting, and other legal and regulatory matters.

The agreement terminates if the shares are not sold by May 26, 2016, unless extended by mutual agreement.  Sections 8 and 10 address indemnification and survival of certain representations and obligations beyond the termination date.  The financial arrangements center around the Agent's commission and the Company's obligation to pay expenses related to the

XinhuaSportsEntertainmentLtd_20070221_F-.summary:
This Content License Agreement, dated December 15, 2001, is between China Economic Information Service of Xinhua News Agency ("CEIS") and Xinhua Financial Network Limited ("XFN").  It grants XFN exclusive worldwide (excluding mainland China) and non-exclusive mainland China licenses to use CEIS's financial and economic news content ("Content").

XFN's key obligations include paying US$1.1 million in five installments over 20 years (first installment contingent on XFN securing additional funding), storing, adapting, and distributing the Content.  CEIS warrants the Content's legality and accuracy, indemnifies XFN against third-party claims, and ensures continuous Content delivery.  XFN retains all rights to amended content and can sub-license and charge for access.

The agreement's term is 20 years, renewable for 10, and is terminable by XFN with 30 days' notice or by either party for material breach or insolvency.  Upon early termination, XFN receives a refund of prepaid fees plus interest.  Governing law is Hong Kong law, with disputes resolved via UNCITRAL arbitration in Hong Kong.  The English version of the contract prevails in case of discrepancies.

MERITLIFEINSURANCECO_06_19_2020-EX-10.(X.summary:
This Master Services Agreement (MSA), dated September 24, 2018, is between Clear Capital ("Company") and RadialSpark, LLC ("Contractor").  The MSA governs the Contractor's provision of management consulting services to the Company on a task-by-task basis, defined in separate Statements of Work (SOWs).  Each SOW details specific services, deliverables, compensation (time and materials plus expenses), and timelines.  The MSA controls in case of conflict with an SOW.

The Contractor's key obligations include providing qualified personnel, performing services professionally, complying with Company safety rules, and cooperating on requested changes.  The Company's obligations are defined in each SOW and include providing necessary resources and personnel.  The Contractor warrants its services don't violate laws and doesn't infringe on third-party rights, including a covenant against bribery.  Ownership of deliverables vests in the Company upon payment.  The Contractor grants a royalty-free license to use its incorporated proprietary information.

The MSA's term is indefinite, terminable by either party with 15 days' notice (or immediately for material breach).  Liability is capped at fees paid under the relevant SOW, excluding specific indemnity obligations.  Confidential information is protected.  The agreement is governed by Arizona law and includes arbitration provisions.  Non-solicitation of employees for one year post-termination is also included.  The Contractor must maintain specified insurance coverage.

TALLGRASSENERGY,LP_02_20_2020-EX-99.26-J.summary:
This Joint Filing Agreement, dated February 19, 2020, governs the joint filing of Section 13 reports under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 concerning Tallgrass Energy, LP.  Parties include several Prairie entities (Prairie ECI Acquiror LP, Prairie Non-ECI Acquiror LP, etc.), BIP Holdings Manager L.L.C., and various Blackstone entities (Blackstone Infrastructure Associates L.P., Blackstone Holdings III L.P., etc.), including Stephen A. Schwarzman.

The agreement's purpose is to facilitate joint filings related to Tallgrass Energy securities.  Each party is obligated to ensure the timely filing of their respective information and its accuracy, but is not responsible for the accuracy of information provided by others unless aware of inaccuracies.

Key obligations involve timely filing and ensuring the accuracy of one's own information.  No party is liable for the inaccuracies of others unless knowingly involved.  The agreement remains in effect until revoked in writing by any party, affecting only the revoking party.  No financial arrangements are specified.  The agreement is executed in counterparts.

KINGPHARMACEUTICALSINC_08_09_2006-EX-10..summary:
This Promotion Agreement, dated June 27, 2006, is between Depomed, Inc. (Depomed) and King Pharmaceuticals, Inc. (King).  It's a co-exclusive promotion agreement for Glumetza, a metformin hydrochloride product.

King's key obligations include promoting Glumetza in the US, meeting minimum Detailing targets (PDEs), and adhering to regulatory compliance. Depomed is responsible for manufacturing, supply, regulatory compliance, and adverse event reporting.  A Joint Commercialization Committee (JCC) oversees marketing strategies and approves promotional materials.  Depomed retains ownership of Glumetza until sale.

Key terms include definitions of various promotional activities, reporting requirements, and intellectual property rights.  Significant portions of the agreement, particularly financial details, are redacted.

The agreement's initial term is until June 27, 2011, renewable annually by mutual agreement.  Early termination clauses exist based on sales performance (Promotion Net Sales below a threshold, or failure to meet PDE minimums) and material breaches.  King receives 50% of Glumetza's Gross Margin as promotion fees, with additional payments for eight quarters post-termination.  Expense allocation and reimbursement mechanisms are detailed but partially redacted.  The agreement includes indemnification clauses and limitations on liability.  A right of first negotiation exists for King regarding combination products using Depomed's technology.  New York law governs.

PerformanceSportsBrandsInc_20110909_S-1_.summary:
This Endorsement Agreement, effective February 21, 2011, is between Andy North (golfer/commentator) and Golfers Incorporated (F2 Golf Clubs).  The agreement secures North's endorsement and appearances to promote F2 golf clubs globally (Contract Territory).

North grants Golfers Incorporated exclusive rights to use his likeness and endorsement for advertising F2 irons, woods, wedges, and putters.  Key obligations include North's appearances (infomercials, commercials, demonstrations, promotional events), use of F2 wedges and golf bag during public appearances, and reasonable efforts to use other F2 products.  Golfers Incorporated must approve all advertising materials.

Financial terms include a guaranteed fee ($55,000 in 2011, $70,000 in 2012), paid in installments, plus a 1% royalty on gross revenue from F2 product sales.  Additional appearance fees are negotiable.  Golfers Incorporated must provide travel expenses and a reasonable supply of products for North's personal use.

The agreement runs from February 21, 2011, to December 31, 2012, unless terminated for material breach (30-day cure period) or other specified events of default (e.g., insolvency).  Golfers Incorporated must indemnify North against certain liabilities.  Florida law governs, with venue in Orlando.  The agreement includes standard clauses on ownership of advertising materials, confidentiality, and severability.
